item.title: Elementor Header #1530
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft

item.title: Elementor Single Post #1579
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
Article Media Article

The TourBox is a general use software controller providing the professional (media) computer user a mix of controls that can be adapted to any software where there are parameters on screen or settings and tools that exist as options to switch between (tool types, for example).

It is purchased by photographers, designers, and artists to provide themselves better interactions with pro software. As dFork often mentions, the interactive contents of GUI windows for pro software often resembles controls of a physical machine and, consistent with computer history, should not actually be confined to a physical interface with mouse and keyboard. This is especially the case when the number of parameters to be controlled is in a large quantity or there is real-time interaction with various onscreen software mechanisms, such as a video editing timeline. A video editing timeline, for example, is an onscreen simulation, through software, of a sliding mechanism for the displayed video in thumbnails. It is a kind of reinterpretation of film editing machines that edited actual film, but adapted to the needs of software. Such a timeline, a set of sliding mechanisms, would be controlled through mechanical controls normally. That is why placing a device like a TourBox NEO or Elite next to a computer and controlling pro software with it will provide a leap in interactive normalcy, as the pro software features should not be reduced to mouse and keyboard. When people feel this normalcy, they feel like they have “augmented” their current computer setup. But it is not a matter of augmentation. Rather, it is a more normal relationship of physical controls to onscreen parameters, live options, and settings. In other words, it is like being handed a screwdriver instead of a Swiss Army Knife when you are installing multiple screws.

Among other uses, the TourBox appears to have a lot of utility changing the brush width and other implement characteristics for those who are using an illustration touchscreen device and stylus for illustration. The Facebook page of TourBox features an array images uploaded by TourBox users and many come from illustrators.

Because a variety of controls are provided, and are all user-definable through software, the goal of the device is clearly to provide a collection of controls that can cover most software situations, where manipulation of software parameters and settings is better mapped to external, physical controls. The website emphasizes that this device can control a lot of software, not just that made by Adobe. For manipulation of 3D models, having a dial, a scroll wheel, and a turning knob that clicks could be mapped to various functions of orbiting the scene camera or rotating the selected object.

The seeming benefit of the TourBox is the assortment of electronic control inputs. If a screen were included, this would raise the price of the device. The Streamdeck is simply an array of buttons with LCD screens behind them, so it does not have sliders or dials. The Loupedeck Live, has 6 small knobs that are all the same and then eight LCD screen touch buttons. For live interactivity with an app, the TourBox seems well-suited among these devices, as its goal is not to launch apps or global system functions specifically.

There is, of course, nothing stopping a person from buying a Streamdeck to launch apps and then use the TourBox to control those apps. This device serves a specific purpose by not having screens built into any of part of the device, in contrast to the Streamdeck or Loupedeck, both of which emphasize their dynamic LCD displays that serve as buttons.

Whereas the original NEO model is wired, the Elite version, first released a year later, is wireless via Bluetooth.

Promo Video from TourBox

In the image below uploaded to the Facebook page of TourBox, one user made an illustration of how she configured the software for her illustration setup. This kind of example is helpful in knowing what kind of configuration a person might make for the device for some kind of application.

It provides several controls on the hardware so that the user can make use of it for software however he or she wishes. This is what distinguishes it from other devices, that it has chose to provide this assortment of controls that do not appear to have any definite use until configured.

It has customizable buttons, a joystick, a dial, and a touchpad, all of which can be programmed to perform specific functions within the software. These features allow users to create a personalized setup.

TourBox NEO hopes to provide an ergonomic design, which can help to reduce fatigue and strain on the hands.

Using a traditional mouse and keyboard for long periods of time can be uncomfortable when using pro software. It can lead to issues such as carpal tunnel syndrome. The TourBox NEO allows users control the software more appropriately when it contains a large number of controls, settings, parameters, or situations where those parameters are access frequently. This can help to reduce strain on the hands and wrists because those actions of manipulating parameters are not converted to the keyboard and mouse in a discordant way, as is the default state for software.

The cursor on screen, if it is used to target individual controls, is a tedious device to use for the purpose of manipulating parameters regularly.

The TourBox NEO appears relatively compact. So, an issue with dials and joysticks not being built into the portable computers that people carry is addressed to a minor extent, as it should be more convenient for users to take with them on the go if indeed it is compact.

The Configuration Software

Without actually using the configuration software, nothing can be said substantially about it, so we won’t here. The name of the software that configures the device is called TourBox Console, available for both Mac and Windows.

It is important to mention the configuration software because user experience of the configuration software of these external devices makes an impact more than a person would expect who has not used one of these device. If the configuration software for any of these devices is ever difficult to use then user can become very unhappy, and can even have negative feelings. At the same time however, once a device is configured, it is often set for what the user is going to do with it. It is just a very important matter that these apps are made easy to use, as there will be constant adjustments at the beginning.

The TourBox NEO Was Funded on Kickstarter, An All-or-Nothing Crowdfunding Website

The TourBox is another example of a success of all-or-nothing crowdfunding. Because of all-or-nothing collections, the technology world can purchase items that are considered “niche” like the TourBox, but which will actually point to a future revision of computer user interfaces, where the hardware that controls the software is not regarded as an external luxury but part of the overall setup.

The Best Outcome

In the future, it is best if there is software specifically developed around a device like the TourBox. Pro apps were designed for a conventional usage of a desktop computer, which means that when the software developers made the interfaces, such as the toolbars and parameter panels, they did not consider external devices like the TourBox. If someone does, this one area where computing will make a big step into the future for software.

Take a look at the interactive setup of an early CAD system below.

Media

item.content:encoded:

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: https://demo.afthemes.com/covernews.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you have an account and you log in to this site, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

Who we share your data with

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

Additional information

How we protect your data

What data breach procedures we have in place

What third parties we receive data from

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
dFork is still being assembled. Thank you for visiting. An introduction is provided below.

Introduction

Welcome to dFork, a website bringing you varied pieces of information on technology and its applications in the fields of multimedia, design, and software.

When we cover a subject, we hope to include different side of that subject. We include media that a person will not find included on news website articles.

Who Is Our Audience?

Whether youre a professional in the fields of multimedia or design, or just an individual looking to learn more about the kind of technologies we cover, dFork probably has something for you. We hope you enjoy your visit and come back often to continue learning and exploring news from a different side with us.

In particular, we focus on providing information and guidance for technologists who have some entry-level exposure to computer code, but who are primarily interested in using computers for pursuits such as art, design, and film. You might not be someone in these categories. If so, we hope you can read the articles alongside our regular readership.

We aim to uncover the world of technology for anyone of this background, helping them to discover new topics they may not have known about before. Whether its discovering the latest multimedia apps, software controller devices, and live coding design tools, our website is setup for the person interested in technology who also cares about design.

The Articles

At dFork, we try to go beyond the surface level about a subject. Or, we try to find a side of a topic where the YouTube video has only a few hundred views. Some topics are helpful for knowing about computer history. They are not talked about often on the Internet, yet they involve the Internet itself. Some require research in books.

dFork Is Not Reporting on Current Events or Expressing Strong Opinions On Them

Our editorials are about issues related to technology, such as that we think people should consider how video media can still exist in a physical format.

Our articles are not time sensitive like the news articles that covers current events, which have a short shelf life. We dont leave articles after their first post. They are to be read years after their publication and in so doing this is how we hope to attract people to our website, that they are searching for a topic, find an article on that topic at our website and then become a regular reader. An article that is rather old by a regular news websites standards might be updated.

At the same time, individuals who are not in these fields should also find our articles to be relevant to current developments in the technology environment.

Noctivagous

dFork is a project of the startup entity Noctivagous. By discussing historical aspects of the computing environment in many of its articles on dFork, Noctivagous supports its efforts to improve the state of software technology, most often as it pertains to computer-user interaction, computer code, and design.

The logo below is temporary because many logos have rounded line joinery (the corners) for their letters. This is normally just a by-product of the vector-drawing programs. They provide this setting and it is easiest to produce, with people not usually noticing it comes out. You have to work hard to go beyond that or use a vector-drawing program that recognizes this issue.

item.title: Refund and Returns Policy
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
This is a sample page.

Overview

Our refund and returns policy lasts 30 days. If 30 days have passed since your purchase, we cant offer you a full refund or exchange.

To be eligible for a return, your item must be unused and in the same condition that you received it. It must also be in the original packaging.

Several types of goods are exempt from being returned. Perishable goods such as food, flowers, newspapers or magazines cannot be returned. We also do not accept products that are intimate or sanitary goods, hazardous materials, or flammable liquids or gases.

Additional non-returnable items:

  • Gift cards
  • Downloadable software products
  • Some health and personal care items

To complete your return, we require a receipt or proof of purchase.

Please do not send your purchase back to the manufacturer.

There are certain situations where only partial refunds are granted:

  • Book with obvious signs of use
  • CD, DVD, VHS tape, software, video game, cassette tape, or vinyl record that has been opened.
  • Any item not in its original condition, is damaged or missing parts for reasons not due to our error.
  • Any item that is returned more than 30 days after delivery

Refunds

Once your return is received and inspected, we will send you an email to notify you that we have received your returned item. We will also notify you of the approval or rejection of your refund.

If you are approved, then your refund will be processed, and a credit will automatically be applied to your credit card or original method of payment, within a certain amount of days.

Late or missing refunds

If you havent received a refund yet, first check your bank account again.

Then contact your credit card company, it may take some time before your refund is officially posted.

Next contact your bank. There is often some processing time before a refund is posted.

If youve done all of this and you still have not received your refund yet, please contact us at {email address}.

Sale items

Only regular priced items may be refunded. Sale items cannot be refunded.

Exchanges

We only replace items if they are defective or damaged. If you need to exchange it for the same item, send us an email at {email address} and send your item to: {physical address}.

Gifts

If the item was marked as a gift when purchased and shipped directly to you, youll receive a gift credit for the value of your return. Once the returned item is received, a gift certificate will be mailed to you.

If the item wasnt marked as a gift when purchased, or the gift giver had the order shipped to themselves to give to you later, we will send a refund to the gift giver and they will find out about your return.

Shipping returns

To return your product, you should mail your product to: {physical address}.

You will be responsible for paying for your own shipping costs for returning your item. Shipping costs are non-refundable. If you receive a refund, the cost of return shipping will be deducted from your refund.

Depending on where you live, the time it may take for your exchanged product to reach you may vary.

If you are returning more expensive items, you may consider using a trackable shipping service or purchasing shipping insurance. We dont guarantee that we will receive your returned item.

Need help?

Contact us at {email} for questions related to refunds and returns.

item.title: The Microwave Oven: Indispensable to Modern Civilization
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
This offhand statement from a Canadian government website about occupational health and safety states something simple but also far-reaching if you consider all microwave ovens that are on at any given moment. Usually we only think of the microwave as it is used in our own, individual homes. And you usually won't think about other people using microwaves on your street. But a public health inspector would recognize that these devices are used in all sorts of environments. That is why the information contained in this sentence would only be available to a government department or a marketer of microwave ovens.

Microwave ovens are used daily in restaurants, cafeterias, lounges, kitchens, snack bars, and homes.

https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/phys_agents/microwave_ovens.html

Microwaves are a key part of how all frozen dishes are thawed and heated, as a small portion of people would be taking the frozen dishes out of their packaging and placing them in a conventional oven instead.

It is worth noting that we as a society use microwave ovens very frequently. Perhaps they are not mentioned because they are a rather embarrassing subject to some extent, that people would rather not admit how much they rely on them and so their usage would be normally underreported in conversation by the public. In this way, collectively we have not come to terms with how much we really rely on this specific appliance. They are in restaurants, lounges, kitchens, snack bars, and homes. Many hotel rooms provide them to guests as well.

They have become an essential part of many people's daily lives but it's probably not something that will be mentioned often in everyday discussions, as it is a device that has also blended into the background and often it has been taken for granted. At the moment a person is using a microwave, also, their objective is to get the food cooked quickly and so they won't stop to consider at that time how much they need the microwave, as preparation of the food in a fast way is the objective.

How much you use a microwave oven depends on what your job and position is, though, whether you spend many of your meals eating out, whether that happens more often than you eat at home, or whether you have another person or an organization cook for you. But to some extent, everyone uses the microwave oven even if they don't intend to. If you are traveling frequently, the food might come from any place along the way, but there will be a microwave oven in one of the airport restaurants and it even may use it to heat an item up quickly. In a regular daily life that remains in the same town or city, in the case you are pressed for time or you don't have a source of prepared food, the microwave oven makes meals fast enough to get you on your way.

Although it seems like stating the obvious to mention the elevated role the microwave plays, in this article it is worth doing because this is a device that is taken for granted. The microwave is limited in some ways and sometimes the food outcomes are unsatisfactory. Yet for some people, it plays a role like the automobile: when no one had an automobile, you would have time to get to another place. But when everyone has one, you need to own a car, get a ride from someone else, or take the bus. This is how it is in other areas as well: when all people and companies own a laser printer, the office environment changes and the pace and demands become different.

How Percy Spencer Made The Microwave Oven

The 59-second video below comes from a video produce by American Forces Network, a television and radio service broadcast to members of the US military by the U.S. government. In the video, it is apparent that a courtroom sketch artist was used to illustrate the event of Percy Spencer discovering food having melted.

To summarize what was stated in the video: Percy Spencer, an American self-taught engineer, was working on radar technology for the Raytheon Corporation during World War II, when he noticed that a candy bar in his pocket had melted while he was standing in front of an active radar tube (magnetron). This led him to recognize that microwaves could cook foods, and he began experimenting with using microwaves for this purpose.

The use of microwaves in World War II was primarily for radar technology. Radar was used to detect the presence of enemy aircraft. His employer, Raytheon, was a government contractor. Microwaves bounce off enemy equipment, which is why they were the basis of radar. As is sometimes the case, 20th century technologies have some link to military. Spencer's discovery of the ability of microwaves to cook food was a byproduct of this radar technology, and he was able to make use of it by developing the first microwave oven.

For a microwave oven to generate the microwaves, it depends on an internal component (found in all microwave ovens) called the magnetron. This device was actually invented by a physicist named Albert W. Hull. So, without Hull's magnetron there could not have been the radar technology that Spencer made use of.

How a Microwave Oven Works

A Microwave Is Considered a Form of Emitted Radio Wave (Energy) on the Electromagnetic Spectrum

The electromagnetic spectrum is the range of all types of electromagnetic radiation, including radio waves, microwaves, infrared radiation, visible light, ultraviolet radiation, X-rays, and gamma rays. Each type of electromagnetic radiation has a different wavelength and frequency, and is used for different purposes.

Microwaves are a type of electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths that are longer than those of visible light, but shorter than those of radio waves. They are used in a variety of applications, including communication technology, radar, and, as in the case of a microwave oven, cooking.

A microwave oven works by using microwaves to cook food by the use of a device called the magnetron. When microwaves are produced by the oven's magnetron, they pass through the oven's metal cavity, where they are absorbed by the food. This causes the water molecules in the food to vibrate, which generates heat and cooks the food. The metal walls of the oven's cavity reflect the microwaves so that they evenly cook the food from all sides.

In summary, a microwave oven uses microwaves, a type of electromagnetic radiation from the electromagnetic spectrum, to cook food. The microwaves are absorbed by the food, causing the water molecules to vibrate and generate heat, which cooks the food.

Of course, later engineers were involved in later models of the microwave oven, such as Rudy Dehn below, who worked for General Electric from the 1960s to the 1980s. In the video he explains how the essential component of the microwave oven, the magnetron works. This video is more of a deeper technical discussion and somewhat shows how inaccessible many parts of scientific instruments are without intensive personal research.

Resources

The Microwave Oven by Van Zante, Helen J (1973) Archive.org

Videos of Interest for Further Watching

item.title: How Do You Even Use Cryptocurrency? Would You Ever Have A Use for It?
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
First, what exactly is cryptocurrency? The word "crypto" actually means hidden, so the word "cryptocurrency" is actually not quite right, with the shorthand "crypto" being even worse and more evil. A proper name would be something like cryptography-based digital currency.

Cryptocurrency is what people call it at the moment. It is a digital or virtual currency that uses cryptography for security. By way of its underlying technology it is decentralized, meaning that it is not controlled by a central authority such as a government or bank, which is appealing to individuals apprehensive about central control of world currency. Many are annoyed by the transaction fees charged by private enterprise stakeholders, such as credit card companies who charge around 3% per transaction. Although that may not sound like a lot, for some businesses, and especially for transactions that are large, 3% can add up and make a business unprofitable. Thus, having an alternative currency that is free of high transaction fees is appealing.

Yet, there are many reasons cryptocurrency has not entered mainstream use, among them being how unapproachable the technology is, the large variety of currencies that continue to fragment and proliferate with no actual purpose, as well as the narrow technical interests of the people generally involved in the area of cryptocurrency, names those who are heavily interested in financial investments, usually also technology.

How Do You Actually Use a Cryptocurrency?

To use cryptocurrency, you need a digital wallet that can be accessed through a computer or smartphone.

To start using cryptocurrency, the first step is to choose a digital wallet and set up an account. There are many different digital wallets available, and each one has its own features and benefits. Some popular digital wallets include Coinbase, Blockchain, and Electrum.

What Is a Digital Wallet?

A digital wallet for cryptocurrency is a software program that allows users to store, manage, and transact with cryptocurrency. Digital wallets are an essential part of the cryptocurrency ecosystem, as they provide a way for users to access their cryptocurrency and use it to make transactions.

A digital wallet for cryptocurrency typically includes several key features and functions, such as the ability to store multiple cryptocurrencies, generate unique addresses for each cryptocurrency, and track the balance and transaction history of the wallet. Some digital wallets also offer additional features, such as the ability to exchange one cryptocurrency for another, or to make transactions using a debit or credit card.

To use a digital wallet for cryptocurrency, users must first set up an account and secure it with a password or other authentication method. They can then add cryptocurrency to their wallet by buying it on an exchange, accepting it as payment, or mining it. Once they have some cryptocurrency in their wallet, they can use it to make transactions by sending it to the recipient's wallet address.

Overall, a digital wallet for cryptocurrency is a software program that allows users to store, manage, and transact with cryptocurrency. It is an essential part of the cryptocurrency ecosystem, and is used by millions of people around the world.

Once you have set up your digital wallet, you can begin acquiring cryptocurrency. There are several ways to do this, including buying it on a cryptocurrency exchange, accepting it as payment for goods or services, or mining it.

Once you have some cryptocurrency in your digital wallet, you can use it to make transactions. This typically involves sending the cryptocurrency to the recipient's digital wallet, using their unique address. The transaction is then recorded on the blockchain, which is a public ledger that tracks all cryptocurrency transactions.

Overall, using cryptocurrency involves setting up a digital wallet, acquiring cryptocurrency, and using it to make transactions. It is a decentralized and secure way to conduct financial transactions online, and it is becoming increasingly popular around the world.

item.title: Parametric Design and Parametric Architecture: Algorithm-Driven Designs
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Parametric design and parametric architecture are approaches to design and construction that use computer algorithms and software to generate and manipulate design elements. This allows for greater flexibility and customization in the design process, as well as the ability to easily explore and iterate on different design options.

One popular software tool for parametric design is Grasshopper, which is a visual programming platform that runs within the 3D modeling software Rhinoceros. With Grasshopper, designers can create algorithms and rules to define and manipulate various design elements, such as shapes, patterns, and materials.

One of the main benefits of parametric design is its ability to adapt to changing design requirements or constraints. For example, a parametric design for a building may take into account factors such as site conditions, zoning regulations, and energy efficiency. The design can then be adjusted and optimized based on these factors, without the need to start the design process from scratch.

Parametric architecture also allows for greater customization and personalization of design. For example, a parametric design for a building facade may allow for the creation of a unique, custom pattern or texture that would not be possible with traditional design methods.

However, parametric design and architecture also have their limitations. The use of complex algorithms and software can make the design process more time-consuming and costly, and may require specialized training or expertise. Additionally, the reliance on technology can also make the design process more vulnerable to technical issues or errors.

Overall, parametric design and parametric architecture offer many potential benefits, but also require careful consideration and planning to ensure their successful implementation.

item.title: Key-Click UI
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Demo

This demo lets you draw vector lines (lines with multiple straight segments).

The gray rectangular area below accepts key presses:

  • Press the "F" key after placing the cursor in the gray area. Then move the mouse.
  • Press "F" again to add another point. You then move the mouse again. Keep adding points as needed.
  • To end drawing of the polyline, press one of three keys: "A", "E", or "R".
  • Press "V" to thicken the stroke and "C" to thin the stroke of the polyline.

Selecting and Dragging, And More

The key-click UI has been developed beyond the demo above to replace many conventions of desktop computing, like dragging, selecting, resizing, and selecting shapes. The purpose of the key-click UI is to provide smooth and adept handling of screen objects.

For reasons of time constraints, only the above features were implemented for this page's demo. But other aspects of using the key-click UI to interact with a software application have been implemented in a vector-drawing program called Floating Marker.

For example: The TAB key serves to select shapes (previously shift + left mouse click). The SPACEBAR will lock and unlock a selection of shapes to the cursor, allowing the user to drag them without ever holding down a mouse button (or a keyboard key).

This drag lock feature is an important part of Floating Marker. If the shape is two inches to the left of the cursor at the time of the lock, it remains at that distance as the cursor is moved with the mouse, until the selection of shapes is unlocked from the cursor (a second press of SPACEBAR). All that the user does is move the mouse to achieve a drag because he has activated a drag lock.

This is much more powerful than conventional selecting and dragging of objects. In vector-drawing, it allows immediate stamping of vector shapes that are locked to the cursor-- something not possible with conventional use of the mouse.

Although the demo above serves to draw straight vectors for graphical purposes, the straight line is just a foundation for implementing the many uses of the key-click UI in a software application.

Vector shapes and lines established with the key-click UI stand in for many other purposes:

1) replace the lasso tool. The resulting filled vector shape is the lasso selection area, but it was established by the key-click UI.

2) replace the selection rectangle. A single vector line established by key-clicks is the diagonal of the upright rectangle.

3) serve as the radius for any regular polygon, circle, etc. The vector line is the radius of a circle or semi-circle).

4) serve as a cut operation to cut a shape in half or cut pieces out of it with another shape (a subtract operation).

5) wire up audio and video "patches" (also called "nodes") as well as disconnect them rapidly.

6) edit, increment and decrement values on the "patches" on hover (e.g. bracket keys will increment and decrement numerical values on hover. Pressing RETURN while hovering over a text property opens editability of that node's text property).

7) carry out a fast dragging operation. a line is drawn from the object to be dragged, point A of the vector line, to its destination, point B of the vector line, and it goes there immediately (when the END key is pressed that finalizes the vector line, just like E in the demo above).

TABLE OF CONTENTS:

  • Other Use Cases in Addition to Vector-Drawing
    • Node-Based Apps
    • 3D
    • Audio Software
    • Database Design Software
    • Mecha Diorama
  • Replacement of Existing Interface Conventions
    • Selecting And Dragging
      • Selecting with TAB
      • Dragging with SPACEBAR Locking of Objects (Called "Carting" Instead of "Dragging")
    • Drag and Drop
    • Manipulating Parameters, Textfields and Sliders
  • How The Key-Click UI Can Make More Shapes Than Polylines in a Vector-Drawing Program
  • npSURFER: Using the Numberpad to Set Up Single Click Labels
  • Translation to VR/AR

Other Use Cases in Addition to Vector-Drawing

Though the key-click UI originates in efforts to make an improved interface for vector-drawing, it has applications across many categories of computer software and replaces many tools and conventions. For example, it has been tested for node-based programming and is much faster to use than current clicking, connecting and dragging of the nodes.

Node-Based Apps

Node-based programming resembles the telephone switchboards in which the operator would connect cables to receiver ports on the board. The "nodes" (also called "patches") are basically just boxes that carry functionality. Hooking them up allows making custom programs, ranging from audio to video, 3D, and more.

When the key-click UI is applied to node-based apps, the nodes are connected using the same interactivity as found in the demo above. The ports located on each node box are connected with a single line. Though each node-based app chooses to draw the wire line slightly differently with curves, they are always established with just two (mouse click) points. The key-click establishes these, and disconnects them, without mouse clicks, making node-based programming much faster.

Examples of apps that use nodes are below:

3D

Audio Software

Database Design Software

Mecha Diorama

For a month or two, a VJ app called Mecha Diorama was prototyped by the company behind dFork. Mecha Diorama implemented the key-click UI for node-based programming. This was an app eventually intended for live 3D scenarios. That prototype app just ended up serving to demonstrate how the key-click UI can be applied to node-based apps. This is how it works:

-- All connectors between nodes are established with the "D" key, starting from one port and ending with the other. With the "X" key, lines are disconnected from a port and also removed from the workspace.

--- With a key like "C", the line is disconnected from the port but affixed to the cursor, so that it can be placed onto a different node. So, "X" totally deletes the line, but "C" can just move it from the port to another one.

-- A node's property values are incremented or decremented by pressing the bracket keys, at any time when the cursor has hovered over a numerical property. In this case, there is no need to double-click to change a value, speeding up usage of the software.

-- Pressing RETURN while hovering over the property (any value) allows immediate editing of the text field, whether it is a number or text.

-- Nodes are selected with the TAB key (as if they were vector shapes). They are moved around by pressing the spacebar that locks the selection to the cursor. This can be one or more nodes. They move in pixel step with the cursor. Pressing the spacebar a second time unlocks the selection (as does ESCAPE). If the node is two inches to the right of the cursor at the time of the drag lock, it remains at that distance as the cursor moves, until it is unlocked.

-- The selection rectangle found in many programs is activated by the CAPS LOCK key. Though a selection rectangle is the consequence, it is really the diagonal established between the two clicks. The first point of the rectangle's diagonal is established when the CAPS LOCK key is first pressed, with the second point of the diagonal being adjusted as the cursor moves. This second point is finalized when the CAPS LOCK is pressed the second time, turning it off and finalizing the selection.

-- The 11 second video below does not show the hooking up of nodes or key-click usage, just that the prototype was made.

Replacement of Existing Interface Conventions

Selecting And Dragging

Selecting with TAB

In the key-click UI, the action of selecting objects is done with the TAB key, instead of the left mouse button. The location is specific and the TAB key is easy to hit because it is large. Using TAB to click is much faster and smoother because one hand on the keyboard deals with selection clicks and the other moves the mouse. Specifically, shift + mouse-click is assigned to TAB for vector shapes. Like usual, clicking outside of a selection deselects everything (in the key-click UI this is pressing TAB when the cursor is located outside of a selection). TAB then has nothing to do with conventional usage and is made to be a click.

Dragging with SPACEBAR Locking of Objects (Called "Carting" Instead of "Dragging")

Dragging takes place by pressing SPACEBAR after a selection is made, and the selected objects are then locked relative to the cursor's location. They move along with the cursor. If they are 5 inches to the left of the cursor at the time of being locked, they remain 5 inches to the left of the cursor as it moves. The SPACEBAR serves to lock and unlock any selection of objects to the cursor like this.

Also, the ESCAPE key deselects everything, canceling this drag lock at the same time if there is one taking place. This whole topic of a drag-lock is also called "carting" instead of "dragging".

Drag and Drop

In the key-click UI, the object to be dragged (such as a folder on the desktop) stays where it is and a single line is drawn from its location (using the same setup as the interactive demo for making polylines). A facsimile of the object is affixed to the cursor as it moves towards the drop destination, just like usual. There are two ways this can occur.

"M" begins the movement of the object underneath the cursor (or a selection of objects). A line then extends from that object as the cursor moves. When the END button ("A") is pressed, it is "dropped". If the drag destination is invalid, the object's image bounces back to its location just like it does currently.

This relieves the mouse hand from having to hold down the mouse button and maneuver the cursor at the same time. Additionally, it can allow copying an object into multiple locations, something not available in today's drag-and-drop. To do this, a different button besides END is used to copy the object (instead of just drop it).

After the movement of the object is initiated with "M", begin a file-copy operation with "C" when it is above any copy destination. If the goal is to copy it to only one location, "A" (END) is pressed after just one copy "C" occurs. But, pressing "C" multiple times over different destinations copies it to those destinations. ESCAPE cancels anything taking place.

Manipulating Parameters, Textfields and Sliders

In a vector-drawing app called Floating Marker (made by the company behind dFork), the bracket keys are used to increment and decrement the values present in a text field when the cursor hovers over it. But, if there is a selection of vector shapes, the vector shapes increase or decrease in size.

The bracket keys are used for interacting with slider controls as well: you do not have to drag the slider knob because you can use bracket keys for the value. At the same time, pressing the TAB key over a slider acts as clicking a point inside the slider, moving the knob to that location.

Also: text fields always receive focus and are put in an editing state when the cursor hovers over them. When the cursor hovers over any text field, the text inside is highlighted and is editable right then. What you then do is start typing, to type over what is in the text field. You never need to click into a text field to activate it. You would only need to click if you needed a specific location inside the text.

If you hover over a text field and don't edit it and then leave the text field, nothing was changed and it knows, even though it turned into an editable state on hover.

As it happens, clicking into one-line text fields is usually unnecessary for desktop software, but this is only made apparent after this is implemented.

A number text field will never need to accept bracket key characters, which is why they are used on hover to increment and decrement the value. Numbers and decimals can be typed in on hover.

If what the user types is not acceptable for the text field (e.g., a number out of range, letters instead of numbers), the text changes back to its older value or to an acceptable value after the cursor leaves the boundaries of the text field's bounding box.

How The Key-Click UI Can Make More Shapes Than Polylines in a Vector-Drawing Program

In a vector-drawing program, the single line segment that a person makes is used to go beyond straight linesm to be programmed as many different things, including the radius of a circle or the bisector of a triangle, the side of a regular polygon, and more. It can also be made the diagonal (interior hypotenuse) of a rectangle, as we explained for the selection rectangle.

For Floating Marker, in the case of curves, it establishes control points for what is called a B-Spline. A B-Spline is a mathematical spline similar to a Bezier curve, but it works better for the key-click UI. It allows accurate depositing of curves in real time and it also allows storage of straight lines.

There isn't time at the moment to implement these kinds of features for a web page demo. In the meantime, you can watch the demo below. In the video, an app mode is turned on that mirrors what is being drawn into four quadrants. What is shown in the video are various curves produced by the B-Spline.

npSURFER: Using the Numberpad to Set Up Single Click Labels

The key-click UI points to the importance of using the keyboard for activation of screen controls. It is better not to have to click a control on a desktop screen by moving the cursor to that location. Though this is how desktop computer software has worked for a long time, it is not the best way to access elements on the screen.

For example, web page links can be activated quickly if the browser window is divided up into rectangles. A free Google Chrome web browser plug-in is provided at http://npsurfer.com to demonstrate this UI.

Translation to VR/AR

The key-click UI can be translated to AR and VR. A polyline can be translated to 3D. The programmer can use controller buttons in place of keyboard keys for clicks. The line starts at the first point of clicking and the second point is affixed to the controller. The other button continues the polyline. A cone can be established with two lines in space.

item.title: The Linux Terminal Blast of Lines Shows How the Terminal Needs a GUI Update
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
The lines roll by in a flash and no one can read them, so what is the point of them flying by so much of the time?

The main issue is that the terminal can, during installation and updates, be divided into sections and temporarily show a GUI according to what is happening. As long as the scripts declare what they are doing, their activity can be placed into progress bars and lists in divided sections inside the terminal.

item.title: npSURFER : The Web Browser Plug-In That Shows How AR User Interfaces Can Exist
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
The consumer product manufacturer impulse is there right away in any category of product: break away from all of the machines' mechanical feeling that is supposedly so inhospitable for the consumer and just interact with the thing directly. This is supposed to be elegant for the consumer because is is like a sofa that is flat and without anything on it.

In fact, though, what a person would want in VR/AR is a rig of suspended keyboard controls located around the waist or torso and worn like a backpack. Pressing a key on this keyboard activates a section in space. Rotating a knob changes something in the VR space.

Instead, what exists are the VR laser pointer interface, which places a great deal of strain on the user. It is like handing the user a long 10 foot pole to touch objects in a room. That is the type of user interface promoted by VR companies.

Their approach believes that any machinery, like a set of keyboard controls and knobs and sliders that would be carried on the body or in front of the body would be too "geeky". How incorrect they are, because the actual silliness comes from using a 10 foot arc to touch and activate buttons in the VR space. Even though the arc is weightless, it does not matter.

item.title: Why People Use Fax Machines (Short Article)
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
There is hidden friction in the multiple steps.

Review the steps for sending documents by flatbed scanner

  1. scan
  2. verify scan worked
  3. click "e-mail image" or select multiple images
  4. fill out information in the email window, including subject and message. make sure image is attached to email.
  5. click "send"

Review the steps for making a fax:

  1. insert paper into feeder
  2. type phone number
  3. press send

On the other end, the person receives the fax immediately in physical form.

item.title: Getting into Programming from Another Angle
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
Whenever software technologies are taught, they are immediately shown in terms of the practical side, how to get things done right away. In 3D modeling, very little is discussed about how the 3D programs work, why they have to be manipulated the way they do, just how to get the models done. This is true for programming. It is better to have an overview.

First it is important to know what kind of machine you are dealing with. The mechanical computer put together by Charles Babbage in 1870 accepted punch cards. When many early electronic computers were programmed they accepted punch cards. The punch cards are preset information, the computer stores the program in memory from those punch cards, and then it execute the programs. In terms of making software, this is still the type of machine that most programmers are working with today. Programmers are today are as if setting up very large stacks of punch cards and they press the "build" button to do the equivalent of feed the cards to the machine.

Conventional programming languages are arranged procedurally and execute the same way. The code, when it is written, is set up to execute one step at a time. When there are loops, inside the computer they are actually also procedural, doing the equivalent of saying "go to step 1" when they reach the final step.

So conventional programming today is like setting up very elaborate punch cards to be fed into the machine. When people are writing code, it is like setting up the very large stack of punch cards. By comparison, in another form of programming, they would be arranging connections between live machine elements that are active or will be when they are turned on. But that is not how most apps are programmed. It is a punch card setup today.

If, on the other hand, a programming system existed entirely out of the artificial intelligence, it would be more of that kind of live setup.

Data - numbers, type,

Operating on The Data

Logic - if a

item.title: Properly Executed Technology Does Not Intimidate Or Overwhelm, Like ChatGPT and AI Today
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
The opposite of properly executed technology is an app that places the faces of a person onto another.

When technology is carried out properly, it does not intimidate the public or the industry. There are clear indications of how to use the technology. The benefits and use cases are also clear from the outset, without a lot of room for speculation.

A great example of this is all-or-nothing crowdfunding.

item.title: Computer Cases for Self-Built PCs That Put Effort into Their Industrial Design
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
In the 1990s, there weren't that many computer companies focusing on the industrial design of their machines. Of course, Steve Jobs changed that at Apple in the late 1990s. Before that, most computer companies were content to ship regular, beige boxes. It still took all the way until the 2010s for other computer companies besides Apple to take note of their industrial design.

As it happens, this has now become somewhat of a priority for many computer companies today, to make computers that carry cases that look appealing. There are of course two ways to get a desktop computer. One is to buy one that is pre-built by a company like Dell. The other is to build it yourself. When this happens, you have the option of choosing the case that you want. Usually it is gamers who do this, but anyone can build a PC.

The number of cases of available is large. Many of them are imitative of Apple's older industrial designs. In any case, here are some brands that are known putting some effort into their industrial design for their DIY computer cases:

  • BitFenix - its cases often imitate the Mac Pro from 2003 to 2009.
  • Phanteks
  • Lian Li
  • NZXT
  • Fractal Design
  • Cooler Master
  • In Win
  • SilverStone
  • Thermaltake

item.title: Building Your Own House Was Common in the Early 20th Century And Several Decades Later
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
In the early 20th century, many people built their own houses using plans and kits from companies like Sears. These companies offered a wide variety of house plans and kits, which included all of the materials and instructions needed to build a complete house.

People have been building their own houses from kits for many years, but the practice became more common in the early 20th century. This was due in part to the growing availability of building materials and tools, as well as the emergence of companies like Sears and other catalog retailers that offered house plans and kits for sale.

This carried forward decades later, as shown in the 1979 book The Complete Kit House Catalog below, one of many that can be found today:

The book above is a how-to guide, but it was often catalog companies that allowed people to choose the plans. In this 1928 catalog (images below) the home owner could look at an illustration of the house and also the plans for whichever kit was desired. Each house plan had its own name, such as "The Crandall" or "The Calloway". The quality of appearance of the homes in this 1928 catalog might be surprising to someone not in the construction industry. Today, more than ever, building your own home would usually be regarded as the domain of tradespeople. And in fact it is rather complicated today compared to the past.

Here are two kit homes from a 1960 catalog from a company called Capp Homes:

To build a house using a kit from SEARS or another company, the first step was to select a house plan and purchase the corresponding kit. The kit would typically include materials such as lumber, windows, doors, and other building components, as well as detailed instructions for assembling the house.

Once the kit was delivered, the next step was to clear and level the building site, and then begin the process of assembling the house. This typically involved laying the foundation, framing the walls and roof, and installing the windows, doors, and other components.

Throughout the process, the builder would follow the instructions included in the kit, and make any necessary adjustments to fit the specific site and conditions. Depending on the size and complexity of the house, the building process could take several months to complete.

In the end, the result was a custom-built house that was designed and constructed by the homeowner, often with the help of friends and family. This was a common way for people to build their own houses in the early 20th century, and it allowed many people to own their own home who might not have been able to afford to buy a pre-existing house.

Reasons to Build Your Own Home

The idea of building a house from a kit was appealing to many people because it offered a way to own a custom-built house at a lower cost than buying a pre-existing home. It also allowed people to build a house that was tailored to their specific needs and preferences, rather than being limited to the designs and features of pre-existing homes.

As a result, many people in the early 20th century chose to build their own houses from kits, and the practice became quite popular. It continued to be a popular way to build a house throughout the 20th century, and even today, there are companies that offer house plans and kits for people who want to build their own homes.

Building Your Own Home Today

While it is not as common as it was in the early 20th century, there are still many people who choose to build their own homes, either from scratch or using pre-fabricated kits. There actually more interest today in the concept of a prefabricated home, one that has most of its pieces constructed at a factory and then shipped. But largely, the costs benefits vary, especially when it comes to modern-looking "prefabs".

item.title: Construction Animations Provide A Different View of Our Urban Environment
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
By the end of the video below two condo towers are completed. Even without any knowledge of the construction industry, a person can appreciate this kind of video, as it shows materials needed for the construction project, schedule of the project, site planning, and at the top includes the four-year timeline as the animation progresses.

According to Autodesk, "90%+ of 4D going on in the industry is for show only.Very few examples exist where 4D is implemented in a way that improves communication and on-site efficiency. [...] Most commonly this is an animation to demonstrate skill and sophistication in front of a customer during the interview process."

How did this come about? It is is part of a subject in construction called BIM. BIM, or Building Information Modeling, is a technology that is used in the construction industry to create digital models of buildings. BIM involves the creation of a 3D model of a building, which includes detailed information about its physical components, such as the dimensions, materials, and other characteristics.

BIM allows construction professionals to plan and design building projects in a virtual environment, which can help to identify potential problems and conflicts before they occur. It also allows users to collaborate and share information about the building design, which can help to improve the efficiency and accuracy of the construction process.

There are many different software programs that can be used for BIM, such as Revit, AutoCAD, and SketchUp. These programs allow users to create and manipulate digital models of buildings, and to add and organize information about the building's components.

Overall, BIM is a technology that is widely used in the construction industry to improve the planning and design of building projects. It allows users to create detailed, accurate models of buildings, and to collaborate and share information about the design process.

4D BIM

The animations come from what is called 4D BIM, or 4-dimensional Building Information Modeling. It is a technology that is used in the construction industry to plan and manage building projects. 4D BIM combines 3D models of a building with a time-based component, allowing users to visualize the construction process and schedule in a virtual environment.

4D BIM is a powerful tool that can help construction professionals to plan and coordinate building projects more efficiently. By using 4D BIM, users can create virtual models of a building that include not only its physical components, but also information about the construction schedule and the sequence of events. This allows users to see how the building will be constructed over time, and to identify potential problems or conflicts before they occur.

4D BIM can also be used to manage and track the progress of a building project, allowing users to see how the construction is progressing and to adjust the schedule as needed. This can help to reduce delays and minimize the risk of errors or accidents during the construction process.

Overall, 4D BIM is a valuable technology that can help construction professionals to plan, coordinate, and manage building projects more effectively. It is becoming increasingly important in the industry, and many construction firms are now using 4D BIM to improve the efficiency and safety of their projects.

item.title: There Is Still Physical Storage Media in Circulation, Like DVDs, And It Has Its Benefits
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Why would you buy a DVD or a Blu-ray disc? They are still being sold, after all. There is something about not being reliant on an Internet connection that is part of it. There are reasons to support playback of old media formats, first because DVD and Blu-ray media is still being sold at some stores and it was purchased in large quantities by some people.

Even if you have the best internet connection on the block, you cant control what happens on the server side of streaming content. Pixelation, slow loading, interruptions, and more are common when streaming video content. And yet, we put up with it because weve convinced ourselves of the convenience of it all.

https://www.reviewgeek.com/137285/you-should-still-buy-blu-rays-and-dvds-heres-why/

Most new computers do not carry a DVD or Blu-ray player with them anymore. At the moment, the most advertised means of playing discs on tablet PCs is software that digitally decodes the copyright protections on the DVD and then copies the DVD to your hard drive. At the time of first introducing their streaming services, vendors did not look at old video discs as much more than a topic of obsoletion, but it is going to extremes to say that people should just ditch all physical videos that they bought. It seems as though the public went along with what the marketing said about the convenience.

There is also the issue of portability, that a DVD (or a VHS tape) could be carried from one house to another and be watched by a group of people without having to log in, manage the connection from the T.V. to a device that displays video through the television.

The convenience of digital media is significant compared to the previous period for renting movies, when the video discs had to be obtained from the rental store. It is simple to click on a movie inside an app and rent it, then watch it without having to drive back to the rental store. And with a subscription to a streaming service, it does not even cost extra to watch another movie or leave one that isn't desirable.

There are no late fees, like what happened when the physical videos had to be returned. It was an annoyance in the case you didn't get a chance to drop by the rental store. But at the same time, the experience of a rental store, especially a local one that provided recommendations on racks from the store, is no longer available, and it basically has nowhere to exist inside the current computing experience (as it exists at the moment).

Though the popularity of digital video streaming has increased to the point of dominance in recent years, DVDs and Blue-ray are still widely used, including by people who don't have credit cards to sign up for streaming services or they don't have a lot of extra money to watch videos all the time but they might want to watch one video a few times per year. Importantly, all of those DVDs and Blu-rays people bought in past years didn't just disappear because of streaming websites. What was contained on the discs isn't limited to movies, because some software that needs to be loaded from the past can still utilized when the computer has a DVD drive. Some books were published with CDs or DVDs that contain data.

Books That Have DVDs or CDs in Them, Old Software on CD

Books that had DVDs or CDs included with them. These multimedia elements can provide additional information or interactive content that can supplement the text of the book. However, with the rise of digital media, it's becoming more and more common for computers to not come with CD or DVD drives. This can make it difficult to access the content on these discs, especially if the software on them is outdated. Some books may offer a digital version of the included book as CD or DVD content.

DVDs or Blu-ray discs are still available for purchase, both new and used. This is because, despite the convenience of digital streaming, they still offer some specific benefits. They can be stored and carried around like regular objects.

Tangible Media

Related to this, we will talk about something important which is that the size of a hard (3.5") floppy disk or a CD meant that carrying, shelving, and organizing the physical computer storage media was consistent with other objects and paperwork in the room. By comparison, it's not easy to shelve an array of USB flash drives. You can do it if you buy extra containers like the one sold to the left on a camera product website. With a VHS tape or DVD, it naturally took the form that matched the surroundings, about the size of a book for a book shelf.

It isn't easy to put a collection of flash drives into a kind of card box to flip through them like the old floppies, because they are smaller than what people can handle in their houses by setting them on a table and relying on it staying where it is. There is actually a product that deals with this in one way, "Flashdrive Organizer Case" (above). This will allow you to keep your USB drives organized, a real need compared to the past.

So, in some ways it would be good for there to be a 3.5" floppy container that could enclose a Flash drive. Then you would insert this into a computer slot like before, even though functionally some of the disk container might not actually contribute to the space of the drive. It contributes in another way and is not useless for having material that is not part of the functionality of the drive. It's easy to drop a flash drive and when they fall they can end up in crevices or grates. That is especially true when people are traveling on trips for photo jobs and video jobs. So an organizer like the one to the right can help.

DVDs and Blu-ray Discs

One reason that people still own DVDs is that they provide a physical copy of the movie or television show that can be played without any concern that an Internet connection will not be available for a streaming service. The streaming service will not have contract issues that prevent the movie from being streamed after it was present earlier. Having a physical copy allows less technologically advanced people to watch their movies and shows without an internet connection or a subscription to a streaming service. It can be useful when traveling or in areas with limited or unreliable internet access.

Some titles are not yet digitized either. Physical media can be a cost-effective way for people to build up a collection of movies and shows that they want, without spending as much money as they would on digital copies.

Just Hook Up an External Drive

Hooking up an external DVD drive to a computer is generally a straightforward process. Most external DVD drives connect to a computer via a USB cable, and can be plugged in and used immediately. However, using an external DVD drive can also be somewhat inconvenient, as it requires carrying around an additional device and making sure it is connected to the computer whenever it is needed. There is something somewhat unsettling about owning a DVD player and plugging it in today when the operating systems do not seem to care about them anymore.

Given the difference in dynamics between the two situations, one of getting streaming video from a high-speed Internet connection and the other playing from a physical disc, the situation should be examined, to see if there is a middle ground where physical media can still exist. There has to be a reason people like to own vinyl records, but mostly people cite the sound quality differences in that case.

item.title: PostScript: The Programming Technology That Shapes Our Printed Life
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
PostScript is a programming language used for printing that has had a profound impact on the way we print and view documents. It is also the the basis for the file format PDF. PDF is, to begin with, a container for PostScript code. With work on the programming language beginning at Xerox PARC and then later taken over and developed in the 1980s by Adobe Systems, PostScript was designed to be a language for printing text and graphics on a wide range of output devices. On computers, for example, it can serve to take what is on screen and accurately depict it on paper.

For example, if a line has two points, and this is generated onscreen with PostScript commands (with example code like moveTo:0,0; lineTo:10,10;), that is the same command that is sent to the printer, so there will be a 1-1 correspondence to what is on the screen and what is on printed paper. Previously, the commands used to draw onscreen graphics were sometimes different than what was sent to the printer. PostScript provided a universal printer command set for all printers.

Steve Jobs identified the importance of the technology, using it for the first commercial laser printer at Apple, the LaserWriter. He also built PostScript into the operating system of NeXT computers, which meant the following:

  • All software applications have access to the same commands for displaying text on screen and printing
  • Any onscreen text or publishing will show up accurately.

The Purpose of PostScript

Unlike other printing computing technologies, the founders of Adobe set out to portray type in the code as "a special case of graphics" [video: 21:35] rather than starting with the individual characters that make up the sequence of type. This then allowed application of graphics transformations (scale, shear, etc.) to the type just like any other graphical object on the page.

Before PostScript and desktop computers, printing a document was a laborious process that required special equipment and expertise. If you wanted to print a document, you had to send it to a printing press or a typesetting machine, which would then produce a hard copy of the document. This was time-consuming and expensive, and it was difficult to make changes to the document once it was printed.

PostScript changed all that by introducing the concept of a "page description language." This is a computer language that describes the visual appearance of a document, including the text, images, and layout. With PostScript, you could create a digital version of a document and then send it to any printer that supported the language. This made it much easier to print documents and to make changes to them after they were printed.

The impact of PostScript on the printing industry cannot be overstated. The term "desktop publishing" came about because of it, with the concept being that an individual could use a Macintosh and a LaserWriter to publish documents at home or the office.

PostScript made printing more accessible and affordable, and it allowed people to create complex documents with multiple fonts and graphics. It also paved the way for the development of desktop publishing software, which made it possible for anyone to create professional-looking documents on their own computers.

Today, PostScript is still widely used in the printing industry, and it continues to evolve and improve. New versions of the language have added support for color printing, transparency, and other advanced features. PostScript has also been integrated into many popular applications, such as Adobe Acrobat and Microsoft Word, making it easier than ever to create and print high-quality documents.

In short, PostScript has shaped the way we view and print documents, and it continues to be a key technology in the world of printing. Without PostScript, the printed word as we know it today would not be possible. That is because when we say "document" we are not limiting ourselves to the printed page, but also billboards, signs on storefronts, product packaging, magazines, and everything that involves a machine producing two-dimensional graphical output for receiving of information.

PostScript's Presence Today

Sample Postscript Code

 %!PS
 /Courier             % name the desired font
 20 selectfont        % choose the size in points and establish 
                      % the font as the current one
 72 500 moveto        % position the current point at 
                      % coordinates 72, 500 (the origin is at the 
                      % lower-left corner of the page)
 (Hello world!) show  % stroke the text in parentheses
 showpage             % print all on the page

Below is example code and output from Bill Casselman's Chapter 1 of Mathematical Illustrations, a book dedicated to demonstrating math concepts in PostScript.

Videos of Interest

Includes story of Steve Jobs calling John Warnock to get the LaserWriter built to accompany the Macintosh, through the use of PostScript, at 14:00. Talks about PDF (Adobe Acrobat) at 27:00.
