item.title: Reasons to Try Software Controllers like Tourbox Neo, Loupedeck, or Streamdeck
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Many features in pro software are better suited to dials, switches, physical sliders and buttons, as they carry many on screen controls that are like those found on large industrial machines. Software is, in fact, a simulated setup corresponding to physical machines, as buttons and sliders are what are found on electronic devices. A music studio's console full of sliders is an example, and no one would want to control all of that with a mouse and keyboard as it would be too tiresome. Thus, for complex software where there are many parameters to manipulate, there are immediate speed gains found when the computer user hooks up an external device with physical, electronic controls corresponding to what is on the screen, as it matches the situation.

It is emphasized here that the software is all, unfortunately, designed around the keyboard and mouse, because that is what ships on a laptop. For a media production professional of some kind who uses a lot of pro software, such as photo and video editing programs or even 3D modeling programs, there are usually significant gains trying out devices like the Loupedeck, Tourbox Neo, and Elgato Stream Deck according to your needs and situation. These devices can help you work more efficiently with your software. They are worth trying as alternatives to using the confining controls of a mouse and keyboard.

In consumer products, there has always been a trend on the part of manufacturers in the last few decades to make the experience as simple as possible, even at the cost of reduced functionality. Thus, although the computing environment usually consists of very complex software matched to the mouse and keyboard, this is simple the consequence of a marketing atmosphere where all consumers are treated as iPod or iPhone users. In pro software, this is not appropriate at all, and the industry that has to get the job done is the electronic music industry. Thus, the variety of equipment provided there is large, there is no hesitation to produce and make use of external peripherals for the onscreen software. The music industry is necessarily comfortable with external devices for obvious reasons, as it shapes the entirety of what they do on stage or in the studio. Elsewhere, such as in photo editing there has been much hesitation.

These devices offer customizable buttons and dials that allow you to easily adjust settings and make changes to your software without having to use your keyboard and mouse. It can save you a lot of time and make your work flow much smoother, but what is important is that you are using the computer more properly, as the controls you use for the software match what is on the screen and in the software. It's actually a matter of rationality, but that does not mean these devices are a perfect fit for the pro software. The ideal case is that external controls for software are developed in tandem, at the same time, as the software itself, and not tacked on with add-on devices like those below. However, that is exceptionally rare, maybe not even existing outside of some video editing consoles for professional video editing software.

  • Elgato Stream Deck: a customizable control panel with 15 LCD keys that can be used to trigger actions in your pro software.
  • Palette Gear: a modular control system with customizable buttons and dials that can be used to control your pro software.
  • Keyboard Maestro: a macro program that allows you to create custom keyboard shortcuts and control your pro software.
  • Control Surface: a customizable control panel with buttons and dials that can be used to control your pro software.
  • Keyboard Shortcut Pro: a keyboard with customizable keys that can be used to create custom keyboard shortcuts for your pro software.

Second, these devices are compatible with a wide range of pro software, so you can use them with the programs you already have. This means you don't have to learn new software or spend money on additional tools.

Third, these devices are designed to be sleek and stylish, so they look great on any desk. They are also compact and portable, making them easy to use and carry around.

Korg nanoKONTROL2.

This is a compact control surface with eight faders, eight knobs, and 24 buttons that can be used to control your pro software. It is compatible with a wide range of programs and allows you to create custom settings and shortcuts. Like the other devices mentioned, the Korg nanoKONTROL2 can help you work more efficiently and effectively with your pro software.

Overall, devices like the Loupedeck, Tourbox Neo, and Streamdeck are worth trying if you use pro software. Their customizable buttons and dials, compatibility with a wide range of programs, and sleek design make them valuable tools for improving your productivity and efficiency.

DaVinci Resolve Micro Panel

One piece of equipment from DaVinci that is similar to the Tourbox Neo, Loupedeck, and Streamdeck is the DaVinci Resolve Micro Panel. This is a compact control surface with customizable buttons and dials that can be used to control DaVinci Resolve, a popular video editing and color grading software. The DaVinci Resolve Micro Panel allows you to make adjustments to your software without having to use your keyboard and mouse, making your work flow smoother and more efficient. It is a valuable tool for anyone using DaVinci Resolve.

The Company Contour and Its Products

Contour is a company that produces a range of devices that are related. These devices include the Contour ShuttleXpress, Contour ShuttlePRO v2, and Contour Design Rollermouse Red.

  • The ShuttleXpress is a compact control surface with five buttons and a jog dial that can be used to control your pro software. It is compatible with a wide range of programs and allows you to create custom settings and shortcuts.
  • The ShuttlePRO v2 is a larger control surface with 13 buttons and a jog dial that can be used to control your pro software. It is also compatible with a wide range of programs and allows you to create custom settings and shortcuts.
  • The Rollermouse Red is a ergonomic mouse with a scroll wheel and eight buttons that can be used to control your pro software. It is designed to reduce strain on your hand and wrist, making it a comfortable and efficient tool for long hours of work.

item.title: How Would You Start on An iPhone and iPad Alternative?
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Sliders in software are borrowed from physical, electronic sliders, like those on audio equipment. It's easy to forget this after using modern computers for such a long time. A pressable button, one that correlates to and activates a specific function in the hardware, stems from electronic panels, especially those in the 1950s afterwards. With graphical interfaces, these conventions were just moved over in a very direct way.

On a digital, dynamic touchscreen (e.g.), one that can be programmed with software, the generation of onscreen graphical buttons that each correlate to a single function is no longer necessary. That setup seems to make sense because it mirrors what people are familiar with.

Instead, a physical set of electronic controls, generic in initial purpose and chosen as an arrangement, would be incorporated into the design of the device. They would be reused constantly inside an interface system, utilized consistently across all touchscreen software to activate the majority of functions present in the software.

A generic physical dial or three would manipulate most parameters that show up in software. This is a more proper way to drive an interactive setup on a touchscreen. But, it will require the inclusion of multiple physical controls on the device itself, something shunned by the current times as people have come to believe "less is more". All future apps will need to recognize these physical, generic controls for their interactive conventions, instead of generating their own specific, fake buttons and sliders, dials, etc.

Even if there are many dials (or parameters to manipulate) in the software, the specific ones that need to be manipulated can be selected by the physical controls on the device. So, there don't have to be the same number of physical dials on the device as the number that appears in the software. There would have to be enough on the device to be swapped out smoothly.

This also allows the situation that the users can plug in additional controls in a modular way to the device, on its side.

It actually is not a simple matter to surpass the iPhone. Two issues: there is the defining nature in the situation, and this is a consequence of the actual holistic upgrade that occurred in 2007. Apple's objective at the time was to make a major set of improvements rising above all other phones available at that time, and it did make that kind of change to smartphones, which produced a fixed definition in the view of the consumer public. Meanwhile, other companies have not had that kind of goal to correct a category of product, perhaps in their companies' existence, and this is definition they will follow. They will only ever manufacture an iPhone knock-off. So there is no one who sets out to make an alternative.

But there is a way out. With the multi-touch screen, when it is treated as the exclusive location of interactivity, the user is constantly catching up with the changing locations of controls on the screen. This advantage, that it can display buttons and menus dynamically, also leads to a problem because there is "hunt and peck" happening or a kind of "Whack-A-Mole" at all times.

To address this, physical controls can complement the touchscreen interface, producing a smoother interface. It is advisable to rely on more than just the touchscreen, to add physical controls, and automotive interfaces have demonstrated this. There are also e-Ink devices that feature both physical buttons for page advancement and a touchscreen.

This page explains how an avenue for making an iPhone alternative involves incorporating physical controls onto the device next to the touchscreen. Before it can be assessed how to do this, a large scale, table-sized device should be manufactured with the added controls.

These controls would be the primary focus of controlling the device's, just as they will for the phone's interface. The operating system software would center on these controls, not the touchscreen, and the device would include slider pads, dials and buttons.

The point is that the iPhone and iPad went to an extreme by removing all physical controls. Touching the screen with the fingers results in an imprecise experience, and this is reason enough to re-evaluate the format of a touchscreen tablet and smartphone. The addition of a third category, a table-sized touchscreen device, is necessary for truly providing an alternative to the desktop PC.

Though many smartphones were unsuccessful in the 2000s, such as the Helio phone, they could be made into finished products today. They featured physical controls but they did not implement them as part of a complete operating system, one with a usable interface.

  • A Large Touchscreen
  • The Finger Obscures Its Own Location of Interaction on The Screen
  • It Might Need to Start With The Table-Sized Device
  • The Controls And Their Locations Are Changing Constantly
  • It Is as If There Will Only Be The iPhone
  • The Leap of the iPhone Came From Its Dedicated Package of Improvements, in Many Facets, Over The Existing Mobile Phone Environment
    • Apple's Success from The iPhone
    • The App Store
    • Previous Phones Had a Hard Time Browsing The Web
  • Start with What Is Uncomfortable about The iPhone
  • A Totally Different Keyboard Interface Is Needed

A Large Touchscreen

In 2006, a year before the iPhone was released, a presentation was uploaded to YouTube featuring MIT professor Jeff Han. He is known for his work with touchscreen interfaces. In the video below, he demonstrates a large multitouch screen that most people had not seen at the time in consumer technology circles.

Before an interaction designer works on a small scale, for a phone like an iPhone, he or she can investigate what happens on a big scale, which is what Apple actually did to make the iPhone interface, making a large prototypal version projected downwards onto a table. This isn't the only starting point, as you can also start with features of a small scale, revealing a different side to the problem. But that is how Apple is said to have worked out the interface, with a big version like the one below.

A studio-table-scale device, in which the person stands and makes the majority commands to the computer using multitouch movements on the touchscreen, has never been manufactured for the home in a way resembling this video featuring Jeff Han. The apps that ran on this kind of device would be exclusive for its own form and interactivity. This is the kind of principle that a person has to know before endeavoring to make a product different from the iPhone or iPad.

Perhaps it looks to some that the product Han demonstrated is unusable compared to an iPad, but actually it just wasn't developed further into a consumer product. What would make it better is to have physical controls affixed to the side, like sliders, dials, knobs, and buttons of various sorts. The interface of the device, and the apps themselves would be controlled by these first. The benefit is that the hand stays in the same general area and the user does not have to continuously reassess what is on screen that is interactive and needs to be pressed. The user interface will be stable. On an iPad or iPhone, it is unstable.

For over a decade there have been reporters using large multi-touch screens on large walls for stage effect during news broadcasts. But when they do use them, those are isolated use cases, such as interacting with a map. There is no software development system in place for complete software suites. There is no way to edit the broadcast video in the editing rooms with that large touchscreen, in other words. It's just being used for effect.

If we figure out what works for a large-scale touchscreen device with physical controls, we can move towards a better device at a smaller scale. For apps, multi-touch interfaces have been entirely confined, for the consumer market, to smaller, portable devices like the iPad or iPhone. It's a gap that there has never been a studio-table-sized touchscreen product available to the general public that can run complete apps, software that is specifically tailored for that device. This means there is a kind of product that could be widely used but is not. So, in a way, the touchscreen interface is not totally known for what it could be for apps, because making an app for each scale of the touchscreen produces different interactions and indicates different directions. And importantly, at a large scale, it should be combined with physical controls.

When the scale of a touchscreen device becomes as large as what is in the 2006 video, it can accommodate professional software functionality, but no one has seen that kind of software yet and it is best not to leave it as a touchscreen alone. Such a product would have to be fully endorsed by a computer company so that an ecosystem of software programmers could get behind it.

At Apple, in the years following the introduction of the iPad and iPhone, there was discussion of the supposed "post-PC era", but this was more than just premature, it was impossible. A better discussion is what kind of large interface could provide an alternative to mouse clicking? It would be a table-sized touchscreen, as at that scale a touchscreen can do many things that a desktop computer does. Even a physical keyboard can be placed just beneath it. By producing this product, companies can work backwards to a different type of phone.

If a larger type of touchscreen computer were produced that had its own ecosystem of professionally-produced apps, or a company just made one in house, an iPhone alternative could come about that works in a different way because it would be a shrunken and reconfigured version potentially. The controls that sat on the side of the table would indicate, perhaps, how the smaller version could work in the pocket. Also, the course that interactivity should take on a touchscreen could be known much more for professional apps. The iPad's default touching interface is not much at all for making pro software.

The Finger Obscures Its Own Location of Interaction on The Screen

There is a case to be made that the point of interaction for touch on a touchscreen should be offset from where the finger comes down on the screen. Right now the activation point is directly underneath the finger, which means there is mild confusion at all times about whether an interaction is going to be successful. There are plenty of errors, hitting the wrong button, but this does not happen on devices with physical controls, because the controls are actually felt. On the iPad or iPhone, the buttons sit underneath glass, and they are not felt.

The controls on the screen, because they sit underneath glass, are obscured by the fingers themselves during interaction. This all by itself prevents professional apps from coming about that match desktop functionality, which is why there was no such thing as the "post-PC era" that was promoted shortly after the iPad appeared. In a better configuration, touch happens a small portion of the time, but when it does it complements the physical controls.

It Might Need to Start With The Table-Sized Device

The studio table-sized device is something that needs to be made a priority for the tech industry. In this setup you might want to edit videos more than on a regular desktop computer. It is much larger than an iPad, it can display many strips of film, and the area of interaction is large enough to make it a workspace, one much more adequate than a desktop screen for editing a movie. It can be controlled from the perimeter of the screen using the physical controls and also on the touchscreen, but does not have to be controlled completely from the touchscreen. Computing power is enough to accommodate this size of a touchscreen, but it was not in the 1990s or 1980s, when the desktop computer's GUI came to be the interface for the mainstream computer.

The dimensions of the iPad mean that it cannot function as a workspace. Editing video on it would be too confining. An important difference is that software companies that make the software for this larger scale of the touchscreen would be completely dedicated to this kind of workspace for software, which is why the video editor would lend itself to being on par with a professional editing system paired to mouse-and-keyboard devices. And actually, it could be even more powerful if physical controls are affixed to the sides of the touchscreen device. Without a very large touchscreen that is as big as the one shown in this video-- or a set of physical controls accompanying the device-- there shouldn't be an immediate expectation that a video editor can work exclusively on a touchscreen. Adding physical controls is a more solid way to proceed on the matter.

(Note: what happened when Microsoft produced a very large touchscreen monitor in 2016 was that it simply served existing desktop apps with touch. It was also not configured in a tabletop format like the cocktail arcade games.)

Another important issue, which is directly related to making an alternative to the iPhone, is that people are actually going to extremes by not including any physical controls next to the touchscreen. To control the screen's interface, they rely entirely on the multitouch screen, believing it to be an all-in-one solution. This includes the demo above, as the table has no physical controls.

The Controls And Their Locations Are Changing Constantly

When a touchscreen is the only allowed means of controlling the interface, the user has to assess controls on the screen constantly, like a game of Whack-A-Mole, which is comparatively fatiguing to using a regular GUI. If, however, there are external controls on the perimeter or near the touchscreen, the user will keep the hand in the same region, on those controls for the majority of the time, or even on the same buttons and knobs for long periods of time. It's really that a set of conventions has to be set up for the physical controls that can be followed for the device's system interface and its apps, not that such controls should be abandoned.

Those controls, though, have to be able to activate apps, activate anything on the entire screen, not just control the features of the app internal to the app. While it seems better to just touch the app icon on the screen, it isn't always, because after the icon is touched the hand obscure the screen and the whole screen changes, and then the user has to find out how to get to the next step on a different area of the overall screen while retracting the hand then placing the hand back on the device. Because this is happening each time that anything happens, these tablet devices and phones are sometimes fatiguing in ways they might not seem to be.

It is much like how the mouse is always used to click the close button of a window: that area of the screen is too tiny for people to be asked to maneuver the cursor into it, yet that's how the PC still is. And they don't just have to do it to close windows, but use the mouse's cursor like tweezers on all kinds of controls. This indicates that not all computer interfaces are finished like people believe. (Mouse interactions is a different topic for another article, but a way out of the problem is called Noctivagous' key-click UI.)

So, in a large scale format for a touchscreen computer, one which includes video editing software made specifically for a screen as big as the one demo'ed by Jeff Han in the video above, you would want buttons, sliders, and dials on the side, or even on the underside of the edges of the table. The same would hold for an iPhone alternative.

On a large table, all four edges of the table can have controls, even modular ones that are plugged in as needed. This is an approach for upgrading many professional desktop computer software apps into a multitouch table for real, such as 3D modeling and 3D animation apps that are very tedious to use in the way that the mouse and keyboard are configured today. Any desktop apps that manage digital representations of physical objects, like film strips for film or real-world, animatable 3D dolls, lighting, and sets, have to be translated properly to a touchscreen setup and not converted to what the iPad has provided alone. Why is it the case that all companies finally gave in and bundled keyboards and trackpads with their touchscreens? A pro desktop app has to be translated to large touchscreens in a way it has never been. Translating to any other interactive medium means not having something be exactly the same as where it came from.

Why, for example, is it taking so long for Apple to release augmented reality headset? One cause is certainly that translating software interfaces to AR is not within the immediate range of the Apple software interface engineers today, as a proper translation of user interaction from desktop software to a mobile device has not occurred since the iPhone, and that was reportedly driven by Steve Jobs. And to some people, the sacrifices involved in making that translation were too large for the long-term, making the interface a little too nubby for apps, which meant that eventually a trackpad and keyboard would come along once again and some people would just go back to desktop computers and wish that they had a multitouch screen. From another perspective, Apple didn't go any further than a prototypal interface for touchscreens for apps, and what has been used for the last decade on the iPad is incomplete for a multitouch device. But what is there is touch at all, and this is something different, so it took off anyway.

To make the software interactivity on par with what is on desktop will take views that Apple simply does not accept within its consumer product mindset today, although it might be the case they have some noteworthy demos with AR. The truth is they have a modernist design mentality that won't allow controls to be added next to a multitouch screen, because you will have to include controls that Steve Jobs would initially reject, out of fear they would be received as too complicated or require something for the owner to learn for more than 3 minutes. What Jobs was talking about, though, is something already addressed by what we are saying. We don't take the view that all users have to use all devices within a few minutes, which has its merit for some consumers but not for others. To force professional software into consumer touch interfaces is causing trouble for tablet devices.

Many e-Ink ebook reader devices have buttons on the side for moving between pages, and some even have had them for accessing chapters. They sit on the side, next to the touchscreen. To many people, these e-Ink readers are preferable to the ones where the company went the minimalist route to eliminate all physical controls, leaving interaction to the touchscreen alone. The controls are stable and powerful.

Steve Jobs is not all there is in the history of computing, which is why the iPad eventually included a trackpad and mouse, and there was never such a thing as the "post-PC" era. If the touchscreen isn't finished why would they be able to go to the next step, to 3D with AR? The basic situation is that there have been different extremes: there was device hardware (the mobile phones predating the iPhone) with lots of controls that did not work very well and tried halfway, and then the heavily minimalist product from Apple that does try hard to help the consumer but feels too minimalist and confining for professional software control of the device.

Adding controls to devices is the kind of break from the Apple past that would take a lot for Apple to do psychologically as an organization, so it has to be discussed elsewhere, as Apple's entire identity is centered around reduction of provided elements, and many people in the public have come to see the world the same way, believing that adding anything is making complicated situations, etc.. But if there is to be an iPhone alternative, this cannot be where a person finds the iPhone today because it is a dead end, and, a topic for another article, it would have been a dead end had Steve Jobs continued as well.

The future of devices includes not totally shunning physical controls and instead including some around the touchscreen, possibly in a modular (plug-in) setup, for different software developers who write different types of apps. This is exemplified by the TourBox software controller or the Loupedeck Live. When the right physical controls are available, the user response is strong with these kinds of external controllers, and it demonstrates how important it is to match external controls to software features. Professional software can be used in a more proper way because the physical controls of a TourBox or Loupedeck, for example, match the parameters and settings on the screen. What interacts with the software is not just the existing keyboard and mouse setup, but instead dials, knobs, and sometimes small buttons with screens.

Ironically perhaps, there are full-sized touchscreen kiosks being used for narrow, defined purposes in commercial environments, such as check-in for packages and ordering of restaurant meals inside the restaurant. The interaction they provide is limited to the user pressing various buttons to achieve an outcome pertaining to the specific commercial situation. Few homes have a touchscreen larger than an iPad that can run apps.

What this shows is that there are many avenues that technology can go that it has not gone, and some of them are just not discussed by the companies or the tech communities. In certain cases, they are investigated but left internal to the company. The iPad interface prototype was reportedly designed in a setup in which a projector was suspended above a table, projecting downwards, so a tabletop device could have been a topic.

For those who are unfamiliar with computer interfaces, the above example, in which a large format touchscreen product has not been available to the public that can run a multitude of apps, indicates also that smaller products like the iPhone also have avenues that have been left unexamined, because what would be provided in the large-scale format can be shrunken down to the size of the iPhone screen.

The countertop setup is exactly what a different type of software would run on and it would allow the use of controls that go beyond the touchscreen, as demonstrated by the joystick and controller buttons on the Pac-Man "cocktail" arcade setup (which does not have a touchscreen).

It Is as If There Will Only Be The iPhone

"The Latest iPhone" is of great interest to the public because there may not be another device as stimulating to the average technology user, one that is carried around in daily life and also brings lots of excitement. But for those who were working in technology in the 2000s, this has become a rather stagnant topic, as it used to be the case that there was wide product variety in the smartphone environment, that manufacturers would try something significantly different from other products.

Today, phone manufacturers all feel that this phone that came out in 2007 is all they will ever make until something comes along for them. This was not the mentality of the 2000s, though they were not actually going anywhere within the confines of the existing interfaces. For one, they were embedding an underpowered operating system with the phones.

You cannot live as a shallow individual at a technology company to surpass the iPhone, nor can you merely wish that surpassing the iPhone would occur. Believe it or not, that is the impression a person gets from these companies. It is the sort of goal that has to be a top priority or a dedicated project all by itself. And on top of that, you have to actually know what you are talking about in the combined area of user interface and real-world living as normal people live it. In simple terms, this unfortunately was limited to Apple's Steve Jobs in that time period, who was coordinating helpful individuals in different areas of the project. To give an example, the onscreen iPhone keyboard that didn't pass muster the first time would have been accepted by other CEOs. This is just a fact of how the companies generally live from day to day. Companies often just don't have the drive to go the extra mile. and if they can market the product and get it in people's hands, they're happy. It is the same today, but the difference is that they work inside the formats that Apple established in 2007. If they can just make the phone bend, that's enough, because possibly their area is display technology.

Thus, to do better than the iPhone, you have to know what made the iPhone better in the first place, explain what you want more than today, list off all of the real things about it that make you concerned, and then of course look into what kind of interactions you want with a future phone that change that problem. For example, Jobs noted in his introduction of the iPhone that a stylus was not something a regular person wants to carry around with a phone. Is this something other executives were unaware of? Probably not. But once this is identified, then there is a whole new category of work that has to be done and it is going to take a lot, or favorable conditions, to make the phone without the stylus in that time period.

It's hard to say what kind of ordinary person in the current environment would venture to do this. To recap:

  • Examine all of the aspects of the iPhone that made it a "leap" beyond the predecessors.
  • Discuss all of the uncomfortable aspects of the existing iPhone interface, including the discomfort it brought in 2007.
  • Look into the history of computer-user interaction.

Few people are willing to do this in today's environment; it is as if they wish for something better and expect it to appear on its own because their company has large amounts of money. Then, if it does not, they basically act like nothing bad happened. They continue to do things the way they have with the existing setup, secretly resigning themselves to the situation.

Before talking about how to surpass the iPhone in an overall way, and not in a small minor software update or modified hardware kind of way (e.g. a bendable iPhone), we'll talk about how the environment of phones was relatively stagnant in 2007. It was not going to get anywhere without a forceful presence like Jobs.

The Leap of the iPhone Came From Its Dedicated Package of Improvements, in Many Facets, Over The Existing Mobile Phone Environment

Speaking of apps, the phones in 2007 were not powerful enough to drive the kinds of apps that people could find on a desktop. They can ran a small type of app if the user tapped its app image with a stylus. After that they're done, and the product ships in that time period. And that's all that was ever going to happen before Jobs and Apple. So how are any of these same companies, many of which have different people at them in large portions, going to surpass the iPhone when there isn't anything about them that has actually changed in this respect? They just kind of realized they need to have better industrial design, so they hired industrial designers for their computer cases. They just kind of realized they needed to get on the Apple train, so they did everything that was working for Apple. But what is substantial about these companies, their objectives, has not changed. Thus it is impossible for any of them to surpass Apple at the current time without a major change in the environment, and there will only be an iPhone, because this is a very difficult problem if you don't have the drive and the background to do it. There are indeed some problems with the iPhone or it wouldn't cause any irritation in anyone the way it does.

Apple's Success from The iPhone

It is an enormous undertaking to make an electronic product, and it really does require multiple teams in engineering, industrial design, software, etc. working independently and then have them communicate to put together a final product. So discussing this issue has to be taken seriously and isn't something small if the goal is to do something different from Apple.

There isn't a single factor in the success of the iPhone. It can't be summarized in a simple way except to say that Apple wished to do better than other phone manufacturers and sought to fill in any deficiencies found in the other phones. Then, it did that in multiple areas, which then benefitted one another in the product to create an altogether different situation to elevate a mobile phone product. That is why here it is called a package upgrade, a kind of interdependent situation.

This package combination upgrade that was contained in the iPhone, when it was released, was bound to make it a success eventually, completely dominating other products, as long as the price became more affordable over time.  From the technical side, unlike all other phones, it contained a complete operating system, a special version of Apple's Mac OS, which meant that unlike all previous phones it could run software just the same as a regular computer, only requiring a few modifications to the apps. This at the time had not been available in any mobile phones, and it brought with it the full array of desktop computer functionality for software developers into a mobile device, which is why a major app ecosystem could come about for the first time on these devices, one offering complete features in the apps, like carrying a miniature desktop computer in the pocket, yet one with a separate dynamic because it was centered around the touch interface.  

At the same time, enabling all of this, the chip in the phone was custom-made for Apple's own product, so that it could actually run a full operating system in a portable device. This meant that the software could run faster and efficiently than the other phones and there could actually be a full operating system on a phone.

Apple also made special deals with a wireless provider so that the networks could accommodate their phones and the features they wanted. So this is a package upgrade they made to the phones.

Initially, software developers were not permitted to put software on the iPhone, but when that finally changed, the phone became something more. Many existing games on desktop computer operating systems only had to be slightly modified for the touchscreen interface, which meant that immediately entire catalogs of small games could be provided.

The advantages the iPhone had were numerous and multi-faceted. Eventually, as long as the cost came down, other phones would never be able to match the offering.

  • Viewing of video files -- other phone models could not handle this or adequately).
  • Browsing the web just as it is shown on the desktop-- Without the pinch gestures or a comparable scheme, no other phone could provide a web browser that made sense.
  • Complete software applications (previously, the phones could only contain a few apps)-- Without a complete set of software frameworks for a complete operating system, the web browser would not be up to par next to desktop browsing.
  • An exclusive partnership with Google for Google Maps, setting the maps on the phone on a different level from most devices.

Often not mentioned but important, the iPhone was able to handle video just like a desktop computer because of the chips.

The App Store

According to published internal e-mails, the app store was suggested by the VP of Software Engineering at the time, Bertrand Serlet, who received permission from Jobs to do it as long as it was ready for the 2008 Macworld conference.

The App Store invited professional developers of all kinds, not just those with ties to the smartphone manufacturer (as had happened previously), which meant that a partnership was not needed to publish apps on the phone.  For many younger programmers, it was a personal goal to publish an app on the phones, for example, meaning that they would go on to make apps for the device. And the software these developers produced hooked into the new interface of a touchscreen smartphone.  This is why a person would have a difficult time discussing "how to make an alternative to the iPhone" right away, a topic that has perplexed many in the tech industry. There are many different areas that were worked on by Apple in that time period. At the time, in 2007, all other phones did not even have an operating system with a full range of functionality in them. So to do something different from the iPhone means that no one can just follow what Apple was about in that time.

Finally, in that time, Apple was able to draw from its existing software engineering audience, third-party developers, who were going to use the exact same software development app to make iPhone apps as their existing Mac OS desktop app.

Previous Phones Had a Hard Time Browsing The Web

Once the deficiencies were filled it by the 2007 iPhone, other companies didn't have much of a chance to surpass the iPhone. As mentioned, because the iPhone OS carried a complete set of frameworks for making software, Apple just converted its existing Mac OS Safari web browser to the phones without much difficulty on the technical side of things. Meanwhile, the other phones could never hope to run such a sophisticated browser and they also did not have a touchscreen to go with it.

From an interface perspective, all the earlier smartphones had a difficult time loading web pages and they employed various strategies to overcome this, but they were constrained by the speed of the phone networks (as was the first iPhone) as well as the processing power in the phones. Even at that time, making your own web browser was a huge job and Apple didn't have to make a custom mobile one like they did, it just ported the Safari from Mac OS and tied it into the touchscreen interface. This again the is package upgrade combination.

To move beyond the iPhone, an entire array of issues has to be addressed. As it happens, the author of this article once met the product designer of the Helio phone, which was highly coveted by many in the public at the time of its release, and he remembers visiting the Helio stores, which were few in number. This phone at the time would be the closest thing to reaching the iPhone, perhaps, next to a Sony Clie. It did not have a multi-touch screen.

Below, an advertisement for the Helio phone.

Start with What Is Uncomfortable about The iPhone

The desire to make an alternative to the iPhone and competing phones comes from how there is actual discomfort from the user interface of these smartphones. In the presentation for the phone, Jobs discussed how any button could be made to show onscreen on any way needed. But one of the disadvantages of the iPhone's user interface is that it lacks any kind of tactile feedback, and the buttons are not real. So at least on this point there is something to address, but it would not necessarily mean making them tactile in real time. The iPhone format relies heavily on a full-sized touchscreen for every user interface action and navigation, and it never activates anything in the software with a button besides the home button. It is acceptable to have controls on these phones other than what is generated by software for the screen, and this was talked about earlier when mentioning the large, tabletop-sized touchscreen. But this leads to the issue of the keyboard.

A Totally Different Keyboard Interface Is Needed

The first Microsoft tablet PCs simply used a stylus in place of the mouse and ran a regular version of Microsoft Windows. The stylus was used to close windows by pressing the small window close buttons with the stylus. The lesson people learned from that is that you cannot take wings of an airplane and weld them to an automobile and still get a plane.

It's actually the same with a keyboard, that a keyboard from typewriters is not what to use inside a software-driven interface, even the iPhone, it just isn't bothering people noticeably. All of this will take a lot of work, just like how the iPhone teams had to put out a lot of effort to go beyond the previous smartphones. It would be better not to use the conventional keyboard layout for the phones. It may be possible to do a Helio type of phone again that is even better than an iPhone, but it cannot use the conventional typewriter keyboard layout because that is a lot like putting wings on a car to make a plane.

What we talk about is how people won't accept a smaller touchscreen and that would be necessary if controls are placed on the phone. But that may not be true after all. While the multi-touch screen is great for many tasks and an improvement in many areas, it can be less efficient than a more traditional button-based interface in certain situations. Generally, people have had a hard time figuring out how to blend the two together without sacrificing the fullscreen experience that consumers prefer in a phone, as people often want to view web pages and videos as large as possible, and the phone screens themselves have gotten larger.

item.title: Getting Started with Cable Management (and The Products)
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
When a lot of cords extend from the computer and it is time to unplug or find room for another cord, it can help if the cords are labeled and also bunched together in such a way that tracing along the cable to its destination is not difficult.

"Cable management", alternatively called "cord management" refers to the organization and routing of cables, cords, and wires in a way that ensures they are tidy, safe, and easy to access. This is a desire any individual would have who has multiple computers and multiple wired devices. It is, in any case, a topic that is good to know about if you own lots of electronics. It isn't a formal topic taught anywhere, and you basically just have to buy and experiment with the products as they pertain to you. Searching on the Internet and looking at products available is basically the job to undertake, with some people buying a little and others buying a lot of cable management products.

Cable management can help to reduce clutter and prevent tripping over cables or damaging them by running over them.

The Basics: Group Cables Together With Zip Ties or Velcro Straps

It starts to look daunting, as if you need to buy all kinds of cable management products to be a manager of the cables. But the basic level of cable management just starts out by using zip ties on hand to fasten a group of cables. Velcro straps are helpful as well.

Cable organizers, such as cable ties, velcro strips, or cable trays, to keep the cables grouped so that they can be moved all at once or they can remain stationary without being separated in the case the computer moves or the desk moves.

For professionals in the field, and those who are manage a large number of cables, they check and maintain their cable management system regularly. But that isn't most people, who struggle to even keep up with the wide variety of connector cables and adapters.

There are many different products available for managing cables and cords. Because of this, it would be better to purchase them in an assortment. Some examples of cable management products include:

  • Cable ties or zip ties, which are used to group cables together and keep them organized.
  • Cable clips or cable saddles, which are used to attach cables to walls or other surfaces.
  • Cable organizers, such as Velcro strips, cable spools, or cable trays, which are used to route and store cables in a neat and orderly manner.
  • Cable labels or identification tags, which are used to label and identify individual cables.
  • Cable management sleeves, wraps, or covers, which are used to enclose and protect cables.
  • Cable management boxes or raceways, which are used to conceal and protect cables while providing easy access.
  • Cable management desks or workstations, which are designed to integrate cable management features into the design of the workspace.

Cable Management Kits

There are so many cable management products it can help just to buy a kit to get started and then find out which products you want that are present in the kits. Then seek out more of those. Search for "cable management kit". In the kit below, there are cable sleeves in the shown in the top left corner and zip ties in the lower right hand corner.

Labeling Cables

Another subject that is related is labeling the cords and cables. Simply put, it can be a matter of using masking tape and a marker to label them. It can involve printing out labels and affixing them. Or it can involve using a label printer to manually print one label at a time for each cord.

There are a variety of products available by searching for "labeling cables" on an online store. One product was named "60 Pieces Self-Adhesive Cable Labels" (shown below).

item.title: Getting a Wok to Cook Meals, Especially For Preparing Large Amounts of Food
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Perhaps intimidating at first, a wok is actually not too difficult to use, and it is very helpful for a wide range of dishes. It's also easy to clean. A wok can cook your noodles and rice very quickly, as the wok's metal is close to the flame and the heat is distributed more evenly across the bowl than a regular pan. A wok is an efficient tool for cooking large amounts of food, and not only Asian dishes in fact. Often woks are used to cook fried food, but like any cooking device it depends on whether that is what you want, as a wok can be used to consistently cook healthy meals that are not high in fat. It is also possible to use less oil because the surface of the wok can be smooth to begin with.

Here are five reasons why you should consider purchasing a wok for cooking.

First, as mentioned, a wok has a unique shape that allows it to distribute heat evenly across the surface of the pan. This allows you to cook food quickly and evenly, without having to constantly stir or rotate the ingredients. This is especially useful when cooking large batches of food, as you can cook everything at once without worrying about burning or undercooking any of the individual ingredients.

Second, a wok can be used to cook a wide range of foods. From stir-fries and sauts to deep-frying and steaming, a wok can handle a lot. This makes it a great option for cooking large amounts of food, as you can easily adapt your recipe to accommodate the size of your wok.

Third, a wok is easy to clean and maintain. Unlike other cooking pans, which can be difficult to scrub and de-grease, a wok has a smooth surface that makes it easy to clean with just a little water and soap. This makes it a convenient choice for cooking large amounts of food, as you won't have to spend hours cleaning up after your meal. You basically cook the meal, put the product into a container (or serve it from the wok), then you clean the wok with soap and water. From this perspective, a wok is something that can be used on a semi-daily basis.

Fourth, a wok is durable and long-lasting. Made from heavy-duty materials, such as carbon steel or cast iron, a wok is built to withstand the rigors of everyday cooking. This means it won't warp or deform over time, even with regular use. This makes it a great investment for any home cook who wants to cook large amounts of food on a regular basis.

From its origins in China to its widespread use in other Asian cuisines, a wok can become your one of your favorite cooking tools.

Here are some food often cooked in a wok:

  • Stir-fries: A wok is traditionally used for stir-frying, a cooking method that involves quickly cooking small, evenly-sized pieces of food over high heat while constantly stirring. This allows the food to cook quickly and evenly, while preserving its flavor and texture. Some popular stir-fries that can be cooked with a wok include chicken and broccoli, beef and peppers, and shrimp and vegetables.
  • Sauts: A wok can also be used for sauting, a cooking method that involves cooking food over medium-high heat in a small amount of fat, often from cooking oils like olive oil. This allows the food to brown and develop a crispy, flavorful crust, while retaining its moisture and tenderness. Some popular sauted dishes that can be cooked with a wok include chicken piccata, pork medallions, and vegetable medleys.
  • Steaming: A wok can also be used for steaming, a cooking method that involves suspending food above boiling water and allowing it to cook with the steam generated by the water. This method is typically used for foods that are delicate and easily damaged by heat, such as fish, dumplings, and vegetables. A wok is ideal for steaming, as its wide, shallow shape allows the steam to circulate and cook the food evenly.

In conclusion, a wok is an efficient, and durable tool for cooking large amounts of food. Whether you're cooking for a large group of people, or simply want to make enough food for leftovers, a wok is a great choice.

Getting a Wok

A wok can be found in any major store, including online, and fortunately in this case it is rather simple to decide which one you want according to your priorities. Some woks comes with wooden covers to place on top of the cooking food, whereas others do not. Certainly not essential to the use of a wok, the purpose of a lid for a wok is to help retain heat and moisture while cooking. A wok cover can also prevent splatters and spills while cooking, as well as keep dust and debris out of the wok while it is not in use.

item.title: "Big Tech" Will Undergo a Transformation After Computer Code Is Upgraded
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
The way to transcend the 1970s is to make code documents, as they harness the power and technological advancements that have occurred since that era. When that occurs, it will become a major issue for all existing computer companies. The web browser itself as it exists today will be reprogrammable in a short period of time, yet programming it into its current form will be like staying in the past and thus it will not exist in the form that it is today. When just a few individuals could reprogram what a web browser is today in a short period of time, how could the web stay the same as it is now?

When a document format like .XPS is remodeled for professional computer programming, and the features added are molded after overarching programmatic moves present in plain text code today, tech companies everywhere will be reshaped-- in Silicon Valley and across the world. A document of code will take on a schematic form, like an architectural blueprint, which means it will be able to describe complex processes that span major domains of the computer's operating system. An image compression algorithm will be describable in symbols, like hieroglyphs, greatly improving the methods used to produce image codecs. Even Apple, Google, and Microsoft will have an existential dilemma, as every operating system will be redoable.

Much of what keeps these companies in power today is that very large financial resources are needed to produce plain text computer code when it reaches the size of an operating system. It just isn't feasible for anyone but those who are well-funded to maintain the software that runs on the machines. But that isn't necessarily a fixed situation. When code can emerge inside a document format, systematic programs are possible that can be produced with far fewer individuals, at levels not available today, once computer code is in a document format.

item.title: The Superior Technologists Will Practice Falun Dafa
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
The best work in technology has always been done by those with higher aspirations, beyond self-interested accumulation of capital and quests for fame. A large portion of entrepreneurs and workers in Silicon Valley have lived their lives desiring those two items first.

It is often overlooked today, but those technologists who are willing to set aside their egos and learn from others, in fields unknown to them, are likely to produce technological goods that have lasting value. That behavior is exceedingly rare, regardless of how much the general population believes itself to possess it. More often than not, if there is an accomplishment of meaningful value, there is a person in Silicon Valley trying to undermine it. As a result, the current technological environment is generally a disappointment compared to the hopes of the 1990s. The artificial intelligence is crafted not to take care of growing problems like landfill waste but to show that it is possible for computers to take away the jobs of people in various fields, just to give an example. The field of "product", which Steve Jobs is known for, is now seen as a means to show off on stage a set of announcements in front of the world, with a series of talking heads always saying the same promises about how much easier and smoother life is going to be after the next product is released. The priority is to have something to say in front of other people and maintain or gain status.

The true picture of today's technology can be found in the nagging software update reminder windows, the gratuitous e-mails about privacy policy updates, the coerced privacy agreements on websites and software, and needless cookie agreements. These are rarely mentioned in the presentations.

In the 2020s, honesty, the truth of the situation, and what the state of technology actually is is less important than maintaining financials. As a result, to maintain those financials, customers are harmed and overcharged. Especially lately in technology, but seen throughout the last 30 years, the careers of many people in technology history have prioritized money and self-interest first and serving the customer base second. For years, the tech reporters barely mention that the VR headsets cause nausea so as not to compromise any scoop that Facebook could give them. When people are bossed around by big tech, the reporter isn't looking out for public interest but instead making sure that VIP treatment will be in the mail for the next big press event, to make sure that relations are strong with the company.

How many entrepreneurs are praised by this news media for making money? They often have been more well-off financially than others, but, at the same time, they left millions of regular people and corporate customers inconvenienced by poor quality software and high prices. Their focus was getting ahead, exclusively. Consequently, they left, as their legacy, trails of long-term technical problems that carry into the present computing environment. News reporters who did not experience those issues firsthand might glorify the financial status of these people anyway, valuing the wealth first. These businesspeople competed by taking shortcuts, and they pushed out many of their rivals to get on top. But only their materialistic admirers who seek after the same sports cars, an especially easy life, or perhaps a large house and yacht will find nothing wrong overall. Unfortunately, that can be a large number of people who do technology work in Silicon Valley.

By contrast, the individuals who made extra sacrifices to establish a good foundation for their technologies, spending the money where it might not show up immediately on the balance sheet, often set a standard that the society cannot ignore today. They also sometimes owned yachts and big houses. This isn't to say that these people were without human problems, conflicts, or that they didn't create enemies. What it indicates is that moral character matters in the midst of making business decisions, and this is especially true when the products made are used by people everyday.

Those who surrounded Steve Jobs admired his values, but do they adhere to them in the present day? Or do they just believe that they do and mention the name of Steve Jobs when the opportunity arises? It's unfortunate, but love from them depends on whether the technologist is famous and wealthy in advance. This is their actual criteria and the Steve Jobs myth they made up and live by. They themselves were not wealthy and famous at the time they began working for Jobs, but that later became their criteria for accepting other people in technology. Steve Jobs hired, recruited, and replied to people who didn't have a name. dFork is operated by a founder of the first crowdfunding website and it has been verified repeatedly that many of the people who surrounded Steve Jobs are hypocrites who use his name for status and carry none of his personal values. Would all of his family members necessarily carry his values, when everyone knows that no one is the same in any family?

No, Really, Where Is The Next iPhone? (A.I. Could Never Make One On Its Own)

It is now 2023 and after more than a decade, there has been no big tech company, with all of its thousands of employees and dozens of highly-compensated executives, that has launched a product as valuable as the iPad or iPhone for the masses. No one in the West or the East. Large volumes of time, money, and workforce personnel that were available to them were not nearly enough. So, there must be a problem.

At the very least, fundamental improvements to the iPhone format could not be achieved, something to make it distinct from its first models, apart from adding cameras and faster processors. It's now OK to live by a lie and claim that a product has been improved greatly because of a marginal technology improvement. Lately, when regular technology users tire of this phone, they start going backwards and seek out minimalistic (old-style) phones that have no touchscreen at all. This indicates that technologists do not all know what they are doing today in Silicon Valley and are instead just in possession of large amounts of capital, spending it every which direction and hoping it will work out. It is just a fact that if they cannot proceed further, they are no longer sure of what to do. If they do not admit this publicly, it doesn't become a news story written by a news reporter-- which then means it isn't a well-known fact.

What is the source of this increasing incompetence in technology lately? For one, if you have accomplished anything in Silicon Valley that is of substance, you will be fought right away in any local technology community and Silicon Valley itself. It is a matter of societal values. In the smaller areas, there will be big fishes who want to be famous in their pond and they have the money. But they are from the small pond and don't really have the experience to match iPhone-like product discussions. It wasn't their goal to learn from anyone else who has done something on a national scale. So, despite all of the stated hopes in local technology efforts, they consistently disappoint because of this phenomenon. There is a character problem at every turn.

Owning an Android phone is owning a phone that will slow down after a few months of usage. But the company that owns this operating system has billions of dollars to spend. So aren't they incompetent on this matter? It has been stated that the processors in the lowest end mobile phone are faster than extremely expensive computers of the early 1990s, but the software on the phones is slow, to the extent it takes time for the dial pad to show up when it is launched.

The standard for the average technology product is exceedingly low in terms of overall user experience. Constantly pestering a customer to update software and displaying pop-ups that say "look at what we did that is new" is a character problem. Viewed differently, it is a matter of selfishness: you would even inconvenience millions of people with frequent software updates and you would add yet another pop-up to all of the ones out there that people have to deal with. In Microsoft Windows, for example, when the operating system crashes, it "ran into a problem". The operating system cannot help offending everyone, telling them that "you are almost there" as it installs the latest update, when it is actually the machine code that that company (Microsoft) that is either almost there or not-- who knows whether the software running is fast enough? That means there is no feeling of shame. They don't feel shame. The people they inconvenience are paying customers, after all. Is it that these companies need competition? They didn't have any before, so not exactly.

The simple truths are there: they really have not changed these smartphones into something else and they act like they have year after year. That's called living a lie. They do not have a significant different product category on par with them after a decade. It cannot be excused, after all, if the resources that everyone claims are needed were there in abundance. What is the source of the problem? Everyone has poor character in Silicon Valley, but they are proud of themselves all the time.

Over the last decade, billions of dollars have been spent on VR, self-driving automobiles, cryptographic currencies, and other similarly poorly-planned enterprises, only to result in startups that sit in no position to capitalize on their past efforts and their technologies. Their teams have many of the most accomplished individuals in scientific and technological fields. Yet, they have no chance at breaking through to public consumption.

Most often, they are in situations where mainstream adoption of their services is impossible if viewed rationally: when someone sits in a self-driving car, they get scared, and this is on video. Wouldn't that be something to talk about in the news? Why don't the news reporters talk about this? So who isn't to blame in this whole Silicon Valley?

No one knows what to do with cryptocurrency who lives a regular life, only the people who are enthusiastic about cryptocurrency itself. VR makes people feel a headache or nausea after about 30 minutes and the VR software does not help anyone do work at regular jobs-- even browsing the web isn't available in a VR headset. It's almost useless apart from playing video games, and most of those are violent. That's called a failure. If it's not called that, no one learns from mistakes and improves himself in the process. When it's a big failure, it has to be reported on that way so that no one can get away with spending billions that go nowhere out of incompetence.

In most cases, this outcome could be predicted far in advance by experienced technologists. Just wearing a VR headset for an hour will reveal what the major problem is: it causes discomfort and sometimes nausea. After using it, you have to do real work, so it collects dust if you aren't a VR gamer enthusiast. So is there any mention of this anywhere? What is wrong with people?

Therefore, the main issue is that people's character requirements are too low: they are afraid to make the deficiencies in their products front and center internally, to admit it in front of people in their presentations. They don't want to mention a single flaw in public, about anything, yet they sell what become complete failures.

Much of the time, they crave recognition and fame and seek to present products even when they have none-- in some cases making announcements for products they had faked for the public demos. No one has ever heard of that happening until the last 10 years: promising products on stage that are completely fake. It shows that many people have nothing going for them because they have poor character. They just want the applause from an audience.

Consistently, in Steve Jobs' presentations there was a willingness to explain the unpleasant that may not always benefit himself, the presenter. This is what competence is about: it involves moral character, and not always saying the words that please the shareholder or news reporter. Regardless of the human faults Jobs had, and there were plenty documented, the best side of him emphasized telling the truth for a large part of the time, in a way that was more forthright than everyone else. The stylus was an undesirable interface implement for the tablets of the 2000s. Many people experienced this before Jobs mentioned it, but it's just not something anyone cared about enough, because people just don't care about what matters a lot of the time; they care about the applause for presenting something, they care about the money directly. This is a matter of morals, that people would be silly to keep working on products and startups without acknowledging central problems of their products.

There is no way out of this: if you don't have high moral character you don't have a product to sell that will help people for real, unless it is someone else's product that you stole for your own company and you took credit for it.

Crowdfunding Websites Have to Deliver Most of the Time, Providing Character Requirements for Participants

A lone exception, of course, has been the online industry of all-or-nothing crowdfunding, which by its entire premise must produce something for the websites to exist. Only one known crowdfunding website ever was on the stock market, one in Finland one time. There have been a lot of management and oversight problems on the websites, in terms of guaranteeing timely, delivered final products, but the format is solid and the crowdfunding industry continues in the face of that. They don't make money from advertising, they don't capture the world's attention for world events. Yet they succeed in providing forums for people's products to get public support.

It's unfortunate that there are problems in the area of holding crowdfunding organizers accountable, but there are also some ways to improve the process. Unlike VR, which is typically useless for non-gamers and can only exist for gamers because someone continuously pours money into it, all-or-nothing crowdfunding is still providing a platform for independent and small product-makers to test demand for their wares. Even many video games get started with it. Many start-ups get initial funding this way, with investors joining the equity-based crowdfunding projects. Regarding the topic of VR, in the first place, it is only because of all-or-nothing crowdfunding that modern VR is a thing at all-- where billions of dollars could be spent or wasted-- all because of the 2012 Kickstarter project that established the modern VR industry.

Because of crowdfunding, this online activity, there are still some interesting technologies in this time period, in spite of all of big tech's shameless privacy violations, increasing software complexity, and general incompetence. AirTags from Apple exist because of a Kickstarter project called Tile and many experimental products, like large format, color e-readers are being sold because there is a place where people can put their money down to try them.

A long time ago, there was also a small period of intersection between all-or-nothing crowdfunding and Steve Jobs, when Apple-- out of an expression of goodwill that could only have arisen from Jobs and his own cultural time period-- made clock faces for the 2010 Kickstarter project TikTok/Luna, an adapter that converted an iPod Nano into a wearable wristwatch. It shows that Jobs would have likely gotten behind all-or-nothing crowdfunding during its popular heyday of the early 2010s. Observing the success of this TikTok/Luna Kickstarter project, it is more likely than not that Apple decided afterwards to undertake the Apple Watch. Anyone would agree who looks at the project. Because of character problems, this is not something that would be truthfully confirmed or denied by Apple. Instead, there would be a big stone wall sent through the e-mail system to the person who asked. This is why the technology environment is a disappointment, as people are taking. More often than not, they have taken from all-or-nothing crowdfunding.

Steve Jobs

Each person finds something of his own that appealing in the person who was Steve Jobs-- who was an everyday businessman with an unusual course of life and a drive to establish what is good for the limited time allotted in human life. First: to those who prize financial success and fame, he satisfies those requirements immediately, especially the story of his life in his later years, just before he died of an illness at 56, making him unobjectionable to just about anyone. You seek money exclusively in your life, you can accept Jobs. If you care only about fame, you can accept him too. But actually, that's not what it was entirely about.

From this bottommost standard of personal values, a person can travel upwards in character and take note that Jobs put extra effort into the appearance and quality of his products. After this, a person respects that the customer service was nice. None of this is without downsides, and criticisms can be made about the high-end costs and environmental waste produced by Apple.

At some point, at one of the even higher levels in society, the person takes note of the rock tumbler analogy mentioned by Jobs-- which is mostly indicating that tolerating conflict is important in life. In this analogy, a group of people start out as rough rocks, they are placed into a rock tumbler (the workplace, tasked with an especially challenging job) where there is difference of opinion, dispute, and eventually a conclusion of some kind. Sometimes the conflict in a group brings a lot of pain and difficulty to everyone, but at the end of it, if many people have persevered to get through the interpersonal challenges, and tries to do better on his own, the group is better for it and everyone as an individual comes out more admirable, more shiny. They also often have something to show for it, which is some kind of technological product.

For those who find this last anecdote to be of particular interest, they can continue their paths for sure by looking into the spiritual practice called Falun Dafa. An ancient spiritual practice that was made public in China in 1992 by Master Li Hongzhi, Falun Dafa involves the cultivation of Truthfulness-Benevolence-Forbearance (Zhen-Shan-Ren in Chinese) through studying the books of the practice, adhering to the requirements, and also consistently practicing the (supplementary) meditation exercises.

item.title: Separating from E-mail To Establish a Business Transaction Network Protocol: Invoices, Inventory, And More
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
In the future, it has to be a trivial matter for a business owner to jump onto a business network and issue an invoice to a customer or seek payment. It can't be normal that every invoice is issued by a proprietary, premium invoicing service. Business objects (invoices, purchase orders, etc.) should flow across the Internet like web pages or e-mails. They should not be treated as a separate technology that can be marketed and sold. There will be transaction costs and intermediate entities, but that is different from a world of premium services that provide what could be in the general computer software itself. What is considered extra (sending a bill to someone on the Internet) should be as simple as the data transmission of an e-mail. Many parts of the digital business environment are not lined up: if people have paid with credit cards, why are their receipts not attached to their bank statements (if they want that)?

Many companies exist to process bill payments and accept payments from customers. This should actually be woven into the computer systems, as it is a utility similar to e-mail. Because it is unrecognized as a utility, private companies are filling in the needs. This makes for a very uncomfortable business software market, as owners are issuing digital invoices to each other from competing services and there is no place where the invoices meet technologically. It really should be that there is a standard, decentralized business transaction network, owned by no one (just like e-mail), and this is the platform for doing digital business.

What is happening instead is the e-mail system is repurposed as the place where billing and invoicing take place, which is interference with other types of communication. When the e-mails come in one after another with written communication, they are side by side with important business invoicing, which is unacceptable.

Invoices, bills, purchase orders, and so on should be made a standard, expected part of the computing environment, just like ACH (direct deposit) is a standard part of the banking systems. Banks do not deal with invoices or purchase orders, so this would be a separate system (a protocol) that needs to be established.

Many staple activities are often dependent on privately-run, subscription-based services today, which means that the computing environment gives the impression that it is progressing all of business, when actually it is causing many fragmentation problems, causing confusion for those who are not part of the paid software ecosystem.

For the digital world to be in synchronization with all of business needs, everyone has to have access to business protocols universally, as if they were e-mail protocols. Some technologies are perceived as premium add-ons that should really be built into the system. As a result, the wide range of different participants in the business environment are not in sync, with some being on one service, others being on another, and many not being online much at all because of the premium state of services. But high-end businesses may purchase from the mid-range or even low-end businesses, so everyone needs to be onboard this business equivalent of the e-mail systems (protocol).

For the digital environment to be consistent, it has to offer standardized, immediate invoicing, accounting, and inventory tracking to all computer owners, not just those who decided to pay a subscription for a service. In e-mail clients, when people want additional features, the software is written for the e-mail client, just like an extension is made for a web browser. So, there would be room afterwards to charge for add-on software features, but services that cover the basic needs should be established. All invoices share a common form and the data formats can accommodate all of the variations out there.

This is an unglamorous area of technology that needs to be addressed, but for the computer to be used evenly across the business sector, to be used easily by all small businesses, (and not just those with experienced IT personnel), it should be another technology like e-mail or web, just one that is used by business people.

At the moment, even at big retail stores, it is frequently e-mail that is being used to make purchase orders, to receive inventory in the back. Where there is a system in place, it is not interface with anyone else's. E-mail is serving too many purposes already and it shouldn't be the place where business is done. When the e-mail protocols were designed, they weren't expecting the world to be reliant on them for so many different online activities, including conducting business.

In addition to this, there will need to be additional file formats provided, as always is the case. For example, at the moment there is no universal file format for a business invoice (which could be named .oinv), a purchase order (.opurc), or a statement (.ostat). These are just examples. If these file formats exist and they are used on a dedicated business transaction network, this is when the Internet could truly move towards digitization of business, because the data and information for business will operate between businesses. Secondly, it would exist independent of any specific, proprietary invoicing and inventory service. From one perspective, there shouldn't even be invoicing software that has a monthly subscription.

A Common Inventory File Format

On the popular Square service, it isn't possible to download all of the inventory with the product images. It also isn't possible to upload images of inventory in a batch to Square. All kinds of these services ask people to upload and download their inventory in the form of spreadsheets. Really, there should be a universal file format for inventory so that it can be uploaded, download, or stored in a straightforward way.

In part because of how each business can be so different, there are many inventory software solutions. But there is no agreed upon file format for inventory, there is no agreed upon file format for invoices, and for the average person, these systems are not integrated typically without a lot of effort. The inventory placed into one system is not easily exported into another without IT personnel.

The result is that when the time arrives to transfer a set of inventory from a database, including the images for the products in that database, the conversion carries an unnecessary cost.
