In the future, there needs to be a file format for inventory that is recognized by all databases, so that there is no longer this conversion cost. It isn't possible to transfer a database of inventory from one system to another seamlessly because there is no agreed upon format for inventory. The same is true for invoicing, purchase orders, etc.

A New Business Transaction and Communication Network Protocol

Technical people will know the following already. But for those who don't, HTTP stands for hypertext transfer protocol and it is a network protocol for web browsers (the clients) and the web servers. Unlike the web, e-mail is more than one protocol. It is divided into two: the send mail transfer protocol (SMTP) is for sending emails and the receiving protocol called POP (Post Office Protocol). It's rather plain and it basically just sends text with attachments. It does not recognize any specific file format and because its software design is from an early era, it is completely vulnerable to junk e-mail.

A new business transaction network would be separate from e-mail and it would anticipate every type of business activity in advance and allow for enabling functionality in business that was not anticipated, called "extensibility" by software engineers. It would recognize file format for inventory, invoicing, billing, purchase orders, and more.

item.title: In Reality, The Food Environment Conspires against Healthy Eating
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
All that it takes is a road trip to find out how hard it is to eat healthy food in the current environment.

For a long time, the interest of large corporate food producers has been to make foods that are addictive and tasty, to squeeze them into places of convenience. Sweet and savory: this means lots of sugar and salt, and this is the main way to attract the masses, regardless of whether the products have nutritional value. The snacks usually do not.

In addition, food options are usually at two extremes: the affordable is either cooked from scratch at home or it is a bag of snacks.

Hardly ever are dishes cooked with brown rice, except at expensive restaurants.

So, it will take a lot of work to eat healthy.

item.title: You Don't Get to Explore Anything with Today's AI. It Just Does Things Out of Your View.
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
The larger picture of A.I. is that there is a lack of perspective in the situation: why let something do something for you completely? If the A.I. serves as a tool in the process of achieving a task, there is no problem with that. What results is the A.I. bringing about a different culture in society. But if it says, "here, let me take over everything you do while you sit in a chair and watch me," who would agree to that if it were a human being? The A.I. takes over in large part because people accept this inferior relationship to the machine.

Kid Pix As Reference Example

In another article, dFork explained the children's interactive program Kid Pix. It's a program that presented the audiovisual capabilities of the machine in such a way that the computer could be accepted as someday bringing about a new culture and not an invasion of existing everyday life. With any graphics program, its goal has to be that in its absence the normal processes that.

With Kid Pix, the user, whether adult or child, gets to explore the tool of the computer for the use of making computer graphics. Certainly there is a lot of work to be done if someone wants to turn Kid Pix's tools into software that makes aesthetic outcomes, but it gained a loyal following because the user was designed to be a part of the process.

Compare this to today's image-making A.I, in which the person enters a line of text and a very sophisticated image comes out of the big machine. Had Kid Pix been designed differently, to just take a line of typewritten text and then return with a finished result, this would have been rather dull. It would be quite horrible. It is the same with the A.I.

Recently, the world has been amazed by the ability of AI to generate realistic imagery and animations, as there are many images that can be generated in a fraction of the time that it would take a professional artist make them. From the start we can just say that if all illustration culture turns into a recombined and regenerated version of what people have produced over time, the world will feel much worse off. If people believe that themselves, the A.I. tools won't be used very often until they adapt to what people need to feel normal.

But in any case, by entering text as the prompt for image-making for today's AI, you simply wait for the results of the AI, what it does outside of any human process. From this perspective, it is totally boring, as it removes human action from human activity. From yet another perspective it is hobbled: how come the live image-generation is not controllable before the output? Why is it set up to just go off and do something and return with results? Who would want that, really?

What we say at dFork is that the less control the user has over the process of digital, the worse the software is. Because vector-drawing software in the past was so difficult to control, many computer graphics users would just end up making things out of the default, provided shapes. Because the bezier curves were always unwieldy to use, people could barely make aesthetically-pleasing renderings. They just looked very precise and it seemed like big progress.

The mistake is believing that what today's AI generates, however photorealistic or professional-looking in terms of artistic techniques, is the end of the matter, that what it does will result in a superior outcome. Once the image-making AI advances further, won't it outdo anything an artist can do, putting it together in a flash? Not exactly. It is instead in an inadequate state, precisely because it does not offer controls. It can do all of this image-making, but it is hobbled because no one can do anything but wait for the result. So it isn't finished at all.

If a technology leaves people feeling worried and despondent, it is bad. This is a simple issue.

If its processes are its own, totally hidden from view, and an artist has no part to play, generally there is something wrong.

If the AI is transformed into a tool-making configuration, along the lines of the old Kid Pix software, that is something different from it being fed a line of text and then going off and doing whatever it does according to its own algorithms and data.

If the goal of a person is to acquire an image right away that contains something, that isn't part of this discussion. In that case, what the person is seeking is a stock photo.

item.title: Pick Up A Wireless Barcode Scanner at the Front of The Store, Scan Physical Product Models, Pick Up Your Machine-Assembled Order at The Exit
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
You wouldn't need to use a shopping cart during grocery shopping if the conventional retail store is rearranged to make use of today's mobile technologies. Instead, you could be handed a wireless barcode scanner at the entrance, one that is embedded with a touchscreen display, and walking the aisles, you would scan models of the items that you usually take off the store shelves and place into your cart. The shelves in this store would have only one of each item in the display area. Their barcodes would be oversized and easy to scan. They would also show indicators of how much inventory is left for each item.

Instead of stocking shelves, the stores keep all inventory in the back and provide only one or two model items of each product inside the retail space, for inspection and evaluation by the customers. The workers (or the robots) in the back would load your order gradually as you shop. Alternatively, they load it all at the end rapidly, if you choose.

As you shop, if you needed 4 of an item, you would scan the product once on the store shelf and increase the order count of that item on the wireless barcode scanner by pressing the physical increment button. You would know how much you are spending as you shop, allowing you to increase or decrease the number of items before finalizing the order and having it assembled in the back.

You could pay with cash at the very end of shopping or swipe your card at the beginning, depending on your preference. Some shoppers will opt to bring their own barcode scanner attached to their phone (a device that exists already and is available). If many stores adopted this setup, the customer would launch the barcode scanning app specific to the retail store upon entering the building, scan the desired items, and then wait for the order to be fulfilled.

Using The Barcode Scanner on Large LED Screens for Certain Products

Not all items need a physical model present in the display area for their barcode to be scanned. Some might show up on large LED monitors, such as magazines that rotate monthly. You would scan their oversized barcodes on a screen. In compact scenarios, many of these items could be navigated on a tall, standing touchscreen LED screen.

Improved Efficiency and Reduced Operation Costs

Costs would go down for stores, as they do not have to manage expensive open-air refrigeration and glass door freezers. The frozen products would just be presented as their empty cardboard boxes, with their accompanying oversized barcodes. All refrigeration would be placed in the inventory room in the back.

As the retail store exists today, the product is first received in the back from the trucks, then it is transported to the inventory shelves for storage. Then it is carted out into the store area and manually stocked.  There is a lot of handling going on: it is then placed into the shopping cart by the customer. After the customer has finished putting all needed products into the cart, the order is taken out of the cart by the cashier (if the customer did not have to place it on the conveyor belt himself). Next, it is transported from the end of check stand into bags. Finally, the bags are placed back into a shopping cart if the order is more than two bags.

An application of modern wireless technology can make this far more efficient. In this different setup, in which the customer does the scanning, in a store space of model items, the robots or workers in the back in the inventory room simply move the product directly from the inventory shelves to the bags. This is the only handling of product after the initial receiving from the semi trucks. There is no need to rotate product on the display shelves in the front of the store because the shelves in the retail store are only displaying model items.

To make the situation continuous, the cart that travels across the inventory room to assemble your order is the one that is taken to your car for you by store employees if your order is large. If your order is small or is for the restaurant seating area, you can pick it up at a window inside the store.

The Layout Of The Store

Initially, this type of store is just for those who opt to patronize it, not those who want to inspect all of the products as they shop. It will be very different in feeling, but in the end easier to get through during busy times.

The first change that would take place on the floor plan of the store is that the inventory room's square footage would increase a great deal while the retail store space would become smaller. This is a benefit because it would not take much time for the customer to go through an entire store of products, as they are all paper or cardboard representations and there is only one of each. Currently, aisles are very long because they carry the majority of store inventory so that store customers can place products into the shopping cart. Only some of the product is left in the back for restocking.

In this scanner-oriented retail configuration, the inventory room is the only place where there is actual product inventory. So, it would make up the majority of the building's floor plan and in all likelihood the focus would be on a new type of inventory shelving for that big room, one that allows easy movement of product for the purpose of assembling orders. This would also include custom refrigeration arrangements so that frozen and refrigerator goods could be placed into the bags.

Likely there would be a track that the inventory room carts sit on, and they would have products placed into them rapidly as they moved down the track. It is possible that robots would play a role in this. When there are ordering errors or products that need to be returned, those could be handled manually by store personnel inside this inventory room. The focus will be the inventory room's reconfiguration, which is a different way of handling merchandise.

In the display area, the promotions in the store would take on a different physical format, as they would not involve assembled displays of the actual retail products, like the end caps for aisles.

The Device Used by The Customer

Customers are already familiar with the barcode scanner at self checkouts. The lead image for this article is actually a label printer that comes with a screen built into it. The photo was modified for the purpose of this article to illustrate what a device would look like.

An existing inventory scanner is shown below, and it makes use of an Android phone and the Android operating system. It shows that this could be a low-cost solution for a lot of stores. In the future, a customer might purchase this and use it at any store, with the key difference being that there is an app launched for each specific store. But all stores would be providing scanners for those who did not buy their own.

A Move Towards Better Service

The service phase would shift to taking groceries to the customer's car. At many stores, the customer might not end up touching the cart that transports the groceries because the checkout clerk's job has been shifted to something different: a worker who transports groceries to the parking lot from the inventory room and then takes the cart back to the inventory room.

If there is a restaurant seating area and the order is small, the groceries could be delivered in a style resembling that of a waiter and customer in a restaurant, though without tips. Or the customer could pick up a small order at a window next to the restaurant seating area.

The Physical Precursor to Regular AR/VR Shopping

Right now there is a complete lack of transition from the physical retail experience to VR/AR. This new retail store configuration could serve as a smooth transition for that because of how it is representations of products being scanned, not the actual goods upfront. The new format centered around the barcode scanner would inadvertently familiarize the public with how digital shopping could exist inside a virtual space. The barcode scanner that consumer is handed at the entrance of a physical store could be mirrored by a VR/AR implementation inside a virtual space using the common VR/AR controllers.

It is of course the case that there only needs to be one of any item displayed in a virtual, digital space and this would mirror the retail configuration just mentioned.

item.title: Using The World's Computing Infrastructure to Coordinate Productive Activity without 100% Monetary Transactions
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
The Internet Carries Capabilities For More Than Just Communications, Transmitting News, and Buying Products

In the 1980s, you wouldn't have time to use a telephone to call dozens of different participants for the project of building a house-- at least not by yourself. In a given city or region, out of tens of thousands, or hundreds of thousands, of people, the task of finding the interested individuals would be difficult unless you were the local television news station. Taking out a newspaper advertisement for that kind of project would be too expensive unless you were a wealthy business or individual and simply wanted to build the house for personal reasons. But now, with the Internet, it is more than just feasible, it is taken for granted that interested individuals can sign up to see a large project happen, just by one person setting up a web page who has advertised it across the Internet. The concept of the situation, though, is that it will be a collection of money that is on the page, and that only a single organizer will carry out the project.

Internet users and startups have not moved the concept over to other coordination and resource allocation scenarios, like collecting labor commitments from all visitors to the web page. They haven't tried collecting signups for material resource contributions, such as a needed object that could be sent through the mail or by freight. If that were to occur, a house could potentially be built with a small amount money. The volumes of material resources that people need to build a house might be on hand across some people's properties. It is a general example. It is immediately applicable to the world that is stocked full of material objects that have been purchased online in abundance. It is a world that continues to focus on using money to buy more on top of the abundant stock to accomplish goals. Driving down a highway reveals that many people's properties contain unused surplus goods, many of which are in good condition but are not put to use. It's especially obvious when going through online advertisements where people are selling their used goods. People acquire a lot of objects that do not fetch much money when sold online and in many cases it is not convenient to bother to sell them. But they might be more interested if they would be put to good use in a project that is coordinated in a sophisticated way using today's computers and the Internet.

Future Uses of The Internet Can Change How People Coordinate Projects, Reducing the Importance of Money When It Is Unnecessary

For most people, money is hard to come by. It's just a fact that only the top tier of society is rich. In actuality, the global network of computers allows elaborate coordination of non-monetary resources, but it has never been used that way. When websites like Kickstarter and IndieGoGo came online, Internet users realized that their own interests could be merged with that of other people living far away because the all-or-nothing collection mechanism could be programmed in computer software and served on the Internet, tapping the power of everyone buying a computer. But everyone stopped there, believing that it was a merely a digital space for collecting financial transactions exclusively for projects. It was only a place for one type of activity: collecting money that would be made use of by a single entity.

Instead, a project organizer could set up a web page listing project roles that need to be fulfilled, and without a lot of money being spent, a very complex project could be assembled by a large number of people who do not know each other that well in advance or aren't necessarily part of an organization. They might not even live in the same geographic area if the project involves building something specific to software or the Internet.

Through this a physical project could be assembled in pieces in separate locations. To give an example, one portion of a built structure might be assembled in one location while another piece is fabricated elsewhere. The pieces might be built in separate locations and sent to a central place to be put together. This can be organized on the Internet and make use of all of the used goods people have.

The Current Belief in Money Above Other Means

Many countries in the West have a firm belief in spending money to accomplish anything of importance. It can indeed acquire the needed resources when the needs are very large. But in large part, there is wealth sitting inside the computer and the Internet. It's not that it is always tapped, just that it took so much for society to build it up over the years that it shouldn't be overlooked for what it can do in the real world. Usually when people are dealing with computers it does not tie back to the real world if it isn't about information or money. That is to say, people frequently do not sit online and organize the details of their real world activities in such a way that it ties into their living environments and the objects they own.

The Existence of The Internet and The Computing Infrastructure Is More Valuable Than It Appears

It takes billions of dollars to set up just one chip manufacturing plant. To produce a computer, a multitude of resources are required throughout multiple supply chains, all the way to the actual mining of precious materials. It takes so-called economy of scale-- very large production volumes of these computers and their computer screens-- to make them affordable for the consumer public. Decades of programming the machines put them in the state they are that is more than the previous decade. Capital investments over the years amount to something that shouldn't be ignored, lately in the field of A.I.

Many telecommunication companies have built up high-speed communication networks around these computer machines, from the wireless telephone companies to the local Internet provider. Chip designing companies like Qualcomm or NVIDIA design the chips before they are sent to factories to be fabricated into real chips. Then, after all of that, the computers that have been networked across the world are viewed simply as gateways for financial transactions, even as material objects and collection of personnel assistance could play a greater role. It takes a lot for the computer industry to exist, other words, and there is something to be said about how a person does not have to be rich to do something big if the Internet actually allows it (e.g. all-or-nothing crowdfunding projects).

It's rare that a "flash mob" comes together and builds something, except in charitable scenarios. In many situations, when the director of a building project has the money to spend, it is a matter of opening up the old phone directory, calling up the relevant contractor, and getting the plans moving for a long-term project that needs be carried out. Anything beyond minor, charitable volunteering will be accomplished with money: the contractor himself will be paid with it, the objects will be purchased at stores with it, the subcontracted labor will be paid with it, and so on.

With the Internet, at least another type of scenario can enter public activity. The Internet sits around with the ability to coordinate collection resources differently according to the needs of many types of activities. This was already demonstrated when all-or-nothing projects appeared in the early 2010s: people can make use of the Internet to bring together people. But it can collect more than just their money. It can also bring together their labor and their personal assets they want to contribute. The Internet industries did not examine the all-or-nothing projects that closely and instead viewed them in terms of accumulating capital. It's really that these websites are taking advantage of globally networked computers. It is people who use the Internet and people can interact with all of the computer terminals in their pockets to coordinate something larger.

The Modern World Is Filled with Property And Assets

Behind every computer sitting in an office building is often a large set of concrete, real world properties (corporate assets). Behind many people's computers are their estates and their storage facilities where they have many objects that will never be utilized. They were acquired in a one-way manner: rapidly from the Internet. But the other end was not accommodated: they cannot be rapidly allocated using the Internet. The result is that there is a lot of material, tangible wealth behind people while they focus on using money to get everything accomplished.

Artificial intelligence could certainly be used as a tool for registering any material objects that a person wants to place on the global computing network to be made use of by someone else.

The mindset of the Internet industry is narrow: the humans behind each computer are just people who can send and receive money with these increasingly powerful terminals. It is not discussed: isn't it true that this is the medium for coordinating participation from large numbers of people in separate locations across the globe, using the complex programmatic capabilities of a computer to acquire tangible, real-world resources without needing to use so much money to do it?

The money has already been spent on the actual computing infrastructure, what has been globally networked. Years and years of accumulating material objects quickly through online commerce means that people have piles of objects they cannot possibly reallocate elsewhere to make them go to good use. The consequence is that there are loads of material resources piling up in people's corporate asset holdings, their houses, backyards, all of which could be identified and utilized in one form or another through the coordinative capabilities of the Internet.

The unfortunate fact is that the public generally considers itself well-versed in technical matters after using an iPhone for a long time or a social media website. Those who succeeded in using the tin-can-on-a-string social media websites of today, accumulating thousands or even millions of followers, including on YouTube, are simply to assured of themselves when it comes to what the Internet is capable of doing in the real world. Prone to chasing hype and excitement, none of these individuals, including the YouTube "creators" are capable of taking a deep breath, looking around, and asking how the Internet relates to the real world.

It was always all-or-nothing crowdfunding that produced the VR headset that the YouTube video "creator" makes videos about, one after another. But none of these technical experts take a moment to ask: isn't it really strange that every technological discussion is about what will execute inside the computer hardware, except for one lone category: all-or-nothing crowdfunding?

item.title: Understanding The Next Wave of User Interface Theory
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
The future of user interface theory is about understanding that which is currently vague or unrecognized in software interfaces but has a lot happening. Why do people look down on video games? Primarily their interfaces are very primitive. It doesn't matter how hard you press the button, the onscreen character will jump to the same height.

Start with what is Tetris about. First it is about tetrominos, the four-blocked pieces. Tetr- is the prefix for four, and of course a domino has only two blocks. The main issue is that video games are software, and that is implemented through pixels. This conceals how Tetris is a mechanical machine existing in software.

What do the arrow keys do? The arrow keys would, if Tetris would implemented mechanically, move a piece to the right or the left one block step, through turning gears. A pressed button on the machine would rotate the piece clockwise. Its neighbor button would rotate the piece counterclockwise.

The pixels are a screen representation of what this mechanical setup would be. So it becomes more that the computer exists

item.title: The Key-Click UI Is The Future UI for Desktop Software
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
The key-click UI is an improved software user interface for the desktop computer. When it is implemented comprehensively (dragging, resizing, etc.), it is far superior to current interactivity found in desktop software.

A software application that implements the key-click UI ignores the clicks of the mouse. All clicks occur with key presses on the keyboard. The mouse is only used to move the cursor.

This is best experienced rather than explained, so a demo is provided below.

Demo (for Desktop Computers Only)

This demo lets you draw polylines (lines with multiple straight segments).

The gray rectangular area below accepts key presses:

  • Press the "F" key after placing the cursor in the gray area. Then move the mouse.
  • Press "F" again to add another point. You then move the mouse again. Keep adding points as needed.
  • To end drawing of the polyline, press one of three keys: "A", "E", or "R".
  • Press "V" to thicken the stroke and "C" to thin the stroke of the polyline.

Modern Capabilities of Software Are Often Bottlenecked by The Mouse

Possibly one of the most developed areas of application computing is electronic music, though not the largest. After decades of technological advances, music synthesis software has become much more capable, and electronic musicians now enjoy the ability to produce an impressive range of sounds on the computer, both realistic and surreal. But despite this, physical synthesizer hardware, featuring knobs and buttons, still carries a strong appeal in this community. Often mentioned as a reason is the unpleasant experience of using a mouse to manipulate controls inside the audio software, especially for long periods of time. Compared to a piano or other musical instrument, the standard computer user interface is tedious and inadequate but this is not only an issue for musicians using audio software. Interacting with desktop computers has remained unchanged since the famous 1968 personal computing demonstration by Douglas Engelbart, the man who came up with the computer mouse.

Unknown to many people today, Engelbart did not use a mouse by itself for that first demonstration. His mouse was paired with a separate device he made that resembled five piano keys. These two devices worked together during his presentation, with the keyboard sitting in between (above). So, in the beginning the mouse was not intended to be left by itself all the time.

Also, the Xerox Star computer, which preceded the Macintosh, featured several extra keys on the keyboard that manipulated text, moved objects, and opened files. When personal computers were introduced in a minimalistic way by Apple with the Macintosh, only a simple mouse remained, accompanied by a basic keyboard. All software was supposed to work inside this simplified setup, which has resulted in a bottleneck for today's software interactivity.

For example, if the mouse were truly sufficient for modern software needs, professional video editors would not feel the need to buy video controller knob hardware for their editing stations.  The recent interest in macro hardware, popular among photo editors and video game streamers (e.g. the Streamdeck device), shows that the mouse isn't always enough, that people want more than memorized shortcuts and the mouse.

But since the majority of software is not tied to external hardware devices yet, there is another means for interacting with software and it is what dFork calls the key-click UI.  In short, it is a reconfiguration of how the keyboard and mouse are used to interact with software, a kind of programmatic re-wiring.  

The key-click UI ignores the mouse's click buttons and repurposes the keys of the keyboard as the click buttons instead, which allows greater control over the software.  Many more click buttons are available for software developers as a result.  In the key-click UI, the mouse strictly serves to change the cursor's location.  This is better experienced rather than explained.

The demo (link below) on dFork.News gives website visitors a chance to try out the key-click UI, producing vector lines in real time in a way that is unlike current vector-drawing software.  It is a preview of how software will surely work in the future, provided that software developers are made aware of the key-click UI and how it can replace each and every convention of the current situation.

DEMO: https://www.dfork.news/key-click-ui/

This demo is just supposed to provide an introduction to what the key-click UI provides.  The key-click UI is not only about drawing vector lines, but rather upgrading how the mouse is used.  Although key-click UI can draw vector lines and shapes much more quickly than a normal vector-drawing software, the points and lines it produces are applied to many areas of software. They are made use of to:

1) replace the lasso tool (the vector shape is the resulting lasso area)

2) replace the selection rectangle (the line is the diagonal of the upright rectangle).

3) connect audio and video "patches" (also called "nodes") in professional production software, as well as disconnect them much more quickly than conventional mouse usage.

4) edit, increment and decrement parameters on the "patches".

5) carry out a dragging operation without holding down a mouse button (the second point of the line is the drag destination-- the place where the object is dropped).

All of these cases and more have been implemented in software prototypes, in particular dFork's own Floating Marker vector drawing program.

http://dfork.news/

KEY-CLICK UI DEMO PAGE: https://www.dfork.news/key-click-ui/

item.title: Using A.I. to Write Code Is Masking The Problems in Our Antiquated Programming Systems
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
For a long time, it was believed that if people could speak to computers and provide them direct verbal instructions, this would be a great advancement in technology.

But reportedly, consumers who use devices like Alexa or Siri to control appliances in the house will stop using them after a short period of time. Microsoft mostly removed its equivalent to Siri, called Cortana, because it was unused in Windows.

In fact, there is a cost to verbalizing computer commands. It would be better, for example, if Alexa accepted its own aural language (e.g. claps) specific to controlling appliances, instead of requiring anything verbalized. Because of this cost of verbalizing, which is quite steep for making computers do things, the gains had by an appliance like Alexa are smaller than anticipated.

The same is true for using A.I. (a LLM) to write code. Though A.I. can be very useful, even instrumental in writing certain, tedious programs in a short period of time, articulating every specific aspect of a computer program for an AI system to write the code is a poor solution masking the underlying problem: the state of code itself is bad and it is overly difficult to write.

Programmers just can't come to terms with how it all exists. If just one semicolon is omitted, the code doesn't run at all. Instruction syntax is very specific and particular in these languages; if the data type of a variable isn't defined correctly, the program doesn't run. Each program has its own particular way of implementing the same command and it will break on minor variations from the others.

Notably, the programming languages' editors are not designed in terms of the code's tokenized (typed out as a discrete unit) keywords, even though keywords are scattered throughout the programming languages. It is a very serious design flaw: any keyword such as "if" or "function" can have the text cursor inserted in the middle and then a typo introduced. The same is true for the variables and function names, that they are not turned into keywords and are instead vulnerable to being broken up with typographic errors.

When there are problems this bad in the overall form (and the interactive design) of the programming languages and their editors, the LLM will be very exhausting to use in most cases.

item.title: ConceptTemplates As a New Interactive Programming Technique
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
Multimedia or interactive programming could easily be distinguished from the rest of computer programming and it could be provided its own set of conventions.

It would be better to be provided a kind of component or class of object that is itself highly configurable and modifiable. How many video games make use of a grid?

-- Tetris (the background board and the pieces themselves)

-- Checkers

-- Chess

Layers of grid components, some whose goal is only to draw tiles, others.

item.title: Unlock Western Furniture, Interiors, and Architecture First by Studying Moldings
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Moldings are decorative features that are commonly found in Western furniture and architecture. By studying moldings, you can gain a deeper understanding of the history, culture, and design principles of Western furniture and architecture.

Moldings are typically made from wood, plaster, or other materials, and are used to add detail and ornamentation to the surfaces of furniture, walls, and ceilings. Moldings can take many different forms, including cornices, crown moldings, baseboards, and chair rails.

The use of moldings in Western furniture and architecture can be traced back to ancient Greece and Rome, where they were used to adorn the exteriors of buildings and the interiors of homes. Over time, moldings became an important element of Western design, and were used to add elegance, refinement, and sophistication to furniture and architecture.

One of the key benefits of studying moldings is that they can provide insight into the historical and cultural context of Western furniture and architecture. By examining the design and ornamentation of moldings, you can learn about the artistic movements and design styles that influenced their creation. For example, you might study the elaborate carvings and gilding of Baroque moldings, or the sleek and minimal lines of Modernist moldings.

Another benefit of studying moldings is that they can help you to understand the principles of design and composition that are used in Western furniture and architecture. By looking at the placement, scale, and proportion of moldings, you can learn how they contribute to the overall balance, harmony, and visual interest of a space. You can also learn how moldings are used to create focal points, draw the eye, and add depth and dimension to a room.

In conclusion, studying moldings is a valuable way to unlock the history, culture, and design principles of Western furniture and architecture. Whether you're a design enthusiast, a historian, or simply curious about the world around you, studying moldings can provide a rich and rewarding learning experience.

item.title: The Four Humor Theory Is Not Something to Laugh at
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
The concept of the four humors has been a part of Western medical tradition for thousands of years. While the idea may seem quaint and outdated today, the four humors are still a useful framework for understanding the human body and its functioning.

The four humors are a set of four bodily fluids that were believed to govern the health and well-being of the body. These fluids were blood, phlegm, yellow bile, and black bile. The humors were thought to be in balance when a person was healthy, but could become imbalanced when a person became sick.

The four humors were thought to be linked to the four elements of nature - earth, air, fire, and water - and were believed to reflect the nature and characteristics of the universe and all things in the world. For example, the humor of blood was thought to be associated with the element of air, and was believed to represent the qualities of warmth and moisture. The humor of black bile, on the other hand, was thought to be associated with the element of earth, and was believed to represent the qualities of coldness and dryness.

The humoral theory of medicine was developed by the ancient Greek physician Hippocrates, who believed that the body was made up of these four fluids, and that the body's health was determined by the balance of the humors. According to Hippocrates, an excess of any one of the humors could lead to illness, and it was the physician's job to restore the balance of the humors through a variety of methods, such as diet, exercise, and medication.

The four humors, linked to the four elements of nature - earth, air, fire, and water - and were thought to reflect the individual's temperament and personality. For example, a person with a predominance of blood was thought to be sanguine and cheerful, while a person with a predominance of black bile was thought to be melancholic and morose.

Despite the fact that the concept of the four humors has been largely discarded by modern medicine, the humoral theory still has some relevance today. For example, the concept of balancing the body's fluids is still an important part of modern medical practice, and many medications are designed to address imbalances in the body's fluids.

In conclusion, while the four humors may seem like a quaint and outdated concept, they are still a useful framework for understanding the human body and its functioning. Whether you are a historian, a medical professional, or simply curious about the history of medicine, the four humors are worth exploring and learning about.

The concept of the four humors was a popular belief in Western culture during the time of Shakespeare and was frequently referenced in his works and other cultural items of the time. The four humors were thought to be the four bodily fluids that governed the health and well-being of the body, and were believed to be in balance when a person was healthy.

In Shakespeare's play "Hamlet," the character Polonius describes the four humors as "the melancholy, the bloody, the flegmatic, and the sanguine." He also links each humor to a particular temperament and personality type, stating that a person with a predominance of black bile is "solemn and sad," while a person with a predominance of blood is "merry and capricious."

The concept of the four humors was also referenced in other cultural items of the time, such as literature, art, and music. For example, the English composer Henry Purcell wrote a vocal piece called "The Humors of Oxford," which features four solo voices representing the four humors. In art, the Dutch painter Frans Hals painted a series of portraits called "The Laughing, the Weeping, the Mellancholic, and the Pensive Man," which depict the four humors as four different men.

Diagrams of the Four Humors

A diagram of the four humors is a visual representation of the concept of the four bodily fluids that were believed to govern the health and well-being of the body. The diagram typically consists of a circular or oval shape, with four sections that represent the four humors.

In the center of the diagram, there is often a symbol or image that represents the balance of the humors. This might be a scale, a circle, or a star, for example. The four sections of the diagram are typically labeled with the names of the four humors: blood, phlegm, yellow bile, and black bile.

Each section of the diagram is typically color-coded to represent the corresponding humor. For example, the section for blood might be colored red, the section for phlegm might be colored white, the section for yellow bile might be colored yellow, and the section for black bile might be colored black.

The diagram may also include additional information, such as the characteristics of each humor and how they relate to health and well-being. For example, the section for blood might include information about the effects of an excess of blood, such as warmth and dryness, while the section for black bile might include information about the effects of an excess of black bile, such as coldness and wetness.

item.title: A Lasting Industrial Design from a 1980s Japanese Computer, The Sony Hitbit
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Many Sony product's industrial designs are enjoyed past the time of their devices' lifespans or relevance to the contemporary computing environment. The Sony Hitbit is a 1980s computer that is notable for its enduring industrial design, demonstrating that there are some design principles lurking somewhere in older devices that are do not just dedicate themselves to reducing a computer's form to the most minimalistic shell. Despite being over 30 years old, the Hitbit's modern appearance still holds up today.

The Hitbit was released in 1986, and it was designed to be a compact and portable computer that could be used for a variety of applications. It featured a black and silver color scheme, with a keyboard that could be detached from the main unit for added flexibility. The Hitbit also had a built-in cassette player and a liquid crystal display (LCD) screen that was capable of displaying text and graphics.

One of the standout features of the Hitbit's design was its slim and lightweight form factor. The main unit measured just 12 inches wide by 9 inches deep by 2 inches tall, and weighed only 4.5 pounds. This made it one of the most portable computers of its time, and allowed users to easily take it with them wherever they went.

The Sony HB-F1XD, above, is a portable computer that was released in 1989. It is a member of the HB-F1 series of computers, which were designed to be compact and lightweight, making them easy to take with you wherever you go.

The HB-F1XD is powered by a 16-bit microprocessor, which provides it with fast and efficient processing power. It also has a built-in 5.25-inch floppy disk drive, which allows users to store and transfer data. The computer also has a built-in keyboard, which can be detached from the main unit for added flexibility.

An Arab company called Sakhr made a version for the Arab world.

item.title: Disney and The Advancement of Animatronics
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Disney is widely known for its early use of animatronics, which are robotic devices that are designed to move and operate in a lifelike manner. In fact, because of audio-animatronics, Disney is often credited with developing and popularizing animatronics, and has used them in a wide range of its productions over the years. In the 1960s, Walt Disney's Imagineering division developed the Audio-Animatronics technology, which was used in a number of Disney's theme park attractions, such as Pirates of the Caribbean and the Haunted Mansion. One of the most famous uses of Audio-Animatronics is in the "Hall of Presidents" attraction at Disney World's Magic Kingdom, which features Audio-Animatronics figures of all of the United States Presidents.

Disney first began using animatronics in its theme park attractions in the 1960s. One of the earliest and most famous examples of Disney's use of animatronics is the Audio-Animatronics figures that were used in the Pirates of the Caribbean attraction at Disneyland. These figures were able to move and perform in a realistic and lifelike manner, and were considered a major breakthrough in the field of animatronics.

Disney has continued to develop and refine its use of animatronics over the years, and has used them in a wide range of its productions. For example, animatronics were used extensively in the Hollywood Studios' "The Great Movie Ride," which featured figures of famous movie characters, such as King Kong and the Wicked Witch of the West.

Disney has also used animatronics in its movies and television shows. For example, animatronics were used in the 1983 movie "Return to Oz," and in the 1990s television series "Dinosaurs." In both of these productions, animatronics were used to create lifelike and realistic characters that were able to move and perform in a believable way.

In conclusion, Disney is often credited with developing and popularizing animatronics, and has used them in a wide range of its productions over the years. From its early use of animatronics in its theme park attractions, to its more recent use of the technology in movies and television shows, Disney has consistently been at the forefront of animatronics development.
