item.title: "Trippy" Displays Should Not Be Considered Sufficient for Future Music Visualizers
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
SUMMARY:

The article discusses the limitations of current music visualizers, which rely solely on displaying the audio waveform data of a song. The author argues that this approach is inadequate for software music players and that music visualizers of the future will need to be provided more detailed real-time information (data) about the music, such as timing of the lyrics, beats, melody, and other aspects of the song, as well as data about the overall structure and composition of the music. This information will lead to much better outcomes in visualizers and bring them past the form of a fad. For large numbers of songs, the data could be obtained through the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms that seek certain categories of information (beats, melody, et.c). In addition, the author suggests that future music visualizers should be more visually appealing and aesthetically ordered. For instance, they should match the type of music being played, rather than being a one-size-fits-all piece of software.

Popular Video Game Interactions with Songs Are Enabled by Extra Data Provided to The Developers

There is a popular virtual reality video game that is one of the most frequently played in VR, and it involves interacting with the beats and notes of the song in real time (though in a way that is irksome to those who regard musical notes as something not to be treated that way). It carries the same category of gameplay as the popular arcade game Dance Dance Revolution in which players had to dance along with notes of songs. What this shows is that people would like to tie the graphical capabilities of the computer to the playing audio files. The reason that that virtual reality video game can do what it does, though, is that it has extra information provided to it beyond the audio waveform data (that is commonly seen in a music visualizer). Each song bundled with the video game has had data made for it, actually. It could be done manually or automatically through the use of software, but almost never is except for these circumstances.

In the past, many music visualizers were simple, trippy displays that lacked sophistication and did not provide much in the way of information about the music. That is because they relied solely on displaying the audio waveform data that was in the audio file or stream as it was playing. The visualizer's audio waveform is a graphical representation of the sound wave of a song, what is present in the file, showing the amplitude (loudness) of the wave over time. Although this information can be useful for analyzing a song's overall volume at certain points, it can represent the song only in a limited way for computer graphics.

For music visualizers to improve, they need to be provided concrete information about multiple elements of the song, such as the beat or melody. By itself, the waveform will only incidentally show this in a music visualizer. It is actually rather vague, but it gets some parts across. It actually does not contain enough computer data for that role.

Just Leaning on The Audio Waveform For The Music Visualizers Made Them a Fad

Music visualizers in the 2000s were a popular feature on many media playback applications, but they were often considered trendy later because, although the public might not have said it out loud, there just isn't anything of interest in the audio waveform after a while for that purpose. In the end, companies like Apple and other streaming services completely removed these music visualizer software features altogether, but this is because they did not address the problem of relying solely on the audio waveform data for their visualizers, just using graphical computer programming techniques to translate it directly to the screen. Whether it is turned into a 3D landscape or rotated around the circle, it's the audio waveform alone. They gave up precisely because they weren't working with any extra information. When people believed that is what visualizers are, then they lose interest in them.

The beats per minute rate is actually very different information from the audio waveform data, for example. So would the notes from the melody of the song. Already that is two sources of information that none of the visualizers ever had.

Because this issue is hardly ever recognized, visualizers are still the same today as in the 2000s, looking only approximately connected to the music they are suppose to represent on the screen. This plain approach to music visualization is no longer sufficient for the demands of modern music.

To meet this requirement, music visualizers of the future will need to be provided more detailed information about the music played, which could include timing of the lyrics.

It necessarily would include information about the beats, melody, and other aspects of the song, as well as data about the overall structure and composition of the music. This is the first step, to get the actual data that represents the songs being played.

How The Player Can Obtain Data That The Music Visualizers Can Use

So, the main issue is that the software developers were not provided any extra data because that isn't inherent to the structure of an audio file. Some additional means of producing this extra data has to occur. Since there are so many aspects to what could be represented, this is a topic that might require some planning. Some of it could be created manually. But a more efficient way to achieve this in today's computing environment is through the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms, which can analyze a song and produce varied information about its structure and content, as configured and desired, then provide this in a parallel file that either accompanies the playing song or is built into the metadata section of the file perhaps. This data can then be supplied for the visualizer, creating animations and visual effects that are closely tied to the music. Software developers will have a much better time making this kind of program.

Putting Order into The Actual Music Visualizer Graphics

In addition to providing more detailed information about the music, future music visualizers will also need to be more visually appealing and aesthetically ordered. What this implies is actually considering the visualizer in terms of concepts that translate. In some cases this can mean a base of movements or animations that are used to match the type of music being played or the song. Different categories can be presented on the screen differently, in other words.

Video and 3D graphics that are played with a music file should have plans, it would be good if what they made matched the type of music being played-- not just exist as one-size-fits-all piece of software.

The future of music visualization will require a shift away from simple, trippy displays, and towards more sophisticated and informative visualizations that provide a deeper experience for music fans that is reflective of the songs' audio contents. The translation to the screen should be accurate, in other words, and not just act as a reconfigured graphical display of audio data.

If the audio data that accompanies the song is meaningful, it is then the case that it can be linked into devices in the home, such as so-called "smart home" lights, or it can be utilized this way in commercial displays in stores and urban environments, such as in high-trafficked areas of a city. The technology is there, but it is underutilized because it is a perfunctory correlation between what is in the song files and what is supposedly being "visualized".

item.title: Social Media Has Lots of Talking, But It Doesn't Make Use of The Computer's Interactive Capabilities
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
ABOVE: AN INTERACTIVE PROGRAM, THE KIND THAT COULD BE EMBEDDABLE IN A SOCIAL MEDIA POST. THIS WAS SHOWN INSIDE A WEB BROWSER FROM A NOW-DEFUNCT FORMAT CALLED .CDF (COMPUTABLE DOCUMENT FORMAT).

User Uploads of Interactive Programs-- Not Just Video Clips and Still Images

Playing movies and displaying still images is not all that computers can do. If social media websites had a more well-rounded set of features that were reflective of the computers people use today, they would allow uploading of interactive media. A soundboard could be uploaded to a Twitter post, just to give an example. What it takes to accomplish this is a universal file format, one that is recognized for the purpose of uploading and distributing interactive media. Of course, along the way, this would allow uploading small video games to social media posts. But the primary purpose would be to expand social media and the web beyond consumption of short video clips, text, and photos. Website users would be able to interact with programmatic content inside a post.

The "Creative Coding" Community Cannot Upload Small Programs into Posts

On Twitter, there are communities of computer programmers who showcase their digital, modern art pieces. What they make often reminds a person of screensavers. This is called "creative coding," and it is associated with specific programming frameworks (such as P5JS). But because there is no way to upload interactive programs to social media, these programmers cannot actually post their interactive work. They have to post captured videos of what their programs do. This is absurd, that people are uploading screen captures of their small computer programs to websites-- for web browsers that are very capable of running them in real time. When Adobe Flash was provided in web browsers, the programmers didn't have to do that.

Normally, website visitors would be able to use a mouse and keyboard to interact with the "creative coding" work (like the one below) but this isn't possible because social websites do not accept uploads of small multimedia programs.

f=0,draw=a=>{for(f||createCanvas(W=400,W,WEBGL),lights(background(0)),j=0;j<PI;j+=PI/32)for(i=0;i<TAU;i+=PI/512)push(),rotateY(i+f),translate(sin(T=tan(atan(i)))*(S=150*sin(j+i)),tan(cos(i+f))*sin(i+f)*150,cos(T)*S),pop(sphere(3*cos(i+f),W));f+=PI/256};//#Processing #p5js pic.twitter.com/QuHuGmp5gd

Koma Tebe (@KomaTebe) March 15, 2023

The main obstacle is that there is no longer a universal, multimedia file format that can be uploaded an upload option that would be positioned next to a video file option (.MP4) or a still image option (.JPG) for attaching media to a post. There used to be, when Adobe Flash was a standard part of the web browser. The file format that was uploaded was .SWF. With it, a website user could embed a multimedia program into a post. Compared to all of the current solutions for user uploads of website multimedia today, it was the most straightforward.

The Abolition of Flash Left The Web In a State of Passive Consumption

Flash faced strong opposition by ideological individuals who were ignorant of all of its valuable features, including that it filled in deficiencies of the web browser that still have not been filled in since. Though many technical aspects have been satisfied with later solutions (HTML5, JavaScript, WebAssembly, etc.), the usability of those solutions has not been up to par. Once Flash was abandoned, interactive media necessarily had to be separated into small pieces, JavaScript files, which prohibited uploading them as a coherent unit, like how a PDF can just be simply e-mailed.

Flash's file format, .SWF, provided a major convenience: it could be easily embedded into a web page just like a .JPG image or .MP4 movie file without much effort and it was self-contained. So, what the web actually needs is a universal file format to replace .SWF, so that a multimedia program can once again be uploaded in unit form to web pages and social media posts. In this form, an interactive program will be able to be e-mailed to groups and individuals just like a PDF or image is today. Once such an interactive file format is available, computer programs will be post-able to a website like Twitter or Facebook rather easily. Social media can offer more than one-way consumption to the website visitor.

Wolfram's Computable Document Format

A PDF lends itself to information and copy. If configured another way, it could contain a computer program (with clickable slider controls, text boxes, etc.) in a similar page format. For the purpose of exchanging such computer programs, in 2011 Wolfram promoted the computational equivalent to a PDF, which it called CDF (Computable Document Format). However, its implementation was not open enough, despite trying to fill an important role for computer software. It ultimately existed as a niche product that could only serve a narrow audience, because the documents were produced entirely by Wolfram's Mathematica software, specialized for for mathematical and scientific computation. All the same, many of the demonstrations of CDF supported the position that portable computer program documents are something important to have.

For today's web browsers, there could be a multimedia-specific file format just like CDF. As long as the file format is universally recognized, just like PDF, any vendor could implement a "viewer" of such a file. The success of PDF has to do with how it is not coupled to a web browser. Neither is a .JPG file or .MP4 file. The interactive file format should not be fused to opening a web browser, in other words.

Myspace and Flash

Go to any web developer conference and there is a mindless reaction to Flash, one of derision. But it is actually Adobe Flash streaming video (.FLV) that made YouTube possible, and years afterwards the video format was replaced by .MP4 movie files. Initially, the video player interface for YouTube was a .SWF file from 2005 to 2011. It shows the major contribution that Flash made to the web and how it was inappropriate for it to be attacked so thoughtlessly by so many ideologically-driven web developers. Many of the solutions that the conventional web development community has put forward (HTML5) has amounted to a fragmentation of the functionality that was well-integrated (though proprietary) in Flash.

With respect to being able to post computer programs, in the late 2000s, the social networking website Myspace allowed embedding Flash programs (.SWF) into user profiles. In that short period of a few years, on that website, a person could post an online game in the form of an Adobe Flash post, adding it to someone else's Myspace profile.

The embedded Flash applet could serve games, photo galleries, or anything a person had programmed in the Flash file. This sort of capability simply does not exist anymore on any of the well-known social media websites because code is separated into multiple JavaScript files. It just doesn't work to use JavaScript and HTML as if it could do what Flash did.

Even Facebook Made Use of Flash in User Profiles

In 2007, on Facebook, if someone made an app out of Flash, such as a painting app, it could be posted onto a person's own profile. A computer user simply cannot do that today on any major website and this is due to how the web browsers are now set up, how they were restricted after the widespread removal of Adobe Flash. The main issue is that those who developed the web browser specifications are not the same as those who produced software for multimedia audiences.

You cannot post computer programs and games onto your own website profile or any one else's. The lack of actual freedom to embed small programs inside a web page-- actually the total absence of any natural capacity to do this-- shows how limited the Internet has become. Very mundane social discussions, made out of text, span the globe and sit on top of computers that carry much speed and functionality to share computer programs. The programs could be varied in their manifestations, from sound boards to animations to small games.

It isn't that web browsers cannot serve software, as there are many applications, even 3D modeling apps that are available. It's that those have to be served by the people who own the website, all of the time. The web visitor is the person who should also be able to upload an app. The best way is to make sure there is a universal document format for this.

The most popular side of the web, social media, is now constrained to delivering still pictures, streaming video, and public commentary. This may seem like a lot to the public. But in the past, the websites could accept actual, embeddable software applications into the web pages, uploaded by the users, without complicated procedures.

After the removal of Flash and Java applet compatibility, the web became a complicated place for uploading software onto the actual web pages, even for web developers who have full control over the website and web servers. The solutions allowed by web browsers usually require many disconnected fragments that hardly ever get packaged together as a single unit.

There is no standard file format for consolidating interactive web media into a single file as there was with Adobe Flash, one that would sit alongisde .JPG, .PNG, .MP4, etc. The consolidated file format was, de facto, Flash. It contained everything needed for the program to execute inside the Flash plug-in. The main issue is that that plug-in was much more capable than what is contained in a web browser today in terms of programmability. Technically everything is there to make what existed in a Flash file, but in actuality the Flash system was much better for writing code. This, in combination with the difficulties uploading the files as single units, has made the web a comparatively boring digital place compared to the 2000s.

Social Media Discussions Began to Dominate The Web Because a Multimedia File Format Was Missing

As a result of these gaps, the talkative social media side of the web has become dominant. It is mostly a medium for public chatter, posting about oneself, contention about world affairs, and remarks about other people. Certain there have been some gains in terms of cultural uploads to these websites. Social media has become an integral part of many people's daily lives on the Internet, with billions of people around the world using the platforms. The world Internet culture is shaped by a restricted software feature set provided in the web browsers, though. The main issue is that the people who can discuss this will not, because they are in denial of it or they never used Flash. The features in the web browser for programmers are not organized properly.

The web has changed significantly since the 2000s, being very centered around Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. For unknown reasons, this extreme narrowing of the web to these websites is hardly ever lamented by website professionals who were around in the 2000s. They are here to stay because many regular computer users depend on these websites to broadcast information to their personal or commercial audiences. Many companies struggled to have any online presence until Facebook provided it with its "pages". But there is very little about this online industry that reflects the capabilities of the machines on which all of it exists. The web browsers offer the user only a small portion of the computer's advanced technologies. The technologies are in raw pieces for the programmer ever since Flash was removed. This is the technical obstacle.

Websites Now Make Computers Behave Like Jukeboxes for Audio and Video

After the Internet turned into a medium for consumption of live information in the 2010s, the web browsers became less oriented toward performing tasks commensurate with what they can provide on the software and hardware side; they became vehicles for text, still images, and video. Absent completely is programmatic, multimedia delivery. The information on social media is actually the live, collective expressions of millions of people all day, but confined to a certain website format of the audiovisual technologies of the past. The artificial limitations of this format are what make the Internet uncomfortable today, in many aspects.

Despite the enormous amount of talking and posting of video clips that takes place on these platforms, they are far from making adequate use of the interactive capabilities of computers, as it is code that should be allowed to be uploaded inside a post. It is as if technology went backwards, and in fact it basically did compared to the goals and the environment of the 1990s. Social media companies are not providing anything near a varied multimedia experience, and because they are using computers that can, people feel uneasy about the websites.

What makes the desktop computer a unique device is that it carries a range of functionality more capable in terms of setting up programs than the previous technologies that were not digital. Earlier machines are just for playback of recorded productions. The computer can play back audio or video on demand, making it act just like a physical jukebox for audio or video. That isn't enough. Instead, audio and video can be programmed into larger, dynamic arrangements, to provided interactive, multimedia experiences, as was the goal. This is altogether missing on the larger Internet even though high speed Internet connections are more common.

Macromedia Flash Transitioned the World to the Web from CD-ROMS

Just before the web became widely available, multimedia was the focus of CD-ROMs. But due to the way the web browser existed, shortly after CD-ROMS appeared, it became harder to transmit the same level of multimedia interactivity over the Internet. The web browser plug-in that changed that in the late 1990s was called Flash. The key issue is that web browsers were never built initially with multimedia capabilities, and that did not happen later by the standards organization that oversees web browser functionality, despite various committees. Flash provided the web browser genuine multimedia capabilities, being the successor to the software system that made a large portion of CD-ROM multimedia titles. Flash existed alongside another (competing) technology called Java applets, which were mini software applications running inside a web page. Without those two technologies, the web browser could mostly just load pages of text and pictures like regular print media. But because neither software format is available for a web page today-- neither an embeddable file format like Flash nor an embeddable application like Java applets is allowed by the official web standards-- the web has tended towards conventional uses of video, audio: playback and consumption. This is a major cause in why people use social media the way that they do. If a new standardized, uploadable format that is like Flash files is available, this will improve the web a great deal. The multimedia has to exist in an encapsulated format; it cannot be uploaded as a set of disconnected files, nor can it be subject to the wide array of security restrictions imposed by web browsers.

Although there are many software applications that can produce multimedia for the web like the past, with Adobe's Animate application officially replacing Flash, this isn't the same as a completely self-contained format that is universally recognized, which is what Flash and Java applets each provided. It has to be that a person uploads a single file and it is just executed.

How the web browser exists technically isn't the same setup as that time period. In both cases, Java applets and Flash files, the files had their contents consolidated into standard formats, and they were usually just individual files. This does not really exist today. It fostered a different dynamic in the social environment of the web. It cannot be that the multimedia that is uploaded is separated into different files made out of JavaScript; this won't work.

Adobe Flash Had Better Tools for The Interactive Side of The Web

In the past, Adobe Flash was able to provide a more interactive and engaging experience for web users because of the ease it provided the web developers who chose to take it up, which was not everyone. The most important benefit on the development side of Flash was that it was very integrated and had a dedicated editor system, which does not exist to this day for web pages because they don't work the same way as the Flash system. One downside of Flash was that it was proprietary, and it required purchasing a software license from a specific company, which went against the philosophical underpinnings of the web browsers. This is one cause of opposition to it, because it sat outside of the web pages that loaded it and did not allow its contents to be openly examined by the web page. But it had a lot of benefits that a plain web browser cannot provide today. And it has a development system that is superior to what is available for making web pages today. A Flash file can actually compile with third-party plug-ins that run code.

Flash began in the 1990s as a browser plug-in for Netscape. Because it filled a void in the features of a web browser that had no multimedia in it, it became a popular web-based system that allowed people to create a wide range of interactive content. Games, animations, and other multimedia experiences were nearly all dependent on it until the 2010s. Advertising firms used it frequently for corporate clients' websites and it made the experience of visiting their websites a fun activity, even though it was just advertising a product.

The reason Flash was used frequently by these firms was that it had an integrated web software development environment, which has not existed since it was abandoned. The supposed successor to Flash, HTML5 and JavaScript, does not have a standardized development environment.

Flash fell out of favor starting around 2009 due to a number of factors, with the security concerns being cited most often. But actually, there were also other reasons it was criticized by those who were not part of the Flash community. They are most often people who are concerned with how web pages load inside a browser programmatically and not how the general public wants to use a web browser. The rise of other web technologies that have been labeled more advanced or modern is not necessarily the case, given that they require much more labor to produce the same result as Adobe Flash. In fact, it looked as though the supposed replacement for Flash, HTML5, was made by people who had never even used Flash at all, and this probably the case given how they were saying it was so much better but it had maybe one fourth of the features and none of the conveniences. It looks as though the people behind HTML5 just hated the presence of a Flash embeds on the page and stopped there without looking further into the situation, then came up with what they thought it was better. But what they provided was actually a scattered mess and overall incomplete.

By 2009, Flash had already been developed for 12 years, by more than one professional software company, meaning that it was developed in multiple aspects. It generally took less time to make Flash apps that were very complex compared to the software development setup of websites today called HTML5.

For interactive apps, an integrated software development environment is important. And this is a cause for why social media websites are so limited to the playback of streaming video and commentary: there simply aren't adequate tools available for these websites to help them go beyond what they have been for the last decade, because no open standard, no equivalent of Flash or Java applets was made afterwards. There are also no individuals out there who advocate or even seem to recognize the issue who work at the official standards organizations.

Consequently, many of the interactive experiences that were once possible with Flash are no longer available on the web. Because they make use of HTML5 and JavaScript, the experience is actually not as smooth, in part because HTML5 and JavaScript carry extra processing overhead. This, as a situation, would then have to be regarded as less advanced, a step backwards even. Because the structure of JavaScript and HTML5 is not proper engineering design, it has created large numbers of JavaScript libraries that actually do things that were easily done in Flash. Many JavaScript libraries exist independent of one another that accomplish the same goals. People have to know a lot more code today to achieve the same outcomes as the 2000s.

It is all a shame, as the interactive capabilities of computers are an important part of what makes them such powerful tools for the web and multimedia, and the many years of the 1980s and 1990s, when people wanted them to be that for a global Internet are now overtaken by social media chatter: a web centered around news media, an Internet that is completely devoted to daily, mass expression of sentiment over political and social affairs. It is as if the computer has been misconfigured for the world, isolated to a small section of what it contains. By making better use of these computer capabilities, social media platforms could provide a more engaging and beneficial experience for users and lead them away from overindulgence of reacting negatively to events.

For example, social media platforms could allow users to create and share interactive games, animations, and other multimedia content. This could be done if a modern web technology were recognized by all browsers that is not the existing HTML5 and JavaScript. It would have to provide an encapsulated file format that requires very little to upload and embed in a page. Flash was an integrated system that had plug-ins, a timeline, a scripting language called ActiveScript, all of which worked together at the same time. This is what has to happen, basically, and when it does these websites will be very different and improved all around.

Conclusion

The fragmentation of HTML5 and JavaScript, particularly how restrictive browsers are with respect to how they are used and that there is not an agreed upon format for a distributable interactive file, as there was with Flash, means that the web is nowhere near as engaging as it was in the 2000s.

The web has lots of video. It has live streaming of people doing things. It has lots of news feeds. But it isn't very pleasant.

When a universally recognized file format is available, whatever experience people have of the web can exist social media services themselves implementing all of the features for the users, meaning that users do not have to wait for a feature to show up. It can be embedded like a Flash file once was.

What is important to start is to have a comprehensive and unified file format that exists for the purpose of distributing interactive or multimedia experiences-- it was .SWF for Flash just like .PDF is a document.

By incorporating more interactive features and content, social media platforms will provide a more satisfying and enjoyable experience for their users, particularly those who are not interested exclusively in the broadcast of opinions and news feeds on a daily basis.

item.title: Injection Molding: A Source of Many Products in Our Environment
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Injection molding is a manufacturing process that involves injecting molten material into a mold to produce a desired shape. This process is widely used in various industries, including automotive, and electronics. Injection molding is capable of producing parts with high precision and detail, making it a popular choice for manufacturing a wide range of products.

A mold and an injection mold are related, but the injection mold is named as such because it has various slots in the mold where the material is injected from the outside, instead of being poured in like a regular mold. This type of mold is a factory process and the requirements for the mold are higher. For a mold there is the original object, it is cast with a material that can hold what will be the substance of the copies, and then the mold is split in two so that it can be put together for the casting process. A mold can be done in a variety of ways at home, with a variety of materials. When it gets to be high-grade, it can become this kind of mold, which is designed for high quantity manufacturing.

A YouTube channel owner who is experienced in manufacturing demonstrates making an injection mold for a plastic spoon.

Some manufacturing processes do not involve making molds but instead make use of machines, routers that drill out the material of the base, through computer-controlled devices. Routers are used when cuts on the material are lying on a flat surface, such as drilling out slots from a sheet of wood for where buttons will go. There are also metal forming machines that take a flat sheet of metal and then bend it around, such as to make a large container box. This applies to all kinds of appliances, from a dryer to a box that sits behind a building for electrical purposes. That type of product that would not be made with a mold because the wall of the box is made out of thinner metal. So what that shows is that certain manufacturing processes work for different scenarios, though different processes could be used to make the same object.

If it has been manufactured and it is made out of plastic, at some point there was likely a mold made for it. But what does the mold look like? For a lawn chair, there is the following video, among many online.

These chairs are designed to be lightweight and easy to move. Injection molding allows manufacturers to create chairs with complex shapes and features. They are an example of a one-shot process that produces a larger object.

Another common product made using injection molding is the sole of a shoe. The soles of shoes are typically made of rubber or plastic, and injection molding allows manufacturers to create soles with intricate designs and patterns that leave an impression on the ground. Injection molding also allows for the creation of soles with different levels of flexibility and durability, depending on the material use for the mold. So different materials can be placed into an injection mold.

item.title: Push Pin Magnets for The Refrigerator Provide Instant Organization of Life's Paperwork
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Push pin magnets are a versatile and convenient organizing tool to have in your home, especially for the paperwork that comes in and can't be dealt with right away or it has to be placed there for later processing. They are especially useful for hanging notes and reminders on the refrigerator or any other metal surface in your house. The shape of the push pins is better than regular refrigerator magnets.

If you ever have used magnets for the refrigerator, you know that you have to often use your fingernails to get them off the fridge. Push pin magnets address this problem because they have a handle. They turn the refrigerator into a real organizing space.

Some of the push pin magnets sold are specifically stronger than others. The standard ones are cheaper, and you get can a lot more of them for the same price. It depends on which strength you need, but if you want the paper to stay there for sure, specifically seek out the stronger kind. The lighter ones are usually made of transparent plastic.

There is something about the push pins that distinguishes them from other sorts of refrigerator magnets because they are not too large and they act a lot like the push pins for a regular, cork bulletin board.

item.title: Projection Mapping: What It Is And How to Get Into It
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Projection mapping, also known as video mapping, is a technology used to turn objects into a display surface for video projection. This technique can be used to add an extra layer of dimension and visual interest to events, buildings, and objects.

The video by an Austrialian digital signage company called Prendi below provides a concise explanation.

Equipment

First, you'll need to put together a projection setup. This typically consists of a projector, a computer, and some kind of media player software. The projector should have a high brightness and resolution, and be capable of projecting onto the surface you plan to use. The computer and media player software will be used to control the content that is projected.

Next, you'll need to create your projection mapping content. This can be done using specialized software, such as MadMapper or Resolume Arena. These programs allow you to create and manipulate your video content, and map it onto the surface you plan to project onto.

Once you have your content and projection system set up, it's time to set up the physical space. This will involve positioning the projector and ensuring that it is properly aligned with the surface you plan to project onto. You may need to experiment with different distances and angles to get the best result.

Once everything is in place, you can start your projection mapping by playing your video content through the media player software. As the video is projected, it will be mapped onto the surface you have chosen, creating the illusion of a dynamic, interactive display. In the case it is set up to create the illusion of 3D objects, the projected images will be correspondingly warped by the software to sit on the surfaces of the blank physical surfaces. This is a major role that the specialized projection mapping software plays.

Projection mapping can add an extra layer of engagement to any event or environment. With the right equipment and software, and a little bit of experimentation, you can create visuals that will please your audience.

Software for Projection Mapping

There are several software options available for creating and controlling projection mapping content. One popular option, just mentioned, is MadMapper, which is a professional-grade tool that allows users to create, manipulate, and map video content onto any surface. It offers a range of features, including support for multiple projectors, the ability to warp and blend images, and real-time video input.

Another option is Resolume Arena, which is a versatile media server and visualizer. It offers a range of features for creating and manipulating projection mapping content, including support for multiple layers, effects, and real-time video input. It also offers a range of options for controlling the content, including MIDI, DMX, and OSC protocols.

These are just a couple of examples of the many software options available for projection mapping. Other options include Modul8, VDMX, and ArKaos GrandVJ.

item.title: Cycling '74's Max Software: Interfacing with MIDI Devices For Music and Live Performance Situations
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Cycling '74's Max is live multimedia software used by installation artists, musicians, and designers to create interactive projects. It is a visual programming language that allows users to create complex programmatic systems by connecting graphical objects, called "objects," with virtual patch cords.

Max was first developed in the late 1980s by Miller Puckette at the Paris-based IRCAM institute for musical research. Puckette now holds a position at the University of California in San Diego. His app was initially designed to be a modular synthesizer, but Puckette decided to open up the software to be used for a wide range of applications, from sound and music composition to video and animation.

In recent years, modular synthesizers have become of interest again among electronic musicians because of the customizable output they can produce.

Uses of Max

One of the main uses of Max is in live installations, such as interactive art exhibits or musical performances. The software's ability to synchronize with external devices, such as MIDI controllers and audio interfaces, provides it the technological conditions to be controlled in real time.

For example, an installation or live performance designer could use Max to create an interactive display that responds to the movements of visitors. The artist could use sensors, such as motion detectors or cameras, to track the visitors' movements and use this data to control the behavior of various elements in the installation, such as lights, sounds, or projections.

Modular "Nodes"

One of the key features of Max is its flexibility and modularity. Users can create their own objects, or use pre-made ones, to build complex systems. These objects can represent anything from simple mathematical operations to more complex processes, such as audio analysis or live video processing. Thus, what is happening can be plotted out but not played as if pressing play on a tape recorder. Many settings of the live installation can be controlled during a performance.

Max also includes a variety of built-in tools and features, such as a timeline and transport controls, which allow users to synchronize their projects with external devices, such as MIDI controllers and audio interfaces.

In addition to its technical capabilities, Max has an established community of users and developers who share resources through online forums.

As the years have passed, it has grown its offering of tools and features.

item.title: Assembling an Arcade Game Cabinet from a Kit
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
The purpose of an arcade cabinet was to make a video game playable for any patron of the establishment. Around the 1980s and 1990s, video game enthusiasts' interest in arcade systems remained for a few reasons. First, they were more powerful than the home systems and their onscreen graphics looked nicer. Second, they provided full-sized controls compared to the hand-held controllers of home systems. So, video game hobbyists would still go to the arcade and play video games while also owning a home video game system. For a time, it was considered something very unusual to own an arcade cabinet at home because it took up lots of room and it was also expensive for most people to buy one. Most of the time, if you heard of one being owned by someone at home, it was because you saw on a television program about how a certain famous person was living with lots of accessories. In the late 1990s, software emulation of the arcade games became possible and you could play hundreds of arcade games on your home computer.

Because of this, it is possible to get an arcade cabinet today that carries a lot of games on it, not just one, and the controls are the same kind any arcade cabinet from the past with joystick and buttons. Here are some reasons someone would like to own an arcade cabinet built from a kit.

  • provide a video game cabinet in your establishment for anyone to play.
  • exhibit a specific video game.

There are more people making indie video games than ever today, so that is a reason this article is being provided. With today's technology and the large variety of games available, what is placed on the machine does not have to be limited to retro games but instead can include the indie games that are made by software developers ranging from small companies to individual software developers. As long as the arcade controls of the machine are mapped to the game's controls itself, any kind of game is playable because it is a computer after all. In a way, it is just a hardened setup of joystick, computer, and computer screen combined with speakers, but the whole of the unit produces a different situation. In the past, the computer in the arcade machine just did one thing, which is drive the graphics and interaction for the single game placed on the board inside the machine.

For a custom arcade cabinet today, all of the parts have to be hooked up somehow: the computer that runs it has to be chosen ahead of time, the monitor has to match the cabinet enclosure, and there has to be a way to select the desired game from a menu list using the joystick and buttons. If all of this is assembled manually, that will take a lot of planning, as it has been done by many people over the last two decades. So, there are companies and open software projects (e.g. RetroPie) that have taken care of many aspects of putting together an arcade cabinet, to make it something that can be done in a short period. If you buy a kit, you get all of the needed components, so we are discussing that route in this article. Anything else amounts to an exercise for the most part, which is fine for those who want to do that and have the experience necessary. But it becomes apparent from videos that even building from a kit can take time. Searching for "arcade cabinet kit" on the web will get anyone finding many listings, but we will discuss what all of the options are. Some kits are just the boards that make the cabinet. Others include everything needed. Finally, some options are the fully built device.

The Arcade1Up Infinity Table

It's worth mentioning that some people might have a different motivation for owning a multi-game device, which is to have two or more people play board games at parties or with the family. For that, there is an option to look into, the company Arcade1Up's Infinity Table device, which is a 32" touchscreen running Android. It has its own collection of officially-licensed board games. This device was funded by backers on Kickstarter in 2021. Some people say that the cost of the device is a bit much at $900. There aren't that many large touchscreen devices available, including for games. In this case several of the games are conversions from what a person buys at the store (e.g. a Monopoly board game) but with the added benefit of animation, sound and touch interaction provided by a touchscreen computer. Reviewers sometimes have their goals and preferences; those with extra money will buy this kind of device if they think it can add value to their living environment. The upside of it is that there is no need to build anything and it is all included, just take it out of the box. And it is family-friendly. The games having a different set of goals than arcade video games, coming from the board game category. We included a YouTube channel owner's review video below for you to get a chance to look at the device.

Building an Arcade Cabinet Device

At dFork, we wanted to find solutions that weren't that complicated for making an arcade cabinet. The reason kits are emphasized is that doing an search on the topic brings up many articles and videos where people explain how they built arcade cabinets from scratch, sometimes using plans, using equipment and tools. That isn't always helpful because that takes a lot of time and access to equipment that many people don't have. To summarize, the best way to proceed on this if you just want to expend a moderate of effort is to buy a cabinet kit that has everything included with it and also includes the software designed for the purpose of navigating through the list of games.

The issue is that there are many options, so we are at least identifying where to start on this endeavor, which is to start with a kit. The kits will allow anything to be loaded in them that is a video game. You can search on the internet for the terms "bartop arcade kit" or "tabletop arcade kit".

It is still not cheap to buy an arcade cabinet and a full-sized one takes up a lot of room. It is expensive to ship, and it is quite involved to assemble a big, custom arcade cabinet without a kit.

Why Not Buy an Older Game?

There doesn't seem to be much advantage for buying one of the original arcade cabinets from the 1990s and 1980s. The older games in their original cabinets bring up the issue of maintenance, so unless you are experienced in electronics it would be better to own a modern, custom arcade cabinet system that is running off of the computers of today. For one, the screen that you install in the cabinet will be a lot lighter than the cathode ray tubes. The older games, when they are hosted in classic arcades, have to be maintained by knowledgeable employees who maintain them and replace the chips on the boards when they get too old. So all around, unless you really know what you want with that, or you have money to pay someone to repair them, it is best not to get into old hardware and instead buy a setup with new hardware. The new hardware loads whatever games you want on it.

In this article, the goal is to have a little bit of assembly work, on the level of furniture, with an intended audience of programmers. Building an arcade cabinet is a different set of skills than programming and working with computers, more along the lines of people who work in wood shops, carpentry, or people who are interested in those topics. So, the goal for the typical technology enthusiast, or a person who is not interested in dedicating a lot of time to the chore, would be able to acquire one of these cabinets by way of a kit.

Just working from the plans alone, the builder of the cabinet would have to have access to shop equipment available to cut the boards. You also will want some electronics experience if you do all of it from scratch. For this reason, we talk about kits here because electronics experience is not necessary.

A full-sized cabinet is a commitment in any living space and the end cost might be $900 to $2000, so another option is the tabletop arcade kits that serve as a kind of abbreviated version of the standing ones. It is also possible to just buy the stand that holds full-sized joysticks and buttons and then hook the game into a regular television.

It is feasible for a handy person to build a full-sized arcade cabinet just from a set of plans, and there are many such plans on the web, for all sorts of form factors for these cabinets. But the issue is whether the person has the background to actually spend time building from these plans. It is not a simple endeavor. It will be time-consuming for anyone who is not provided pre-made components for the cabinet and pre-assembled electronic kits.

There is a YouTube channel owner who was sponsored by an electronics store, which carries its own tabletop cabinet for retro games. From watching this a little bit, you can see that even with a tabletop cabinet there is some work to do.

If your video game arcade cabinet is placed in a public place, it can act as a kiosk for passersby to go up to it and play a custom game. The novelty of having one at home would wear off compared to being able to place one in a public place with a custom setup, a game that would normally not reside on this hardware.

As a small disclaimer, this article is not made by someone who has put together an actual arcade cabinet yet, but instead serves to provide research on the topic for your benefit, in case you are interested in finding resources as well.

item.title: Thymol-Based Cleaning Products Are Great for The House
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Thymol-based cleaning products are great for use in the home because they are effective at killing germs and bacteria, and they have a pleasant, natural scent. They also eliminate odors quite well if you spray a the cleaning product across the affected area.

Thymol is an organic compound that is derived from thyme oil, and it has been used for centuries as a natural disinfectant and antiseptic. In cleaning products, it is often combined with other natural ingredients, such as vinegar and essential oils, to create an effective and environmentally friendly cleaning solution.

One of the benefits of using thymol-based cleaning products is that they are safe for use around children and pets. Many commercial cleaning products contain harsh chemicals that can be harmful if ingested or inhaled, but thymol-based products are generally considered safe for use around children and pets.

Apart from this, you won't need to worry about the potential negative effects of harsh chemicals.

It's Better to Have Natural Cleaning Fragrances in Your House

Another benefit of thymol-based cleaning products is that they have a pleasant, natural scent. Many commercial cleaning products have strong, synthetic fragrances that can be overpowering and unpleasant, but thymol-based products have a refreshing, herbal scent that is much more pleasant to be around. This makes them a great choice for people who are sensitive to strong fragrances or who simply prefer a more natural, organic scent.

Overall, thymol-based cleaning products are a great choice for use in the home. They are safe, effective, and have a pleasant, natural scent, making them a great alternative to traditional commercial cleaning products. If you are looking for a natural and effective way to clean your home, consider using thymol-based cleaning products.

Thymol-Based Cleaning Wipes

If you keyboard needs cleaning, for example, thymol-based cleaning wipes are the way to go because they clean the surface with a natural cleaning agent, which means that what your hands touch afterwards will only be the thymol cleaning product. Often, cleaning wipes are made with harsh chemicals, but thymol-based ones clean surfaces very well too.

When you use natural cleaning products instead of harsh ones made out of conventional chemicals, your house does feel better overall. Any fumes from cleaning are not going to bother you.

item.title: TouchDesigner: A Node-Based Programming Multimedia Software Application
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
TouchDesigner is a professional-grade software application that is used for real-time visual design, performance, and so-called "creative coding". It is a powerful tool that is widely used in the entertainment, visual arts, and design industries, and it offers a range of features and capabilities that make it a helpful choice for a variety of projects.

A reason to use TouchDesigner is its modular design. The software is built around a node-based interface that allows users to easily create and customize their projects by connecting different nodes together. This makes it easy to experiment with different design approaches and quickly iterate on ideas.

For projects that require fast and accurate visualization of complex data sets, such as simulations, 3D graphics, and interactive installations, this can be of value. In addition to its technical capabilities, TouchDesigner also offers a wide range of possibilities for installation projects. It can be used to create interactive installations, immersive environments, and other digital projects that engage audiences and enhance the user experience.

Because it makes use of nodes, TouchDesigner is flexible and can be used in a variety of settings, from large-scale installations to small-scale projects. It is apparently compatible with a wide range of hardware and software platforms, making it easy to integrate into existing workflows and environments.

Like all software, there is a period of time required for learning the specific conventions and becoming familiar with the environment of the application.

item.title: The Beginning of Vector-Editing Programs in the 1980s, Starting with Xfig and Adobe Illustrator
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Before Adobe Illustrator was released in 1987, there was a vector-editing application released in 1985 for Sun Microsystems' computers, called Xfig. 1985 is rather early for a vector-editing program to come about for desktop computers, being only one year after the introduction of the Macintosh. But, in fact, hardly ever mentioned is that in 1984 MIT had begun work on what became the X Window System, which provided the foundation for graphical user interfaces (with windows and buttons) for Unix operating systems. This is how it was possible for a vector-editing program to predate a Macintosh version provided by Adobe in 1987.

Sun Microsystems, a different computer company (that developed Java in the 1990s), also featured a graphical user interface with its UNIX SunView system. This is the system on which Xfig was developed, according the limited accounts available on the web. Today, Xfig is open source, and it has been updated to the present day for Linux and other UNIX-like systems. It has not been officially ported to Windows and Mac.

Though Xfig was the earliest, with Adobe Illustrator coming a few years later, Adobe provided the field of vector graphics many of its core technology concepts that would make vector graphics, digital documents, complex page layout, and the printing of the onscreen graphics a feasible technological reality. The founders of Adobe, in particular, had careers in this field.

A very early demo of computer graphics resembling what is known now as vector-editing, was the 1963 machine called Sketchpad, put together by Ivan Sutherland. Sutherland left academia for a time to start his own computer companies that manufactured graphics software and hardware. Sutherland's business partner and fellow computer scientist, David Evans, was the academic advisor of John Warnock, who co-founded Adobe with Xerox PARC researcher Charles Geschke. So, the history of computer graphics has some links between the individuals involved, partly because many were recipients of the same government grants (ARPA) at the time that were established to drive science and technology, to match accomplishments of the USSR.

Charles Geschke recruited Warnock for Xerox PARC. It was in 1982 amidst increasing disappointment among researchers that the two decided to leave and form their own company, Adobe. As it happens, also, John Warnocks father was a traditional typesetter and when putting together font technologies, he would frequently go to his father to get feedback on the accuracy of his typography output. His wife, also, was a graphic artist, assisting in the construction of Adobe Illustrator. Many factors came together for vector graphics to become an established set of conventions on computers, from Warnock's working next to Ivan Sutherland to Charles Geschke being a member of the original 1970s Xerox PARC team.

When Adobe Illustrator was first released, it was not received as a person would today, as it was not a category of software the world was yet familiar with. In one talk, Warnock discusses how he was unsure how to promote this program at the time. The photo editing program Adobe Photoshop is actually a program that Adobe purchased in 1989 from University of Michigan computer science graduate John Knoll, who was working on the program with his brother. Knoll went on to become a special effects supervisor for Industrial Light and Magic and worked on the later Star Wars films. Geschke and Warnock purchased Knoll's program even though conditions in technology were not quite ready for photo editing in 1989. They anticipated that hard drive space and memory costs would go down and size would increase to the point that Photoshop would be of value for them in the future. In the 1990s, these two programs worked together, alongside the page layout programs that prepared pages for print, to provide print publications and magazines a different look.

It is because of Warnock and Gesche's PostScript technology that printable documents can be translated accurately from screen to printer and also transmitted across computer networks easily, especially with the PDF document introduced by Adobe in the 1990s. It contains PostScript code.

A biography of Warnock is perhaps best stated by himself in a 39 minute 2011 talk he gave at the Scientific Computing and Imaging Institute at the University of Utah. The University of Utah is a place where a large group of people taught or took classes in an era of early computing, from Alan Kay to Charles Geschke to John Warnock. Alan Kay and John Warnock graduated the same year from the university, in fact. Among the various individuals there is Ed Catmull, who co-founded Pixar and worked on 3D graphics technologies still in use today.

In the video below, Warnock discusses at the 11:34 mark how the University of Utah is a place where many people in the field of computer graphics and technology:

https://youtube.com/watch?v=T4rvd6EZnsc&t=694

Below, Warnock introduces Adobe Illustrator for the Macintosh in 1987.

In the video below, a promotional video from Adobe in the 1980s hypes up how much better its software can be for a graphic designer.
