item.title: Get Started Cooking by Learning to Make Rice. Three Different Heating Methods to Cook It.
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
dFork intends to teach you how to get started cooking in a slightly different way from other websites and the advice here comes from personal observations and discussions, to really get you going from zero, in a way that is consistent with all advice from expert food websites.

Often the authors of the online guides are expert cooks which means you want to read their articles accordingly, knowing that sometimes they assume knowledge you actually have to acquire through practice, over time. They probably got started in their craft early. Meanwhile, you may just want to know how to cook in your apartment or house where you live.

There has to be a starting point and we say it can be rice.

Rice

Cooking rice is the basic cooking skill that will open the door to the rest of cooking for a person, something you might not hear elsewhere but most cooks will likely appreciate. That is because there are many guides out there. So if you have not cooked before, this is a good place to start. You don't have to cut vegetables at the very beginning of getting into cooking if you do this.

The benefits of learning to cook rice go beyond just cooking rice by itself, because if you start to practice this one skill, it becomes the platform for getting into the rest of cooking. You can add more to the rice after you know how to cook it.

Once you are comfortable cooking rice, then you start to change your rice dishes up by incorporating other cooking skills over time, including more types of ingredients, to the point you can, at the end, realize how it all comes together.

Of course, cooking rice is found in many cuisine recipes. It can be used in a variety of dishes, from stir-fries and curries to salads and bowls. Thus, if you are just starting out in the kitchen, the first step dFork recommends is that you learn how to cook rice.

Heating Methods

Here dFork discusses cooking with 1) the stovetop, 2) rice cooker, and 3) pressure cooker.

  • you want to be able to cook rice on the stovetop because this is where regular cooking takes place.
  • but you might want to start out with a rice cooker because it is so easy and "foolproof".
  • yet, a pressure cooker is recommended if you plan to start cooking all the time because it lets you prepare a wide range of dishes in the same appliance, without always needing the stovetop and a pan or pot.

If you are worried about how things will go, as long as you follow the directions, the rice cooker is the easiest way to get started from the very beginning. Basic rice cooker models are inexpensive appliances and they have the same magnetic mechanism in them. They are also found in most stores where kitchen supplies and appliances are sold, like Target, Wal-mart, Amazon, etc.

If you get practiced with all three heating methods over time (stovetop, rice cooker, and pressure cooker), that is best because then you know how each situation works.

Which Rice to Use

There are two kinds of rice you can cook: brown rice and white rice, with brown rice basically being the healthier option of the two because it has not been processed and is what was found in the fields. White rice is white because it has been processed in a factory, it has been milled to remove the bran and the germ. Unless it is a health-food oriented restaurant, most restaurants are serving white rice. Of course, white rice turns brown when it is fried, so brown rice is not the same as the rice that was made brown from frying in fried rice dishes.

dFork recommends buying mostly brown rice for diet and healthy eating purposes, but that is because we teach cooking that way. It easier for maintaining a healthy weight range.

With respect to preparing the rice:

  • Brown rice generally requires more water and a longer cooking time, as the bran and germ need to be fully hydrated and softened.
  • White rice, on the other hand, cooks more quickly and requires less water.

Cooking The Rice

  1. Stovetop:

The stovetop is the set of burners on top of the oven. You place a pot over one of the burners and follow the directions below. When people cook, often the pot is open, without a lid. But you don't leave rice cooking in an open-aired pot because when rice is cooked is there is circulation of the moisture and some amount of pressure, to make the rice thick. To cook the rice, you use a pot with a tight-fitting lid. It doesn't have to feature an air hole like the model below. But if there isn't one, there will be some noise as the lid jiggles during cooking. There will be jiggling with the lid that has the hole, too, just not as much. Along with a pot, you will want a measuring cup, and a spoon or spatula, preferably a large wooden spoon.

Equipment for Cooking Rice on the Stovetop:

Instructions:

Instructions on how to cook any package of uncooked ingredients or legume are found on the back of the packaging and this is where you can start as well. If you read the back of the package, it will say something similar to what is below:

  • Generally you want to rinse rice at least a little before cooking it. You can rinse the rice in a fine-mesh strainer under cold water until the water runs clear. If you don't have a strainer, just rinse the rice in the pot by filling it up and emptying the water a few times. Rinsing the rice removes excess starch and dirt from the surface of the grains.
  • Measure the rice and water according to the package instructions or your preference. As a general rule, you will need about
    • For white rice: 1 1/2 cups of water for every cup of white rice
    • For brown rice: 2 cups of water for every cup of brown rice.
  • Place the rice and water in the pot and bring to a boil over high heat. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot with the lid, and simmer for the recommended cooking time.
  • Once the rice is cooked, turn off the heat and let it sit covered for an additional 5-10 minutes. This allows the rice to steam and absorb any remaining water.
  • Fluff the rice with a fork and serve.

  1. Rice cooker:

A rice cooker is a convenient appliance that automatically cooks rice. Once it is turned on, it cooks the rice and then shuts off automatically through the use of an internal mechanism that detects a temperature that matches when the rice is finished. That is how it can cook either brown rice or white rice without needing to be told what is in its. In either case, if the temperature reaches a certain level (and the water to rice ratio was right), the rice is finished and the cooker turns off.

To use a rice cooker:

  • Rinse the rice in a fine-mesh strainer under cold water until the water runs clear. If you don't have a strainer, you can also rinse repeatedly in a pot.
  • The measurement instructions are the same as for cooking rice over a pot. The cooker just automates the process of what would happen on a stovetop.
    • For white rice: 1 1/2 cups of water for every cup of white rice
    • For brown rice: 2 cups of water for every cup of brown rice.
  • Place the rice and water in the rice cooker pot and close the lid.
  • Press the "cook" button and let the rice cooker carry out its job.
  • Once the rice is cooked, the rice cooker will automatically switch to "keep warm" mode. This allows you to leave the rice covered in the rice cooker until you are ready to take it out.
  1. Pressure cooker:

A pressure cooker is a fast and efficient way to cook rice. It works by creating a seal and trapping steam inside the pot, which cooks the rice in a fraction of the time it would take on the stovetop. To cook rice in a pressure cooker, follow these steps:

  • Rinse the rice in a fine-mesh strainer under cold water until the water runs clear.
  • The measurement instructions are the same as for cooking rice over a pot.
    • For white rice: 1 1/2 cups of water for every cup of white rice
    • For brown rice: 2 cups of water for every cup of brown rice.
  • Place the rice and water in the pressure cooker pot and close the lid.
  • Set the pressure cooker to "high pressure" and cook for the recommended time. The "rice" button on a pressure cooker might actually be for white rice, so it is better to cook the rice under manual settings the first time.
  • Once the rice is cooked, you have the option to let the allow the pressure cooker release pressure naturally through its valve or manually release the pressure.
  • You can fluff the rice with a fork.

With a little practice, you'll be able to produce cooked rice every time.

What to Put on Top of the Rice

What can you add to the rice? For basics, you can get soy sauce for your first cooking.

Substitute Vegetable Broth for the Water

Substituting vegetable broth for water when cooking rice is a simple way to add flavor to your dish. Vegetable broth is a liquid made from simmered vegetables, herbs, and spices. You could make it yourself, but it takes hours, so people buy it. It is often used as a base for soups, stews, and sauces.

To substitute vegetable broth for water when cooking rice, simply use the same amount of broth as you would water. For example, if the recipe calls for 1 cup of water, use 1 cup of vegetable broth instead.

Using broth will add additional sodium (salt) to your dish, so depending on your dietary preferences you may want to choose a low-sodium variety. For example, if you are planning to add soy sauce, which has a lot of sodium in it, you would purchase the vegetable broth that has no sodium (salt) in it so that you can add your soy sauce later.

Using vegetable broth when cooking rice can add depth of flavor. You can also try using other types of broth, such as chicken or beef broth, for a different outcome.

Get a Food Container Set for Storing The Food

For storing food in the refrigerator, food containers are better to use than plastic wrap. You don't need to use plastic wrap to cover a bowl or plate if you have purchased a food container like the ones below, with an air-tight lid. Just look up "food container sets". You can find them at your local store that carries these products.

You have options for the material of these food containers, which is whether to get a plastic container, a hard plastic container, or glass containers with air-tight plastic lids. Some models have clasps whereas others just rely on the pressure of the plastic lid against the sides of the container.

Going Forward

After learning to cook rice, you can look up rice recipes that include complex ingredient combinations, including cut vegetables. That's it for this article.

item.title: Using a Password Book to Deal with the Barrage of Passwords and Usernames
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
There has to be a defense against the complexity of maintaining an inventory of passwords. The most important password is the one that opens up the physical computer. In this same level of importance is banking, the cloud storage passwords, email passwords. Anywhere that a purchase can be made automatically is a top tiered password level.

After that, dFork recommends making lower tiers: for some websites it does not matter if someone gets the login information, like a job application website for one submission of a resume. Pranksters might order some coffees in the cafe's app, but is it important? All of the individual job websites ask for passwords, and these are throwaway logins if the employer does not hire you, so why not make a single password for this lowest tier?

Other websites are very important and it matters more that they have a secure password or one that is different from the rest. So there has to be an examination of what the login is for, ranging from the very important, like utility bill websites and bank account websites, to the trivial signup of a website that you are just trying out. aren't sure whether you will ever use again but you think you could. Since every website requires separate sign-ups to use it.

It helps to have a central location to store all of this that is not also in a digital space, requiring its own password. One option is to use a physical password book.

A Much More Demanding Internet on The User

The technology environment, especially the Internet, has changed drastically since the 2000s. Unlike the 2000s, there are many more website sign-ups required, as there are many more services a person has to sign up for. Alongside this, there are increasing problems with cybersecurity: "phishing" (luring the person to give up login information), and the news of security breaches at all kinds of companies and organizations, where passwords and personal information has been stolen from large numbers of people. A consequence is that a burden has been placed on the Internet user with respect to passwords, both making sure they are secure and keeping track of a large number of them. Some websites simply require "two-factor authentication" because security is so bad.

Over time there has been a sense that there is a "right" way to manage lots of passwords, but this might just be a myth that developed over time. If a problem happens, people are quick to assign blame to the person, perhaps out of a strong desire to believe that bad things only happen because of choosing the wrong course of action or failing to implement the right practical strategy. Common sense wasn't followed or else this problem would not have happened, is this type of reaction. Certainly that can happen, but is it really common sense to make a new password for each website? Does it even make sense to keep track of dozens of passwords that are all different?

Perhaps there is an ideal for maintaining personal password security in this, one that satisfies all of the supposed experts' ideals. But at the moment, that ideal has to be regarded as separate from what is reasonable for a person to uphold, and that is the point of this article, to provide discussions about how to maintain a secure password strategy that is also manageable, with there being a balance. In practice, many pieces of advice don't seem to hold up for actual usage of computers. At some point in the future there would have to be a way to consistently use a physical keychain device. This appears to be a solution for the future, but the product category is not ready for the public and the offerings are confusing.

After not making the password guessable, the first recommendation circulated is, "don't ever re-use a password", but maybe reusing a password a few times for the less important websites is more in keeping with the situation. It is true that changing the password to something different each time is secure, but the real world does not feel like it allows that kind of strategy to work consistently and also allow normal use of computers. You wouldn't use the same password for all websites and devices because that password would be a skeleton key for all of your digital accounts. At the same time though, a lot of the suggestions to manage passwords seem dubious.

For example, when the Mac operating system suggests a very long and complex password that it can store on your behalf, there should be some hestitation as to whether this is the way to go. Regular computer users often use different operating systems, moving between different computing environments, and there has to be a way to record login information on paper sometimes. It's just a reality. Passwords may need to be shared with trusted individuals, in actual practice, and this will involve writing them down.

When the computer company simply says, "as long as you use our operating system you'll be very secure because we'll store it in software" this destabilizes what the user can find for password security, because it means that even the computer company is giving (self-serving) security advice that is not realistic for the technological environment. The web browser will store the password for you, but you might need to use a different one.

After this happens, what security advice should be seen as the way to go? Is the solution really to purchase additional software that maintains the passwords?

This then leads to the situation of keeping a password book.

Keeping a Password Book

To some, a password book seems silly in the face of the security recommendations about how to keep passwords and logins secure. If someone gets the password book, they get everything. But that can also be true for actually sitting down at the machine: there are web browsers (designed by security-oriented software engineers) routinely asking if the person wants to save the username and password (and address information) for each website. They also attempt to store credit card information.

Over time, a large number of passwords, user names, and personal information accumulates inside the web browser. Everyone sort of knows, sort of feels, that all that it takes is someone opening up your web browser on that machine after you are logged into the OS, looking at the stored settings in the web browser, and then logging into all of the websites where you saved password information. If someone got hold of the computer's login and took remote control of it, they can do that immediately, which is a strategy some scammers have. In that case, all they need is one password: your login for the computer or the login for remote control of it.

The web browser becomes vulnerable after all of this complex password-making. After all of the contortions of making different passwords, they can just open up the web browser and log into your websites.

If, on the other hand, the most important passwords are written down and not stored inside the machine, this is mostly secure, as no one can get to them even if they hack the machine.

Why Use a Physical Password Book

Depending on the situation, a password book could be more secure than storing passwords on the computer or in an online password manager. A password book isn't something that gets hacked. But also, a password book allows you to stay organized. Many password books are laid out alphabetically. You can choose which a system to organize your passwords, such as by category or alphabetically.

What is important, though, is that a password book does not tell you what is inside it in a table of contents unless you maintain that or put tabs in the password book. This is something experienced firsthand, that you don't know what passwords are in the book necessarily unless you are dedicated to putting all of them in there. If you put all of them in there and keep it consistent, there is no problem. If on the other hand you store some in the web browser and others in the password book you will have a problem because you will wonder where the login information is located. So this is important, that as soon as you make new login information you consistently put it in the password book. It can still exist in the web browser to be autofilled at the same time, but it always has to be in the password book.

As long as you keep your password book up to date, this is a way to handle the complexity of the digital environment that relies on many different user accounts and passwords. Removing old information can just involves placing a sheet of paper over the area and pasting it on top.

A Password Book Is Not Limited to Storing Passwords

This is a notebook where you can record your login information in a secure, organized manner, and it is necessarily immune to digital hacking, being a notebook. It allows you to have all of your passwords and usernames in one place, but you can include in it other important information that is not tied to websites, such as your company's tax identification numbers and serial numbers for software that you have purchased. If this is the route that you take, it can be very valuable.

Additionally, it helps to include names and phone numbers of repair services, like electrical, plumbing, heat and air, and appliance repair. You can also include the names and phone number of a few personal contacts. All of it allows you to continue living in the case there is some digital inconvenience.

How to Protect the Password Book

The password book is portable, but unless your life is primarily nomadic, it would likely reside in a secure or relatively hidden part of your house. If you leave the home for a long time, it would be placed in a safe or a safe box somewhere.

If you spend most of your time on the road, it would reside in your backpack. But in the case you carry it on your person on a daily basis, you would want to apply a cipher to all of the contents in advance, as described in the section below.

This is especially helpful if you use multiple devices or computers that are not running the same operating system.

You Can Use a Cipher for The Password Book

It is a good idea to take steps to protect your login information, especially if you are concerned about someone accessing your password book. One method to consider is offsetting the characters in your passwords by a position. This technique, also known as a Caesar cipher, involves shifting the letters in your password by a certain number of places in the alphabet or numeric sequence.

For example, if you offset your password characters by one position, "a" would become "b", "0" would become "1", and "2" would become "3". This simple change can make it more difficult for someone to guess or hack your password, since they would not know the exact characters used.

If the shift is 3, "a" would become "d", "b" would become "e", and so on. To decode a message encrypted with a Caesar cipher, you simply need to shift the letters back by the same number of places.

There are other ciphers you could use for a password that are more complex, but a Caeser cipher will allow you to decode the message more quickly. If you use a complex one, it will be harder to make use of the password book except as a last resort.

Whether to Use a Password Book or Not Depends on The Individual

In this discussion, we have exposed that the issue of storing and retrieving passwords is more complex than common advice allows and it also depends heavily on the person's own situation. If the person stays primarily close to home, then a password book will work. If the person is traveling frequently, it can work as well but security measures would have to be taken and a backup copy of the book would need to be made for the most important passwords.

item.title: Keeping a Box of Borax around the House Because It Has Many Uses
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Borax, also known as sodium tetraborate, is often a useful substance to have around the house. Here are a few of the many uses for borax:

  1. Cleaning: Borax is a natural cleaning agent that is effective at removing dirt, stains, and odors. It can be used to clean a variety of surfaces, including floors, counters, and tiles. It is also a good choice for people who are sensitive to harsh chemicals, as it is non-toxic and biodegradable.
  2. Laundry: Borax can be used as a natural laundry booster, helping to brighten and whiten clothes. It can also be used to remove stains and deodorize laundry.
  3. Pest control: Borax can be used as a natural pest control solution. It is effective at killing ants, roaches, and other insects.
  4. Gardening: Borax can be used to improve the health of plants. It can be used as a natural fertilizer, helping to improve soil structure and increase the availability of nutrients to plants.

Take time to look up the various uses on your own on the web, as many people have made lists.

Ronald Reagan was once a spokesman for a Borax-based product called Boraxo:

The famous twenty mule borax team from Death Valley California

A great example of page design and published in the year 1900: The famous twenty mule borax team from Death Valley California

From the National Archives [Link]

item.title: The Multimedia "Multipurpose Toolkit:" VVVV
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
VVVV is a visual programming language and environment for creating interactive media and graphics. It is often used in fields such as audiovisual performances, interactive installations, and VJing (video jockeying).

The software began in 2001 by a group in Germany and in 2021 decided to make a complete rewrite of the code. Both the old version and the newer version are exclusive to the Windows platform.

One of the features of VVVV is its use of a "patching" interface, where users can connect nodes to create visual programs. These nodes represent functions, values, and other data, and can be easily rearranged and modified to change the behavior of the program.

VVVV also includes a variety of built-in libraries and plugins for tasks such as 3D rendering, audio processing, and network communication. This makes it a tool for creating complex, interactive projects.

In addition to its technical capabilities, VVVV has a community of users and developers who share resources and tutorials.

item.title: The Linotype Machine
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
The Linotype machine was a major printing device that changed the way that newspapers and other printed materials were produced for the time. It was invented by Ottmar Mergenthaler in the late 1800s and quickly became the standard for printing houses around the world.

The Linotype machine worked by casting entire lines of type at once, rather than the traditional method of setting each individual letter by hand. This not only saved time and labor, but also allowed for the creation of more complex and sophisticated layouts, with multiple columns and even images. It even had the ability to mechanically justify a line of type.

 

The video below explains how the machine works (but it is not part of the film in the title of this article). The explanation begins at 1:43.

In the example below, three lines of type are lined up in the manual way to set type (before the Linotype machine came about).

 

To operate the Linotype machine, the operator would first select the desired font and size of the type. They would then input the text to be printed by typing it onto a keyboard, which would automatically cast the corresponding letters and spaces in a line of type. The line of type was then placed into a mold and melted lead was poured over it, creating a solid, metal block of type. This block, known as a "slug," could then be used to print multiple copies of the same text.

The Linotype machine was not without its drawbacks, however. It required a skilled operator and was expensive to maintain. It was also relatively slow compared to modern printing methods, and the lead slugs it produced were heavy and difficult to handle. Nevertheless, the Linotype machine played a crucial role in the development of modern printing and mass communication, and it remains an important part of printing history.

A Film about The Linotype Machine

A documentarian Doug Wilson funded a film about the Linotype machine on Kickstarter in 2012, Linotype: The Film. The trailer is shown below and the film can be accessed on various streaming services, including some that film for free, including Tubi and Roku.

Watch "Linotype: The Film" (on Tubi):

https://tubitv.com/movies/569684/linotype-the-film-in-search-of-the-eighth-wonder-of-the-world

Trailer:

To operate the Linotype machine, the operator would first select the desired font and size of the type. They would then input the text to be printed by typing it onto a keyboard, which would automatically cast the corresponding letters and spaces in a line of type. The line of type was then placed into a mold and melted lead was poured over it, creating a solid, metal block of type. This block, known as a "slug," could then be used to print multiple copies of the same text.

The Linotype machine was not without its drawbacks, however. It required a skilled operator and was expensive to maintain. Of course, it is relatively slow compared to modern printing methods. The lead slugs it produced were heavy and difficult to handle. Nevertheless, the Linotype machine played a very important role in the development of modern printing and mass communication, and it remains an important part of printing history.

 

A major difference of computer typography is that a final design takes place before printing, and when it is in this final stage it can still be modified. Meanwhile, with traditional typesetting processes, the final design stage takes when the type is laid out with metal. The two take place together, at the same time in that there isn't as much flexibility to make modifications.

item.title: Traditional Printing, The Letterpress
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
The terms "font," "italic," and "font family" all come from the world of traditional typesetting, but today they are most commonly used in everyday life within computer typography, exclusively for the overwhelming majority of people.

In traditional typesetting, a font was a specific set of type characters that were cast from metal or wood. These type characters, or "fonts," were used to print texts on a printing press. Each font was designed with a specific style, such as serif or sans-serif, and could be modified with attributes like bold or italic.

The term "italic" refers to a style of typeface that slopes to the right and is often used to emphasize certain words or phrases. In traditional typesetting, italic type was produced by casting a separate set of type characters that were slanted to the right.

A film called "Pressing On: The Letterpress Film" deals with the topic of traditional printing processes, the appeal they have to many people today. It was funded in 2015 on Kickstarter. It is now available for streaming on various services, including on Tubi for free.

There is a clip below of a woman who had been trained in modern graphic design on computers but found the experience of traditional type to be very different.

A clip not part of the Letterpress film was found on Vimeo below and it provides a short set of

nt.

Many terms from traditional type and letterpressing are still used in the context of computer typography, but they have taken on new meanings. Fonts are now digital files that are installed on a computer and used to display text on a screen or in print; their existence is separated from the act of printing because what will be printed is viewed in advance and can be manipuated.

The term "italic" is still used to refer to a slanted typeface, but it can now be easily applied to any font using computer software. And font families can include a wide range of styles and variations, from thin to extra bold and from condensed to expanded.

Despite the evolution of these terms in the digital age, it's important to remember their origins in traditional typesetting. Understanding the history of these terms can help us be informed of the limitations of current computer user interfaces, how some of the nostalgia for old typesetting processes comes from problems brought about by user interfaces in software today.

item.title: e-Ink Readers. Why People Like Them, The Display Technology.
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
There are several advantages to using an e-ink reader. If you do not own one or have not looked into the technology, the first thing to know is that the screen technology used in e-ink readers is totally different from that on other devices like the iPhone, with the most prominent aspect being the screen refresh rate is extremely low and suitable mostly for reading and taking notes. It is intended to mimic the look of traditional ink on paper, which is much better for reading.. The e-Ink looks better for print uses than LED displays found on a smartphone or tablet computer.

The underlying technology was developed in the 1990s, called E-ink. Short for electronic ink, it is a type of display technology that can be found also in smart watches, and other wearables. Lately it can be found on price tags in stores, such as at Best Buy, so that prices can be updated remotely to reflect the computer inventory of the store. E-Ink in the display is made up of tiny particles of pigment suspended in a liquid medium. So, this is different from the LED displays, which are microscopic LED lights lit up to produce an overall image. Any lighting comes from a secondary source built into the device afterwards and is not part of the display technology called e-Ink.

To begin with, e-Ink displays have been black and white because the e-Ink particles of pigment are charged with either a positive or negative charge. They are moved around within the liquid medium using electrical charges. By manipulating the charges on the particles, the display can create the appearance of different shades. In recent years there have been some color displays and over the years the screen refresh rate has been improved. Additionally, the technical need to refresh the display so as to clear out the e-Ink particles on every page turn, has been reduced.

The Different e-Ink Readers

The ebooks come in different formats, but PDF is usually not the one. PDF was at its inception meant for stationary, print layouts, meaning that if the page set was for A4 or letter format, the contents of the pages would not be "reflowable" for a small computer display, meaning that the contents would have to be shrunk down or viewed within a small frame of the overall document format. Thus, an ebook file exists because it natively supports text layouts that are reflowable, similar to how making a web browser window small rearranges the contents to fit the size of the frame of the window. Since PDF does not natively support this (though Adobe has been working on AI methods to recognize text and reflow it), you need to download documents in an ebook format if you do not have an e-Ink display that is full-size, which would mean close to the size of the original document. That is, most e-Ink readers are only a small portion of an A4 or letter paper document, but you would want to buy an e-Ink reader the size of a letter document if that is the kind of PDF you would be viewing. Since most ebooks are published in an ebook format, this unnecessary for most people. Additionally, at the current time, full-sized e-Ink readers that approach the size of an A4 piece of paper cost several hundred dollars. They are not necessary for reading books and other materials when the ebook file format with reflowable text is used.

But there are different file formats. Amazon uses its proprietary MOBI ebook format for reflowable text, whereas the standard is called EPUB and this is used by nearly all devices that are not Amazon. It's also important to note that Amazon's Kindle line of e-ink readers does not even support the EPUB format at all, which means that EPUB has to be converted through a roundabout process. EPUB is an open standard for digital books that is supported by many other e-reader devices and software applications, including Apple's iPad books reader and other software.

If you're interested in purchasing an e-reader and you want the ability to read EPUB files, there are a number of options available from different manufacturers, including the Kobo and Nook lines of e-readers, which both support EPUB. The Nook is sold at Barnes and Noble stores and is owned by Barnes and Noble. Kobo is owned by a Japanese company called Rakuten. They each have their own online stores. An advantage of buying an Amazon reader is of course how it links into your Amazon account and the whole online store of ebooks maintained by Amazon, but there is greater flexibility provided to you if you buying an alternative device.

A general purpose reader that supports EPUB is the Kobo Libra 2 (2021), by Rakuten, and this is just a recommendation on account of having used it. The advantage of the Kobo Libra 2 is that it does have two physical buttons. Some readers do not have buttons at all which means that to turn the page you touch the screen. The Libra 2 has two page-turning buttons.

Get a Fintie Case (or Other Brand) for The Reader

You don't just want to carry around the bare device, and likely the cover that comes in the box won't feel sufficient to stand up over time. A popular brand for third-party covers for eReaders (and other devices) is called Fintie. Their cover for the Kobo Libra 2 is very helpful and fits the device specifically. This kind of sturdy cover provides real protection for the device and is better for carrying it and placing it in bags. Rakuten also has a premium cover for the Kobo Libra 2 that it sells and it may work fine too. Regardless of the brand of e-Ink reader device that you buy, getting a cover is important for keeping the device protected.

There Are Many High-End eReader Devices

The number of e-book reader devices available can be overwhelming if you are looking beyond the typical offerings from Barnes and Noble (the Nook) or Rakuten's Libra. For a website that regularly reviews recent e-book reader devices, Good e-Reader.

On that website you can get information about the cutting edge devices that have color in them, come with a stylus for writing notes. Many of the higher-end e-readers run Android and can install apps found in a phone or tablet computer. Below is one example, a model from the Onyx Boox series. These devices, especially the color ones, can be popular for readers of comic books, because they show the comic images in a way similar to print publications.

item.title: Parametric Design and Parametric Architecture: A Fading Trend in Need of Revival and Programmatic Updates
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Emerging in the mid-to-late 2000, and then over the next decade gradually losing popularity among designers and architects, parametric design and parametric architecture are approaches to designs of buildings and other built forms by using computer algorithms and software, which generate and manipulate the core design elements. Parametric of course indicates the manipulation of parameters, with adjustment of parameters being the main activity after they have been established in the programming environment. The addition of programmatic elements determines what the three-dimensional models look like and how they are generated. They may, for example, change slightly the repeated element with each instance that it is being generated.

Parametric design software allows for a specific style of computational customization for shaping the designs. The computer being the driver of the outcomes principally, and then the designer or architect making use of that software in a scripting or node-based programming way, the software provides, within its constraints shaped by today's 3D software conventions, the ability to "iterate" (a common term in modern design discussions) on different design outcomes within the software.

The first well-known architecture firm to make public use of this was the famous "starchitect" Zaha Hadid, who died in 2016. And, perhaps because of the cultural heritage of geometric designs in Arab architecture and design, parametric design has retained appeal in the Arab world and this is where some complete online courses on the subject can be found.

Unfortunately, this specialized field of architecture and design has been relegated to something like a fad, though not totally. For one, once anyone knows how to do it the outcomes look similar to other designers, indicating that parametric architecture actually has a limited aesthetic range despite being flexible programmatically at a small level of the design. Also, the designs can be very ostentatious while also often unaesthetic, making them objectionable to the public. Being defined in very strong ways by the software that drives it, the field of parametric design can only be improved if re-examined by a combination of programming and architectural design principles that draw from the past predating modern times.

Improving the area of parametric design is actually going to be a job of programmers informed by traditional methods, and not modern architecture experts and designers alone, as the outcomes tend to look the same, being a general byproduct of what programming languages will produce when made use of at a higher level of abstraction through the use of nodes, in node-based programming. In combination with these software programming environments, the form, or morphology of plants and other microscopic patterns is often incorporated into the designs manually by the designers. The exteriors of many buildings will resemble cellular structures, for example.

Probably the most popular software tool for parametric design has been Grasshopper, which is a visual programming platform that runs within the 3D modeling software Rhinoceros. With Grasshopper, designers can create algorithms and rules to define and manipulate various design elements, such as shapes, patterns, and materials.

On the side of actual construction and not design alone, parametric design for a building may take into account factors such as site conditions, zoning regulations, and energy efficiency. The design can then be adjusted and optimized based on these factors, without the need to start the design process from scratch. However, that is not what it is primarily known for.

A parametric design for a building facade may allow for affixing custom pattern or texture that would not be normally attained without a computer running algorithmic programs.

Parametric design and architecture also have their building requirements. Anything that is designed also has to be built, and when the designs are complex and unusual this means that there will be engineering considerations so that the buildings are strong and resilient like any other built structure.

item.title: The USPS Makes Use of Artificial Intelligence, Relying On It for Sorting High Quantities of Mail
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
The topic of machine learning within artificial intelligence has gained interest in the last several years, taking off in 2023 with OpenAI's public tools. But it might come as a surprise that for a long time the U.S. postal service has been making use of machine learning. The postal service relies on artificial intelligence for recognition of addresses on letters and postcards. In a session from a conference about artificial intelligence called Ai4 Conference, there is a video featuring Greg Crabb, Vice President and Chief Information Security Officer at the U.S. Postal Service. He explains briefly:

"The postal service was one of the early pioneers in the use of artificial intelligence, specifically optical character reading and handwriting recognition-- in order to be able to move mail efficiently... you can't deliver mail, all those pieces of paper, without using artificial intelligence.

A sorting system made specifically for the postal service, called the Advanced Facer Canceller System, was originally an electromechanical system first installed in 1992. A Facebook post made by the U.S. Postal Service in 2010 indicated that there was a newer system installed that year. The system is described in the video below at the 2:45 mark.

The government is often an early adopter or initiator of technologies, with the Census Bureau once attempting to create a system in partnership with the two main founders of of the first electronic computer, the ENIAC. Government bureaus frequently process enormous volumes of information, sometimes more than what is needed by the private sector, precisely because they serve most of the population. That is, sometimes the government's audience is everyone, whereas any business is only a small portion, even if it is very large.

Since 2010, machine learning has become an increasingly well-known topic in popular technology, especially as computers sped up to the point they could handle it, and programming libraries were introduced that made artificial intelligence mainstream among programmers. As it happens, handwriting recognition is something now available in introductory courses on the topic of machine learning. It takes place by "training" the machine learning algorithm in various provided cases of letters and numbers that are handwritten or typewritten. A large supply of letters and numbers are provided to the algorithm. Then, because it is machine learning, it can detect when those letters show up somewhere else slightly different from the training images, because has a large training set. Often the larger the training set, the more cases it can recognize. The machine learning can make inferences about what it encounters.

According to Crabb, the USPS has several less essential use cases and pilot projects for artificial intelligence, such as using video analytics in USPS offices to reduce the amount of time customers spend standing in line at its post offices. In the slide, Crabb indicates that the analytics are somehow used to reduced wait times. The slide indicates that heatmaps are being utilized, so that would mean that the cameras are equipped with some infrared technology too.

This kind of data might also be used, for example, to find out what customers are seeking while in the post office lobby, though that is not stated. In another effort, the USPS is using AI to understand how postal employees are moving across the floors in processing center, with the stated objective being to improve the operations of these centers.

Artificial intelligence-- or its subset category, machine learning-- relies on collections of data. This data will be processed by its algorithms. A major source for collecting data in the environment, the USPS recognized, could be its vehicles that deliver mail. Postal service vehicles are, after all, driving most days of the week across nearly all streets, to most locations where there are receptacles for mail, making them an attractive source of data collection for a recent subject called "smart cities".

In a "smart city", the conditions and states of the city are monitored by electronic devices of various sorts, placed in various locations or attached to vehicles. Crabb states that some postal vehicles carry devices to collect data with the objective to assist autonomous vehicle technology ("self-driving cars")-- they assist in providing map information for this automotive field. In addition, the delivery vehicles, as they carry out their purpose of delivering mail, can collect information about road conditions to inform the city about which roads need improvement. There would likely be no more up-to-date and accurate source of map and road data than postal vehicles given how they travel 6 days of the week. And for any large city, which needs to have road conditions reported to know when there are problems, this could be helpful information.

In the above slide there is a small computer, called an edge computing module when talked about within a new computing trend called "edge computing". This term sounds complicated, but it is just a conceptual framing for how a small computer is used. The "edge" device is a small computer that would travel with the car or be placed in some part of a building, but it might not be connected to the Internet or a network right away, and it can gather data independent of a central data center, and so using it is called "edge computing", as these computers technically sit on "the edge" of computing network diagrams.

A lot can be packed into a small computer today, as demonstrated by mobile phones. These edge computing devices are often used in situations where it is necessary to process physical data in real-time. Edge computing modules can be used in a variety of applications, including smart cities.

The presentation provided by Crabb mostly discusses how artificial intelligence technology is used for security. Crabb is a security officer and data science specialist in one, and his actual position is the chief security officer. He happens also to be mentioning the use of A.I. for processing mail at the beginning. Later in the video he describes how A.I. can be used to prevent postal mail crimes.

All of these efforts would put the USPS in a position to be a customer of NVIDIA, who is specializing in this category of services and products, including "edge computing". The 2010 technology installed across the country to read mail was actually put together by Siemens and did not involve NVIDIA at the time, as NVIDIA was more focused on graphics card hardware technology until about the mid-2010s. In the following article on NVIDIA's website in 2019, NVIDIA explains how it has assisted the U.S. Postal Service.

The article states:

The Postal Service operates the worlds highest volume logistics operation, processing and delivering some 146 billion pieces of mail annually, including more than 6 billion packages. The new AI system will process package data 10x faster and with higher accuracy.

Engineering teams from the Postal Service and NVIDIA have been collaborating for several months to develop AI models, using NVIDIA software including TensorRT for high-throughput, low-latency inference optimization

It's hard to know what exactly how A.I. is improving package processing speeds without direct information from NVIDIA or the U.S. Postal Service, but this is the sort of scenario where dramatic implementations of A.I. technology are not going to be picked up by a mainstream news. A person would have to be a specialist in the field to find out about these specific cases and there are many times that it is just too industry-specific (logistics) to be in the news. Since both the U.S. Postal Service and NVIDIA would be said to be self-promoting, it would be even harder to see a news article on this topic of AI applied to postal processing. But they are the only people who would be talking about it.

Many companies provide artificial intelligence products and even processors. The mentioned NVIDIA product, TensorRT, is named as such because there is a certain mathematical object, called a tensor, that is central to machine learning algorithms. A math object adopted from other fields of mathematics and physics, tensors are used in various machine learning algorithms to represent and manipulate data, such as images, text, and time series. They assist in the processing of these types of data.

Sorting Waste

On a different topic of sorting, computers and machine learning can be used to address the major problems posed by wasted precious materials placed into landfills. But this is not something talked about often, despite its importance. Relatively few companies handle the waste end of production using A.I. compared to the manufacturing side.

For the stage just before it reaches the landfill, a UK startup company supported by Microsoft, NVIDIA, and the robot company Fanuc, has made software to control a robot product that sorts recycling from a stream of waste on a conveyor belt. Robots are sometimes in use today for recycling facilities, but according to online information this startup provides one with a lower cost. Below is a promotional video from Microsoft.

NVIDIA, who is invested in the artificial intelligence and machine learning space, because of both its software products and hardware products that enable these technologies, has an entire page dedicated to this startup on its blog post. It's important to note that this is a relatively underdeveloped area of A.I. despite how production of waste is a global concern.

item.title: The Mouse Is Not Enough for Pro Computers: External Controls Should Be Integrated with The Development of Complex Software
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
The First Mouse Demonstration Had a Second Device to The Left of the Keyboard

Douglas Engelbart's first demonstration of the mouse, given in 1968, featured a second device called a "chording keyboard" that was used in conjunction with the mouse. The chording keyboard allowed Engelbart to input commands and navigate the computer interface more quickly and efficiently, and it was an integral part of the early mouse-based computing system.  (Douglas Engelbart made several major contributions to modern computing, including the introduction of the mouse to control the first hypertext-based system, in this 1968 demonstration of his technologies.)

In terms of user interface, it may not be appreciated today that this second chording keyboard device was there because it does make sense to control a computer or software with more than just a simple device like a mouse alone, which is why Engelbart included it. The Xerox Alto and Xerox Star computers, the first successors to Engelbart's computing setup, only included a mouse, but they had multiple mouse buttons. By contrast, the Macintosh shipped with just one mouse button on its mouse device. Since the Macintosh set the trend for GUI-based computing, there has been a general hesitancy on the part of the software industry to go beyond the mouse and keyboard for software, even software that is very complex like 3D. When the situation becomes obvious, like video editing, then video editors will purchase external control deck peripherals. But it is uncommon for software developers to tie their software to external devices and it is most often the case that keyboard and mouse in its standard interface setup are regarded as satisfactory for all cases.

In the future, this should not be the mentality because the standard mouse and keyboard interface setup are like a Swiss Army knife being used in contexts where a set of real tools needs to be available. Thus, when people purchase recent devices and tie them to existing software, like Tourbox Neo or Loupedeck, they get immediate gains. It's just that this is an add-on situation, and the software needs to be built around such controls in the first place because tacking them on secondarily will run against the software's layout.

It's very important that future computer software not regard keyboard "shortcuts" in combination with the mouse as adequate for controlling complex, professional software. The history of computers even indicates this already.

If the current computing environment were more in line with how computers should exist today, it would build software around, and ship video editing deck controls with, the video editing software. Using video editing software with the mouse would be regarded as a last resort by the general public. That is to say, if a person bothers to learn video editing software, he would also have to purchase a video editing equipment, which would be more inexpensive if it were the norm.

The First 3D Systems Had Extra Peripherals to Control the 3D Objects

Below is the PS300, a computer graphics system sold in the 1980s by Evans and Sutherland Computer Corporation. In this setup, there is a total of three devices: eight dials, a grid of keys, and a three-button mouse.

In the best case, and what has to happen for software to truly improve, future 3D software will be developed alongside these kinds of controls from the very beginning. In other words, applications like Blender, 3D Studio Max, or Maya, etc. should all start over and dedicate themselves to a specific interface hardware that sits next to the computer. If portability of this device is a concern, there should be a portable version of the computer peripheral. Using the mouse to control 3D objects on screen should not be regarded as sufficient.

The Macintosh Encouraged An Oversimplified Interaction Environment with Software in All Areas, Lasting to the Present Day

The conventional understanding is that the Macintosh somehow improved on computer produced by Xerox, making them more accessible to a consuming public. But this is more something that was just repeated over the years by news media articles to the point that none have examined the situation. 

The main issue is that all computer users have been treated exactly the same because of the mindset promoted by the Macintosh in the 1980s compared to the Xerox computers. That there is no distinction in the hardware setup sold to professional computer users of software and those who are using the computer for more advanced purposes. Professional computer users are supplied with the same equipment, just a mouse, like a regular consumer, and software that is shipped all conforms to the same simple .

In my opinion, the software architectures developed at Xerox for Smalltalk and the Xerox Star were significantly more advanced than either the Mac or Windows. The Star was a tremendous accomplishment, with features that current systems haven't even started to implement I have great respect for the amazing computer scientists at Xerox PARC, who led the way with innovations we all take for granted now, and from whom I learned a tremendous amount about software design.

Bruce Horn, member of the Macintosh team. On Xerox, Apple and Progress

The Xerox computers were obviously plenty easy to use, and even the term and the convention of an "icon" was taken by Apple from the Xerox Star machine. Never a cited event, the Macintosh team actually bought a Xerox Star machine and studied it while making the Macintosh, meaning that what they were working on was not limited, as conventional accounts say, to Steve Jobs roaming around the Xerox lab.

It is not exactly the case and in some areas it is the complete opposite.  Many aspects of the Macintosh may have been mistaken in their efforts to simplify the Xerox computers for the hope of widespread adoption, being overly concerned that early computer users would not understand the machines.   The Xerox computers on which the Macintosh was based, the Xerox Star and Xerox Alto, were plenty simple to use and the Xerox Alto was developed around teaching pedagogy.  Both the Star and the Alto had multiple mouse buttons (as did Engelbarts mouse in the 1968 demo).  

Apple could have developed a more complex, sophisticated system rivaling the Xerox architectures. But the Mac had to ship, and it had to be relatively inexpensive - we couldn't afford the time or expense of the "best possible" design. 

Bruce Horn, member of the Macintosh team.

It is just important to note that the computer scientists at Xerox were experts in making the devices they were working on, whereas the teams assembled at Apple for the Macintosh were in a rushed environment to churn out a product that would be sold in large quantities and would also be the future of the company.

With the Macintosh, Apple altered these borrowed technologies such that the mouse had only one button.  In the 1990s, Apple reversed this, beginning with implementing control+click to activate the menu that Windows had with the right click.  Its something that should be reported on, that this one act of reducing the range of interaction with the machine has left an impact on software to the present day.  With the introduction of Apples "Magic Mouse" and "Magic Trackpad," meant that Apple has for a long time quietly embraced and endorsed multiple clicks.  Additionally, the touchscreen devices accept multiple gestures.  This shows that Apples decision.  

But it was more impactful because it shaped how the software operated in both the Windows and Macintosh environment.  It would have been better if consumers had been slowly introduced to a Xerox Star and Alto setup, perhaps, because 

The Xerox Star, which was introduced in 1981, had a number of keys on its keyboard that are not found on modern keyboards. These keys were designed to provide quick access to commonly used functions and commands, such as copy, paste, and other operations.

The time to incorporate a key on the keyboard relates to the number of times it is pressed.  Therefore, on todays computers, there ought to be a close button for closing tabs and windows.  When that deficiency is filled in all of a sudden with external devices like dedicated macro keyboards, those devices appear very capable.  But the main part of this is that there just arent controls placed on or near existing keyboards to match what is on the screen.

Overall, while the mouse is a convenient and widely used device for interacting with computers, it is inadequate for manipulating 3D models on screen. But the notion has been reversed, that the addition of external devices is somehow an upgrade, when in reality it was that the setup was held back to begin with when the Macintosh and Windows software environment developed around just the mouse, with a hesitation to develop the software around another type of peripheral.  Oddly, many people have believed that just using a mouse to control all of this complex software is an advancement over making use of other devices.

The notion that all software should be adapted to just a single mouse device, with a keyboard, originated with Apples introduction of the Macintosh in the 1980s.  There is some indication it has held back the computer software industry severely.  A lack of rationality is built into the computing environment, in which all software, regardless of the quantity of parameters to manipulate onscreen or what they serve to manipulated, is adapted to a single all-purpose mouse device.

In addition to the mouse and chording keyboard that was actually part of the first mouse setup, the first 3D graphics systems from Evans and Sutherland, which were developed in the 1970s, also included external peripherals with dials and buttons that allowed users to more precisely control the 3D models. 

In research conditions, peripherals that included specialized controllers and gloves that tracked the movement of the user's fingers and provided haptic feedback, allowing users to more naturally interact with the virtual environment.

Overall, the early 3D systems from Evans and Sutherland had much more control over the 3D models than is possible with today's mouse-based systems. The combination of specialized controllers, gloves, and other peripherals allowed users to manipulate the 3D models with greater precision and naturalness. While modern 3D systems have come a long way in terms of accessibility and ease of use, the use of external peripherals with dials and buttons can still provide a more intuitive and precise method of interacting with 3D models.

The mouse is a widely used and familiar device for interacting with computers, but it does have its limitations when it comes to manipulating 3D models on screen.

One of the main issues with using a mouse for 3D modeling is that it can be difficult to accurately control the position and orientation of the 3D model. The mouse is designed for movement in two dimensions, while 3D modeling requires movement in three dimensions. This means that the mouse is essentially being stretched beyond its capabilities, leading to imprecise and awkward control.

In contrast, external controls such as those found on the Tourbox Neo offer a more intuitive and precise method of manipulating 3D models. These external controls often include dials, knobs, and buttons that allow users to more accurately control the position and orientation of the 3D model. This can lead to a more natural and fluid experience, as the controls are more closely aligned with the movements required for 3D modeling.

Overall, while the mouse is a convenient and widely used device for interacting with computers, it is inadequate for manipulating 3D models on screen. External controls such as those found on the Tourbox Neo offer a more intuitive and precise method of control, making them a better choice for 3D modeling and other tasks that require precise movement in three dimensions.

item.title: The All-Or-Nothing Consensus Mechanism: The Basis of Crowdfunding
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
This article was written by a co-founder of the first all-or-nothing crowdfunding website Fundable (2005-2009). His website made the word crowdfunding because of a user named Michael Sullivan and his Fundavlog. This is not in Wikipedia.

TABLE OF CONTENTS

  • All-or-Nothing Is Mostly Theoretical, Not a Technical Approach
    • All-Or-Nothing Is Organization of Participation and Resources, Not Just Money
    • Other Technological Settings Besides The Web
  • In Terms of Global Reach, All-Or-Nothing Crowdfunding Is More Like an Apple Product in That It Is for High-End Consumers
  • The Various Terms Associated with All-or-Nothing Collections
  • The Rational Choice to Participate
  • Expanding All-or-Nothing Crowdfunding
  • Demands on Version 2.0 Crowdfunding Website Features Are Significant
  • Conclusion
  • More Resources

All-or-Nothing Is Mostly Theoretical, Not a Technical Approach

The concern here is with the important concept of a class of human problems which can be called "no technical solution problems" and, more specifically, with the identification and discussion of one of these.

Garret Hardin - Tragedy of the Commons (1968), an article often cited on the topic of collective action. (LINK)

It is often pointed out, though not always recognized, that technical solutions by themselves are not the path towards resolving major problems. Websites serve all-or-nothing collections, but a website is just a technical medium for an all-or-nothing collection, whereas the all-or-nothing model itself is a philosophical or theoretical matter.

In the 2010s, a segment of the Internet public became familiar with participating in all-or-nothing projects, pledging money conditionally on a web page and seeing the successful projects produce physical objects that could be touched and used. This funding method is still associated with just a few major websites. But in fact it is a consensus mechanism that can be implemented in other settings besides a website. In Mexico, for example, because of a lack of digital resources and widespread access to the Internet, for a time there was a crowdfunding website called Fondeadora that had to carry out some of its projects in person.

An all-or-nothing group action can be organized in person, such as at a large meeting of people, by way of envelopes handed to participants. When the envelopes are passed to a central location, they can either contain personal checks or a statements of commitments to participate in the project. In this physical implementation, if there isn't enough money in all of the envelopes, or if the number of commitments to participate on the project is too low, the envelopes can all just be mailed back to those who were in the meeting room. This is a measurement of the group's will. Unlike plain voting, it can simultaneously procure resources for the project.

So, the all-or-nothing consensus mechanism that has made the crowdfunding industry-- that was the basis of the first crowdfunding website where the word "crowdfunding" was coined (Fundable 2005-2009)-- does not have to be implemented on the Internet, but it is done there most efficiently in most cases. What is important to note is that the implementations that have been provided to Internet users have been artificially limited to one format, which is a collection pot for a single individual to manage.

An all-or-nothing collection is more of a theoretical concept than a technical one, but there are preferable technical settings and there are numerous possible configurations. Not all of the configurations will take the form of a mere collection pot. The all-or-nothing collection is closely associated with the web today because the web can implement it most powerfully, taking in contributions by reaching across large geographic areas. Whereas there might be only 10 people in a large city who would support a given project, there can be 1000 aggregated from across the nation or multiple countries because of the web, which sits on the Internet.

The computer and its programmable capabilities also provide opportunities to display statuses of consensus at every step. Each of these steps would have to be implemented separately in most other physical settings: announcing the status of the collection, providing updates on a bulletin board that would resemble a train timetable display. And that physical event would have to be advertised somewhere in the real world. The web is usually the most convenient medium, therefore, consolidating each step of the implementation of an all-or-nothing social sequence.

The web is also the medium that spurred discussion of the concept for many Internet and technology enthusiasts, as its emergence in the early days produced interest in how it could be made use of. More people came up with the concept of an all-or-nothing collection after the Internet became widely available in the 1990s. None attempted to implement it until a website called Fundable (2005-2009) came online, however. Those who implemented it after Fundable did not all succeed, until Kickstarter and IndieGoGo appeared and borrowed the essentials of their websites from Fundable. Because the all-or-nothing concept was much more open-ended in 2005 than the public realizes today, not all websites that attempted to package it as a product succeeded at all; they fell flat because their slight differences reflected a different set of goals, most of which would not have worked. It can go in any direction, and people have often brought their own personal conceptions to it at the same time, some with product expertise and others without. There are many technologists who assumed that all it took was some kind of technical implementation of an all-or-nothing collection and that would do the job. But, just like how the iPod was not the first portable digital music player, and there were many to follow, there is a consumer product aspect to establishing something like the all-or-nothing consensus mechanism in the time period when it was not even a well-known approach. It isn't just a conditional pot of money. It is a conditional pot of money that means someone is going to lose money if the goal is not reach, making it feel risky in the early days.

In summary, in the first place the public had not heard of an all-or-nothing collection in 2005, and secondly those actually attempted to implement it were not all the reference for later websites like Kickstarter and IndieGoGo. So it is actually Fundable that is the foundation of the entire all-or-nothing crowdfunding industry, even though many people conceived of an all-or-nothing collection as a theoretical object of interest for the web.

All-Or-Nothing Is Organization of Participation and Resources, Not Just Money

Usually an all-or-nothing collection is associated with money. But, as mentioned, it would not have to be a request for money included in the envelope; it can also include a form for labor or material commitments. A person could commit to a job on the project or agree to provide a material object that he or she possesses already.

As it exists today, the all-or-nothing mechanism collects capital from many individuals then sends the total to an individual entity. But in an alternative setup, the consensus mechanism would serve to organize long-term, active engagement and participation from the entire group-- not just the agreement that everyone would like the organizer to do a thing independently. The group does not participate at all today. They are simply the people who provide the capital.

Some essential aspects of a project can be carried out by the "backers" themselves over the course of the project's execution. In this case, the organizer is not always serving his own project but might act as a director, or manager of the entire project, just like how a film has a director and multiple executive producers. At the moment, all-or-nothing collections are configured in a format more often about mutual self-interest, in which the audience wants a product and the organizer wants to be able to make it. Beyond that, the two do not have much contact.

Even in the most charitable or non-profit projects, all major crowdfunding projects are organized in this way, with the contributions landing on a single organizer and the backers unable to participate in any step during the execution. The web obviously allows more than just one manifestation of all-or-nothing collections like this. Yet the changes just discussed are all theoretical currently. They will take time to work out both technically and in practice.

Other Technological Settings Besides The Web

The all-or-nothing model is not tied to a specific technology, the web. This consensus technique could theoretically take place on toll-free phone numbers, in which people call in and provide credit card information to pledge for the all-or-nothing total, or they could select from a telephone menu what type of role they would play in a project. This is just less efficient than the web for most situations, but it is possible to implement for a live television show, for example as well. In that scenario, people who would never visit a website to do a thing might pick up the phone and make a call in response to the show. Whether there are enough short-term tasks taken up by the participants, or enough money collected on the phone number for the stated purpose, determines whether the endeavor proceeds to the next stage.

It would take very little to implement all-or-nothing collections in a VR/AR environment. The participants all travel to the 3D room and press a large button located in the center of that room that produces a conditional pledge, drawing from the wallet that they carried into the room. They can also select from a menu of commitments shown before them inside the VR room, possibly on multiple wall. The progress bar for the entire project can exist as a physical cylinder, standing upright. The progress bar would be a large, cylindrical, glass tube of liquid.

In Terms of Global Reach, All-Or-Nothing Crowdfunding Is More Like an Apple Product in That It Is for High-End Consumers

The majority of the world uses Android for a smartphone, not an iPhone, for affordability and home computer compatibility reasons. Those who have used an all-or-nothing crowdfunding website or have read news articles about them may get the impression that the entire world has participated in an all-or-nothing collection. That's often the case in any activity a person engages in. But relative to the population, it is actually small, and it is limited to certain nations as well, most often in the U.S. The projects that made entire industries, such as the 2012 Oculus Rift VR headset Kickstarter project, were limited in the number of actual participants. Even though many projects collect millions of dollars, it actually only takes a few thousand people to reach that kind of goal. What this shows is that there is a lot of opportunity to expand the concept in ways that are applicable to other demographics and other income brackets, bringing in a much larger group of people into this use of the web. From one perspective, all-or-nothing crowdfunding has not taken off compared to where it could go because it has only taken one limited form, the aggregated capital sent to an individual.

A major limitation of the crowdfunding industry today is that it relies on the participants having lots of extra spending money. What this does is produce higher-end products and outcomes. But the range of what the projects can be about is small. There are only so many people who want to produce a short film. There are only so many people who know how to make electronics or have a personal goal to make them, etc.

It it has a very defined format, relying on a single project organizer to do all of the work in response to a collection of capital. Whether that organizer is a person or an organization, the execution stage takes place independent of the backers. It has the potential to exist more broadly such that many participants might not even use money to pledge their work or contributions all the time. But before that can happen, the industry needs to know a bit of theory, as we are discussing it here. What is collected can go beyond money, and those who participate during the implementation of the project can include those who actually made the pledges.

The Various Terms Associated with All-or-Nothing Collections

"Crowdfunding" does not have a clear definition at the moment, though it is meant to imply that a crowd of people, people who do not necessarily know each other, have funded something. Even though it is this all-or-nothing model that made crowdfunding work to begin with, many other types of websites are grouped under the broad category called "crowdfunding" because they involve the collections of money. In this circumstance, what made crowdfunding work got lost because the public and news media have been generally interested in the collection of money rather than the participatory mechanisms (or program) that coordinates aggregated participation from the public. Also hardly mentioned is that some projects are oriented towards groups of people who know each other or are part of a community whereas others just hope to collect funds from anyone who is interested.

Almost never has there been discussion about the all-or-nothing mechanism itself in news articles over the years. Part of this has to do with how Kickstarter and IndieGoGo underemphasized its role, leading the public to focus on the money and how much is collected by any given organizer. There might not be a case where news article discusses in detail the all-or-nothing model as the main subject, even though it is what makes Kickstarter and IndieGoGo work beyond just fundraising. Open-ended online fundraising existed previously, so it is fundamental that all-or-nothing is present on these websites.

As we have said, the development of all-or-nothing follows Fundable (2005-2009) because other implementations believed that technical work was all that was truly necessary.

There have been many terms for the all or nothing collection concept, previous to the 2000s even, with all of them circling around the same class of problems facing mankind that has been mentioned in philosophy for a long time: it is generally difficult to coordinate participation from a large group of individuals, especially outside of a formal organization. On the same topic, it is difficult to govern the resources of an organization in such a way that there is even distribution for the fair and just operations so that those with the most power and money keep their share while they are also not infringing on those in the lower tiers.

Here are some terms that are, in some way, referring to having an all-or-nothing mechanism determine the status of group consensus:

  • Assurance Contract (1990s)
  • Threshold Pledge (2000s)
  • Street Performer Protocol (1996) - The same as above, except tying the concept of all-or-nothing outcomes to an ideological viewpoint about copyrights, in which the outcome would supposedly be an environment totally devoid of copyright protections. One article claimed that this would be a near-inevitable result. This Street Performer Protocol was produced in an era when the web was new and excitement was strong about the Internet.
  • Provision Point Mechanism (2008)

According to his website, the founder of WIRED magazine, Kevin Kelly, came up with his own term, "1000 True Fans", in which a group of people carried out an all-or-nothing contract, and he saw the later emergence of the crowdfunding industry as validation of his discussion of the concept.

However, discussing the model is not the same as putting together a website for the public to use.
