The Internet, an international communications technology, with interactive terminals available to and used by all who are online, lends itself to this sort of model most easily, as any bulletin posted can reach the desired number of individuals within a day. But this isn't to say that the general Internet public, or the Internet industry, would take the step on its own to apply the all-or-nothing concept to the technology. The mere existence of the Internet is not a guarantee that an all-or-nothing website would come about that people believe could work for them, one that they found appealing and comprehensible. And it is also the case that the lay public would not be discussing all-or-nothing collections on its own. It was the opposite: industry leaders and the lay public required a long convincing period before they took up these kinds of projects, even though the Internet could facilitate them most easily.

This is the mistake too many technologists make, which is that once something is established they categorize it as a given when in many cases it was not accepted by the public at first.

The Rational Choice to Participate

Too often, making rational decisions is regarded as being aligned with self-interest, especially in the fields of economics and other social sciences. In a certain pool of people, if there is a high risk that a portion of them acts in a very self-interested way, regarding it as the most rational course of action for themselves as individuals-- not building up their feelings of altruism for the situation (an element that is also present in human nature and co-existing with selfishness)-- then it is hard to say what will happen. All sorts of preventative measures and procedures have to be enacted to ensure the smooth execution of a project when these are the conditions.

Because all-or-nothing has only served to tell the project organizer whether to do something (a representative measure of group interest) these kinds of problems that test the group as a whole have not played out. The group members have served the role as consumers, exclusively, so far in the crowdfunding industry. The problems that have arisen have been limited to what the project organizer has done or not done. The group itself that makes the pledges has never been given responsibilities.

At the current time, the all-or-nothing collection model simply confirms the collective desires of a group of individuals. That was a big first step to carry out in 2005, but since the process is well-established there should be an aspiration for more. Most often it is a group of strangers who never talk to each other at any point who are part of this crowdfunding of today. They just have money to send the organizer. In some cases, the collection is utilized for a local, formal organization or local group of people who do know each other or could get to know each other if they don't already. Yet, they are usually just expressing support through finances.

Conflict and disagreement are the norm in society, with different factions frequently appearing in any group endeavor in society, and it is difficult to achieve a state of consensus for taking action and setting up schedules for a large group of people in general, even more the case outside of formal situations like voting booths, where all are called to state on paper what they want to do or not. In those meeting hall situations, opportunities to carry out objectives with the public's will or enforce accountability to a person's stated commitments are naturally present, whereas most arenas of everyday life do not allow setting up rules of accountability. It's hard to know what some people are going to do after they have expressed interest in a certain outcome. In specific scenarios, the all-or-nothing collection model can be applied; what is wanted is what is measured right away. They have not just said they want a virtual reality headset, they have put down their money conditional on it happening, in other words. But previously, they might all just say they want it and do very little.

This kind of mechanism can bring out some positive behavior in people, as they will sometimes be charitable in their contributions first while also expecting to receive a product later. They will not treat the situation exactly the same as a consumer transaction every time, though perhaps if they did most of the time there would be better accountability.

Expanding All-or-Nothing Crowdfunding

With all-or-nothing crowdfunding, you could build a small house according to your designs in two ways:

  • you can collect the money from backers and send it to subcontractors who build the small house with their own workers.
  • you can collect the money for all of the materials and have local people who sent some money build it in a way similar to Habitat for Humanity. (This would be feasible for a small house and prefabricated components.) This would be for a shared community house, for example.

This applies to all kinds of other projects as well. In that case, what is important is that there is a balancing of specialized participants: the small house has to be supervised by people with construction experience. Sometimes it is better to just send the money to skilled tradesmen and subcontractors.

The point of having the group participate would be to give them experience building a small house and to reduce costs. What is important is making sure that there is enough money in the case participants do not show up.

The all-or-nothing format in the current time is not very broad, as it only asks for money in the case the person would like to see a product or outcome produced. In a later version it can reflect a wider array of the philosophical concerns that it initially represented-- those involving the balancing of resources among people who would like to see an objective achieved.

Demands on Version 2.0 Crowdfunding Website Features Are Significant

To give an example, in the construction industry the coordination of constructing a very large building requires a great deal of planning and scheduling. When the backers are doing more than just sending money, the websites will need many planning and schedules features. The computer network can be made to do this alongside the conditional pledges of money. It can coordinate other forms of group participation beside the collection of money, even at a large scale. It has the most convenient tool on which it can be implemented ever in this civilization: the Internet.

When all individuals know that the money they put down will only be collected when there is a minimum amount collected by everyone, there is a kind of guarantee provided that there will be some progress, but they don't carry any of the burden in a consumer setup. On this plain, all-or-nothing money collection organized by a single individual or group, the burden shifts from the participants to the organizer, who has an executive role, implementing and organizing everything that has to be done. That is the only individual entity actually executing anything amidst all of these people who want it to happen. There can be products made that depends on all of the backers to make phone calls and arrangements to facilitate its production. It would likely happen first in organizations that have people who feel comfortable doing this before it branched out.

In the current implementations, the contributors (or "backers") play a passive role and simply receive the output of paying money.

In this way, it is not exactly like traditional accounts of participation problems because those involve people in villages in which all were asked to participate as a group in person, such as to build a wall made out of brick at the same time. Anyone who did not partake in building the wall would benefit from the wall later anyway. So far, that kind of scenario has not been addressed by websites, in which people would actually show up to a site as a result of their pledge on a web page.

Additionally, it is difficult, in informal situations outside of congregations with established procedures, to prevent what is called the "free rider problem." That there are individuals who stand to gain by just observing the hard work of others and they may undermine the entire project entirely to the extent that it never gets started because of the threat that they will come about at some point, not contribute, and so on. If, for example, there are 30 people and 20 are needed to work on a site to achieve a goal, there might only be 15 people who proactively agree to work on the project while the other 15 observe. Through a consensus mechanism like an all-or-nothing collection, however, it is possible to make gains on that number and add an additional 5 who might not be proactive in their efforts to participate but nevertheless are incorporated into the overall project. They at least have material resources they can offer, they are often willing to contribute them but perhaps not regard themselves as enthusiastic like the original 15 members.

An all-or-nothing collection also eliminates the need to conduct surveys in advance of collecting money, as it is the survey and money collection in one. A large group of people may all share the same wish for a certain outcome but each member is individually concerned in private that the others will not follow through, or not have the same objective that all in the group actually share. Thus, there is often latent desire for an outcome among a large group of people, but prior to the convenience of the Internet implementing all-or-nothing collections it was very difficult to gather them under a single endeavor.

For example, a large group of technology enthusiasts do not drive the financial decisions at a large technology company that seeks to manufacturing products predominantly for making money. It may see the value in a certain product category but be unwilling to do research if its executives do not see immediate financial returns in the effort. Yet, all might actually agree at the same time that this technology the enthusiasts wish to see happen and made purchasable is a worthwhile endeavor. For this reason, Oculus VR was able to be funded, along with many other kinds of products initially, though not later, considered too niche or risky by the major corporations. It is important to note that the situation is not limited to that, that there may be a large pool of people who all carry a strong desire all of a sudden for something odd, zany, or something that is in fact not a productive use of time for a large corporation if the product is not modified heavily for public consumption.

This goes back to the often reference phrase in the early years of Kickstarter, "I would pay $20 to see XYZ happen," such as bringing a band to a certain venue, or seeing a remake of a certain video game. This sort of diesre was previously very difficult to fulfill before all-or-nothing collections were implemented widely on the Internet because, for one, there was no place for likeminded individuals to pool their money to see that thing happen, even though a certain group of people would like to see it occur.

Currently unique to the Internet, it can draw participation from a very large geographic area, even across many parts of the globe, so if there are a total of 1000 people needed, there are no limitations imposed by the typical need to procure these supporters from a local area, which may only have a dozen candidates as participants in the project and maybe only 3 actual ones who would get involved. In small projects that actually pertain to a local geographic area (e.g. funding a local project specific to and beneficial for the local area) this is not a relevant matter. Nonetheless, it consolidates all individuals in that local area, too, by way of the Internet, specifically the web. This became even easier when all individuals actively check their e-mail by way of smartphones they carry in their pockets, which is when use of the Internet became truly mainstream and integrated into the functioning of society in an overt way.

The closest possible scenario for very large projects previously would be advertising such a project on national radio or television and then having audience members call into a telephone number.

Conclusion

Currently, all-or-nothing crowdfunding is like a large funnel for liquid capital, with all of it leading to a single individual. After that, everyone waits.

Known but not emphasized, it is the all-or-nothing collection model that enables websites like Kickstarter and IndieGoGo to facilitate the manufacture of products that are regarded as too niche or speculative to be placed on store shelves (initially, as later they can be found there). In the beginning, they are often regarded as speculative investments to the typical investor and other businesspeople. Some in fact will not go beyond that classification, whereas other are picked up by larger companies and then commercialized in mainstream markets, such as the Tile tracker.

When crowdfunding is expanded beyond funneling all of the money to a single entity, it will reach a greater number of people on the Internet. A house can be built because people brought building materials to the site. The right experts will arrive on site. They will have signed up for their roles on the all-or-nothing crowdfunding website.

More Resources

The Vast Superiority of All-Or-Nothing Crowdfunding

For Crowdfunding To Remain Interesting...

Participatory Crowdfunding

item.title: The Wide Range of Dishes That Can Be Cooked in Pressure Cooker
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
If you haven't read the article discussing the benefits of using an electric pressure cooker, read that here: Start Cooking With an Electric Pressure Cooker.

The pressure cookers not only have different modes, but the different modes can provide flexibility for a range of meals and food items. The cookers include equipment for steaming vegetables, usually a small metal rack, too.

Some examples of dishes that can be cooked in a pressure cooker include:

  1. Garbanzo beans: Pressure cookers are great for cooking dried beans, such as garbanzo beans (also known as chickpeas), because they cook much faster than on the stovetop. To cook garbanzo beans in a pressure cooker, simply add the beans to the pot with water and any desired seasonings, seal the lid, and cook on high pressure for about 25-30 minutes. Beans often have to be soaked for an hour or overnight before they are cooked on a stove, but a pressure cooker makes it so that you can cook them without soaking the beans first.
  2. Cake: Yes, it is possible to make cake in a pressure cooker! To do this, you will need a pressure cooker-specific cake pan that fits inside the pot. Simply follow your favorite cake recipe, pour the batter into the pan, and cook on low pressure for about 30-35 minutes.
  3. Steamed vegetables: A pressure cooker is an excellent tool for quickly steaming vegetables. Many pressure cookers come with a steamer basket, which you place in the pressure cooker for steaming. To steam vegetables in a pressure cooker, add a cup or two of water to the pot, place a steamer basket or tray inside, and add the vegetables. Close the lid and cook on high pressure for 3-5 minutes, depending on the type and size of the vegetables.
  4. Rice: Rice can be cooked in a pressure cooker in much less time than it takes on the stovetop. To cook rice in a pressure cooker, simply add the rice and water to the pot, seal the lid, and cook on high pressure for about 6-8 minutes (for white rice) or 8-10 minutes (for brown rice).
  5. Stews: Pressure cookers are great for making stews because they can cook the ingredients quickly and evenly, resulting in tender meats and flavorful vegetables. To make a stew in a pressure cooker, simply add your ingredients (such as diced meats, vegetables, and broth) to the pot, seal the lid, and cook on high pressure for about 30-40 minutes.
  6. Soups: Like stews, soups can also be made in a pressure cooker. To make soup in a pressure cooker, add your ingredients (such as vegetables, meats, and broth) to the pot, seal the lid, and cook on high pressure for about 15-20 minutes.
  7. Braised meats: Braising is a cooking method in which meats are first seared and then cooked slowly in a liquid, resulting in tender and flavorful dishes. A pressure cooker can be used to braise meats in a much shorter amount of time than on the stovetop or in the oven. To braise meats in a pressure cooker, sear the meats in the pot, then add liquid (such as broth or wine) and any desired vegetables or seasonings. Seal the lid and cook on high pressure for about 45 minutes to an hour, depending on the type and size of the meat.
  8. Hard-boiled eggs: A pressure cooker can be used to make perfectly cooked hard-boiled eggs in a fraction of the time it takes to boil them on the stovetop. To make hard-boiled eggs in a pressure cooker, add the eggs to the pot with water, seal the lid, and cook on high pressure for about 5-6 minutes.
  9. Potatoes: Many pressure cookers come with a small metal rack on which you can place large vegetables, like potatoes. Select the "manual" or "pressure cook" function on the pressure cooker, and set the timer for 15-20 minutes (depending on the size of the potatoes). After they are cooked, you can add a butter product and milk product to them and blend them to make mashed potatoes. Or you can remove them and season them or add topping as if they are baked potatoes.
  10. Yogurt: Many pressure cookers have a special, non-pressure setting for making yogurt, which means that it is set at low temperature relative to normal cooking, and it operates for several hours at 110-115F. It involve pouring in milk (or a milk alternative) plus the yogurt bought from the store that includes the starting culture and acts as the base for making yogurt.

Saute Vegetables in the Multifunction Pressure Cooker, Then Cook The Rest of the Ingredients

Most modern pressure cookers have a "saute" or "browning" function that allows you to saute ingredients, such as onions, green peppers, and garlic, in the pot before adding the rest of the ingredients and cooking under pressure.

Sauteing vegetables before cooking them in a pressure cooker can be very convenient because it allows you to add flavor and depth to your dishes. When you saute onions, green peppers, and other vegetables, you are essentially caramelizing them, which brings out their natural sweetness and enhances their flavor. By sauteing these ingredients before adding the rest of the ingredients to the pressure cooker, you can create a more flavorful and well-rounded dish.

In addition to adding flavor, sauteing vegetables before cooking them in a pressure cooker can also be convenient because it allows you to cook everything in one pot. This saves time and reduces the number of dishes you need to wash. Plus, because the pressure cooker cooks food so quickly, you can have a delicious, home-cooked meal on the table in a fraction of the time it would take to cook on the stovetop or in the oven.

Here is a general process for using the saute function on a pressure cooker:

  1. Place the pressure cooker pot on the stove and turn the heat to medium-high.
  2. Add some oil or butter to the pot.
  3. Once the oil is hot, add the vegetables you want to saute, such as onions, green peppers, and garlic.
  4. Saute the vegetables until they are tender and starting to brown, stirring occasionally. This should take about 5-7 minutes.
  5. Once the vegetables are sauteed, you can add the rest of your ingredients, such as rice or other grains, meats, and broth or water.
  6. Stir the ingredients to combine, making sure that the rice or grains are fully submerged in the liquid.
  7. Close the lid of the pressure cooker and make sure it is properly sealed.
  8. Select the appropriate cooking time and pressure level for the recipe you are using.
  9. Turn the heat to high and wait for the pressure cooker to reach pressure. This will typically take about 10-15 minutes.
  10. Once the pressure cooker reaches pressure, it will start the countdown for the cooking time. The timer will start counting down once the desired pressure is reached.
  11. When the cooking time is up, the pressure cooker will automatically switch to the "keep warm" setting and start to release the pressure. This process, known as "natural pressure release," can take about 10-15 minutes.
  12. Once the pressure has been fully released, the pressure cooker will switch off. Carefully open the lid and serve the cooked dish.

Note: The specific steps and settings for using the saute function on a pressure cooker may vary depending on the make and model of the appliance. Be sure to consult the user manual for your specific pressure cooker for more detailed instructions.

Making Yogurt in an Electric Pressure Cooker

Other functions of a pressure cooker make use of pressure, but producing yogurt does not. It is actually a relatively low temperature mode for the cooker compared to regular cooking: 110-115F. Making yogurt in a pressure cooker is a simple and efficient way to produce creamy, homemade yogurt without the need for a yogurt maker or special equipment. Here is a general recipe for making yogurt in a pressure cooker:

Ingredients:

  • 4 cups whole milk
  • 2 tablespoons plain yogurt with active cultures (use a store-bought brand or a previous batch of homemade yogurt)

Instructions:

  1. Pour the milk into the pressure cooker pot and close the lid.
  2. Select the "yogurt" or "slow cook" function on your pressure cooker, and set the timer for 6 hours.
  3. When the timer goes off, carefully open the lid and check the temperature of the milk. It should be between 110-115F. If the milk is not at this temperature, close the lid and continue to slow cook for another hour or until the desired temperature is reached.
  4. Once the milk has reached the desired temperature, add the plain yogurt with active cultures and stir to combine.
  5. Close the lid of the pressure cooker and select the "yogurt" function again. Set the timer for 8-12 hours, depending on the thickness and tanginess desired.
  6. When the timer goes off, carefully open the lid and check the consistency of the yogurt. It should be thick and creamy. If it is not yet at the desired consistency, close the lid and continue to slow cook for another 2-4 hours.
  7. Once the yogurt has reached the desired consistency, carefully transfer it to a container and refrigerate until chilled.
  8. The yogurt can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

Note: The specific steps and settings for making yogurt in a pressure cooker may vary depending on the make and model of the appliance. Be sure to consult the user manual for your specific pressure cooker for more detailed instructions.

item.title: Start Cooking With an Electric Pressure Cooker
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Whether you cook or are just a beginner to cooking, you should consider getting an electric pressure cooker for the kitchen. It is something so helpful that there is no reason not to have one if you cook at home all the time and you can afford one. This isn'tto state a personal opinion, but rather there is just no reason to stick to a stove at all times when this is available today. For certain foods, there are still times when a stove is preferable, such as when making stir fry dishes with a wok, but this is an immensely helpful tool for cooking that shouldn't be overlooked. It is highly beneficial for those with busy schedules.

The Electric Pressure Cooker Became Popular with The Instant Pot

The electric pressure cooker has become increasingly popular in recent years in large part because of the introduction of the Instant Pot in 2010. The Instant Pot is a multi-cooker: it combines the functions of a pressure cooker, slow cooker, rice cooker, and more in one appliance. It has become a common choice for home cooks because of all of the conveniences this provides, and it has helped to introduce many people to cooking, too. Because it has so many features, it became popular, as it consolidates so much functionality into a single location.

For experienced cooks, they have often seen the benefits of using an electric pressure cooker for many dishes because the outcomes are mostly the same but the time required is significantly less. It is possible, in an electric pressure cooker, to make not only soup, but also cake, steamed vegetables, and pasta.

Many competing brands followed the Instant Pot, including the Multipot, which the author of this article has used, but the status of the company is unknown at the time of this article. The appliance brand Ninja offers a pressure cooker model that carries air fry functionality in the same device, which would be a great all-purpose device for cooking, as adding the option of air frying means that what is cooked can then be air-fried as well. The addition of air frying to the electric pressure cooker is a recent phenomenon, as originally it was just different modes for the heating of food.

It is because of the Instant Pot that electric pressure cookers became more advanced and user-friendly in recent years. So, this isn't the same as the manual pressure cookers that sit on the stove and need to be monitored. The benefit of the electric pressure cooker is that a person does not have to monitor it and can even leave it in place long after it is finished cooking, because it will keep the food warm afterwards.

Electric pressure cookers can help to cook food quickly and efficiently, but the cooking quality is that of a stovetop-cooked meal. With an electric pressure cooker, you can cook a wide variety of dishes quickly and easily.

How It Works

A pressure cooker is a sealed pot with a release valve for excess steam. It traps steam inside, which raises the temperature and cooks the food more quickly than other methods.

An electric pressure cooker takes a certain amount of time to reach cooking temperature, then it cooks for a period of time, then shuts off and turns to warming the food.

The first pressure cooker was invented by Denis Papin, a French physicist, in the late 17th century. Papin's invention was not widely adopted at the time, but it laid the groundwork for the development of modern pressure cookers. The modern pressure cooker was developed in the early 20th century.

Electric pressure cookers are powered by electricity whereas regular pressure cookers sit on a stove.

Early electric pressure cookers were large, heavy appliances that often required a separate power outlet.

A Big Appeal: No Need to Watch the Stove or Oven While the Meal Cooks

One of the benefits of a pressure cooker is that cooking does not need to be monitored, unlike food that is being cooked on a stove in a pot or a pan. You can leave the device on its own, and after it is done cooking and it can sit there and keep the food warm for you for several hours. This allows you to do other household chores while you cook food.

Being an all-in-one setup that can make a lot of food quickly, it has many uses for cooking. The popularity of the device in recent years comes from how it is a multi-use kitchen appliance that can be used to cook a wide range of dishes. This means it can be used multiple days per week to keep up the variation in cooking outcomes.

Some types of dishes that can be cooked in an electric pressure cooker include:

  • Soups and stews: An electric pressure cooker is great for cooking soups and stews because it can quickly and evenly cook the ingredients, resulting in a rich, flavorful broth.  This is the easiest for when you want to cook food quickly.  All you have to do is dump a set of ingredients into the pot, set the timer, and you have a stew in 15 or 30 minutes of cooking time.  (It sometimes take 10 minutes to build up the pressure before it starts cooking).
  • Meat dishes: An electric pressure cooker is perfect for cooking tough cuts of meat, such as beef brisket or pork shoulder, because the high pressure and heat help to tenderize the meat and make it juicy and flavorful.
  • Rice and grains: An electric pressure cooker can be used to cook rice and grains quickly and evenly, without the need for constant stirring or monitoring.  This is especially helpful when talking about beans, as they do not have to be soaked overnight to be cooked.  Brown rice, which is considered healthier than white rice, takes a lot less time even though its shell is harder than white rice.
  • Vegetables: An electric pressure cooker is great for cooking vegetables because it can quickly and evenly cook them, resulting in tender, flavorful vegetables that retain their nutrients. 
  • Desserts: Believe it or not, an electric pressure cooker can also be used to make desserts, such as cheesecake or crme brle.
  • Many cookers can make yogurt as well, which is a different temperature setting of 110 to 115 degrees.

Many electric pressure cookers come with pre-programmed settings that make it easy to cook all oof these dishes with after pressing their buttons.  This means that even if you are a beginner cook, you can easily use an electric pressure cooker to create quality meals.  Because the pot is large, if your time is short for the week, you can make nice food to be eaten over a few days.

Getting Started Cooking with a Pressure Cooker

Using a pressure cooker can be a great way to get started cooking, especially if you are short on time or looking for an efficient way to prepare meals. Here are a few tips to help you get started with cooking in a pressure cooker:

  1. Watch videos about how to use the pressure cooker. Before you start cooking with your pressure cooker, watch online videos about how they work, specifically the mode. How it works is simple, but getting acquainted with the pressure cooker can be a little confusing at first and this is best dealt with by watching an online video. The video instructions will include information on how to seal the lid, how to release pressure. Each model has its preset and means of adjusting cooking times and settings.
  2. Just try cooking rice to begin with, because all you have to do is follow the instructions about how much water, how much rice, and how much time it is cooked. As you get started with cooking in a pressure cooker, simple recipes that only require a few ingredients can be made progressively more complex by you over time. You get a chance to become familiar with the appliance, how it works, while also learning how to put dishes together.
  3. Cooking times are different: Because pressure cookers cook food much faster than the traditional methods of the oven or the stovetop, you usually have to adjust cooking times for recipes that are meant for the stovetop or in the oven. Usually there is a table of cooking times for the pressure cooker that came with the manual for all kinds of foods and ingredients..
  4. There are many different dishes that can be made in a pressure cooker, from soups and stews to rice and grains to braised meats and steamed vegetables. Once you get used to cooking all of them, you can begin to combine them a little at a time.
  5. Watch videos online or look for Facebook groups about pressure cooker recipes.
  6. Follow recipe instructions carefully and do not make substitutions unless you are told how or know what is happening. When recipes do not turn out for beginner cooks, it is usually (but not absolutely always) because they made ingredient substitutions or did not follow the recipe closely enough.

Example Dishes

Some specific dishes that can be prepared in an Instant Pot include:

  • Stews and soups
  • Beans and lentils
  • Rice and grains
  • Meat (such as chicken, beef, pork)
  • Fish and seafood
  • Eggs (such as hard-boiled, soft-boiled, and poached)
  • Vegetables
  • Desserts (such as cakes and cheesecake)
  • Yogurt
  • Pasta
  • Chili
  • Pot Roast
  • Baked Potatoes
  • Jambalaya
  • BBQ Ribs
  • Frittata
  • Pulled Pork
  • Curry
  • Risotto
  • Tenderloin
  • Steamed Dumplings
  • Shredded Chicken
  • Applesauce
  • Rice Pudding
  • Brown Rice

Tutorials on The Web

There are many resources on the web on this topic. That is the end of this article.

item.title: Take Note of The Helpful Manufacturer-Recommended Recipes on The Back of Food Products at the Grocery Store
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
There are lots of food products out there that come with great recipes on the back of the package, provided by the manufacturer. If you're looking to learn how to cook, these can be a great resource.

The author of this article found a great lentil soup recipe on the back of a package of lentils while shopping at a big box store, just to give an example, as there are many recipes found in many stores. On a package of beans was a recipe for Cuban beans and rice that only required a few more ingredients.

If you're looking to add some variety to your meal planning, check out the recipes provided by food manufacturers. Not only are they a great resource for delicious and easy-to-make dishes, but they can also help you learn new cooking techniques and techniques. Next time you're at the store, don't forget to flip over the packaging and see what recipes you can find.

One of the benefits of using these recipes is that they are typically easy to follow and include clear instructions. They also often include helpful tips and variations on the recipe, so you can customize it to your liking.

Another advantage of using manufacturer-provided recipes is that they are often created by professional chefs or food experts, so you can trust that they will turn out well. These recipes are also designed to highlight the specific product that you're using, so you can be sure that the flavor and texture will be just right.

So next time you're at the grocery store, don't just toss the packaging in the trash after you've finished the product. Take a moment to flip it over and see if there are any tasty recipes that you can try out. You might just discover a new favorite dish.

item.title: How Can A Programming Language Transition to a Document File Format?
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
If you wanted to make a more interactive version of a programming language inside a code editor, one that can behave more like a multimedia page layout document instead of a file of text, a most helpful way to start is by making a document format.

XML would be a convenient base format to use. Just using C# as an example, you can convert all of the plain text C# keywords and conventions directly into XML tags and attributes for this document file format. Here is how a switch statement can exist in our document format:

<switch expression="x">
    <case value="1">
        ...
    </case>
    <case value="2">
        ...
    </case>
    <default>
        ...
    </default>
</switch>

How the switch statement is rendered and interacted with by the user is up to the code editor itself. The code, as it exists inside a programming language, can be reconfigured in many ways. For example, the switch statement can be arranged to flow on the page horizontally, with each case as a column (instead of a typewritten, plain text row as it is today). Additionally, any case for the switch can be toggled on or off inside the editor during programming because it is rendered from XML, which means it can be treated as an interactive element. Code editors can process the XML-base code documents as interactive.

This can bring about a new type of editor interactivity, as the XML immediately provides a new range. Also what this demonstrates is that other features can be placed inside computer code that are not provided in the plain text editors today.

For making a document file format, XML is chosen as the base structure because it is a convenient choice for processing interactive content compared to some other file formats. When XML is utilized to represent what is now in plain text, discussions about how a mainstream programming language can exist become something unchartered and different.

Converting all of the existing code syntax from plain text to XML is a lengthy chore for all aspects of any programming language, so by directing ChatGPT and then modifying the results, we can assemble some examples.

XML is flexible for representing code because it is easy to parse and style. Many document file formats are already made out of XML, which means their features can be included. For making code, numerous features will be available for the code editors; the ability to customize a programming language after it is converted to XML is so deep that it depends on the goals of the code designer to set up a plan in advance.

Separating The Layout from The Code in The Document Format

A big advantage of placing conventional, plain text computer code into a code document format is that it provides modern computing features, like layout. But right away when making the file format, we encounter an issue that doesn't exist today in plain text: there is of course no layout inside a file of plain text for regular lines of computer code and scripting files like those made of JavaScript. Since that is the case, the first step we have taken is to establish layout commands that exist in a separate area of the document, apart from the code section of the document. In an HTML document, the layout commands, such as the <p> tag, are embedded right next to the text, but we won't do that because code exists presently in plain text.

In a future programming language that arises from XML completely, this would not be necessary. But converting an existing plain text-based programming language to XML will necessitate separation of layout commands from the code area (or an approach that with the same goal).

The format for our document will then be like this:

<document>

  <layout>
   [layout descriptors for statement bodies like switch, if, if-else, func, etc.]
  </layout>

  <code>
   [tags representing statement bodies like switch, if, if-else, func, etc.]
  </code>

</document>

The page layout is not mingled with the rest of the code because it will interfere with representing the code logic that is in a plain text form. It is thus placed in a separate <layout> section in which each <layoutBox> tag indicates the start and end IDs of code statements like switch. This way, there is no combining of the layout instructions for the editor within the XML-formatted code, and the code can be easily converted over to plain text.

<layout>
<layoutBox startId="30" endId="50"/>
<layoutBox startId="51" endId="43"/>
</layout>

The Code Section of The Document

We made several examples on this page. Here is a for statement moved into XML for the document.

<for loopVariable="i" start="1" end="10" step="1">     
... 
</for>

Each aspect of the for loop is placed into an attribute. The more that code is placed into XML attributes and tags, the more we can parse it directly with an XML parser, program its interface interactivity directly, and also style it. For the most part, we don't want any untagged plain text in the inside of this file unless perhaps it is something like <string></string>, in which the contents is a string value or <integer></integer> in which the contents is the number.

Provided below are various examples that provide an impression of what it would be like to convert existing plain text code to a document format.

Class, Interface, and Methods

Interface:

<interface name="IMyInterface">
    ...
</interface>

Class Declaration with Namespace:

<namespace name="MyNamespace">
<class name="MyClass">
    <constructor access="public">
        <parameter type="int" name="x"/>
        <parameter type="string" name="y"/>
        <assign variable="_x" value="x"/>
        <assign variable="_y" value="y"/>
    </constructor>
</class>
</namespace>

Declare a Method:

<method name="MyMethod" returnType="int">
    <parameter type="int" name="x"/>
    <parameter type="string" name="y"/>

    <return>
        <operation op="add" left="x" right="1"/>
    </return>

</method>

Call a Method:

<call method="MyMethod">
    <parameter value="10"/>
    <parameter value="'Hello World'"/>
</call>

When calling a method, assign the result to a variable sampleInt1:

<call method="MyMethod" assign="sampleInt1">
    <parameter value="10"/>
    <parameter value="'Hello World'"/>
</call>

Declare an object instance:

<declare type="MyClass" name="myObject">
    <constructor>
        <parameter type="int" name="x"/>
        <parameter type="string" name="y"/>
    </constructor>
</declare>

Loops

For loop

<for loopVariable="i" start="1" end="10" step="1">
    ...
</for>

While loop:

<while condition="x < 10">
    ...
</while>

Do-while loop:

Below we put the conditional expression in plain text, but really we want the expression to be in tags later.

<do>
    ...
    <while condition="x < 10"/>
</do>

Conditional Statement

If Statement:

There are multiple ways to represent expressions found in a conditional branching statement. We can introduce the following expression enclosures here: anyOfFollowingIsTrue, oneOfFollowingIsTrue, allOfFollowingIsTrue, allOfFollowingIsFalse, etc. In the example below, the evaluated expressions are in plain text, but that is for this example. In the next example we show a way to convert that to XML too.

<if>

<expression>

<anyOfFollowingIsTrue>

  <oneOfFollowingIsTrue>
    <expression>x > 1</expression>  
    <expression>x < 15</expression>
  </oneOfFollowingIsTrue>

  <allOfFollowingIsTrue>
    <expression>y > 5</expression>  
    <expression>y < 50</expression>
  </allOfFollowingIsTrue>

</anyOfFollowingIsTrue>

</expression>

<instructions>
[XML-formatted code to execute for if statement]
</instructions>

</if>

To turn the expression (x < 30) into XML:

<expression>

  <expressionLeft var="x"/>

  <expressionOperator op="<"/>

  <expressionRight int="30" />

</expression>

Control Structures

Switch:

<switch expression="x">
    <case value="1">
        ...
    </case>
    <case value="2">
        ...
    </case>
    <default>
        ...
    </default>
</switch>

Try Catch

<try>
    ...
    <catch exceptionType="Exception" exceptionVar="e">
        ...
    </catch>
    <finally>
        ...
    </finally>
</try>

Data Structures

Enum

<enum name="MyEnum">
    <value name="Red"/>
    <value name="Green"/>
    <value name="Blue"/>
</enum>

Properties

<property name="MyProperty" type="int">
    <get access="public">
        <return>_myField</return>
    </get>
    <set access="public">
        <assign variable="_myField" value="value"/>
    </set>
</property>

Implications of Converting Code to XML

A different category of programming features will be available to code once it is converted to a document format. It becomes more obvious that many of the terms for the C#, C++, and other programming languages' code are specific to the file format, plain text. Do you even need to use the word "for" for a loop? You could just use loop. You don't even have to display the word "loop" either and could make a large symbol for it instead.

Some new types of programming conventions can be added to the XML version of a programming language that would probably never be added to the plain text version. There was once a proposal for the SVG vector file format that could be carried over into an XML document format. It was the <replicate> tag. But what is different about this is that it is not just a normal loop like a for or while loop, but pertains to a specific area, graphics, which means that different subjects of computing can bring their own custom tags into the programming language. Calling it replicate is more descriptive for its purpose than just loop or for. This <replicate> tag also carries multiple attributes using <replicationAttribute>, embedded inside the loop. They take action on properties of the graphical element.

<drawingCanvas name="drawingCanvas1">

<ellipse cy="-1000" cx="400" rx="30" ry="50" fill="url(#f)">
stroke-width=".5" stroke="none" >

<replicate repeatCount="140" >

<replicateAttribute attributeName="cy"
from="300" to="100" />
<replicateAttribute attributeName="transform" from="rotate(0 400 200)"
to="rotate(1240 400 200)" />
<replicateAttribute attributeName="ry"
from="100" to="15" />
<replicateAttribute attributeName="rx"
from="100" to="10" />
<replicateAttribute attributeName="opacity" from="1" to=".5" />

</replicate>

</ellipse>
</drawingCanvas>

Conclusion

There are many features to a programming language like C#, C++, etc., so finishing the full document format would be an extensive effort, to accommodate all features. But the benefits are greater interactivity, inclusion of multimedia features, and actual layout and organization to the code, such as accordions user interface controls.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Computer Code Needs a Document Format, But Typical Programmers Are Fixated on Using Plain Text - dFork
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] dFork has another article on this topic here, and it is explained how to convert a typical programming language to XML. […]

item.title: The TourBox: Interact with Pro Software by Configuring From an Assortment of Controls
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
The TourBox is a physical software controller providing the professional (media) computer user a mix of controls that can be adapted to most software applications. It is of particular value when there are live parameters to manipulate on screen or there are settings and tools that exist as an array of options for the user to switch between (different brushes, tools, for example).

This device is purchased by photographers, designers, and artists to provide themselves better interactions with pro software. For a long time, video editors have used video control decks. A keyboard and mouse cannot be considered sufficient controls for all software. It is just the norm today. The video control deck is the type of controller that can exist for other software.

Typically these devices are talked about in terms of the extra gains they provide, how they provide speed enhancements. It is faster, but placing a device like a TourBox NEO or Elite next to a computer and controlling pro software with it usually provides a leap in interactive normalcy, as in principle, pro software features should not be reduced to mouse and keyboard.

Complex software would necessarily benefit from controls beyond two click buttons and a scroll wheel on a mouse. There are no dials or knobs on a typical keyboard, but there are knobs, sliders, and dials in the software. So when there is a match between what is next to the keyboard and what is on the screen, there is going to be a gain.

When people feel this bit of normalcy return by buying a device (such as the TourBox), they talk about it like they have "augmented" their current computer setup. But it is not a matter of augmentation. Rather, it is a more expected relationship of physical controls to onscreen parameters, live options, and settings. In other words, it is like being handed a screwdriver instead of always being given a Swiss Army Knife (the mouse) when you are installing multiple screws.

dFork often mentions that the interactive contents of GUI windows for pro software resemble arrays of controls found on panels of a physical machine and, consistent with computer history, should not actually have their interface confined to mouse and keyboard. When computer graphics software was originally worked on in the 1970s and 1980s, there were devices to control the CAD or 3D modeling software besides the keyboard and mouse. It was just naturally understood that they went together.

This is especially the case when there is real-time interaction with various onscreen software mechanisms, with a video editing timeline being one of them. A video editing timeline is an onscreen simulation, through software, of a sliding mechanism for the displayed video sequence made of thumbnails. It is a kind of digital adaptation of film editing machines that were once used to edit actual film, but now it has been reshaped to the needs of software. Now in the form of a linear timeline machine-- a set of sliding mechanisms-- would be controlled through mechanical controls just the same.

Among other uses, the TourBox appears to have a lot of utility changing the brush width and other drawing implement characteristics for those who are using an illustration touchscreen device and stylus for illustration. The Facebook page of TourBox features an array images uploaded by TourBox users.

All of the device's controls user-definable through software. The website emphasizes that this device can control a lot of software, not just that made by Adobe. For manipulation of 3D models, having a dial, a scroll wheel, and a turning knob that clicks could be mapped to various functions of orbiting the scene camera or rotating the selected object.

The seeming benefit of the TourBox is the assortment of electronic control inputs, whereas other devices typically repeat a set of their controls. Popular among video game streamers, the Streamdeck is a tabular arrangement of buttons with LCD screens behind them. It does not have sliders or dials. A comparable product in this category, the Loupedeck Live, has 6 small knobs that are all the same in size and then eight LCD screen touch buttons. Each device has its own purpose. The TourBox seems well-suited among these devices for controlling apps specifically, as its goal is not to launch apps or global system functions.

There is, of course, nothing stopping a person from buying a Streamdeck to launch apps and then use the TourBox to control those apps.

This device serves a specific purpose by not having screens built into any of part of the device, in contrast to the Streamdeck or Loupedeck, both of which emphasize their dynamic LCD displays that serve as buttons.

Whereas the original NEO model is wired, the Elite version, first released a year later, is wireless via Bluetooth.

Promo Video from TourBox

In the image below uploaded to the Facebook page of TourBox, there is an illustration of how to configure the software for a custom illustration setup.

The Configuration Software

Without actually using the configuration software, nothing can be said in this article about it, so we won't. The name of the software that configures the device is called TourBox Console, available for both Mac and Windows.

It is important to mention the configuration software. User experience of the configuration software of these external devices makes an impact on the user more than a person would expect who has not used one of these devices. If the configuration software for any of these devices is ever difficult to use then user can become very unhappy, and can even have negative feelings. At the same time however, once a device is configured, it is often set for what the user is going to do with it. It is just very important that these apps are made easy to use, as there will be constant adjustments at the beginning.

The TourBox NEO Was Funded on Kickstarter, An All-or-Nothing Crowdfunding Website

The TourBox is another example of a success of all-or-nothing crowdfunding. Because of all-or-nothing collections, the technology world can purchase items that are considered niche like the TourBox, but which will actually point to a future revision of computer user interfaces, where the hardware that controls the software is not regarded as an external luxury but part of the overall setup.

The Best Outcome

In the future, it is best if there is software specifically developed around a device like the TourBox. Pro apps were designed for a conventional usage of a desktop computer with keyboard and mouse. This means that when the software developers made the interfaces, such as the toolbars and parameter panels, they did not consider external devices like the TourBox. If someone does make software around a device like the TourBox, it might be something very improved.

To conclude, take a look at the interactive setup of an early CAD system below. Though it looks outdated by having so many controls, those can help get the job done in a better way.

item.title: For The VJ (Video Jockey): Live Performance Software
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
What Is a VJ? Its Distant Connections to The Avant Garde

The 2010s experienced a growing, worldwide interest in DJs performing at festivals and arena venues, and frequently these DJs have had digital media playing behind them, sometimes in unconventional lighting setups. The person who controls that, either at a club or a small modern art gallery, is often called the VJ.

A VJ (short for "video jockey") is a performer or artist who uses video and audio technology to create and manipulate visual media in real time, often as part of a live performance. The real concept of what a VJ refers to really came to prominence in the 1990s, when electronic music reached a new stage called "electronica", in which the technology had advanced beyond the 1980s, with many more mainstream music albums being made from synthesizer sounds and those sounds were made from more advanced equipment than what was available in the 1980s. Thus, as the sounds advanced, there was a corresponding advancement of the audiovisual performance.

As a category of moving images, this type of video performance goes back to avante garde filmmaking of the 1960s and 1970s, in which many short films did not contain narrative or story content and sought not to make films as they exist in cinema. As clubs came into existence in the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s, often complex backdrops were a desired feature.

Avant-garde cinema and performance art have also been important influences on the development of VJ culture. Many VJs draw inspiration from avant-garde filmmakers and artists who have explored the use of new technologies and unconventional techniques in their work. VJing itself can be seen as an avant-garde practice, as it often involves the use of new technologies and the creation of unconventional visual experiences.

For the most part today, VJs use a combination software applications, hardware controllers, and live video and audio inputs, to create a visual experience that is synchronous with music or other audio sources.

VJs may work in a variety of settings, including clubs, concerts, festivals, and other live events, as well as in television and film production. They may also create and perform audiovisual installations or multimedia artworks.

In a live performance setting, VJs may work alongside DJs or other musicians, using video and audio technology to create a visual accompaniment to the music. They may also create original video content or use pre-existing media, such as film clips, animations, or live video feeds.

Some common software tools used by VJs include VDMX, Resolume, and Modul8. These are often used in combination with external controllers like MIDI controllers and other hardware devices. VJs may also use live video and audio inputs, such as cameras, microphones, and other sensors, to capture and manipulate real-time video and audio.

VDMX (Mac OS only)

VDMX (VideoDraw Mixer) is a software application for Mac OS that allows its users to create and perform real-time audio and video compositions. It is often used in live performance settings, as well as for music video production, VJing (visual performance art).

Node-based programming is available for this software, but the key difference is that the program is meant to be used in a real-time or live setting. So, while many types of programs feature node-based programming setups, they are generally for code compilation for a final program or output, such as a 3D scene.

VDMX features such a node-based interface, and it allows users to create custom audio and video processing chains using a variety of "patches," or pre-designed processing node modules. These nodes can be connected in a variety of ways to create complex, dynamic audio and video effects, such as color correction, image warping, audio analysis and synthesis, and more.

Node-based programming is often very difficult to control, but it is a key resource for lots of software today, such as the procedural 3D modeling tool Houdini and the generation of texture for the 3D software Blender. It is also used in Unreal Engine under the marketed name, "Blueprints".

MIDI and OSC (Open Sound Control) for real-time control and synchronization with other software and hardware.

What is MIDI?

MIDI (Musical Instrument Digital Interface) is a protocol that allows computers and other electronic devices to communicate with each other and with musical instruments. It is widely used in the music industry for a variety of applications, including recording, production, and performance.

MIDI data consists of messages that are sent between devices, specifying things like what notes are being played on a keyboard, what parameters are being adjusted on a synthesizer, or what kind of data is being transmitted between devices. MIDI messages are sent over a MIDI connection, which can be a physical connection (such as a MIDI cable) or a wireless connection (such as Bluetooth MIDI).

MIDI is a flexible protocol that can be used to transmit a wide range of data, including information about pitch, velocity, timing, and other performance parameters. It is commonly used to control synthesizers, drum machines, and other electronic musical instruments, as well as to synchronize different devices and software applications in a music production or performance setup.

In addition to its use in the music industry, MIDI is also used in a variety of other applications, such as lighting and stage design, video game development, and interactive installations.

VDMX is widely used in the electronic music and visual performance communities, and has a strong following among VJs, visual artists, and music producers. It is known for its powerful audio and video processing capabilities, as well as its flexible and customizable interface.

Modul8 (Mac OS Only)

Produced by garageCube, who are also the makers of MadMapper, a software application which assists in the making of projection mappings onto physical environments, Modul8 is a software application for Mac OS that allows users to create and perform real-time audio and video compositions. Like VDMX, it is often used in live performance settings, as well as for music video production, VJing (visual performance art), and other forms of audiovisual media.

One key difference between Modul8 and VDMX is their user interface and workflow.

Both Modul8 and VDMX are widely used in the electronic music and visual performance communities.

If you want to do an advanced VJ show that incorporates projection mapping, modul8 can be coupled with madMapper[...]! Sharing content between the two applications is easy thanks to built-in support for the open source Syphon framework.

modul8.com

The choice of what live performance software to use depends on the specific needs and preferences of the user, as well as the type of project or performance they are working on.

Resolume (Mac OS Only)

item.title: Kid Pix: Interactive Software That Existed in a Category of Its Own
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
For the most part, whenever video, sound effects, and imagery are all combined into an interactive experience, no output is produced by the user. Instead, it means that video games are being played, especially when it comes to children, teenagers, and now adults.

If it is video being produced by software, then there is a video editor program for that alone. If it is graphics the user makes, then there is vector graphics editor software. And then if it is sound, then there is a music composition or musical instrument program, and so one. All of these tasks are separated. Production of media is usually confined to real-world consumption: video will play on a television, audio on stereo speakers, and graphics reside on printed media.

All of this makes sense, but that isn't entirely how the future of software looked in 1989 after the introduction of Craig Hickman's Kid Pix software, because it came with implications about software that were relevant to more than producing painting software for children. Even though it was interactive software meant for children, at the time even adults could appreciate Kid Pix for how it made use of the computer's capabilities to produce sound and graphics at the same time.

A person uploaded a demonstration of version 1.2 of the software in a YouTube video:

Below, at the 6:45 mark (autoplays at that point), there is a demo of Kid Pix from a Broderbund employee:

Kid Pix (1989)

The Story of Kid Pix

Kid Pix was first authored by one person (in a period when producing computer software was more straightforward but limited to few people), a computer programmer named Craig Hickman. Hickman was very pleased after coming across the Macintosh in its early years, and he produce some small computer programs with it for practice, include one that produced an animation. Later he eventually decided to make a black-and-white drawing program for his child, one that was an alternative to the MacPaint program included with the Macintosh. This was not originally a start-up endeavor. Instead, it was part of what Hickman wanted to do with the computer. After observing his son use MacPaint, he thought it was easy to use but not ready for a very young child's use of the computer.

Kid Pix is a software item obscured for most people who use the computer today, as it hasn't received a major update in more than a decade. Nevertheless, the making of the first Kid Pix program is a topic that has interested many people who once used Kid Pix in the 1990s, and Craig provided a full account on his website: Kid Pix - The Early Years.

A person might want to know how Hickman came about making this software because other software like it has not come along since, but at the end of this article we talk about some ways to continue what Kid Pix was doing into a more finished form. According to the article by Hickman, he made a list of requirements for himself for the software, which would make the program suitable for children's use:

1. (The Prime Directive) The program should be extremely easy to use. No manual should be needed and program features should "explain themselves" through use. All tasks should be able to be performed in the simplest, most straightforward way. The program should go out of its way to meet the user.

2. As long as The Prime Directive is not violated, every opportunity should be taken to make the program surprising and satisfying to use. No opportunity should be missed. The process of making a picture should be as important as the picture produced.

3. The program should, in some way, expand the concept of what computer paint programs are, as well as what mark making can be.

4. The program should be open ended. Premade graphics should be modifiable by the user.

5. I wanted each tool to have a large number of options but I didn't want the user to be overwhelmed with options. I didn't want to use pull-down menus for this because, among other reasons, Ben had trouble with them. The system I developed involved displaying a selection of 14 options for each tool in a window at the bottom of the screen. As the tool selection changed, the options changed.

It is #3 that has made the topic of Kid Pix something of interest to people among Mac enthusiasts. Hickman released early versions of Kid Pix for free, which were distributed on informal computer networks of the time, and he found regular checks in the mail. Though not mentioned in the article, this was termed "shareware" at the time because the software was free to share but often provided an address where a person could send a check. Later, he approached publisher Broderbund, who eventually published it in 1991.

Not bound by the conventional requirements of a graphics program, sometimes the tools that Kid Pix provided implied possibilities for future graphics software, though it isn't brought up very often today. To be sure, Kid Pix cannot produce output beyond the what is in a children's computer program because its goal was just to be a painting app for children to use. Its output turns into digital fingerpainting for children, but entertaining. It might not have to be useless for adults to use in a redo of the app, but that is how it is in the earliest version.

There was the entertaining use of interactive controls that everyone could laugh at. For example, for there is the "Undo Guy" who says "oh no!" every time he is clicked to undo a drawing action. There is the truck tool that drags around squares of the image directly. With the truck tool, pressing the mouse button and dragging cuts off a 100x100 pixel portion of the image and drags it with the mouse. As this is happening there is a sound effect of a truck hauling something.

It demonstrated that the combination of sound effects, images, and live interaction with the computer could produce a different class of software activity for people who were using these relatively new GUI computers, that they could be making, producing, and consuming experiences that combined all of the technologies.

Years have passed since the original 1989 Macintosh version of Kid Pix came out, but in some ways the software has been been left in a category of its own in the area of interactive software. Different software vendors have owned licensing rights to Kid Pix over the years and they all have made different editions. The last version includes tools for making digital stories by children.

  1. Kid Pix Deluxe (1989): The original version of Kid Pix, released for Macintosh computers followed by the 1991 commercial release by Broderbund.
  2. Kid Pix Deluxe 3D (1998): A version of Kid Pix that added 3D graphics and animation capabilities.
  3. Kid Pix Deluxe 4 (2002): The fourth version of Kid Pix, released for Windows and Macintosh computers.
  4. Kid Pix Studio Deluxe (2004): A version of Kid Pix that included additional features such as a movie maker, music maker, and tools for creating interactive presentations.
  5. Kid Pix Deluxe 5 (2007): The fifth version of Kid Pix, released for Windows and Macintosh computers.
  6. Kid Pix Deluxe 3D (2013): A version of Kid Pix that was re-released for newer computers, with updated graphics and improved 3D animation capabilities.
  7. Kid Pix Deluxe 3D (2019): The latest version of Kid Pix, released for Windows and Macintosh computers.

Mario Paint (1992)

A year after the first Kid Pix was sold by Broderbund, including a version it translated for Japan, Nintendo released its contribution to this category, Mario Paint, for its Super Nintendo video game system, and the product was packaged with a mouse and keyboard, unlike the video games that just came with a cartridge. It would be hard to believe that Nintendo had not come across Kid Pix and its Japanese version. But Nintendo added an animation sequencer to its own product. It also included a music composer. So, whereas a young person might use Kid Pix for a while and have fun, Super Nintendo players could be a little older and they might use Mario Paint for longer because they could make animations and melodies with that played through the television. Simply put, the first version of Kid Pix deposited images on the still image canvas and then later added recording features for making animations and so on.

Mario Paint was pushing the constraints of the Super Nintendo hardware, which has a modified version of the CPU shipped with the Apple IIGS (the successor to the Apple II). It only had 256224 pixels to work with for any game cartridge. The software Mario Paint and Kid Pix are some of the few in this category of interactive drawing applications that are designed for children but often appreciated by adults as well.

Below is a set of commercials for Mario Paint. The first few aired in Japan whereas the later ones aired in the United States.

Kid Pix Versions

As time has passed and disk space has become larger, Kid Pix corresponding included more sophisticated

screenshot

Making a Comparable Interactive Media Production App But for Regular Computer Users

Here is a list:

  • The presets, stock video and stock animations will be different, tailored for serious uses.
  • The whole of the app remains easy to use for leisure but not to the extend that the output would not be of value in the future.
  • Audio tracks would be provided so that people can match them.
  • A timeline and keyframe sequencer would have to be different so that it is still part of a leisure situation.

This would provide regular computer users a form of recreation that is not video games, which is not available for them at the current time.

item.title: Smalltalk: The Programming Language That Influences Most Application Code Running Today
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Programming languages today have been highly influenced by Smalltalk, a programming language made in the 1970s. Many people in computer science believe that the original goals of Smalltalk have not been represented by the latest in modern computing, even though Smalltalk was made in the 1970s on much earlier computers.

At some point, nearly all computer users have heard of the programming languages C++, Java (and often Python as well). These and all programming languages used to make commercial software have roots in an earlier programming language developed at the now famous Xerox PARC lab in the 1970s. It was called Smalltalk. Xerox PARC is the source of many personal computer technologies in the current environment, including graphical user interfaces (buttons and windows), the laser printer, ethernet (locally-networked computers), computer displays made out of pixels, and the use of a mouse with this setup. Highly secretive at the time of its existence, it was the place where a large array of technologies emerged that have impacted how everyone interacts with the computer. Its impact can be attributed in part to the concentrated effort in organizing the research center itself, that only the most qualified individuals in a range of fields were invited. Xerox PARC's stated research mission was to create "the office of the future." It was Jobs' visit to PARC that led to the Macintosh and in some major aspects the Macintosh Apple produced was a limited product compare to the software on PARC machines.

The name of the first Xerox computer was the Alto. Enabling all of this on the programming side in the Alto machine was Smalltalk, a programming language devised in majority part by Alan Kay and Dan Ingalls. Kay had a long interest in the field of pedagogy, various learning theories from psychologists, and he incorporated that into many aspects of the Alto's software environment.

Smalltalk and Object-Oriented Programming

Normally, when talking about computer programming, a non-specialist, or someone just beginning to learn programming, considers the code being executed in terms of how its proceeds, that the computer executes one line, then goes to another line and executes that. Though that is one way programming languages had existed, it isn't suitable to stay in that way of programming for making graphical user interfaces that contain windows, scroll bars, and buttons.

In particular, Smalltalk popularized and developed the concept of using "objects" in computer code, instead of just sequential execution of instructions. It went beyond having the programming language make procedure blocks of code (i.e. functions) that refer to one another.

In that case of the graphical user interface, in which there are displayed objects on screen like buttons, the computer code is better structured in such a way that it can be regarded as blueprints for these onscreen controls. These are programmer-made templates of sorts that the computer can use every time it wants to make that kind of object on screen, like a window or button. This is more preferable than just programming the window as linear blocks of code that execute instructions and refer to one another. The influential C programming language largely exists like that, being without any objects.

These "objects" demonstrated by Smalltalk, and present in code today, are in fact like collections of data that contain everything an onscreen control would need: for a button it contains data for what the title is of the button, how big the button is, what happens when it is clicked. The object blueprint for a button is structured this way.

Every object on the screen on a modern computer (a button, a window, the close button) is actually represented in code files as this blueprinted "object" concept that Smalltalk popularized. At the same time that Smalltalk improved computer programming with this "object", the concept of an "object" in code also enabled consistent programming of the GUI.

As mentioned, C did not have objets. That is a reason why C++ was first made. It is often used to make GUI software instead of C: its main feature was implementing a version of Smalltalk's "objects" on top of C, as a set of add-ons.

Once a blueprint is made for an object, like a window, it can produce an instance of that object many times, and each time it will contain the same collection of data (window title, window position, window size) because it comes from that blueprint. The window object contains methods that allow it to perform certain actions, such as opening, closing, or resizing. Whereas C could be made to do that, this is more appropriate for the job.

If someone wants to make a different kind of window, as an offshoot from that first window blueprint, they can do so and they don't have to make the first blueprint. For example, let's say they want to make a window with a smaller titlebar and that's it. By telling the computer that the new blueprint should inherit all of the properties of the first window blueprint, the programmer can change or add to the properties of the original blueprint-- without affecting the original window blueprint. He or she can make a copy of the original window blueprint just by referring to its name, then just change a few things.

Because these object blueprints can be exchanged among people, it makes the computer programming very flexible, for all kinds of purposes. The data on the computer can be represented in terms of an object, so can images, event paragraphs of text.

Also important is that these objects can be told that others exist and then send them information. This was a key part of Kay's strategy for Smalltalk, that the objects could send messages to each other. So, the window object that shows up on screen as a window, for example, is actually set up to send "messages" to the window manager object and vice-versa. If a window moves or closes, it will tell the window manager what it is doing. Both are "objects" in code. The window manager object manages all of the window objects.

Smalltalk discussed this in terms of "message passing", but the way it is implemented in code today isn't quite as complex or deep as that sounds. It usually amounts to activating functions (calling routines) that reside in the other object.

By representing objects as conceptual structures in code, object-oriented programming allows developers to create reusable software components that can be easily combined and modified to meet specific needs of a project.

Xerox PARC, Smalltalk, and The Goals of Alan Kay

While many modern programming languages have adopted some of the key concepts and features of object-oriented programming, they are said by Kay not to have fully embodied the broader goals that Kay and his colleagues were trying to promote with Smalltalk.

Bruce Horn, who was in his teens at the time he was shown Xerox computers, worked on the Macintosh. He said in 1996:

In many ways, the computing world has made remarkably small advances since 1976, and we continually reinvent the wheel. Smalltalk had a nice bytecoded multi-platform virtual machine long before Java [dFork editor: the programs could run without needing to be compiled and could run on multiple processor types]. Object oriented programming is the hot thing now, and it's almost 30 years old (see the Simula-67 language). Environments have not progressed much either: I feel the Smalltalk environments from the late 1970's are the most pleasant, cleanest, fastest, and smoothest programming environments I have ever used. Although CodeWarrior is reasonably good for C++ development, I haven't seen anything that compares favorably to the Smalltalk systems I used almost 20 years ago. The Smalltalk systems of today aren't as clean, easy to use, or well- designed as the originals, in my opinion.

"Where It All Began" - Folklore.org

Object-oriented programming was first discussed in the 1960s by Ole-Johan Dahl and Kristen Nygaard, the creators of the Simula programming language. Simula was the first programming language to use the concept of classes (that make the blueprints for objects) and objects , and it is considered to be the first object-oriented programming language. However, it was Smalltalk, which was developed in the 1970s, that brought the concept of OOP to the forefront and popularized it.

Since its development, Smalltalk has had a significant influence on the development of many other programming languages, including C++, Java, and Objective-C, which have all adopted many of the key concepts and features of OOP. As a result, OOP has become one of the most widely used programming frameworks (as in framework for how to carry out a task) in the world, and it is now used in the development of a wide variety of software applications.

According to Kay, the OOP that is often associated with modern programming languages is a limited version of the OOP that he and his colleagues were trying to promote with Smalltalk. Kay believes that computers have become part of a "pop culture" that prioritizes commercial and competitive pressures and this has put a "low pass filter" on the work that was done in the 1970s.

Links:

Interview with Alan Kay from ACM: https://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=1039523

Video:

The video below was for a product that was not sold. A later one was, called the Xerox Star.
