item.title: Product Crowdfunding Across The World
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Did you know that product crowdfunding takes place in other countries? That there are different kinds of all-or-nothing crowdfunding websites, with a few specializing in their own categories, such as one for electronics designers? Most people believe product crowdfunding is limited to Kickstarter and IndieGoGo. But there are a few dozen active crowdfunding websites in other countries. Also, Kickstarter and IndieGoGo both operate in many countries outside of the United States and Canada, which may be a reason there are not as many in other countries. But there are some made by entrepreneurs local to that country.

Japan

In Japan, Campfire (https://camp-fire.jp/) is a crowdfunding platform that is similar to Kickstarter and Indiegogo. It was founded in 2011 and has funded a wide range of projects, including artistic projects, social impact projects, and technology projects.

Other crowdfunding platforms that are available in Japan include:

Makuake (https://www.makuake.com/): This platform has funded a wide range of projects, including social impact projects, and business ventures.

Motion Gallery (https://www.motion-gallery.net/): This platform focuses on film, animation, and other media projects. (Also: https://basic.motion-gallery.net/)

United Kingdom

In the UK, Unbound (https://www.unbound.com/) is a crowdfunding platform that focuses on funding books, magazines, and other printed media. It has funded a wide range of projects, including novels, cookbooks, art books. Project organizers on Unbound can offer a variety of rewards to backers, including signed copies of their books, personalized dedications, and other special perks.

Netherlands

Voordekunst (https://www.voordekunst.nl/) is a crowdfunding platform that is based in the Netherlands and is available in Belgium as well. It was founded in 2010 and has funded over 3,000 creative projects to date, including art, design, and music projects.

Voordekunst allows creators to set up crowdfunding campaigns to raise funds for their projects. Backers can support projects by pledging a certain amount of money in exchange for rewards, which can be anything from a digital copy of the finished project to a personalized version of the project.

Voordekunst also has a "Voordekunst Academy" program, which provides project organizers with resources and support to help them successfully fund their projects.

South Korea

Tumblbug (https://www.tumblbug.com/) has funded a wide range of successful projects, including art, design, music, and film projects.

Makestar (https://www.makestar.co/), labeled "Korean Wave Cultulre" or k-culture crowdfunding website, funds projects related to South Korean pop culture, like k-pop, including albums, concerts, and games.

Niche Product Crowdfunding Websites

Crowd Supply (https://www.crowdsupply.com/) is a crowdfunding platform that focuses on hardware and electronics projects. It was founded in 2012.

Crowd Supply helps project organizers bring their hardware and electronics projects to market by providing resources and support for prototyping, manufacturing, and crowdfunding campaigns. It also helps with fulfillment and distribution, so creators can focus on developing their products.

Project organizers on Crowd Supply can set up crowdfunding campaigns to raise funds for their projects. Backers can support projects by pledging a certain amount of money in exchange for rewards, which can be anything from a digital copy of the finished product to a fully assembled version of the product.

Crowd Supply has funded a wide range of hardware and electronics projects, including consumer electronics, scientific instruments, and industrial equipment. It provides a platform for electronics engineers and hardware designers to connect with backers and bring their products to a concrete form.

More from Other Countries:

Russia: Boomstarter (https://www.boomstarter.ru/)

Germany: Startnext (https://www.startnext.com/)

France: KissKissBankBank (https://www.kisskissbankbank.com/)

Italy: Eppela (https://www.eppela.com/)

Spain: Verkami (https://www.verkami.com/)

Brazil: Benfeitoria (https://www.benfeitoria.com/)

Indonesia: Kitabisa (https://www.kitabisa.com/)

Netherlands: Oneplanetcrowd (https://www.oneplanetcrowd.com/)

Poland: PolakPotrafi (https://www.polakpotrafi.pl/), Zrzutka (https://www.zrzutka.pl/)

Switzerland: WeMakeIt (https://www.wemakeit.com/)

Denmark: Boomerang (https://www.boomerang.dk/)

Norway: FundedByMe (https://www.fundedbyme.com/)

item.title: The Looking Glass Display
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
It is possible there could someday be a technological future where computer monitors are not limited to displaying imagery in a flattened format. Instead, many objects could extend from the screen into 3D. The Looking Glass, a semi-holographic display, possibly provides a glimpse into what a holographic computing experience might be.

The Looking Glass display is a technology that utilizes light fields to create 3D, holographic-like images. A light field is a collection of light rays that contain information about the direction and intensity of light. By capturing and recreating this information across a densely packed array of LEDs, it is possible to create the illusion of a 3D image that can be viewed from multiple angles.

The images are captured from different angles and broken up into sequences that can be processed and displayed by the device.

In the below video, a maker of classic video games, Jeff Minter of Llamasoft, attempted to convert one of his games to the first model of the display in 2019. He mentioned on his website that there were some issues along the way.

The Looking Glass is usually regarded as semi-holographic because the conventional definition of a hologram or a holographic display is one that can generate free-standing, full-scale moving imagery in a room or a large space, which so far has not occurred. To accomplish that there would have to be a technology to suspend the images in mid air, such that if a person touched them he or she would not be touching the setup that produces the images in any way. Since this is not yet available, the founder of Looking Glass attempted to get around this by stacking layers of very small, densely-packed LEDs in an acrylic plastic and then lighting them up such that they generate light fields similar to the originally captured objects, which were recorded from different angles. The first model of the Looking Glass worked that way, just like the objects that are sometimes cast inside transparent acrylic, except that what was in the acrylic was the electronic LEDs like those on a computer monitor. This has to be a semi-holographic approach because it confines the imagery that the devices can produce to the physical set up that produces light fields. The Looking Glass is more like a very advanced version of a live optical illusion frame a person would encounter at a funhouse or carnival, and when the company attempts to scale up that frame, it becomes more expensive. In videos, viewers are consistently reacting strongly to the results.

The Looking Glass display uses a combination of specialized software and hardware to capture and recreate light fields, allowing users to experience 3D holographic images in a way that emulates the way physical objects are viewed in the real world. Regular computer 3D models and scenes can be imported into the device's software tools (which are extensions for Unity). The display is promoted for a wide range of applications, including gaming, design, and more.

A Project Enabled by All-or-Nothing Crowdfunding

The Looking Glass display is a technology that was made possible through the use of crowdfunding. Specifically, Shawne Frayne and his team at Looking Glass Factory used the all-or-nothing crowdfunding platform Kickstarter to fund the development of their first model.

Most viewers of dFork are familiar with all-or-nothing crowdfunding, a type of crowdfunding in which a project only receives funding if it meets its financial goal within a certain time frame. If the goal is not met, the project does not receive any funding. This type of crowdfunding is often used for projects that require a significant amount of funding, such as the development of a new technology. But conventional channels of funding will often not take a risk on these endeavors.

The first model of the Looking Glass display was successfully funded on Kickstarter in 2018, with the campaign reaching its goal within a few weeks. This success allowed Frayne and his team to move forward with finalizing the technology they had and eventually release the first version of the Looking Glass display to the public.

The success of the Kickstarter campaign also helped to attract investment from outside sources, allowing Looking Glass Factory to continue developing and improving the technology. When it came time to release a new model in 2020, Looking Glass once again looked to all-or-nothing crowdfunding to confirm demand for the product, ensuring that they would not lose money.

item.title: How The Etch-A-Sketch Could Be Made into a Finished Device: Add Just Two Controls That Address Its Shortcomings
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
If the Etch-A-Sketch had nothing intriguing about it, people wouldn't keep buying it and it wouldn't have stuck around for so long. Even though it has a lot of shortcomings, there has to be a reason many people have positive feelings toward it.

To fix the Etch-A-Sketch, such that it might actually be carried around by adults, there are two controls that can be added. Doing thisaddresses the initial problems in the device. It will also reveal why people liked the original Etch-A-Sketch.

How do we do this and you haven't seen this addressed? We work in this area in software, called vector-drawing or vector illustration. Drawing machines relate to vector-drawing interfaces.

Two Controls to Fix The Etch-A-Sketch

1. A Means to Turn Off The Drawing Tip

In the Etch-A-Sketch, how it makes lines is the removal of the silver powder from underneath the plastic by a traveling tip. (Shaking the Etch-A-Sketch scatters the silver powder back onto the glass and "erases" the drawing.) But because the tip has no mechanism for being pushed down, it always removes silver powder, always. The first and most obvious problem is that you cannot stop it from drawing. So, the first addition is a button that depressed (turns off) the drawing point so that it can be relocated on the page without making any marks on the drawing.

A button that presses the internal frame down by a few millimeters, each time to suspend drawing, would likely solve this issue, though this is just at first glance. In the mechanics of the device, this would push down the traveling tip so that it doesn't remove any silver dust from the back of the surface. An issue that comes up afterwards is that the entire screen is coated in silver powder, so the tip would have to be visible when it is not removing the powder. Perhaps when this additional button is pressed, it would make an LED light glow on the tip so that the user of the Etch-A-Sketch knows the location of the tip while it moves. Currently the user of the Etch-A-Sketch knows where it is because it touches the glass and thus removes the silver powder.

2. A Directional Knob To Control The Angle of The Drawing Point

When an Etch-A-Sketch is made, it is provide two knobs, with one controlling the horizontal movement and the other controlling the vertical movement of the tip. The problem of course is that anything other than 90 degree lines is difficult.

The second addition we suggest is a directional knob. This knob will change the angle of the drawing point so that it can be locked to 5 degree increments. This way, the user can easily get to certain angles and draw polygonal shapes. But, it should have a nearby switch, possibly placed within the knob itself, to unlock the increments as well, so that it can freely move the angle outside of the 5 degree increments. This will require a set of modifications and additions to the mechanics of the Etch-A-Sketch. But without it, the Etch-A-Sketch is somewhat absurd, only able to naturally draw lines in 90 degree increments.

The Key-Click UI

Now we will talk about our own software, which is in the same discussion as an Etch-A-Sketch that has been fixed for regular use, because our software draws hard lines too. It does it in a way that is different, in a way that is modifying the existing software setup shipped to all computers today. Fortunately, its rather straightforward to try out in a demo we provide on this website. Instead of using mouse buttons to lay down points, you don't use the mouse buttons, you use keys instead.

Floating Marker: A Set of Drawing Machines in Software

To use software that is even faster than what a modified Etch-A-Sketch would accomplish, that makes use of the key-click UI take a look at Noctivagous' Floating Marker web page. Just like how the Etch-A-Sketch as it is shipped today is too constrained, so is a vector-editing application that a person can buy today. We just fixed the Etch-A-Sketch and made it something actually useful for a grown person. Floating Marker is going for the same outcome in software by modifying the existing interactive setup of mouse and keyboard, to draw lines rapidly. Since we have these computers and it takes a lot to manufacture them, they shouldn't cause us trouble when we want to put down vector graphics, they usually do. But with Floating Marker, you can use the mouse and keyboard in such a way that your computer feels like a fluid drawing machine. Take a look, in the video below:

Read more at http://floatingmarker.app.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: <iframe title="Floating Marker: Live Product Design Doodle 1 (90 Repl.)" width="640" height="480" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/JTjfK3A7_-0?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" allowfullscreen></iframe>

item.title: Taking Another Approach to The Joystick: Looking at Camera Tripod Grip Mechanisms and Dollies
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
If the interface of a game is more accurate, it will be hard to play only when the game is hard in terms of the state of the game. Some video games are hard to play because their controls do not match accurately what is on the screen. To put it differently, for video games to be considered closer to a skill, the interface of the machines has to be improved so that it is more accurate. For example, how much force is applied to a tennis racket changes how far the ball goes. But video game buttons are actually not sensitive to force, either the standard joystick or the buttons. It doesn't matter how hard you press the buttons on the games or how much force is applied on the joystick: the hardware does not detect this.

Considered the first arcade video game, Pong, produced by Atari, was controlled by knobs, not a joystick in fact. There have been a variety of controls incorporated into arcade machines, with some featuring special setups designed specifically for that game. The arcade version of Paperboy, regarded as a classic in which a paperboy rides dodges obstacles along his paper route, makes use of its own mock bicycle handles in place of the joystick. But the joystick has long been the dominant interface for most arcade games, paired with 2 to 8 buttons. Other controls might include rolling balls for games that involve rolling a ball in the game.

What is an example of a good interface? A video editing control deck that controls the computer's sequence of images for editing video. Compared to this apparatus, arcade machines in general have provided inadequate controls for what is on the screen. But in fact, video games were made for entertainment and were not taken as a big deal initially in the 1980s, which means that the standards for the interface were never as high. The games were supposed to be for amusement, such as for pizza parlors, playable by anyone and not just dedicated video game enthusiasts. For the most part, the interfaces were regarded as novelty, such as the Power Glove. So, the video game companies and hardware companies were not that worried about whether the joystick matched the action on the screen.

But if we take up improving the interface of these machines anyway given how much more weight has been given to them today, including the production of "gamer chairs", then we should consider some of these controls. To the author, neither the rolling ball nor the joystick feels right relative to what is on the screen. To give an example, there is the arcade game Puzzle Bobble, which would benefit from a custom interface because it is manipulating the boat wheel in steps. Instead, it used the joystick, making it harder to play.

Despite its widespread use, the joystick has always been an unsatisfying interface. The benefit of the joystick and its endurance is that it prevents any kind of repetitive motion strain on the player's hands because he or she doesn't come into contact with the ball of the stick for very long.

It could be said that video games have never had proper interfaces and that the interfaces provided for them have remained too simple for a long time. For one, when pressing a button, it does not detect the force applied; Mario jumps the same height whether you press the button hard or soft. A different kind of control might change that and make the video games more vivid in experience.

When talking about replacing the joystick, the goal is not to add enhancements, like vibrations that give the impression of experiencing action in the game. It is the overall configuration that can be updated into a different form.

Implementing an Alternative Using Camera Tripod Mechanisms As a Basis

Instead of beginning with a list of problems with the joystick, here is a path for the video games that allow for large physical controls, such as those placed in a standing cabinet in an arcade. After this is produced, probably a smaller version can come about. The author was handling a mobile phone adapter for a camera tripod (it is called the SideKick360) and he noticed that the mechanism, if it were placed on a larger moving framework of some sort, could be a very precise and smooth interface for controlling games. The part that gripped the mobile phone from two ends attached to the mount with a ball grip.

This points to how the panning and tilting motions provided by a camera grip on a tripod are a starting point for what could control a character game, potentially a very good match for onscreen activity. Camera tripods, especially those meant for video because they are designed for a path of movement by the camera, address issues similar to those found in controlling a video game's onscreen character. The camera has to move in the environment in a stable way for the tripod user. Some tripods have accessory dollies that they are mounted on which allows backwards and forward motions. Others are part of rigs that can move with the subject, such as a Steadicam (photo). There are many consumer camera products with gimbal controls that could be used as a reference for a different controller device that controls a game. In a video game, the automobile on a road or racetrack is moving according to rotational controls by way of a large steering wheel, but a steering wheel arcade interface might not be the only way to control that rotational movement, and this is the impression a person gets while using many camera tripod products.

When video game interfaces improve like this, a major benefit is that the software industry might get better controls for 3D modeling software and other types of software. Of course, the software industry does not have to wait for that to happen.

A Tripod Gimbal That Is Not Stationary

What the player of a video game would want, in place of the joystick, is something more like a tripod gimbal, but one that does not remain stationary. The joystick always remains stationary, which hinders what it can provide. This different kind of device might be placed on a dolly track, flat with the surface of the arcade machine, and it would be able to move around within the constraints of its tracks in both the horizontal and vertical directions. For example, if you placed a grip in the middle of a rod on a foosball table (in between where the plastic players are), but also allowed movement straight ahead and backwards along the top of the foosball table, you would already be off to an improved start for an interface that controls an arcade machine. The sliding action of the rod is a constraint, it would just have a gimbal placed on top of it perhaps.

The joystick is unpleasant to use because it remains stationary and is too simple. It is actually a directional pad (the arrows), with an elongated stick situation in the middle that activates the pad, which is why on some home controllers it can be unscrewed and removed. It feels disconnected from the kind of movement the person is trying to make for the game because it only does this one thing, which is activate a directional pad. It also has a bobble movement to it when controlling what is in the game, in which it bounces back.

The joystick doesn't provide a feeling of controlling anything, just activating certain inputs of the machine momentarily. It is maybe is about 1/3 of what it should be in terms of matching what it is referencing for the games. For one, it leans at an angle to activate the direction it is being moved. It would be better if the entire stick remained perpendicular to the surface of the controls, but it has to lean over.

That the use of it is always momentary is an issue. The top of the joystick is pushed sporadically, not really gripped to be controlled, as a person might with a camera tripod grip. The player is gripping the ball or the top of the joystick, but the point of action for the player of the game is not the ball of the joystick. There was an exception to this, an arcade game called Ikari Warriors (1986). In this custom setup that only this one manufacturer seems to have produced, the video game makes use of a rotary dial placed on the top of the joystick. Rotating it changes the direction of the onscreen character as it moves in a top-down combat environment. This is something different but it is not a lot better because the base situation is still the same.

Buttons with Force Sensitivity

For another article, we will talk about how the buttons need to be improved so that they actually detect how much force is applied to them by the player.

item.title: Countdown Timers for Stop Lights
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
It's easy to find yourself at an intersection where the light could turn green for you because there is no other traffic, but the signal remains red anyway because it follows the programming. Although it takes into account that your car has driven over the strips of metal that it uses to detect the presence of a car, it does not know that it should just immediately change the signal for you. This would be an area called smart traffic lights, but it does not appear to be a big research subject at the current time. However, replacing those metal strips in some areas of the country are cameras analyzing the traffic at the intersection. They do use artificial intelligence, in an area of computing called "computer vision". They know where the cars, pedestrians, and bicycles are.

Notably, this is what the traffic signal does for itself. This use of A.I. is still not informing the drivers of what is happening at the intersection.

Even though traffic signals make up a large part of people's lives, there isn't much discussion about them in technology news. In part that is because there isn't a lot of public information about them. There is always a general sense by the public that something can be done to improve traffic signals, without much actual results occurring year after year. But there is a device already in use in countries across the world that can improve the driver's experience, and it is called the countdown timer. It tells the drivers how much time is left before the red light turns green or vice-versa.

A countdown timer fulfills that need just to discussed, to provide more indication of what is happening to driving public. Too often when a traffic signal is taking a long time the question arises whether there is something wrong with it. This device can also provide assurance to the driver that the light is in order if it is taking a long time by provide.

Countdown Timers

The official name is Traffic Signal Countdown Timer (TSCT). These are are accessories for a traffic signal device that count down the number of seconds until the light changes, informing the driver(s) at the intersection.

There are two modes for them: the first mode provides a countdown timer for the red until the signal turns green, reducing the impatience caused by long wait times at red lights. The second mode is for the green, counting down the remaining seconds before the green light changes to yellow. A locale may decide to install one or both.

There are numerous advantages provided by installing them, and readers who would like a thorough dive can read this research article and this one from Oregon State University. According to one author of those research articles, these devices are currently not widely allowed in the United States because they are not in the official manual produced by the Federal Highway Administration, called the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. However, the administration does allow making a request to experiment. It isn't that this is an untested product worldwide or even an experimental topic, just that it is not accepted yet in the U.S. manual for traffic intersections.

This signal accessory has been in use in a variety of countries throughout the world for more than a decade, but it is isn't something known by drivers across the U.S. and if it appeared suddenly it would certainly draw attention. One YouTube poster, when he saw the countdown timer for the first time in the Philippines (it is actually many other places as well), titled his video, "Only in the Philippines", indicating what a shift it might be for Americans to see it implemented in their own country. Perhaps for that reason it requires permission. Yet, there are some unconventional traffic signals that have appeared in the U.S. in recent years, including the recent flashing yellow arrow for turning right or left.

Just by doing a web search, here is one vendor website from Hungary that sells the devices to cities across the world. But in the U.S., cities cannot just install them without permission.

This video below from Thailand demonstrates a timer active for both the green and the red. Some researchers in Taiwan believe that only the red countdown should be provided. Other researchers at Oregon State said that countdown timers for the green light improved safety. As you approach a traffic signal from a you would know how much time you have left, whether you have to stop soon before the signal turns yellow. This would be very useful if the green light is far away but still within sight, because you would know to slow down from a distance.

Circular Progress Meter

A lot of people find the concept of a countdown timer appealing, including those outside of traffic planning. In one concept promoted by a designer named Damjan Stankovic from Eastern Europe (who later came to work for AirBnB as a designer), the timer indicator is embedded inside the red portion of the traffic light. There are no indications that this model was ever sold or installed in cities. It looks to have been a concept promoted by Stankovic himself and recognized by a design award organization calling itself the Red Dot Awards. The Guardian made an article about this in 2009, but it did not go further than this. One issue is that in this configuration, the countdown component of the signal might not be as visible at a distance like the accompanying numeric timer. What is actually sold to cities is the numeric timer and the image below is just a photoshopped concept.

Adding Artificial Intelligence to Traffic Signals

Given how central traffic signals are to both the experience of a modern city and most commuters' lives, it would normally be expected, with the advent of modern artificial intelligence, that this would be an area of high research activity. Even if an automobile is fitted with artificial intelligence to drive it automatically, it still has to stop at traffic signals.

The first traffic signals did not actually feature a yellow light. It was just two lights: a red light for "stop" and a green light for "go". The yellow light was added later in response to the major safety issues produced by having no delay between green and red. So one issue is that the yellow light might need some kind of amendment after all of these years, as all drivers have experienced the uncomfortable moment of being at the end of a yellow without time to stop. Countdown timers could be a first step towards improving the yellow light.

References:

Research Article: Improved driver responses at intersections with red signal
countdown timers

Research Article: Safer driver responses at intersections with green signal
countdown timers

Article: Traffic signal countdown timers lead to improved driver responses

Video: Road Guy Rob - How do stop lights "see" your car (to turn green)?

item.title: The Missed Opportunities and Potential of The SVG File Format
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
For those who want a refresher, raster image files are also called bitmap files, and common file formats include JPEG, GIF, PNG, and WEBP, TIFF. They only contain information for a grid of square pixels, and their resolution is fixed. Vector graphics files, instead, contain information about the data points that make up the graphical figures, which means that the scale can be changed without causing pixellation. They can also embed bitmap files in them that have their own fixed resolutions. An example file format for this is PDF. The predecessor to PDF was called EPS and it is still used for authoring programs.

Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) began as a call for proposals in 1999 by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), sent to various companies who had a stake in the area of vector graphics format for the web. A few proposals came back but in the end, it was mostly Adobe's PGML (Precision Graphics Markup Language) proposal that became the basis for SVG.

PDF and EPS are the kinds of file formats that are supposed to be independent of the need to own the authoring program that produced them. There haven't been many universal formats for vector graphics and about the only other one discussed besides PDF and EPS is SVG. But there are differences because PDF is supposed to be for multi-page documents whereas SVG is supposed to be for standalone vector graphics images. It isn't possible to declare, officially, multiple pages inside the SVG format. In a way, the objective of SVG, to artificially limit its scope to displaying images like JPEG or PNG has been a problem, because any time there are vector graphics there is the likelihood of needing multiple pages and multiple layers. In raster, that is rarely the case and people use PDF for that purpose.

Popular on web pages are JPEG, GIF, PNG, and WEBP, but less popular has been the vector graphics format, SVG, in part because it does not come with all of the functionality needed for it to be a suitable vector format for the web. But importantly, for it to be a suitable format for web it also has to be suitable for print at the same time, which is a big part of the problem.

  • Internally, it does not allow for multi-line text, only single lines of text, which might sound somewhat absurd. This means that you cannot actually put a paragraph of text inside an SVG. All paragraphs are broken up into single line elements inside the file.
  • It does not support rendering mesh gradients, which was supported by Adobe's PostScript in 1997.
  • Its color configuration is only for computer screens and not printers, which is actually an unnecessary limitation and trivial to change in the official specification.
  • Unlike PostScript, it does not have any programmatic capabilities except those provided by JavaScript if the person opens it up in a web browser.
    • PDF is actually made out of scripting code, PostScript, so PostScript files are always actually technically more like programs that execute, they just don't access the filesystem or Internet.

There is actually a lot of potential in having a vector graphics format made out of XML like SVG, though, because there are other technologies that can be put in the file and no particular vendor owns the file, which also means that authoring programs can center around.

The shortcomings of SVG are produced by the inaction of the same organization that made it come about, so perhaps the criticism is that its lethargic status causes a problem because no one ventures to do an alternative format because it is always around. That is to say, if it weren't around maybe someone would do one that works well for everyone.

If SVG had the right set of features, it might be more popular today among professional printing companies, but it lacks a great deal of functionality that is needed to be considered a serious, standalone vector graphics format. Support for it has been inconsistent across operating systems, despite its potential. For example, it could be a convenient format for software developers to provide user interface designs and application icons with their apps because it can be scaled, on its own, as much as is needed on any screen and keep a normal file size. It also has the potential to accept user interactivity programmed into the actual file, because it made out of XML. But that isn't actually what is accepted. Instead, software developers are asked to make several versions of their application icons in raster format, from 1024x1024 pixels in various sizes all the way down to 16x16 pixels. This would be unnecessary if SVG were both more widely embraced and it had a set of needed features.

A major reason that software companies of all sorts have not supported it is that it carries a lot of limitations that the W3C has not decided to fill in. Support for it has been spotty over the years across computers.

There have been several proposed features that were not included in the SVG specification that could be of value.

One proposed feature that was not included in the SVG specification is the ability to include 3D graphics. While SVG is primarily a 2D graphics format, a 3D scene or a 3D object can be re-rendered at any desired resolution along with the vector graphics, which would mean this would really be a file format for an operating system's file navigation and overall interface. However, 3D graphics are not currently supported in SVG.

They can be artificially, because you can just put them in the file and any SVG renderer will ignore the custom XML tags that you include in the file, while your own programs pick up the 3D model that you put into the file. Some vector-drawing programs do this: they make use of SVG but add their own tags to the file structure so that they can extend it. But their additions would have to be recognized elswehere.

One proposed feature that was not included in the SVG specification is support for animation. While SVG does support the use of animation. There have also been proposals to include support for audio and video in the SVG specification. While it is possible to include audio and video in an SVG document using external resources, the ability to directly include audio and video within the SVG file itself has not been included in the specification.

There have been proposals to include support for scientific and technical graphics, such as diagrams and charts, as well as support for interactive applications, such as games and simulations. However, these proposals have not been included in the SVG specification.

One proposed feature is the ability to use mesh gradients in SVG. Mesh gradients are gradients that are made up of a series of interconnected points and lines, allowing for more complex gradients than the traditional linear and radial gradients that are currently supported in SVG and usually what people are using when they make gradients. While there have been efforts to include mesh gradients in the SVG specification, they pulled them out at the last minute.

Another proposed feature is the ability to use hatching in SVG. Hatching is a technique used to add texture and depth to a graphic by drawing a series of closely spaced, parallel lines. Hatching is commonly used in technical drawings and diagrams, and the ability to use hatching in SVG would allow for more detailed and accurate representations of these types of graphics. However, hatching has not yet been included in the SVG specification.

Finally, there has been a proposal to include a "replicate" tag in the SVG specification. The replicate tag would allow for the creation of repeating patterns within an SVG graphic, making it easier to create tiled or repeating backgrounds and other types of repeating graphics. However, the replicate tag has not yet been included in the SVG specification.

If the SVG wants to play the role of an open standard, it really needs to include the proposals that people make that would put it in a position of an alternative to proprietary formats like PDF and EPS.

item.title: An AI-Based Machine That Cuts Vegetables for Cooking
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Drop an onion into the top of a kitchen appliance with box dimensions about the size of a microwave oven, press the "cut" button, and within 30 seconds the vegetable you placed into the machine was both recognized as an onion and diced (because you set the machine to "dice"). Open up the door and on the right side are the diced onion pieces and on the left side are the vegetable scraps, chopped and ready for the compost bin. If you have ever cooked regularly but are often too busy to do so, you can see what an impactful machine this would be for yourself and other people. Of course, it might be used at restaurants as well.

Putting A.I. In Situations Where It Matters And Helps (But Doesn't Take Over Everything)

Lately, people in many industries and government departments are recognizing artificial intelligence as a useful tool for addressing complex problems. Nevertheless, in the mainstream it is frequently directed at non-problems or peripheral matters: the world doesn't need a device to take over the production of art or perform tasks that people accomplish just fine already. But they do stand to gain by having A.I. eliminate friction in modern life by having it fill potholes, sort recycling, cut vegetables. The place where A.I. should be placed are the problems.

For a cooking appliance, the initial temptation might be to devise a comprehensive AI-based machine that cooks the entire meal from start to finish with all of the raw ingredients provided. But it's far more important to address immediate issues that are causing friction. The cost of the machine will be less and its impact will reach more people. In any given activity, the A.I. should aspire to take over obvious problems rather than take over the whole process. The result of a machine that consumes the cook's entire job position would once again be one that intimidates the public, yet another example of A.I. attempting to take over a human activity from start to finish. It isn't necessary to have the machine complete every stage of a job, but rather address the problems occurring in the various stages that making the work challenging. One type of A.I. project tries to build the entire road by itself unattended while the other deals with the individual problems taking place during road construction.

On this topic, most home cooks would agree (if they evaluated it, at least) that the main deterrent to cooking every day is often the cutting stage and the knowledge ahead of time that it will require cleanup. It's what people dread and what stops them from doing more to cook at home. They aren't afraid to cook in general, so the A.I. does not have to take over the general area of cooking a meal. It's just that in time periods with a slower place of life, when life did not have too many demands, cutting vegetables was not as big of a chore.

The Role of An A.I.-Based Machine for Cutting Vegetables

There hasn't been enough time , but so far A.I. has not yet been applied to consumer kitchen appliances. The home kitchen can benefit a great deal from the use of embedded computers with A.I. capabilities, but the key is to make sure it counts.

For those who haven't yet gotten into cooking, an AI-supervised machine that can cut any fruit or vegetable may sound like addressing a problem of slight inconvenience. But actually, depending on what is happening that day, the cooking step of cutting vegetables can be a

  • a fun thing to do
  • a minor issue
  • a job that is rushed, with scrap cleanup having to take place later that night
  • the main cause of not cooking that meal that time and opting for a frozen, microwaved meal.

This shows that the feasibility chores and activities depend on what is happening that day or week.

When a machine of this kind is provided, it will make the difference between cooking and not cooking many times, among many other benefits it would provide.

There Are Several Steps to Cutting a Simple Vegetable

The vegetable cutting step is relatively involved depending on the vegetables. For a green bell pepper, it has to be pitted and the interior seeds have to be removed. For an onion, the skin has to be removed after the first cut. Carrots have to be peeled before being chopped. Some need to be soaked in advance. When the dish calls for several different vegetables like this and they all need to be peeled or prepped before cutting, it becomes too much work for the meal if you are very busy that day. Once the initial expense is covered for a device that does this job, the home cook will make more healthy meals affordably.

There are of course containers of cut onions available at the store, but the cost is higher and this kind of machine would cut the vegetables on demand instead.

If the machine places the remnants of the cutting process into a container on the left side, this also means there is little cleanup, which is the other effect of cutting vegetables.

With today's artificial intelligence technology, the machine will be able to accurately and efficiently slice, dice, and chop a wide range of vegetables using the same set of cutting machinery that was built into it. What is interesting is that 30 seconds for chopping one onion being is not very long. Given that it is A.I. at work, the machine might be able to peel vegetables that are dropped into it, such as potatoes and carrots. It would come equipped with a base set of cutting tools and, with the assistance of its own A.I. reuse them according to the vegetable.

There are commercial vegetable-cutting machines already on the market, they are designed for factories or professional kitchens. They do their job well, but their design is for producing large quantities of specific vegetables in a short time.

The purpose of an A.I. machine would not be to cut the vegetables as quickly as possible but instead eliminate that friction of cutting vegetables. A machine designed for home use would not have such intense speed requirements for the kitchen compared to a commercial cutting device. It would be multi-purpose, covering most vegetables a person would use.

item.title: Design Software Does Not Categorize Fonts
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
It's often time-consuming to find the right font from the computer because they are not categorized in the software menus by their appearance.

When a user opens the font list on their computer, they are often presented with a long list of fonts that are not organized in any particular order apart from alphabetical. If you think about it, it doesn't matter a whole lot what the name of a font is, so this would not be the sorting criteria for the fonts.

When the fonts are just put in an alphabetical list, this can make it difficult to find a font that is appropriate for a particular job because there are fonts of all appearances are placed one after another, usually in a menu but also sometimes in a scrollable list.

There are also many fonts that should be able to be hidden because they were installed in the system for special use cases, such as for certain foreign languages. There is no option provided in the system preferences menu to hide these.

But probably the main reason why it is hard to select a font from the computer is that the fonts are not typically organized by appearance. What is important to note is how sans-serif (fonts like Helvetica that do not have strokes extending past intersections of the letters) can produce a large variety, so just grouping the fonts into serif (e.g. Times New Roman) and sans-serif (e.g. Helvetica) will not be enough. Within those two categories there are fonts suitable for book text and others that work best for headlines. Others would only be used in decorative situations, like those containing noise. So it does have to be worked out what categories are provided and it isn't a trivial issue. Here are some categories, for example:

  • Thin and Tall
  • Thin, Tall, and Bold
  • Helvetica-Like
  • Suitable for reading paragraph text
  • The font is a display font (for headlines, advertisements) and not for paragraph text
  • The font is a headline font.
  • The font is antique-looking
  • The font is sci-fi-looking

Which categories to use is a matter of debate perhaps. Additionally it would be acceptable to place a font into multiple categories if that fit the situation.

Historically, in software fonts have always been listed alphabetically, by font family, in the menu. Of course, the most problematic situation in software is when they are listed alphabetically but provide no preview of what they look like (the list of names are not set in the fonts they indicate), which is less common today.

When the fonts are listed alphabetically, this means that a user has to scroll through the entire list of fonts to find one of a certain appearance. Some fonts look like they would work for paragraph text but they don't (as they are display fonts). Others could be grouped together because they are very similar in intention by the font designers, but they located are in different parts of the alphabetical list. They may never have had a formal name provided for what they are doing.

Just like how the paperwork environment becomes higher in requirements when output everywhere is produced by a home printer, the standard for page design changes when all users are provided lists of fonts using computer typography. So it is important, especially when the number of fonts is large, for the design software to group the fonts into suitable categories.

Again, this could actually be done automatically by the system through machine learning because what happens is that any installed font that was not part of the system earlier will be categorized by machine learning according to different categories.

Design by Tweaking

"Design by tweaking" is a topic. "Design by tweaking" is very uncomfortable for the designer because it does not start out with a full set of proper conditions but instead relies on sequential tweaks back and forth, such as trying one font in a menu after another. In a computing environment that does not group fonts, this is happening more frequently. Grouping the fonts will significantly reduce the quantity of trial and error, as a user tries out different fonts to see how they look in their project is.

Noctivagous, the company behind dFork, tried out grouping fonts by appearance in a file menu and the benefits were present. This is something all design software companies can do to improve the experience of their software.

item.title: The Vital Importance of Unity and Unreal Engine to the VR/AR Industry
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
TABLE OF CONTENTS:

  • Introduction
  • Facebook Does Not Control a Desktop Operating System
  • The Contradiction: VR Is Supposed to Depart from Existing Computing But Is Totally Fused to It
  • What Does AR and VR Do for People That They Can Do Now?
  • Unity and Unreal Engine Are Central to Facebook's VR Business, But VR/AR Needs Its Own Systems Instead for Making Apps
  • Android Has Android Studio, iOS has Xcode... What Does VR Have?
  • Reasons Apple Will Likely Not Center Its Headsets Around Unity and Unreal Engine
  • Comparing Unity and Unreal Engine

Introduction

In any field of the computer industry, the software development tools that programmers are provided will shape the products they make. But the VR industry has ignored some important rules to this situation. A major reason that Apple attracts and retains software developers with its App Store is that it controls and develops its own code editor system, Xcode, and it shapes the software toolkits around its own hardware. What it offers today was built up over several years, upon many frameworks inherited from NeXT, the company that Steve Jobs founded in the late 1980s. The system is integrated, in other words, and all of the parts can help one another.

Facebook and other VR and AR companies are not involved in the base layer of the operating system that they use. They don't control or direct Microsoft Windows, in other words. When they provide tools for making VR apps and games, they are actually just additions placed on top of what Microsoft or Apple control in the operating system. To make matters complicated, the tools are separated by a second layer: they rely on third-party game engine software to make anything significant for their VR hardware. Thus, Facebook and other companies have two levels of political separation from the operating system, something Apple does not. They all rely on Epic Games' Unreal Engine and Unity Technologies' Unity game engine for any production of games, entertainment, and software. This holds for all VR and AR companies at the moment.

The problem is that these tools were not ever built for what makes computers useful to people in everyday life across society-- apps. They were built for video games first, whereas Apple's tools were all built for software applications and not usually for games. When a product comes to market, it is usually utility software applications that determine whether it can succeed, not video games. The iPhone 1.0 lets you browse a map wherever you are, it lets you browse the web and check e-mail. There is no successful strategy that bets on video games first and is also is trying to make a general purpose device. Yet that is the kind of muddle-headed strategy that has come out of VR/AR companies for the last several years. They have not paid attention to what truly made the iPhone work which is a coherent software development system owned by the operating system vendor. Instead they have taken the shortcut route of sorts and repurposed Unity and Unreal Engine.

Apple has released a small and unused application for Apple software developers, called "Reality Composer". It is far from a toolset anyone could use to for making complete AR apps. Its purpose is to make the kind of AR "experiences" a person can get while rotating an iPad or iPhone and moving it around a room, to see 3D models placed inside the room. It's no surprise, of course, but this already demonstrates that Apple intends to rely on its own tools independent of Unity and Unreal Engine. Historically, they have always done that. But they will gain enormous advantage over Facebook and other VR/AR companies if everything else in their software and hardware is working together in combination. They are not trying to fit themselves inside Unreal Engine, which has goals other than what Apple wants. Even Unity is trying to be many things.

Because their tools will be centered around the task of AR-- and not secondarily a set of add-ons to someone else's 3D game engine toolkit, on someone else's operating system-- it is likely that software developers will find it easier to do basic apps quickly. It isn't that everyone knows how Apple will succeed. It's that it is very likely that Apple will get a running start quickly as software developers won't need much time to convert their existing iPad and iPhone apps to any AR/VR system provided by Apple. The advantages Apple starts with are numerous, in other words.

These advantages that Apple has have to be addressed by the AR/VR community if they are to remain relevant. Without information about the future Apple hardware, no one can say what will happen in terms of whether Apple is prepared. But there are rules to the industry. The conditions are favorable for a repeat of history with the iPod, in which Apple controlled the computer that the iPod hooked into and it provided straightforward software that was "plug and play" with its own operating system at the time. This iTunes software was ported to Windows in 2003 and then the iPod became popular. Apple controlled the software (iTunes) and the hardware (iPod). The same occurred with the iPhone, but Apple controlled not only the hardware and software, but this time came to offer its own development tool kits.

Why is AR/VR not the same as an iPod or iPhone? 3D is a difficult topic, AR is a totally different domain from all previous categories of technology, and it remains to be seen whether Apple can measure up to the highly developed asset ecosystems that surround Unity and Unreal Engine. GUI rules are not even that solid today for 2D applications, so we will have to wait to see how Apple has made its own UI for 3D. It also remains to be seen whether Apple will produce an overpriced product with excessively premium or luxury features, which is a tendency of the company today. It is unknown whether its software interfaces for AR software development will exist in a significantly better state than what people had in the past. There is a lot of work needed to match Unity and Unreal, yet Apple owns its entire 3D graphics technology (Metal) under the hood, which it runs on its own custom-designed chips. So it is difficult to predict how Apple's AR developer tools will exist, which will be the centerpiece of how its AR software develops. It's an aspect to the situation you might not read about elsewhere, but it is very important. Apple has never been put on the line like that with its Xcode tools. It has only been providing the same overall system to make iPad, Mac and iPhone apps. Within that, it has only been adding features incrementally over the last decade. 3D is something different and the rules of user interface programming are different as well.

Facebook Does Not Control a Desktop Operating System

If an owner of an operating system (Apple) provides an AR and VR product, it can tie that directly into the daily processes that users are involved in already. The operating system is the first location where it is possible to provide a transition from the daily life of desktop computers and mobile phones to the VR/AR spaces (or other future computing devices). Real life as it is lived on desktop and mobile devices will have to easily integrate with any AR device. Apple is like the only company to try that. The difference is that Microsoft does not own its own game engine and will likely refrain from competing with Unity and Unreal Engine. This leaves Apple as the sole entity in possession of an operating system, a graphics stack (Metal), and hardware all together.

Apple is unlikely to make use of Unity or Unreal Engine, and so it is likely to reveal its own system for programming AR apps similar to Xcode. It may also have decided to extend Xcode instead of making a separate app for making AR apps, or building out "Reality Composer". It does not really matter, as long as the system works well. If this is a holdup, everything else Apple made will turn bad.

What is important is that existing, useful apps made for iPad and iPhone will be immediately translatable to an AR headset, whereas Facebook does not have that ease of conversion for VR because apps made for Windows because what is made for Unity and Unreal Engine are usually games. So what would be converted inside Unity and Unreal to VR normally is a game. If it is a normal software application, it would have to be converted over to Unity/UE from scratch in interface programming.

Since Facebook does not control the foundational layer of the operating system and it does not have a desktop computer user base, it is in an odd position to be promoting its products as a lifestyle shift, one that could separate from how people use the computer today. Additionally, the tools and software that Apple is likely to provide for a consumer AR/VR product will surely relate to the work people do during the day, whereas Facebook has tailored its software and app store around video games and entertainment primarily.

According to Facebook, there will be widespread adoption of its technologies if it works inside video games and entertainment first, acting as a kind of attractor for the public. But the computer industry has never worked that way; the public would have to be the ones to make logical connections between playing VR video games and the software applications they work with in everyday life. No major software industry like iPhone apps, Macintosh apps, or iPad apps starts within the narrow category of video games and then branches out to how people use the computer during daily life, such as at work and during travel. It is instead that the video games supplement the overall technology situation. When video game consoles for the television are used, they hardly feel related to regular computers, as all major functionality provided by computers is hidden and reduced to gaming interfaces, usually just the controllers and their buttons.

Frequently, video game enthusiasts will say that video games have advanced computer technology. The base technologies, though, were all developed in research labs or at companies like Silicon Graphics, with VR getting its start in the 1960s and later in the late 1980s for purposes other than video games. It could be said that video games incentivized corporate products at graphics card companies like NVIDIA that they funded these startups. But Silicon Graphics only worked with Nintendo in its later years and that was because it had done work elsewhere in advance. The impact of video games on graphics is a mixed situation, and even in the cases where video games made contributions, people who play video games still have to admit that what software provides for daily life is the important first step-- supporting business and everyday needs. If you cannot use a VR headset to browse the web out of the box, something is misguided in terms of thinking at the VR company. If the web browser is exactly the same as what is on the desktop, that is also a problem, as there was no reason to have the VR headset.

It is a cold, hard fact, that it isn't possible to navigate the file system of Microsoft Windows through an Oculus VR headset, except as a reproduction of a desktop computer screen. What is the point of the VR hardware if they are going to make flat computer monitors inside it, to run the same apps that are on computers now? Worse, you have to use these big computer screens inside VR with a laser pointer device, inside the VR. This is reminiscent of the early 2000s tablet PCs that simply displayed mouse-driven desktop operating system interfaces inside the tablet, exactly as they existed on the mouse-driven desktop. If a new category of technology comes about, the whole of the situation has to be changed. If you are in VR, you should navigate files in 3D.

The Contradiction: VR Is Supposed to Depart from Existing Computing But Is Totally Fused to It

The VR industry is more like a software layer built on top of existing app and game development systems, which themselves were built on top of the existing mainstream operating system, Microsoft Windows. So it is tethered to what exists now by sitting on top of other people's products. This makes for a contradiction because what VR industry people have been promoting is as if VR will someday turn into a completely separate computing environment, one that exists entirely because of VR and AR interfacing with life in a way unlike traditional desktop computing. Instead it is actually that it sits on top of desktop computers.

There is a strong argument that Facebook and other companies in this industry can never truly succeed with VR if they don't make their own consumer operating system to go along with it, because what VR/AR promotes is supposed to be a separate "future life" for people (the so-called "metaverse"). People would then need to import all of their contacts and have real apps inside that new use of technology. The future will include what exists in the present. The future will incorporate what people do and how they live. The future will not be starting over to serve VR/AR.

No matter what, Facebook's VR and AR will be limited to making video games and entertainment apps if it does not merge its company objectives into how people live from day to day, outside of recreational game-making and one-off uses of its technology in work environments (e.g. training employees). As if intent to self-sabotage, Facebook begins collecting information about consumers in a most dystopian way, leaving the door open to collecting 3D information about the spaces where people use their VR hardware. There is no way that Facebook can compete with Apple's stated commitments to privacy, regardless of whether Apple truly follows through on them, because Facebook does not appear to make the same kinds of statements when it should with a technology that carries running cameras that can gather 3D information.

There is no such thing as the computing public jumping on VR and AR all at once, as even the web and e-mail required transition. So there has to be an e-mail client when you put on the VR headset. But if it the same as what is on the iPad, why not use the iPad? Consumers will use their existing data on their existing operating systems and devices-- if they ever end up using a technology like VR and AR regularly as it exists today. Anything on a regular computer has to be accessible inside VR/AR.

What Does AR and VR Do for People That They Can Do Now?

What can you do in VR and AR that you can do right now on a desktop computer? Edit 2D video? No. Edit a digital photo? No. This is really unacceptable. Perhaps these use cases are less interesting because no one will hype it up in a news story that the VR headset is doing something that people can already do, so a company ignores these essential needs of a device and promotes flashy games instead.

We have not even broached the topic here of how the typical headsets have a history of producing discomfort and cannot be worn for long periods of time, which would be essential to address if they are to be regarded as either lifestyle or work devices that replace desktop computing even partially. This is really the dealbreaker for everyone except the most ardent VR enthusiasts, but this article is written as if that won't be an issue someday, which is not a given after the last several years.

Superficially, they could get away with tying themselves to video games, but there is a lot more discipline needed at these companies when they are forced to relate what they are doing with their VR products to real world needs. A cause is that the Oculus VR headset was promoted as a video game device in the first place, it always had video game industry people involved in it, and they are usually the least associated with how normal people live their work lives.

Unity and Unreal Engine Are Central to Facebook's VR Business, But VR/AR Needs Its Own Systems Instead for Making Apps

If the VR/AR industry rallied around, and agreed upon, a universal development system that is not a plain distribution of Unity and Unreal (it could be a forked version of one of them), this would be the best outcome, because then all software development features would line up with what VR/AR requires. Unity and Unreal do not care a great deal about VR/AR specifically but are just able to support these industries. This is a problem for engineering. It is a problem for user interface. It affects the whole of the VR technologies. It is also a problem that Apple does not face.

After all of the talk of "the metaverse," that would have to be implemented inside either Unity or Unreal Engine (originally designed to be game-making engines) at the current time, unless another developed system is made or repurposed. If the discussion of "the metaverse" mentions the most essential aspect of how the VR apps are actually made, it comes down to these two systems, which are rather mundane desktop software apps (integrated development environments) compared to the demos of what VR is supposed to be.

A big part of the difficulty that the VR industry faces is that it does not have its own set of tools for VR specifically, centered around its own needs. And each company competes with the others, so could they agree to make one that all are supposed to be using?

What is important to note is how reliant Facebook is on software, both operating systems and game engines, that it does not design or control. Either Unity or Unreal Engine could add something unwanted and cause a problem for Facebook. So it is odd that after all of the money spent on hardware, Facebook would not try to control its own developer tools or run its apps on a custom operating system.

A big problem is that the tools are not ground-up for VR, but instead tie-ins to third-part software, Unity and Unreal. By contrast, everything Apple does will fit in like a plug into its existing system.

It's the difference between building your own car model from the ground up for a specific use case (like a Humvee) or modifying a different model, e.g. a GM Escalade, that is already in production by another company. The latter is what Facebook is doing. The former is what Apple can do if it wants to. For VR/AR, it's better to have a custom-made car (software development system) made from top to bottom than repurposing a stock one in production made by someone else.

Professional-level VR games all use Unity and Unreal Engine, by way of a set of add-ons specific to VR needs. But they are add-ons, they are called this, which means they won't really be owned by the VR/AR industry. It won't be the case for Apple, who will be able to tie everything into its own system, from top to bottom.

The add-ons provide the programmer software functionality inside Unity or Unreal Engine for all of the movements and actions specific to VR and its controllers. But it should not be a set of add-ons but instead part of the whole of the system. The tools that are available normally in Unity and Unreal Engine were made for another set of goals: to make video experiences and software for 2D screens that are stationary.

Convenience routines are built into software development systems that natural match the specific areas that they serve. If you don't have that and instead attach add-ons or plug-ins to someone else's development system (Unreal/Unity), you are working inside their system awkwardly, and many aspects of the software will not line up. It will become hacky, which is a complaint many people have about making VR/AR apps today..

If Apple has made an adequate set of AR/VR development tools, it will have a very large advantage over Facebook (Meta) because all of the tools will be tailored to the needs of AR as Apple wants it. The needs actually involve a large array of considerations not present in interacting with 3D objects displayed on regular 2D computer monitors.

Android Has Android Studio, iOS has Xcode... What Does VR Have?

VR faces a number of issues because it is trying to do a new technology but also tie into existing development systems without a universally agreed upon code editor system. This is usually not how software development has been done historically for apps, that a company would be reliant a different software development system made by someone else. The vendors own their own software systems normally.

--- For iPhone and iPad apps, there is Apple's Xcode and only that can compile them.

--- For Microsoft desktop, web, and tablet apps, there is Microsoft's own Visual Studio and that is usually what people use.

--- There is also Google's Android Studio for Android apps.

When Google deviated from this and did not provide a code editor for its Flutter system, adoption rates were not as strong. IDEs (integrated development environments) are very important for modern apps and they have to be owned by the company that produces the system.

If the programmer opts to use a third-party editor to make Microsoft apps, for example, that is a personal choice and there will be issues that come up because some features won't be available that Microsoft provides in its own toolkits in Visual Studio. To have the entire VR division of Facebook (now calling itself "Meta") so reliant on a third-party software development system could be viewed as controversial. It would be reasonable even to object to this at a stockholder meeting, as it is not good practice in software engineering to rely on other people's software tools.

Reasons Apple Will Likely Not Center Its Headsets Around Unity and Unreal Engine

It is unlikely that Apple, for its AR headset, would choose to be dependent on either of these two software systems (Unity and Unreal Engine). Likely, if the AR headset is released someday, there will be an extensive set of additions to Apple's own Xcode. Possibly there will be a dedicated editor. At the moment, it may be a more complete version of Apple's Reality Composer app. The reason is, if Apple were to make use of Unreal Engine or Unity, they would be beholden to those two companies, on their own computer platforms. They would be promoting Microsoft's C# for Unity and C++ for Unreal Engine, neither of which Apple promotes to its third-party software developers. So, short of some deal with someone, is likely that Apple is working on its own software development tools for headsets it will ship. It is apparently related to Swift.

The reasons Facebook and other VR companies opted to remain on Unity and Unreal are many, and they include that both systems have extensive ecosystems in which any 3D game made in those platforms can actually be converted over.

Comparing Unity and Unreal Engine

Apart from video games, Unity and Unreal Engine are also the focus of the entertainment industry. Weta Digital, a special effects company, purchased Unity. Meanwhile, Unreal Engine has been used for making many movies.

Unity is a cross-platform game engine that allows software developers to program interactive "experiences" and video games. It offers an integrated development environment and tools, including a scripting system, physics engine, user interface tools. It primarily makes use of C#.

Unreal Engine, developed by Epic Games has a large set of features and tools, including a famously realistic-looking graphics renderer (called Nanite) and a particle physics and physics engine. For beginner programmers especially, it features a node-based programming system. The movie and entertainment industry makes extensive use of Unreal Engine in studio setups. The photorealism allows shooting films that do not have to be on location. Most or even all of a production can stay inside a studio in 2023, which is a new phenomenon in movie-making platforms.

item.title: Wordpress Now Drives >30% of Sites on The Web Because of Its Plug-in Ecosystem
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
Web Servers Provide Very Little to Web Developers

The software utilities that come with web servers are very basic and are far from a ready-made system that can manage news articles or provide an online store. It is like a plot of undeveloped real estate or a building with just floors and no walls and interiors. Over the years an open, free package of software for web servers called WordPress has filled various needs brought by this situation. Its ease of use came from its simple original purpose, to serve blog articles. As it evolved, it eventually reached lay people who set up company websites. It is called WordPress.

All news websites run some kind of content management system that sits on top of the very basic web servers. WordPress is such a content management system (a term abbreviated as CMS), and it has become increasingly popular over the years. Its prevalence is now at the point that some people have estimated it drives a third of websites on the web. Regardless, there are some very large news websites that use it, and there are also small shops, so it covers the range required to be a large portion of websites out there.

According to data from W3Techs, WordPress is used by 43.2% of all websites on the internet in 2022. This is an increase from 39.5% in 2021.

https://blog.hubspot.com/website/wordpress-stats

WordPress is favored over other CMS options because it is often simpler to set up initially and does not require a lot of technical knowledge, but this also means it only serves a specific category of website functionality well: store websites, web journals (blogs), and other information services like news websites. Beyond its initial range just mentioned, a lot of customization is required and another system is often preferred by web software engineers.

In recent years, one of the causes for its success is the plugin ecosystem that has developed around it. The plug-ins added some very complex functionality that WordPress needed for making more developed websites, beyond just blogs. In response, WordPress itself added features reflective of the new user base and the new plug-ins, but not a lot.

Originally, Wordpress was developed for the web development community in the mid-2000s, in a time when blogs were very popular among people in that community and the iPhone had not been released. As a base set of utilities, it was centered around this activity of blogging, and this is evident all the way to the present day when interacting with it, as it is centered around "posts" and "articles". Going beyond these two types of web pages it serves takes plug-ins and customization.

Though it was widely used among bloggers in that time, it was never intended for driving news websites and e-commerce without a lot of additional software development work. Many people have done that software development work and provided it to customers through the plug-in system WordPress provides. This has filled in those gaps, such that anyone can add functionality chosen from a wide spectrum to their own WordPress server, customized for their own purposes.

Largely, the plug-in ecosystem resembles the app industry found on Google and Apple devices, with many plug-in makers offering limited versions of their plug-ins and promoting subscriptions to those who try them out. (For example, the WPForms plug-in that produces online submission forms is helpful without purchasing the pro version, which is a monthly or yearly subscription.)

Elementor and Themes

One plugin that has contributed significantly to WordPress's popularity in recent years is a tool for making complex pages via drag-and-drop, called Elementor. It comes with a stock library of "widgets" that allow users to design and customize their WordPress websites without needing any web programming knowledge. The free version provides a basic set of widgets and then the pro version completes the set of many needed widgets for more complicated information websites.

What is worth noting is that Elementor, along with a few other similar enterprises, are fully-developed companies centered around providing features for WordPress. Because of the size of Wordpress user base, the plug-in ecosystem has produced a source of income for many plug-in makers. These plug-ins will only be seen normally by those who run these websites. The convenience and relative ease of use of Elementor have made it a popular option among WordPress users, leading to its widespread adoption.

WordPress filled in gaps in web servers, and then Elementor filled in gaps inside the software structure of WordPress. This is so much so that there are enterprises that make commercial plug-ins for the Elementor WordPress plug-in-- making plug-ins for this WordPress plug-in. Usually in software development this would indicate starting over somewhere by someone.

Themes And The Complexity of The Web

Themes change the appearance of the whole WordPress website. Often, for purposes beyond making a small website they will eventually be the products to buy for many people, except those who want to make their own. Generally, if WordPress is going to be used for anything significant, something will have to be purchased from someone who has made a pre-made product. In fact purchasing these products is a reasonable move for making a professional-looking website due to the complexity of web development today.

For simple websites like a simple business website that won't change for a long time, nothing needs to be purchased necessarily. But for bigger projects, an experienced web developer might actually opt for purchasing Elementor and WordPress for clients, or even a personal website, because of the growing complexity of the web.

Unlike the 2000s, the web has grown into a very complicated set of requirements: it has to accommodate all kinds of screen sizes on mobile devices and desktop computers and also be indexed by search engines, able to sync with all different kinds of social media websites, etc. None of this has been accommodated in the web servers themselves, which are basically the same as they were in the 1990s overall. This is certainly a cause in the growing market share of WordPress.

In the 1990s, many websites were done manually, with text editors. But the industry has reached point in which the web technologies cannot be produced manually anymore without expending excessive effort. Whatever is produced manually will have to accommodate too many situations, and the web servers do not help with this.

The themes that come with WordPress usually do adapt to every situation and this is part of the appeal to web developers.

Also, a free or commercial WordPress theme does not have to look the same as when it is purchased, which means that if you buy a certain theme your website does not have to look the same as someone else who bought that one too. You can customize it to the extent that no one knows you bought the same theme as someone else. That is because it often include a large number customization options, to change the font, font sizes, colors, and so on.

Many WordPress themes include multiple, pre-designed page templates.
