The WordPress Plug-ins Brought in a User Base

Quite frequently, the plug-ins are providing functionality that WordPress would have in it if it were commercial software. What pushes Wordpress past all other content management systems is the wide number of people using it, so there will always be resources for people who use it, which then feeds back into its popularity.

Ironically perhaps, it makes use of a website programming technology that has been around since 1995, PHP. It was part of the early period of the web. There is no problem with this, as PHP was also the basis of Facebook and is still used across the Internet. Programming languages do not expire exactly, but frequently with the web development community there is a desire to feel more advanced than previous years.

Conclusion

The vast and constantly growing plugin ecosystem is one of the main reasons WordPress has become so popular. By filling in what web servers do not have and allowing users to easily customize and extend the functionality of their websites, WordPress is likely to stick around, until there is a major revision to web browsers and web servers. No indication of that is found anywhere at the current time.

item.title: Files Are Hard to Organize on Computers Today
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Often it seems like computer technology accelerates and changes so quickly that a person cannot keep track of it. But in actuality, only one side of the computer is changing and accelerating. Hardly ever mentioned is that the conventions established early on (in the 1970s specifically) persist throughout the decades, even though computers have become much faster and gained much more storage capacity. The mouse is still around and generally unchanged, but the computer itself is much faster, to give an example. Any kind of hardware interface could be used to interact with the computer, but it is this device demonstrated in 1968 by Douglas Engelbart. Arguably, the field of user interface is undeveloped because when touchscreen interfaces were introduced to the public with with iPad, the mouse returned several years later. In the same way, there is much to be added in other areas of the computer, including the organization scheme of the file system.

Navigating through files on computers is the same on all computers because the structure of the filesystem was established on a system called MULTICS which carried over into the UNIX operating system in the 1970s. The way that the computer's hierarchical file system exists is a lot more rigid than is recognized, and there is a lot of room for improvement. It was never designed for the accelerated environment in which we live. It is unfortunately the case that these conventions are almost never revisited, and it makes the computer increasingly uncomfortable to use as more technologies are added to the machines. Though usable, the MULTICS directory structure does not accommodate more complex usage of the computers decades after its introduction. This shows that there is a cost to bringing old computing conventions into the present. A very old directory structure is implemented on very large hard drives, thousands of times larger than those of the 1970s.

Some computer science concepts appear almost timeless and they carry forward without any problem. Others need to be to re-examined or augmented.

It is actually a challenge to keep track of the files a person has made or receives. For example, a folder of photos might have 50 images downloaded from a camera, with all of them pertaining to the same subject. There is only one means of categorization: they need to be classified into certain subfolders inside that folder. The user has to make subdirectories to make any category divisions for the images. The problem with this is that the images are consequently all hidden at the level of the first folder-- they are concealed inside the various subdirectories that the user had to make just to implement organization of the folder. To view what are only 50 images, if there are 5 categories (subdirectories) of images and about 10 in each subdirectory, each subdirectory has to be inspected one by one to view its contents.

This is a bit like having to reach a destination by car by only traveling straight and making right turns. However, it can be rectified. In a proper form of organization-- one that could be easily implemented by an operating system today-- the category groupings of images would be able to be browsed from within the same folder without being concealed and placed into subfolders. To do this, there can be grouping "labels" placed around various groups of files.

In this setup, the user can categorize them but doing so does not force their placement into subdirectories that hide contents of the category. Instead, in the file system navigator, the groupings there would be outlines around each grouping of files inside the folder, and only when there is a need for a subdirectory would one be made. Only if immediate visibility is unimportant would they placed into a subdirectory.

That is to say, there is no need for a computer to force all subcategorization of files into subdirectories. It is just that that is how it is right now and that is how it has been. Because the personal computer's file system is so simplistic and reduced, what is available today for the consumer is incorrect hierarchy, causing problems for organizing information, everywhere. Fortunately, it can be fixed rather easily, just by adding the functionality mentioned. There are other features that can be added as well to make this better still. This rigid file system hierarchy issue is an important problem to address because, with the example of the folder of photos, at any point in the future each subdirectory has to be manually traversed by the computer user, which means that over the course of any computer session the computer user will become gradually irritated by the computer. This occurs at the same time that people find it difficult to recall where their files are; they sit inside an incorrect organizational hierarchy.

What we described for the file system is the organizing setup for all files on all data servers, personal computers-- for everything the computer contains-- so it is important to make this topic a priority. The impacts will be felt in other areas of computing as well, as many software applications are programmed with this. It is generally just an oversight that was never recognized and not the type of issue that would be made a priority by the software engineering or computer science of today. Once it is exposed, everyone can agree that a file system hierarchy should not exist as forced generation of subfolders, with that being the only means of organizing information. As we just said, it could be instead that that the list of images inside the folder have outlines around the groups and fewer subdirectories are made. That because there is a user interface "cost" for making a subdirectory if it does not have a real purpose for being there.

Once same-folder groupings are provided, the first, most obvious benefit is that there will be far less searching of files, because it will be easier to get to them. And computer users everywhere will generally will know where their files are more often. The interfaces for interacting with the files will improve as well, (such as the Mac OS Finder or Windows' File Explorer).

The experience of navigating and organizing files on a filesystem currently is poor because it is a very bare and rigid structure in place. In computer science, it is discussed in terms of a tree, as shown in an image below. In the next section, we get more technical, but what has just been discussed is something everyone can comprehend.

Tree Structures

Just like an organization chart, in computer science a tree structure consists of nodes (circles), starting from the root (the top circle in the image at top of this article). They then extend at each level, creating what is regarded as a "tree". The image that someone made above shows how the file system is an example of this abstract tree. Navigation and traversal of this sort of tree is a primary topic in computers in many different areas of software and hardware.

For a computer's file system, the tree node can contain two types of objects: a file or a subdirectory (which is a new node for the tree). What this means is that either the user places a file in the directory or makes another level down on the tree. This has been an unmodified setup since personal computers were first sold, and it has lead to a significant problem for consumers: a new level of the tree has to be generated for any separation of information. This means there is lots of back and forth for the user across the computer. The files in any directory can only be organized (grouped) if they are put into yet another subdirectory.

In other words, there is no way to group the contents of a folder within that same folder, but there can be.

As everyone knows, the contents of a folder can be sorted, alphabetically or by size and modification date. This is just a sorting algorithm, however. At the moment, within that folder there are no conventions for grouping the contents outside of subfolders.

Until this changes, it is the reason organizing files on all operating systems, from Mac OS to Windows is not simple. It is hard to organize your files, in actuality.

This phenomenon is also a demonstration of how there are many aspects to modern computers that can be improved, dramatically in some cases, because what is in place has just been there since the 1970s or 1980s.

item.title: Computer Code Needs a Document Format
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
Code is much more antiquated than it appears. It is in plain text, to start with. Typewritten text has become the definition in the minds of most programmers for the symbols that should instruct a computer. In history, other programming languages existed that made use of graphical symbols, such as the famous APL that made programs out of mathematical symbols. Though perhaps too arcane for the software programmer today, APL nevertheless demonstrated that the symbols a programmer uses can go beyond typewritten words and always spelling everything out.

No matter, modern computer code should graduate beyond its plain text legacy and begin to mirror the more advanced developments of computing of the last several decades. Hard drives were in the megabytes at the time of C++'s introduction in 1984, and processor clock speeds were in the single digit or double-digit megahertz. With much faster, capable hardware, the outcomes that programmers are trying to achieve today are much more computationally intensive, such as A.I. and real-time 3D modeling and animation. But the tools they use to build these kinds of applications are very close to the 1970s. Computer code needs a document format because computer code still exists in a very primitive and dated medium-- plain text.

For computer programming to truly advance, it should provide a presentation inside the IDE that is superior to the old type terminal screens of the 1970s. Code itself, before it is compiled, can be much more pictorial and interactive because the machines themselves can do this very easily compared to the 1970s and 1980s. A lot of catchup needs to be done in this area.

Programmers know that no matter the file extension for code, it is all .TXT. But instead, code should now sit on the hard drive in a traditional document format, just like .docx or .xlsx. Specifically, dFork singles out OpenXPS (.xps), which is like PDF made out of XML, and also GraphML, which is XML for node graphs, as references for planning out a new document file format. The goal is to bring the programming languages themselves-- at the time they are being edited inside an IDE or code editor-- into parity with the technological state of the machines. The code as it is edited inside a code editor should look more advanced than the 1970s since the software applications being made are much more advanced.

A format like .xps allows rich text and formatting for the code itself, just like exists already in Wolfram Language. The reason to use GraphML is that graph information about the program can be maintained at all times by the IDE and stored inside the file, assisting IDEs and the compilers. If there is any stored information about compilation, it can sit inside the file of code itself in the graph. The combination of these two technologies in a document format would greatly upgrade how code is parsed, rendered, and interacted with, as it would be comparatively easy to see how a project of code looks in the form of a data visualization.

The goal is to keep all existing programming practices as they are, but implement them inside a document format first so that functionality present in modern software can be provided inside the programming languages themselves. A curve variable should be assignable to an interactive curve control like below. A window variable should be assignable to an interactive representation of the window's properties. A document format that replaces plain text is necessary for these features to be implemented properly in code editors.

Many code editors have already taken the first step, setting color variables equal to color picker controls inside the IDE. The example below would just apply this convention to more situations.

Modern interactivity is much more important than people would believe because computers have advanced for decades in both processing power and storage capacity while the medium for plain text has stood completely still. A 10MB hard drive was considered sizable at the time of C++'s introduction in 1984. The situation with computer code existing behind the state of technology it is jerry-rigged to produce is much more serious than it appears to the typical programmer. When the medium for code is plain text, this is too limiting for plotting out large software systems that reside on today's hard drives that can carry gigabytes and terabytes.

Whereas building construction plans can be navigated interactively through CAD, code is in textual pieces, scattered across many different folders in a project, with no overarching view. There is no attempt to upgrade the overall form of code but instead a stubborn insistence that it remain in the antiquated state of plain text.

Importantly, the way that code is processed by GUI code editors is actively concealing how primitive the code's file format is for making advanced software. When computer code is displayed with color, this is artificial, as the text color information is completely absent in the code files. A file of code cannot tell the code editor how to color it, as it is in plain text and has no markup. Code exists just like it did in the 1970s, when it showed up in green on the black monitors. The code editors just do whatever they want to make code look more sophisticated compared to that time. They add the colors on their own (called "highlighting"), and they also add interactive functionality to computer code that the file format doesn't officially indicate anywhere. They have done this since color monitors and graphical interfaces were first made available, as a sort of shim. Few programmers would want to write code without keyword coloring , but the code files don't contain any information beyond text characters. They cannot do that inherently. They can provide nothing that would enable rich composition and form and so the GUI code editors pretend that this isn't happening.

By contrast, a web page is a document. It is a complex file format that carries all kinds of text styling information, and the web browsers are provided instructions for how the page should be laid out. There is layout of information on a web page. The problem is that there is no layout information that can be inserted into a conventional file of text.

If computer code files had these kinds of capabilities they would break away from their existing file format, plain text (.txt) for the better. It takes only a slight addition: either text styling or layout and they would necessarily depart from .txt and exist in the form of documents, just like spreadsheets and magazine page layout files. This would be mean that code is processed by the code editors in a way more fitting for the times in which we live; it would match the kind of software it is attempting to produce. The code available for making software would be a lot more pleasant to use; computers are actually thousands of times faster than the 1970s, and the applications they run are much larger and more complex.

Though the software in use today is nearly all compiled from plain text code, the plain text file format is unsatisfactory for describing complex schematics for apps and programs that can run on modern machines. The consequences are found in many news articles: bugs are cropping up as software file sizes are getting larger, and security concerns are growing alongside it. The code projects have turned into enormous haystacks that provide very little in the form of navigation.

It's all a consequence of taking the plain text file format too far for professional programming practices, so far that it is basically now immoral. Today's computers can perform many more and varied, complex tasks compared to the 1970s, to the extent it is a huge gap in era. So for a programmer to insist on writing code exactly like the 1970s indicates a lack of rational thought. An out of date file format has been stretched far beyond its suitable range, and the better path is to establish an equivalent of OpenXPS (.xps) tailored for code, perhaps inclusive of graphs (GraphML) so that precompilation information could even be stored inside the code files. Programming languages just need to be ported over to an OpenXPS-like format.

A document format implemented for code will not only provide superior compositional processes for the programmer, it will make the code projects far easier to manage and survey. If graphs (e.g. GraphML) are built into the code document files themselves, bugs will be prevented or found much earlier. Built into the situation, there will be opportunities to map out the code project in a blueprint or schematic kind of way. Subsequent to this, a whole range of upgrades would occur across the computing environment: the capabilities provided to programmers would expand into areas not available today, because for the first time the documents allow them to exist. Plain text just doesn't allow anything significant compared to interactive apps.

Features That Any Programmer Should Want from a Code Editor

Setting a variable in code equal to an interactive graph or diagram is not available in any mainstream professional programming language, and there is no downside to making this possible. To do this right, of course it has to be a document file that is establish. It is this that has to be loaded into and rendered inside the code editor-- not a plain text file.

Many other types of interactive controls can be assigned to variables, including state machines and workflows.

What is missing is a capability to add interactive, modular components to the code, utilized by the programmer. The programming language itself should be extensible: if you would like to set a variable type equal to a custom control (an animation curve control, for example) and it doesn't exist, you should be able to make this.

To provide another example: a set of designed, programmatic widgets made specifically for programming 3D modeling programs, will greatly the shorten time required for making 3D program, and the overall structure of the code will be much more sturdy and clean.

Computer code currently is only for writing what will be running inside the program. What can also be programmed-- but only when the code extends from a document format-- are the interactive widgets or components that comprise a line or section of code. In the example below, a custom widget can be programmed by the software engineer for adjusting animation curves. Another, shown beneath it, is for preparing the parameters of a window. These sorts of widgets can be contained in a document, but they would be crammed into a file of plain text with strategies that just imply it is time for a complex file format.

Sophisticated tabs and UI widgets like the ones below will allow for greatly condensing large volumes of parameters into a single line of code. There are no optimization disadvantages, as all of the parameters of such a widget end up would just produce a corresponding series of function calls in plain text.

The benefits will be huge: in many cases the interactive component will describe programmatic information in a compact form that would take many pages of plain text, if plain text would ever be used to describe it in that way at all. Some types of widgets simply are not allowed by the plain text format.

Why miss out on such a broad technological upgrade when it is just a matter of changing the code's file format from the raw plain text to something more sensible, to match today's computer hardware that is so much more advanced?

For the first, time, a group overarching conceptual processes, such as those that make up an image codec algorithm, can be placed inside a line of code.

Everywhere, software projects are becoming unmanageable because of their growing size, and security problems are a direct result.

The code compilers that formulate the executable code out of the typewritten documents will have a much better range of opportunities to know what is happening in the code files before the stage of compilation. When problems occur in the code, they will be easier to identify by the compiler in advance, as there will be actual structure internal to the documents that permits sophisticated analysis of them.

Before the program is executed, any changes to the code can be linked to the effects in a most visible way on the schematics. Schematics can exist, because code is no longer limited to plain text. Any potential negative impacts can be flagged before they are included in the finished product. At the moment, it feels unusually backwards to trace the root of a problem, they can slip in too easily with just a slight change of text. Usually, the time when a problem can be identified is after code compilation. The reason is simple, which is there isn't much substance to plain text as a file format, so there cannot be much available for analysis at the stage of programming. The tools that analyze the plain text struggle too, precisely because there is no structure present in the files, and thus their errors are often completely overlooked. Very often the warnings are wrong.

Diagrams can describe complex programmatic processes. If the file is a document, this is what can coexist with regular code. Because many processes can be summed up in a diagram, artificial intelligence applications, 3D modeling software, and all kinds of complex computer programs will be able to be rewritten without the same amount of repetitive efforts, because computer code project information (the lines of code) will not be so flat and bare like it is today.

With the use of artificial intelligence, existing code can be converted to diagrams, such that a lot of code does not have to be rewritten at all. Many chores will will be much more concise and legible.

A file of code will be much more powerful because the situation currently is that there isn't much that can be provided. The plain text file format simply does not allow expanding beyond its minute range of alphanumeric, monospaced characters.

Artificial Intelligence Is Impacted Too

After transitioning to a document format, especially one that is similar in structure to OpenXPS (.xps), the code will exist in better harmony with the state of the technology of the 2020s. It is in fact the case that artificial intelligence, or machine learning, is programmed in majority part in plain text. Where it is not, there is a semi-document or document format being used. As a matter of fact, one code editor system called Jupyter Notebook is frequently used by artificial intelligence software engineers because it fabricated its own a document format and placed it on top of the Python programming language, inside its own custom web software, so as to provide an interactive programming setup. This is actively used by a founder of OpenAI, Andrej Karpathy, in his tutorials on YouTube. Already this indicates that many programmers want more out of the programming languages. However, what Jupyter did to improve the A.I. programmer's experience with Python is not the last step to take. It did not actually change how the Python code exists and is entered into the machine, just how the programmer interacts with its results, showing graphical output in alternation with the commands that the software engineer provides. That is, the code itself was not made graphical, just the step-by-step output, as the software engineer makes the code. Thus, the programming in this system is still done in plain text, just interactively with graphical output.

Because the file format plain text is so limited, even this one move required making a document format. And just this small move made a big improvement such that artificial intelligence programmers want to use it and it made their tools like ChatGPT possible. The key issue, however, is that this was an unconscious reaction to the situation and not a deliberate effort to upgrade code to a document format. If it had been, the code itself would have been upgraded as well.

The Plain Text File Format Obscures How to Improve Computer Programming

When code continues to exist like the 1970s, in plain text, there isn't a lot that can be done with it to make it more advanced. In this case, improving it would mean mirroring the features found in the software it is attempting to manufacture.

A document format will allow insertion of non-text elements, but plain text by itself never will. Because this is still invisible to the majority of software engineering professionals, the discussions on how to improve programming become very minor. For example: should the typewritten function keyword (that declares a function) show up as "function" "func" or "fn"? Should a line of code end with a semicolon or not? It varies from one programming language to another. But none of that is necessary to resolve when the code on the computer screen is produced from a document file format. For example, each line or compound statement of code is wrapped in a graphical outline it doesn't need a semicolon anymore.

The programming languages' syntax differences consist entirely of variations in plain text (typewritten) schemes. The features are different in each programming language, but they can only be expressed in plain text, which is extraordinarily limiting.

Furthermore, many features that are added to the programming languages themselves actually arise out of the dynamic that the plain text format is producing. In newer versions of the programming languages, the additions provided inside the code are just workarounds for the file format, in actuality, but the programming language developers do not typically realize that or discuss it that way, as this isn't a common discussion.

Just this slight change, providing a document format, will upgrade the computer code that programmers use everywhere as a whole, bringing it up to the conditions found in the rest of the computer, matching the code to the much larger hard drives, the machines' graphics capabilities, the faster bus speeds on the motherboards, and larger memory sizes. The desire for this is there already, expressed every day-- not just by artificial intelligence software engineers who use tools like Jupyter Notebook for programming with Python00 but other types of programmers who use specialized programming languages like Wolfram Language, sketching out their initial programs one step at a time.

Perhaps a painful realization has to be accepted before there can be real progress in computer code: if even color scheme information cannot be provided inside the file, this shows how limited the computer code files have been for making software for the last few decades, going to back when computers could handle color on high resolution displays. A document file format could have existed a long time ago, but this was not how software engineering development proceeded.

Because the plain text code files still cannot contain font, color, page layout, or other styling information, they were, the whole time, very constrained in how they could evolve. Programming languages remain essentially the same as three decades ago; Apple's Mac OS relies on code from the late 1980s. Although the impression is provided to everyone that computer companies are always advancing, in reality most of the time the flagship software has code in it stretching back two or more decades. The PostScript programming language that makes up a PDF file, for example, was formulated in the 1980s and is essentially the same. It was made for machines with very limited memory. Sometimes it is just the hardware that has advanced, around the computer code that has remained almost the entirely same the entire time.

The main cause is that the evolution of computer code has been confined to what can exist inside this very limited text file format, .txt, even though computers have gained much more capacity to provide interactions on the computer screen. But there is another issue, which is that the people who would redesign the code are often left out of discussions when computer programming comes up, and this is another cause.

Many software engineers might object to this viewpoint, but as soon as a document format is made, it becomes evident immediately that plain text will have to be transcended eventually, as it is already moving gradually in that direction out of necessity.

For example: a math matrix should be presented in a form that is like a math matrix on paper, in a box of some sort, not broken up into individual typewriter lines just because of the constraints of plain text. Doing this, making a document format, does not change the compiled result. The compiler does not change until someone begins to improve that as well in response to the new situation. Initially, upgrading the file format just changes what form the code takes inside the code editors. The compilers can accept the same instructions. Later, they can be modified so that they remain optimized.

When we say that computer code should have a document format, we are saying that instructions for how to arrange the code on the screen should be contained inside the code files, just like how web pages contain this.

The Software Engineering Community Believes That Computer Code Must Be Made Out of Plain Text

Currently, all professional programming language code for making apps is stored in plain text (.txt), and even though this file format is no longer adequate, there is some kind of residual feeling in many individuals that this is the only way it could exist. Since it always looks like typewritten text, people commonly think that code must be in typewritten text. The other side of this is that many people have attempted to upgrade computer code in the wrong direction, which seemed to support the notion that computer code is synonymous with plain text.

There is no room for expanding what a file of plain text can do on a modern computer screen. It cannot provide any instructions about how it should be laid out, so the code always looks like typewritten text.

The stubborn situation has produced absurd results, particularly in the area of computer graphics. Take for example math matrices just mentioned. They are used to make computer graphics software. They change the location and form of the onscreen objects, for one. On paper, and in print, math matrices are laid out on 2 dimensional grid (columns and rows). But in code, math matrices are typed out as if using a typewriter. Most unpleasantly, a multi-column matrix is by default typed out on a single line and has to be manually formatted to be a matrix of information.

First this indicates that a mathematical topic cannot be treated as a unit by the code editor, which is a major consistency problem. The issue is that there are a lot of areas like this in computer programming, that many areas are not satisfactorily represented in the code, and that's why moving the file format up to a document is extremely important.

As we mentioned, in the early days the plain text would just show up as green on the old computer monitors. It's not classic code that was on those machines, as if people had established what should exist onwards. The limitations of those old computer programs were brought into today, with computer companies stuffing more into this dated file format all the time. When color monitors became mainstream, the software programmers came up with their own programs running in the background of the code editor for analyzing the same old typewriter text, just to color it. Then as the years went by there were functions added inside the code editor. But no one actually changed how code files exist. And it is all the same as back then in the 1970s.

The files of code should now be able to contain font, styling, and other related information, including layout. A file of plain text (.txt) is as its name describes: it only contains a flat stream of individual text characters. A to Z, space, return, 0-9, and punctuation (./{}*[],;) is a basic summary of all that is allowed. Regardless of the programming language used, whether it is Java, C++, or Python, the code is composed, edited, and stored in this manner. It is all just .txt, but interpreted in a different way by each code editor, on its own, according to what its developers came up with. All mainstream programming languages just renamed plain text (.txt) to their own file extension (.java, .cpp, .py). It's that superficial. Then, the actual distinctions in syntax across all of the programming languages actually exist inside the topic of plain text. It is the plain text medium where syntax distinctions take place.

As soon as a file is in a document format, this expands the information that the code files can contain because whatever you find. Computer code files are not yet generated as documents.

Many Professionals Programmers Believe That Programming Is Synonymous with a Plain Text Experience Too

For many reasons, this basic file format has become associated with programming itself. There are two major depictions: the Hollywood depictions of code, then there is plain text, which is associated with actually doing work with a computer's instructions. But this is an incorrect conception of the situation. Furthermore, using plain text for code is now a mismatched situation, because this very bare format is being used to make software for machines that are thousands of times faster than the 1970s, when the programming systems could not actually process much more than plain text. The kinds of programming languages that could exist-- if code took on a document format-- would be great in variety and the distinctions among them could actually be significant and not limited to minor plain text differences.

Because plain text is actually inadequate for programming the latest software applications, the code editors that the majority of software engineers use have effectively transformed their interactions with plain text such that they actually treat the code files like documents. Plain text has very few features, and so the code editors provided by Google, Apple, and Microsoft start implementing normal graphical software features inside it.

There is an unfounded notion in computer science, shared by many computer scientists and software engineers, that computer code (specifically the kind that makes apps and system programs) is inextricably tied to this old file format because of its supposed simplicity, but that is just a result of the topic not having been discussed by the majority. Secondly there has been no company that would try to upgrade it consistent with its existing conditions. When there have been attempts to upgrade it beyond plain text, they have approached it from far away from how code exists presently. They always want to do things from a position far outside of how software is made, then come in and change it, which means that code never has had an opportunity to leave the plain text file format.

There is nothing about computer code that ties it to plain text except historical developments in business. Efforts to change the programming situation have comprised of attempts to dictate code from the outside, often going the diagrammatic route out of context of the code that people write already, which is far away from fitting into the computing environment. Put simply, an elevation of computer code should just start by changing the file format to a document format, just like how a web page, spreadsheet, or other type of complex information document exists. Then the changes have to occur gradually such that they are compatible at each step.

Because plain text is so closely associated with code itself, it has to be mentioned here that computer code is just a set of symbols and words for instructing the computer to perform operations according to what the engineers want. As long as the set of symbols accomplishes the goal, producing optimized software, and as long as it is something the programmer can easily use and become skilled with, it does not matter what file format is being used. It can be a document format.

The point of the program's code is to instruct the computer, and since the computer has upgraded its capabilities since the 1970s-- a time when computer code could only exist as plain text-- then the code can be upgraded to match everything else. Interacting with plain text has worked up until this point, but it doesn't even matter what specific file format the computer code takes, whether it is pictorial even, as long as it is up to standard in terms of efficiency of execution and can be made use of by professional software engineers. For many reasons, though, software engineers believe, almost anywhere, that it has to be in plain text, that only plain text will really work, and that anything else is going to lead to problems and bad user interfaces. This is just the impression they have formed after interacting with programming systems that attempted to dictate from the outside how code is.

Another point is that the expertise required to upgrade plain text code to a better state has not been around for the last several decades. As mentioned, when companies have attempted to upgrade code, they have not started from its present state, as it exists in plain text, but instead tried to shape the situation from the outside, from a level that does not have a possibility of meshing with how software engineers make code. So, the software engineers all formed the notion that code cannot be upgraded much without causing problems. In actuality, it is the file format that has to be upgraded. It can be moved to a document format, which doesn't dictate how people write code until later in the situation.

There is yet another side to this: the code editors have unknowingly been upgrading code to a semi-document format the whole time over the last few decades. The last decade in particular has seen code editors add a large number of code-writing conveniences. When they do this, they are implementing modern GUI software application features on top of the plain text format of the old days of computers, interpreting this plain text to make it behave like a regular software document.

Those Who Prefer Emacs and Vi Editors

The plain text file format is something ingrained in the typical software engineer to the point it is unknown how many programmers would be receptive to something different in form. Additionally, there are some programmers (who exist as a vocal minority) who do not use GUI-based code editors for their code, and they claim that the best code is written with very raw, command line text editors, such as emacs and vi. That may hold for some types of programs. However, this is an impractical viewpoint at major software and video game companies, where the code has to be edited side by side with the windows and GUI controls, as well as the images, databases, or 3D models that the program makes use of. Professional programming done in commercial business environments uses the high-end, GUI-based code editors (called IDEs) and only on minor tasks would there be the luxury to stay inside an antiquated text editor that works inside interactivity of a computer terminal era.

Code Editors Are Unintentionally Making Documents or Semi-Documents out of The Plain Text

It is inevitable that plain text would fail to hold up for the kinds of apps that professional software engineers make today. Since code is edited on computers with graphical interfaces (not old computer terminals), code editors have unintentionally ended up interpreting the plain text files as documents. It makes sense to be able to pick a color for a color variable, so lately GUI color pickers are often placed inside the plain text by the code editor.  This is minor progress, but it shows that at this point, a document format-- the equivalent of OpenXPS (.xps) for code files-- is necessary.  The volume and complexity of code has increased with each decade, yet no document format has been admitted into the code editors yet.

This is true for all major programming languages, from Python to C++ to JavaScript, which simply have changed the .txt extension to their own. 

Code editors are doing everything to enhance their idiomatic interactions with the .txt format instead of just moving to a document format. Other examples include making interactive controls that recognize and collapse/expand sections of code. This is when it gets truly absurd because the code does not actually contain structured data to tell the code editor where the sections are. With the advent of graphical user interfaces, the concept of a document emerged.  Documents can contain structured information to tell the code editor where the sections are. A web page, for example, is a document, just like a spreadsheet.

What's more, a document can contain complex information, styling, and also multimedia elements. Page layout documents for magazines and newspapers are also in a document format.  Their information can be arranged into multiple columns. 

By comparison, plain text is extremely bare.  There is nothing about plain text that fuses it to computer code in terms of computer science; it is just what people have used.  Currently, a file of code cannot be organized in a complex way-- as long as it remains in plain text.

Because plain text is so limited, code editors have gone out of their way to interpret it, placing modern software features on top this basic file format.  They add functionality to code files that goes beyond conventional editing of text-- such as autocompleting function names and variables and depositing large chunks of pre-made code.  They even generate small thumbnails of the plain text files.  GUI breakpoints are placed to the side of the plain text code.  At this point, the mainstream code editors should formally transition to a document file format.

With the increasing size of code repositories, the need for a document format for code is becoming obvious so that code is more like regular engineering documents.  Such a format can allow the software programmers to survey large volumes of complex information.  The quantity of programmatic information has grown dramatically over the decades, yet organizing features have not been added to programming's medium, as plain text is the medium and it prevents this.

Conclusion

The plain text file format inhibits code from embedding complex information, something as basic as keyword coloring for the file.  At the same time, code editors are attempting to circumvent these limitations more and more. The code editors are much more feature-filled than they were a decade and a half ago: they do embed interactive functionality in the editing software. This is why it is time to upgrade the file format for code to match computer software, not old terminals.

By transitioning from plain text to a document format, code can take advantage of technological advancements that have occurred since the 1970s.  Especially for large repositories, code can be viewed in the form of a map or blueprint.  It can be inspected from an overview level, instead of just 20 to 30 lines at a time.

The conversion of programming language files into a formal document structure allows for the proper incorporation of modern software features, and not the shims that exist in code editors today.  The compiled result will remain unchanged in terms of speed, as it is only the representation of code that is changed.

dFork has another article on this topic here, and it is explained how to convert a typical programming language to XML.

item.title: Wire Up The Windows If You'd Like. Software Applications Operate In Isolation from One Another
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
When a web page loads inside a web browser, no other application can access the information inside the web page, unless the user performs copy and paste. If, on the other hand, the application windows can publish data ports on them, just like in node-based programming, they can transmit information, multimedia data, and live application events between one another. One application will be able to make use of another, such as a web browser. This is a major expansion of the utility of an operating system and improves the value of its application ecosystem.

With relatively little effort on the part of developers, all windows from all applications can publish and receive data. It is the advanced or pro user who will make use of this extension to windows. The windows' ports will be programmed by the app developer with the same kinds of routines that make copy and paste happen. For the first time, applications will make use of one another, out of the box.

The underlying application situation is that there are common classifications of data that applications are engaged with, which is what makes copy-and-paste simple in the first place. From one viewpoint, inter-application communication is too limited today. It only exists as drag-and-drop or copy-and-paste.

It isn't that all windows would reveal their ports at all times. By default, they would look the same as today. The data ports only would be displayed on a window after the user decides to use them. And the type of user would certainly be enthusiast-level or prosumer.

Once the advanced computer user is provided the well-known connector lines already used in node-based programming, it will be possible to assemble programmatic flows, making custom meta-applications out of multiple running programs. The specific data ports desired by the user are chosen on the back side of the window and then made available on the front. Separate applications, written by different vendors, will be able to "talk" to each other and make use of each other's functionality.

Computers are supposed to be flexible, and the functionality of today's computer programs should be opened up this way so that the work done by one software developer in one app can be utilized beyond its confines. Computers were not powerful enough to do this when the concept of an app was introduced with the Macintosh.

Already, a software developer does not have to know how the the copy and paste command is going to be used, just what the category of data is that will be copied. It will be no different for the window's displayed node ports, when they can publish and receive data. But unlike copy and paste, which are single operations, the connector lines can represent live transmission lines for data.

Returning to the first example, when the web page finishes loading in a web browser's window, a different application that has a connector attached to it can be notified of a specific event (e.g. a new page loads or the page scrolls) and also access the contents of the page, processing it afterwards. In this scenario, the pro user can greatly enhance his use of the computer, for his own needs. In keeping with the goals of Xerox PARC in the 1970s, eventually even the elements on the web pages themselves can also accept and receive connector lines. All advanced users will find many varied kinds of uses for the ports on windows. Their contents can reveal ports as well.

In this upgraded configuration, information can travel across three or more software applications, in a chain, undergoing processing at each step.  If desired, an application's keyboard or mouse event can be sent to different windows, for three different apps, at the same time. In other words, a single key press can be sent to three other applications from its originating window, if configured by the user. This demonstrates the broad flexibility added to desktop software by implementing node-based programming schemes inside the windows themselves. All that is needed is the OS vendors' addition of ports on the windows inside the existing software development kits.

At Xerox, Software Was Supposed to Be Interconnectable

The original goal of the Xerox Alto desktop computer at Xerox PARC (which was the basis of the Macintosh) was to have everything that was programmed connectable to anything else. Any object was supposed to be accessible by another object, able to communicate and receive messages. All of this was supposed to be done on the code level, however (but those machines were made in the 1970s). Instead, what software is about today is isolated commercial silos, and the functional parts of each application are completely sealed off from one another.

The provision of ports on application windows will make this interconnectedness of software possible for the prosumer instead of just someone like a programmer at Xerox. It may reveal what has been missing after applications have existed as silos the entire time. All kinds of meta-applications will become possible for the user, constructed on the fly in just a few steps, because node-based programming is something any pro computer user can take up. People from all kinds of backgrounds, in audio production and computer graphics must learn this already in their use of professional software. So, this is far away from expecting the prosumer public to write code in some unfamiliar scheme.

Concepts of a software application today are in large part a consequence of the Macintosh and how it defined an application and a document in the 1980s, though much of that was also from the Xerox Star machine. Accomplishing this expansion of what all software applications can offer by allowing them to connect to each other is simply a matter of the operating system allowing devs to declare what code functions will provide the ports inside their software. The demands to implement this are relatively small, being similar to drag-and-drop and copy-and-paste. Copy and paste has to be programmed specifically for all apps already, and this is the same kind of software programming logic. In the terminology of programming, it is a matter of the app software engineer providing the system a set of callback functions. Of course, it could be time-consuming if a window has many ports.

Not Implementing This Leaves Software Unnecessarily Limited

Whether it is Mac OS or Windows, a software vendor puts a lot of effort into its own software application and does not consider what other apps might be doing. It is an artificial situation, but there was never an opportunity for an app to connect to another meaningfully. The use of the operating system currently exists in the form of application silos. We all believe that this is how software should exist, but people are more able to conceive of computers somewhat differently when they know it is a historical byproduct.

There is plenty of live software event information that can be provided from one app to another at the moment, and in the future the app ecosystem will be able to develop around this new system-wide shift towards interconnected capabilities of the apps.

Live, inter-application, node-based programming treating all windows as the patches or nodes is the kind of system-wide feature offering that has to be established by the operating system vendor, unfortunately. It cannot be put in by application developers themselves cooperating with one another on their own. An operating system that provides it will be far ahead in terms of computer extensibility.

Software Will Reach Beyond Its Size

A small software application commonly exist to serve a single purpose, but even for a smaller application, the ability to hook into other apps will expand its usefulness. To give an example: if there is an app and its sole purpose is to take audio data from a song file and visualize it real-time on the screen with animations, it is not a suite of functionality like an audio production application. By convention, the file is imported by the user inside such a visualizer application, prompting the user to navigate through files on the hard drive. After the file is selected, the app can process what has been imported. But in the future, the audio data can come from a different running application. The structure of software will change, to be more fluid and flexible.

The audio data fed to this music visualizer application can come from a web browser window that is playing audio. The music visualizer make take audio from somewhere else, such as a video conferencing app. All of this live information will be possible to publish between the apps and windows. In our example, the small app visualizes the audio. But to give another example, any kind of transcription software would receive the same benefits: any video on the web would be transcribable-- just a matter of hooking up a connector line from the video on a web page to the running app. Regardless of its purpose, it can accept the live audio data. If an app serves to mix video from different sources, it can take video from one or more web browser windows and mix that with a video file playing from the hard drive. What people use the computer for will expand greatly.

Even video game players will find something in this. The data to be processed, whether it is audio or video, can also come from the window of a video game being played. Just like copy and paste, the specific use of any published data on a given window does not have to be predicted by the video game software developer. The video game can choose to publish score information. How that score information is used does not need to be known ahead of time. It can even provide live event information of what is happening inside the game, such as the character's position and movement, which can be utilized in another application.

If Copying And Paste Is Essential, This May Be Viewed That Way Too

Since the beginning of graphical interfaces on the personal computer, an individual software application has never been set up to interact with another one regularly outside of copy and paste. Yet, copying and pasting chunks of data between software is certainly regarded as essential. This is an example of where the output of one application is already utilized by another because the operating system behaves as the intermediate manager of data. Enabling the wiring up of windows takes the situation up a level by recognizing that applications can feed into one another.

As a person performs some activity in one application, it can be mirrored and processed inside two or three other ones. It is the ability to provide live streams of data between applications that will show how much better desktop software can be. The specialized software in one category will be usable by specialized software in another, which would be unprecedented.

The Internet can be utilized in all of this, too. What happens in an application can be transmitted to a remote server. What happens on a remote server can be pulled in and transmitted through multiple applications. A regular consumer can, with just a few steps of hooking up the connecting lines between windows, transmit his web browsing session to a remote video streaming server, just to give an example. Previously, it might have required a plug-in for the browser that was specially made for that one purpose. Software will not have to anticipate everything specific that people want to do on the machine.

Automation will become much easier. Whenever an application successfully completes a significant operation, such as the rendering of an image or 3D movie, it can report this to any other application that has been hooked up to receive a notification. The rendering can be uploaded right away to a file server or it could be e-mailed or posted to a social website (or all at the same time), by exporting from the same data port.

What this shows is that how people use the desktop computer can change, such that user can play a more active role in what they get out of the machine. This will translate to less reliance on specific software. There won't be a need to purchase so much software for every minor task and there will be uses of the computer available right away that are not even feasible today. Of course, for those who don't want to be wiring up windows, the software will work as it does today.

Apps That Are Just Nodes

The computing world has one concept for a GUI-based executable program and that is "application", one that has buttons, controls, or displays graphics. But as soon as all applications recognize the newly-provided functionality to publish data, a different category of application will come to exist on the operating system alongside the others, one that is not necessarily launched into the taskbar (or "Dock"), but is just a very complex node that sits in between the application windows. The applications all provide lots of functionality, but there may be a need to have filters that sit between them.

If there are so many connector lines, there can be application-independent nodes that act as intermediates and often the purpose will be to process the information moving between them. They will be launched inside the operating system just like an app. But they won't be apps.

A base set of these nodes will be provided by the operating system, to begin with. When they become very large but are still just serving the purpose of nodes, they might be called node-applications. One such node-application might exist only to accept live data so as to transmit it to a specific server type. But if it launched as an application, that wouldn't make sense because it only fits into the new availability of ports on windows. This kind of node-application is an intermediate node. Any kind of intermediate node can be acknowledged by the operating system as a running application window of its own, but the purpose is to operate within this setup.

At the moment, the film editing software won't ever talk to graphics animation software written by a different company. It might not seem like anyone would want to do this, but when it is possible, the various functions built into each application will be tappable by the others. In turn, the software developers will recognize this new feature. If the operating system allows publishing node-based ports on all of the windows, providing a software development kit for software engineers to export the functionality they already wrote, the software ecosystem will anticipate further uses of the nodes. This will lead to an evolution of desktop computer software.

How It Would Work

In the example of a web page being loaded, by dragging a line from the data port of the web page's window to a window of a different application, that other application then accepts web page event information. All of the ports can actually sit on the other side of the window in a grid layout, with the window flipping around like a card. Then, whichever port are being used could be selected by the user, then displayed on the sides of the window on the front.

There are three locations for the ports:

  • -- The application level (for events indicating when the application quits, prints, etc.), attached to the application image in the Dock or taskbar.
  • -- The window level (for activity pertaining to the whole window)
  • -- The window's objects level (for hooking up a connector to a specific object found inside the window, carrying its own available ports).

To summarize, each window in the operating system can, by default, publish ports, and then the developers can further customize the ports. But there are events at the application level and there are also complex objects inside a window that produce events and data as well.

The operating system will manage node-based programming operations taking place across applications, just like how it manages copy and paste between applications. In a big way, the user will be making uses of software out of software, because the windows will allow this. When software engineers participate in publishing functionality, the state of the ecosystem will be better.

As mentioned, the operating system itself can provide a set of intermediary nodes, too, which are not tied to specific application, but instead serve to filter or transform the data.

By wiring up windows, the following can occur

  • -- The time information from a timeline can be published from an application window in real time, to any other application.
  • -- When an e-mail is received in the mail app, it can notify another app and transmit the e-mail message's information as well.
  • -- The information stored in a contact list in the address book application is sent to another application easily, by dragging a line to it. But this type of line evaporates after it is attached, as it is just a one-time action, drawing information from one source to another.
  • -- When a web page is loaded inside a web browser, the window can provide a port that allows accessing the contents of the page by any application. The user hooks up to various applications and can then, for example, get access to all of the images of the page within another application. The lines between the windows hook up the same way as node-based programming.

For Connectors, Specific Uses Do Not Need to Be Known In Advance

Copy and paste is the lead-in for this discussion on how to advance desktop computer operating systems, specifically how they provide GUI-based software. Copy and paste is a universal bridge between software written by developers who likely never talked to each other. When data is copied using Control + C or Command + C, it is placed onto the operating system's pasteboard.

The computer immediately provides a higher level of value to the consumer. Two software vendors do not ever have to have collaborated in advance, but they know the kinds of things that will be done with their data, just like they know this when they write copy and paste routines for their apps. They only need to provide transmitting and receiving ports on the windows. It will be possible to hide ports, of course.

This will allow applications to transmit information, software events, and other information regardless of whether the software developers of separate applications anticipated this.

The entire operating system will become completely customizable. And because software developers can choose to publish and accept specific types of information on the windows, they will be able to enable their applications to fit into this larger model.

To give an example, there is already a small bridge between all software, one which has been provided from the very beginning, and that is copy and paste. Copy and paste is a kind of bulletin board managed by the operating system that all software applications can access.

But it stopped there. The live mouse activity from a drawing program cannot be transmitted to another application running behind it unless one or both developers agree to inter-application communication. That is simply a technical limitation of the current setup.

Conclusion

All Windows, All Software Applications, Will Publish Node-Based Programming Ports

To give an example, the pasteboard process sits outside of all running applications and is supervised by the operating system. Because of the pasteboard, if a web browser copies an image from a web page, it can be pasted directly into a photo editor, a film editor, or 3D modeling program. This demonstrates the immense value provided by connectibility between software applications. The next goal then, is to extend beyond just the pasteboard pattern that bridges software applications and to make all kinds of information and activity transmissible in the same kind of universal way, one that does not require specific and advanced participation by the software developers. The pasteboard just involves the transmission of isolated chunks of data. It does not link software applications together. does not transmit keyboard events or other types of live activity and data.

In any node-based programming situation, computer programs are made by wiring up boxes containing live data ports. But when node-based programming is applied as if application windows themselves are nodes, and this is available across the operating system, this will be deep, fluid customization of the computer's software functionality.

How would the two software applications talk to each and in a form that is of value to the computer user? At first, a lay person might ask why this would be desirable, to have two software applications talk to each other or transmit information, but that is largely for not knowing what the implications are.

Certainly mainstream and effective for many tasks, node-based programming is a feature built into various professional software applications, but inside the applications.

Every window contains a lot of parameters and functionality. Configured a different way, it can become a node in a larger node-based programming environment.

What would it take for a vector-drawing program to communicate with the web browser in a meaningful way besides copy and paste? This doesn't exist inside the current scheme of operating systems. Once it does, the entire computing environment will change and the concept of what can exist on the operating system in executable form also changes.

item.title: The Shopping Cart
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
ABOVE: AN OVERSIZED PROMOTIONAL SHOPPING CART IN FRONT OF A GROCERY STORE OWNED BY SYLVAN GOLDMAN. Source: The Cart That Changed The World by Terry P. Wilson

Interview with Sylvan Goldman

The video below features an interview with Sylvan Goldman, the person who designed the first shopping cart. The interview was conducted in 1977 by Charles Kuralt, a CBS television program host who traveled across the country in a motor home to interview everyday Americans.

Instead of the everyday person, Sylvan is the focus of the interview, for being the man who established the first use of shopping carts. Later, he sold a variation of the shopping cart in the form of luggage carts, first for train travel and then airports. Interestingly, it was only on account of train station workers threatening a strike after seeing the carts that Goldman decided to call up the Oklahoma City airport and sell the remainder of his carts for air travel. After that, luggage carts came to be available in airports everywhere. Another variation that Goldman produced is the grocery store restocking cart (for restocking store shelves). All of these seem obvious today, but they were not in use previously, and they came to be more important as refrigeration became more widespread and the nation's population increased after the second world war.

Establishing the shopping cart and its offshoots like the luggage cart took a fair amount of "hustle," something that has always been characteristic of grocery retail marketing because of slim profit margins, the need to move high volumes of product, and the intense levels of competition.

That Sylvan is featured on Charles Kuralt's television program as an exception reflects the perceived mundanity of the shopping cart, as it was typically regular people who were Kuralt's subject matter. Furthermore, other interviews with Goldman are not readily available besides this one, showing that when reporters look to interview notable individuals, they may be looking for a popular name surrounding an exciting subject. This is despite how pervasive the shopping cart is and how retail stores have evolved around it. Many stores, such as Wal-Mart and Target came about entirely because it had caught on.

According to Goldman's biography, money was not actually the obsession in his life, just an activity like any other. But a person might get a different impression from how the interview is conducted by Kuralt. For the most part, it appears that Goldman attempted to stay out of the spotlight and this is another reason why he is not associated with the shopping cart.

Unchanged Since the 1960s

For several decades, the design of the shopping cart has remained unchanged, and this is because its design is not accidental. Its features were modified over time in response to retail store conditions. As we will explain, there is a second part to the story, which is the essential modification of nesting that a different person, a man named Orla Watson, came up with in the 1940s. Subsequent to the nesting of carts, Sylvan Goldman took over further refinement, turning the cart into what it is today.

There can be plenty to improve upon with the shopping cart, but it will take a different process than just looking at the cart for a short while and then coming up with dictates. Manufacturers modified the shopping cart over time such that it is now tailored for the retail settings. When it is this adapted for the environment, superficial assessments on how to upgrade it will fall flat. Usually they just involve attaching electronics or making the cart out of a different material like plastic.

In the initial years, the shopping cart (image above) comprised of two detached wire baskets sitting on two shelves of a foldable, rolling frame. Sylvan Goldman, in 1936, in Oklahoma City came up with this design after he observed two folding chairs in his office one evening. He then realized that this could be a workable foundation for a rolling cart. As explained in the interview above, women were the main shopping customers in those times, and he noticed that they often struggled to carry a full basket and their purses at the same time. Goldman worked with his maintenance man to build the first carts in a downtown Oklahoma City maintenance building set up for his stores.

The carts were not simple for Goldman to market at first, being initially shunned by nearly all customers, but eventually he prevailed and they caught on. As the video above explains, it took hiring models, who used them in the store, to persuade customers to try them out. Goldman did everything needed to get the shopping cart in use across the country, but he wasn't the only contributor to its evolutionary process that resulted in how it looks today.

Orla Watson's Nesting of The Shopping Cart

About a decade later, in 1947, another individual came along, Orla Watson of Kansas City, and he devised the hinged flap that allows for the carts to be nested, something with us today. He is also the person who fused the two baskets to the frame of the cart. Because of Orla, the carts nest into each other. Previously, the cart's frame was folded up just like a folding chair and the baskets were placed into a nearby stack, which was a manual process that had to be done for each customer. This was not a problem when the stores were small like they were in the late 1930s.

Orla's nesting of the carts, in addition to saving space, allowed for self-service retrieval of the cart by the shopper, setting the stage for many retail stores in the coming decades that would rely entirely on customers' use of the shopping cart. This self-service aspect is not remarked upon, but it is what allows big retail stores to exist they way they have: the store personnel do not need to assemble and disassemble the carts for customers as they come in and leave. If they did, it would slow the whole retail experience down. That improvement only was possible after Orla Watson's upgrade. Nesting is not only about space-saving (estimated to reduce space to 1/5 according to Watson) but also self-service.

The features of the shopping cart, adapted over time, have reflected the needs of the retail environment and the shoppers. For instance, there is a fold-out flap for placing a child in the cart to face the mother. As soon as the first shopping carts were introduced by Sylvan Goldman in the late 1930s, children were placed into them, and so that is why today there is the fold-out seat. It is a need that surfaced early on. In the early days, as mentioned, women were the main grocery store shoppers. The space on the bottom of modern carts allows placing heavier items like large sacks.

Discussing The Initial Resistance to The Shopping Cart

It sounds simple that there is a shopping cart now. But, as mentioned, the first day that Goldman attempted to introduce the shopping cart to his stores the patrons initially did not want them and completely ignored them. After having taken out an ad in the newspaper, Sylvan assumed that when he arrived on the morning of the cart's introduction that his device would be a "sensation." Instead, the carts were standing untouched at each of the stores.

According to a biography of Goldman, women remarked that the work the cart involved was something they already had to do when they moved a baby stroller. Men saw it as taking away their job to carry heavy objects whenever the hand baskets became full. For women, at Goldman's stores, if a hand basket ever became full, it was usually set aside at one of the check stands and an empty one was provided.

Since it wasn't until Goldman hired models to shop with his carts in the store that customers tried them out, what this shows is that people may bring preconceived feelings and concepts to a situation and what they need might not be what they immediate accept without explanation. Second, not all situations allow an explanation, like a grocery store The wheeled shopping cart was initially regarded as an unfamiliar or foreign object in the grocery store because a new concept had to be tried out, with customers familiarizing themselves with it. The stores of today exist around it, so this may not make sense, but in those times the cart was being inserted into a format only known for providing hand baskets. After the customers saw the models shop with the carts, they recognized how it could work according to Goldman's own objectives, then they became comfortable using them. So, they needed to know what the goals were of the device by seeing it used.

This was also true elsewhere after Goldman succeeded in getting his own customers to use the cart in his stores: grocers in the eastern part of the country, where he first promoted it after putting it in his stores, did not understand the rolling cart, even though Goldman had them in active use in Oklahoma City. In response, Goldman shot film footage of his own employees and models using the carts in the store-- just like his customers were doing during the daytime-- and then he had that footage shown to prospective cart buyers. Afterwards, orders for the carts came in.

Even though the grocery customers did not understand the value of a shopping cart, what Goldman possessed held immense value for them, as there was a genuine problem being addressed that Goldman had observed: women were struggling to carry overfull grocery hand baskets and their belongings at the same time. Placing two of these baskets onto a rolling cart made a lot of sense. But the customers might not be able to realize that, not seeing their own situation. The folding mechanism came out of the need to set aside the frame once a cart was not in use. (Otherwise, all of the carts would have taken up too much space.)

It's says on the first advertisement that Goldman had commissioned the manufacture of multiple carts in advance for each store. Though the biography does not mention it, the shock and disappointment must have been significant at the time because that is more than one store. The later success would overshadow such an event and maybe make it something Goldman didn't want to mention-- as if he were complaining about a hard time preceding a huge success. But he had made enough carts for multiple stores that morning. And he had them made in his own maintenance building. It looks like, in actuality, Goldman hired the models because he was in a significant dilemma in addition to wanting to see people use the carts. His purpose in hiring the models was to overcome the retail environment's psychological obstacle that he didn't expect to be there. But his expertise in the grocery business was not small, having spent his entire life in this profession, so he was the right person to attempt to get people to use the carts.

The reason he expected the shopping cart to be an automatic hit is that he was in the position to see that it would be-- if people saw it for what it was. It is simply that he didn't know that they would not initially. Once they did, customers took the cart up everywhere. So, the objective of hiring the models was not to persuade people to an ideological viewpoint, but to have them see the cart for what it was, to see what problem it was addressing that they actually had. It was, in actuality, that they did not understand their own situation, that they basically needed a rolling cart right then in history. And when they understood it, they all got behind it.

Subsequently, and around the same time, economic and technological environmental factors advanced, allowing different buying patterns: in the next two decades, refrigeration and freezers became more common in the household, more spending money became available for foods, and the automobile became commonplace, allowing people to carry larger purchases home from a greater distance.

Stores expanded and evolved in response to all of these changes in the environment. The first shopping carts were small relative to today's because the stores were not the same. They were smaller because it was a time period with a smaller population and a different urban setup, that needed time to grow around the cart, which relates to the automobile and refrigeration.

Attempts to "Update" The Shopping Cart

Some attempts have been made to "update" the shopping cart, but there has to be a purpose to doing that, which is why most efforts have not gone beyond adding gadgets. The features of the shopping cart developed over time, in response to the needs and interests of the retail environment, and they are not as accidental as they appear. When there is a product is as mundane as a shopping cart, it might be assumed by the public that a cart design was simply made and that was the end of the matter.
