But, as just explained, the real story of the shopping cart was more; it was one of response and evolution. For example, after shopping carts became well-established and popular, it was then possible to enlarge the basket, to make a cart with just one large wire basket instead of the two. Then, after a full decade of the modern shopping cart in the 1950s (below), stores like Target and Wal-Mart were able to be established in the early 1960s. They exist entirely around the shopping cart, though online shopping is now a significant portion of their sales.

The Wheels on The Cart: Caster Wheels

The name of the wheel part on a shopping cart is "caster wheel". Caster wheels are the source of the problem that many people encounter when they go to a store and have a bad cart experience. They were there at the very beginning, on the first shopping carts. Because they are solid and are not filled with air, they never have flats. Dirt and debris can accumulate on the sides though, making them stick.

There are two shortcomings of the shopping cart: first that that the wheels wear out or get stuck easily, and second that it makes a lot of noise when being nested and un-nested. Addressed in a different article on dFork, they also cause crowding issues when many people have come to the store.

To address the wheels being a weak point of the device, what is important is to change the repair situation. At dFork, it is believed that any grocery store employeeshould be able to replace caster wheels on a shopping cart, just as easily as unclipping a bicycle wheel. But at the moment, the caster wheels are affixed with a bolt, requiring a wrench, which means that only maintenance staff will replace the wheel. At many stores, it is an outside service contracted to repair the wheels. Since bicycle wheels can be unclipped and clipped on, they are a useful reference for shopping cart caster wheels of the future. A caster wheel that can be removed easily when it is damaged will be replaced much sooner.

Installing a retrofit adapter on each shopping cart wheel, one that lets employees unclip worn-out caster wheels and clip on new ones, will address the problem of stuck, squeaky, or worn out wheels. Bending down and unclipping a wheel is something most people can do. After this exists, the wheels will get replaced all the time,as any employee can do it in a few minutes. It would be helpful if this kind of adapter only worked with a special tool, so thatshopping cart wheels are only able to be taken off only by the stores. There would be a lot of adapters to buy, four per cart, so a store could gradually install the adapters on the carts over time.

In the first place: why are there so many shopping carts with worn-out wheels? If there are 100 carts, there are 400 wheels that can have an issue. It only takes one wheel on a cart for there to be an issue.

In a different dFork article, we discuss how to get rid of the shopping cart completely during the retail experience.

Designed Features of The Shopping Cart

The modern shopping cart meets several requirements that keeps it unchanged. First, it has to be durable for both indoor and outdoor environments, with its wheels able to travel across smooth floors and concrete. It has to be able to be rained on and even recovered after has been buried in snowed. The parts that are not metal (e.g. the handlebar) that can wear out have to be small in number. In terms of usability, it has to be able to be steered easily by the public. It also has to be stored in a compact way. Finally, it has to be easily cleaned if it gets dirty.

Each feature of the shopping cart was part of Goldman's later business, the Folding Carrier Company in Oklahoma City, where he manufactured and designed the later carts. Methods for bending the wire had to be devised, and basically a small area of industry had to be devised as well. One of the interim stage models of the big modern shopping cart would look very strange to customers today (the one above), yet they were produced by Goldman and used in various stores.

For all of these reasons, a complete overhaul of the shopping cart might not be a person's first objective, but to start with just the wheels that cause so many customers trouble. A bad cart experience makes for a miserable trip to the grocery story, so it is in the interest of the retailers to support an upgrade to the design of the wheels. It may be the easiest fix in the whole of the situation. Because a cart has to be pushed around by a customer, even after just one of the wheels has failed, or one of the wheels continues to make a squeaking noise, this can be a major source of irritation.

If any store employee could unclip one of the wheels with a special tool and easily replace it with a new one, basically there would no longer be the "shopping cart with the squeaky wheel" phenomenon or the one that has a stuck wheel. The wheels themselves are not too expensive. Replacing the wheels just has to be a job that any employee can do in the back of the store in a few minutes. Currently, it requires a wrench. So the problem is that there is no unclipping mechanism, similar to the bicycle wheels that clip on and off. This is basically all it takes.

It seems as though it would be a major engineering solution, but in this case the engineering interacts with the business setup: for the regular store employees to replace the wheels routinely, they have to be easy to unclip.

The retail stores are not in the maintenance business but instead need to deal with daily processing of a very large volume of goods, updating shelf prices, maintaining their stock, receiving inventory in the back, and so on. Any given store has a lot going on. The wheels themselves are not easy to repair by the average employee, but they probably could be.

SOURCES:

The Cart That Changed The World: The Career of Sylvan N. Goldman by Terry P. Wilson (1978)

item.title: The Lack of Rich Internet Application (RIA) Functionality in Web Browsers Causes Problems
item.dc:creator: dfork_2juvft
item.content:encoded:
ABOVE: A SCREENSHOT FROM ADOBE FLEX, WHICH ALLOWED EASILY COMPOSING RICH INTERNET WEB APPLICATIONS. IT WAS USED FOR BOTH INTERNAL CORPORATE NEEDS AND EXTERNAL WEB APPS.

The Web Fosters Information Consumption

Most uses of the web are information-oriented, so they are easily transmitted in page-like formats, such as product listings or online auctions. News can be distributed easily in a web page format because a physical page is already the container for news articles. The web browser's "page" is the basic unit of the web and it is how the web browser was configured. Consequently, the web fosters the serving of information on the Internet. It has historically been unable to accommodate multimedia and interactivity in a consistent, universally-accepted way, which is why Adobe Flash came about in the first place. Though the web seems like the only configuration for using the Internet, other protocols once existed that were not defined in this way.

When the designated interactivity on a given website is minor, the typical tools provided to web developers are adequate; they suffice for laying out web pages for news websites, restaurant menus, store product listings, and tables of information. Even YouTube or Netflix is not much more than web pages with videos placed inside them. Instagram is is the same, rather minimal in terms of interactivity demands on the software developer as well.

Rich Internet Applications, The Shimmed Use of The Web Browser

Many businesses on the web, such as banks, are using the web browser to serve interactive applications-- software in which many parameters and pieces of information are being accessed or edited by the user in menus, panels, and so on. This is unlike a web page. In the technology industry, this topic was at one time called rich internet applications (RIA), deliberately separated from discussions about the web pages. In the 2000s, there was was broad recognition that when the computer is serving interactivity, even for something as simple as an e-mail navigator, the mode of the web browser should become different, it should enter an RIA mode.

Rich Internet Applications, however, is a topic that lost interest after smartphones took over the attention of the developer community, around 2010. The topic is no less relevant; it's merely that people forgot this important topic. The programmer population got distracted by mobile web development. On the other side, many programmers became consumed with writing apps that sit outside of a web browser, in an app store. But there is a middle ground that has been absent. It is in fact necessary that there are complete frameworks for writing apps inside a web browser, but the web browsers do not contain RIA functionality for real, even though there are lots of people writing things that look like apps on websites.

Because the topic of RIA was basically ignored in technology discussions over the last decade, there are now a lot of problems for web developers when they need to write applications (like online banking) because the web browsers are not capable of serving RIAs. Put differently, a website like Gmail is a dirty hack, reusing the basic elements of web pages that are only suited for serving streams of information. Their code bases reflect this as well, that they are jerry-rigging everything inside these web browsers. This was true for the original Google Maps in 2005, that everyone was in amazement that Google managed to pull off interactive, scrollable maps with the incomplete and inadequate state of RIA in web browsers.

Returning to the example of an online banking app, because the toolsets to make a substantial app for a web browser are actually missing inside the web browsers, these banking apps exist in a quasi-application state (just like Gmail). They necessarily make use of web page elements to give the false impression of serving normal app software. It then gets really dirty because normal apps don't have a back and forward button and they don't need to wait for web operations to complete.

These quasi-apps borrow the conventions of traditional app software and imitate them using web page technology, specifically JavaScript libraries that attempt to compensate for the inadequate situation.

A banking application or a retail checkout (e.g. Square) on the web should really be programmed inside a genuine app toolset recognized by the web browser, using the same methodologies that produce executables for the computer's hard drive. Repurposing web pages as the basis for web applications is unacceptable leads to unreliable and insecure software.

Because proper RIA tools were never produced after the iPhone and Android phones became mainstream, an incorrect norm developed: the web development community began to believe that these compensating JavaScript libraries were something more than elaborate and extensive shims. As a result, the web is now filled with these quasi-applications.

Some app developers (e.g. Spotify) will use the web browser as the foundation of their traditional desktop and web applications. They just don't have the right tools provided to them. They need an RIA toolset that is feature-complete, just like Adobe Flex was trying to be.

RIA Development Tools Will Greatly Improve Use of The Internet

When someday a payment or banking app is programmed as a real app, with traditional app tools and methods, it will be much smoother and reliable. Anyone who writes traditional mobile or desktop apps can see that these web applications are plagued with syncing problems and they are unusually slow, even when they are doing basic tasks, like loading lists of information. It's simply because the web app developers don't have what they need. Computers are faster than ever, and so are internet speeds and the web servers, so what is missing is the software toolset. There shouldn't be so many slowdown or syncing problems in these apps.

Anytime the wrong software tools are used, the software engineers are going to spend a lot of time tracking down issues that result from the situation. Web pages should not be the basis of rich internet applications (RIA).

WebAssembly vs. RIA

Technically, it is possible to serve a custom rich internet application through a recent feature addition to web browsers called WebAssembly, but overall this technology has not measured up as a finished solution for making RIAs universally. For various reasons, no one has endeavored to make standard application tools to develop RIAs that run on WebAssembly, and so every programmer and company does his own thing with it. It doesn't try to become standard for RIA use cases. The web browser itself needs to contain the RIA conventions, not have them running on top of WebAssembly.

As a result, there is now at the W3C a committee dedicated to making specifications for rich internet application (RIA) functionality inside web browsers. It is long overdue. Many JavaScript libraries that are all circling around the unaddressed issue that browsers just don't have what is needed for making RIAs. Once an RIA toolset is provided, they won't have much reason to be used for new web software. That is how important the situation is.

Macromedia/Adobe Flex

Sometimes technology moves backwards on the web, especially in the 2010s. This need for RIAs was long ago identified by Macromedia (later purchased by Adobe) with its Flex toolset, released in 2006. Because Macromedia's Flex was an extension of Macromedia Flash, when Flash was removed from web browsers in the 2010s, the most forward framework for making cross-platform RIAs disappeared. Regardless of how good or bad Flex applications were (initially they were slow), it was the most developed toolset available for the job of transmitting complete, interactive apps over the web through a browser. It was utilized by Rosetta Stone for several years to distribute its interactive language learning software on DVD and CD, across multiple operating systems. The company was able to do that because at one point Adobe provided a way to execute Flex apps outside of a web browser with its AIR system, and that is why many companies used it. AIR was a way to take the rich internet application made in Flex and distribute it as conventional software on a hard disk.

There Are Web Apps Today, But Not RIA

In computers, there is a big difference between what a programmer can pull off versus what a programmer would normally set out to do given what is actually available. The first activity is why there are many 3D modeling or photo editor apps served inside web browsers today, even though the web browsers are inadequate in terms of RIA toolsets. The junky feel of web apps results precisely from the situation, that many people and companies have been engaged in pulling off feats inside inadequate software toolsets. Rather than implement what is missing, they often insists on using what is there that isn't good enough. People have often tried to stretch inadequate toolsets instead of demanding an improvement to the situation.

The second activity (what an app developer would normally do) is why complete and feature-filled apps are less common on the web than they would be. Normally, no one wants to write an app for a web browser today because it gets dirty and hacky very fast. If the web browser were improved, and RIA tools sets were included though, very complex apps could just be served in real-time and even downloaded to be executed later, independent of the web browser.

The Web Browser Does Not Recognize The Concept of an App or RIA (Rich Internet App)

There is no distinction made by the web browser between a "web app" and a web page, and this something most users would not likely know. But given that the web browser is host to many JavaScript-based apps, it is time for it to do this. That's why the W3C has the RIA committee in the first place. Anyone making a web app is forced to use the same exact programming utilities in the browser that the regular web pages use. What has to happen is that the web browser operates with native recognition of RIA, turning on separate modes and states that recognize the RIA needs, make the window and its controls behave differently than it does normally for information.

The lack of rich internet application functionality in web browsers can cause significant problems for developers, forcing them to resort to hacky <div> tag combinations with JavaScript to achieve their desired results. As internet speeds have become better worldwide, the limitations of the 1990s web browser software engineering is starting to be felt.

item.title: The Document Scanner Replaces The Fax Machine (Except for Printing)
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
For a long time throughout the 2000s, there were technologists asking why fax machines were still being used by many businesspeople. They thought that the business world just couldn't get with the times, and they found it ridiculous that businesses and offices continued to make use of faxes despite the wide accessibility of the Internet. By the 2000s, e-mail was mainstream and flatbed scanners were easily purchased.

The issue is that, like the pager that many professionals continued to find useful, there was something beneficial in the situation, and it relates to how there just wasn't much complexity to using the technology to get results. A fax machine will sit in place all day, and if something important happened, a person walks into the office and picks up the result.

There is a convenience to sending a fax on the fax machine that is superior to manually scanning a document on a connected flatbed scanner, waiting for the image to show up on a computer screen, then dragging that file to an e-mail application as an attachment, entering the e-mail address, and then clicking the "Send" button. The solution to address that came much later with the dedicated, standalone touchscreen document scanner (top image) that has a networkable computer embedded inside it.

The standalone fax machine does not require that many technical steps: enter the phone number with the number keys and then press "Fax" and the other person receives a printout on the spot, page by page, and it basically always works unless the line is busy. This is not only attractive for fast-paced business but how a device should operate as a whole. The other feature is that it not only scanned the documents to be sent, but it also sat there idle, waiting for faxes to come in, and it printed them out. Unless a computer user makes a special, advanced setup, no received e-mail attachment will be automatically printed out.

The one-step action of a fax machine was not reproduced by computer scanning setups until the document scanner arrived, for a variety of reasons. First, touchscreens became popular only in the 2010s, with the mainstream usage of touchscreen mobile devices. Second, abundant cloud storage was not available until the 2010s. The document scanners usually include free cloud storage with them.

The document scanner is significantly different from a regular home office flatbed scanner carrying a feeder attachment because it will connect to the Internet and send out the scans completely independent of a desktop computer. This is the part that makes it resemble a fax machine, as anyone can walk up to it and use it. It also feeds and scans documents more quickly than the home office flatbed scanners, and it has a built-in software for sending the scanned results across the Internet to varied types of digital locations. It will take the scanned documents, scan both sides at the same time, and, shortly after are were scanned in, digitally re-orient them if they are upside down. A high speed model scans 60 pages per minute, both sides.

Though there are important differences to point out between the document scanner and fax machine, they both serve to scan a document and transmit it in one step. Press "Scan" after configuring the destination or destinations of the document, the paper slips through the machine and the task is done. For anyone dealing with a lot of business paperwork, business cards, receipts, or files, the document scanner is something valuable for managing the increased volume of paper that need to be tracked or archived today. The added benefit is that the document scanner allows archiving of the scans concurrent with sending them out to the destinations and recipients. If a home office individual wants to go paperless in a world that is still producing lots of paper, this is the way to go.

Briefly, it has to be mentioned that computers were supposed to make the world more paperless but many people find that it has been the opposite. When paper has been scanned through these devices to multiple locations, including a USB flash drive attached to the document scanner, it feels safer to recycle certain types of paper work, reducing clutter.

There is a misconception in the public and mainstream technology news that technology advances in beneficial ways at all times, that what has come later is always superior to what came before. But in reality, it is often the case that technology manufacturers get ahead of themselves in their rush to come out with advancements, and they overlook major aspects what was working very well in the existing situation (e.g. the fax machine) before moving to their future solution. Unfortunately, many technology industries create a more chaotic situation than existed before: it now takes more steps to send someone a scanned multi-page document because fax machines have been relegated to supposed obsoletion.

For example, small to mid-sized offices are not known to have replaced their fax machines with document scanners, but in all likelihood they would look closer at this device if they were informed. First is the advantage that everything scanned can be sent to more than one place at the same time upon being scanned: the scanner can be configured to send the scan to multiple destinations when the "Scan" button is pressed. The scan can be directed to multiple e-mail recipients and multiple cloud storage services with one press. It also allows-- unlike the fax machine-- the digitization of business paperwork for accounting purposes, allowing receipts and invoices to be scanned and OCR'ed for searching. On the Fujitsu model (not tested by dFork, but popular in sales like its competitor, Raven), there is the option to make certain types of documents automatically forwarded by the scanner to their destination after they are scanned. This could be a certain email address or storage location on the Internet. Finally, most document scanners feature a fax option, but only sending not printing.

Just like the current document scanners being sold, the fax machine is less technical to use overall. But there are far fewer manufacturers of these machines. It indicates that if the public caught on, there would be a much larger market for them.

Anyone who uses a document scanner knows that it's not only more efficient to have these features available at the press of a button, it feels smoother. To send the document and have it received by the other person, all that has to be done is the press of the "Send" button.

Current Document Scanners Do Not Print Out Documents from Senders, Unlike The Fax Machine

There are two actions to the fax machine that are contained in a single device: the scanning of documents to be sent out and the printing of documents that can be received. By contrast, there are no known document scanners that also sit idle so that e-mailed documents are printed out once they reach the document scanner's designated e-mail address. This is the difference, that the fax machine would sit and wait to print out what someone sent it. But the document scanners don't have printing hardware packaged with them. This could change if the market became larger.

Without a document scanner, what we have to replace this fused fax printer setup is now multipart: once the email comes in, a system menu option ("Print...") has to be selected, followed by a print window, and then only after accepting the settings of the print window is the email printed. The same is true for when the document needs to be scanned: the paper is put into the feeder, the person goes back to the computer to press the "Scan" button inside the software, and then from there there are multiple steps to take inside the software.

Conclusion

The proliferation of steps adds a cost. The way to go backwards to the fax machine type of situation is to acquire a document scanner for a home or office. Not all businesses might want or need a document scanner currently because their large copiers could accomplish the same goals. Some home office demands are too small for scanning documents. But the benefits of owning a device for many people have been overlooked and there has been an assumption that home office printer-scanners have the topic covered.

The document scanner is hooked into the Internet and it provides a touchscreen interface for configuring which person or what service receives the documents you are about to scan. You press the button and it scans and sends your document in a single step.

The key difference is that the document scanners are not provided printing functionality like the fax machine. They are not bundled with printer hardware, only scanner hardware, but if more people showed interest in the document scanner this one shortcoming could be addressed by the companies. So, they don't sit there with their own email address and print out whatever is sent to their email address. If they receive a fax, they send it to the computer. But a fax machine never archived its scans, nor did it connect to the Internet and allow multiple destinations for each scan operation.

item.title: Implementing Interactive Media for Social Websites, A Feature That Is Long Overdue
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
ABOVE: AN INTERACTIVE PROGRAM, THE KIND THAT COULD BE EMBEDDED IN A SOCIAL MEDIA POST. THIS WAS RENDERED INSIDE A WEB BROWSER BY A NOW-DEFUNCT INTERACTIVE FILE FORMAT CALLED .CDF (COMPUTABLE DOCUMENT FORMAT). IT WAS THE PROGRAMMATIC EQUIVALENT OF A .PDF AND COULD BE TRANSMITTED OVER E-MAIL.

It's Just Text, Photos, and Video Today

Where Is Interactive Multimedia on The Social Media Websites?

The experience of social media is limited to video streams, comments, and photos.  But playing movie files and displaying still images is not the full range of what computers can do.  If social media websites carried a well-rounded set of functionality that was reflective of computers, they would allow uploads of interactive media, just like they did before Adobe Flash was removed from mainstream web browsers. 

A soundboard (a board of clickable buttons that plays sound clips) could be uploaded to a Twitter post, to give an example. In the past, it was embeddable as part of a Myspace post. Interactive animations, fun software-based musical instruments, and even choose-your-own-adventure multimedia could spread across social media today instead of just popular video clips. Here are some more specific examples revealing how the web has been constrained by the lack of functionality that was once provided by Flash:

In 2023, an automobile company should be able to upload an interactive 3D model of its car to Twitter, Facebook or Instagram for prospective customers to explore.

A small, self-made video game should be uploadable to a social media post for visitors to play.

A slideshow should be uploadable as part of a social media post and provide interactive objects and experiences beyond turning of pages. (This is already possible in the ePub format, which is processed by e-readers.)

Scholars and non-profit organizations should be able to post interactive graphics and charts to social media.

Animations should not be limited to movie files (.MP4) but also include clickability (e.g. choose-your-own adventure multimedia like what was found on CD-ROMs).

A 2D interactive visualization (e.g. a sports play diagram) should be easily transmitted through social media and downloadable for opening later.

A simple program like a calculator should be postable inside a social media post. It should be e-mailable like a PDF, after it was downloaded from that post. It should be usable inside the e-mail client at the time it arrives.

An interactive map, including the option to show a street view, should be embeddable in a social media post.

A Wikipedia article should be able to provide interactive math diagrams.

A website should be able to offer downloadable study cards (that can be clicked to display the other side).

Some find it controversial that there would be a replacement file format for .SWF, but it's actually a prerequisite for a coherent future. The importance of having a designated file format can be illustrated in the following. If a magazine layout is sent across e-mail in the office as individual page images-- attached to e-mails a collection of separated image files-- this of course can work but it will impede usage of the computer for page layouts and create a lot of unintended difficulties, discouraging use of the computer for this task for everyone but those who can put up with it. So, of course when people transmit page layouts they send it as a single document.

The same applies to interactive multimedia because right now it is in those individual pieces. What's more, because of how web browsers work, because it is in those individual fragments, only the website administrator or owner can upload it to a web page (without special workarounds). Interactive multimedia was formally recognized with .SWF and when there is no formal recognition in computing, a technology cannot take off.

Previously, anyone could upload interactive multimedia to a website because it did not have to be hosted on that website. For example, in the late 2000s, the social media website Myspace allowed anything interactive that was programmed in Flash (.SWF) to be embedded in a Myspace post-- which is what a YouTube video player was made out of back then, a .SWF file. The .SWF file was hosted on YouTube's servers and just embedded in a Myspace user's custom HTML code. Because of the flexibility of Flash, many types of multimedia were uploadable to Myspace, not just videos. They didn't have to be hosted on Myspace, unlike today where everything is hosted on the social media websites themselves and they block embeds from other domains.

After Flashs removal, immediately web users could no longer upload multimedia or interactivity in the finished form of compiled documents. Multimedia lost its formal recognition as a technology overnight. Suddenly, it had to exist in separate pieces, in the web page programming language JavaScript, which by its structure totally inhibits interactive multimedia uploads. An alternative that can execute in the web browser, called WebAssembly or WASM, is not designed for this purpose, which is why even though it can produce interactive experiences it cannot reproduce the needed setup of a portable document (.SWF).

A big problem is that many people who write web pages professionally feel like they should dictate all matters of how the world interacts with computers on the Internet, even though there are many shortcomings of the modern web browser and there are many technologies that are not part of the WWW ideologies. The individuals who advocated for Flashs removal hadno connection to those working in multimedia and interactive software. They were not concerned with how anyone was negatively impacted by their campaign, being in another area of the technical spectrum. Too often they harbored strong resentment towards Flash, they never used it themselves, and they never bothered to investigate what was working well in the situation or what needed to carry forward for multimedia. It was just a blanket rejection of the situation. As a result, now it is difficult to share interactive programs on the web.

If .SWF (Flash) was to be removed, there needed to be a replacement file format first. But this kind of consideration is beyond the range of considerations of the types of individuals who fought hard to remove it. Simply put, the people who dictate the standards that drive web browsers are very different in mindset from the people who were involved in the Adobe Flash community, and they lacked perspective and understanding of interactive multimedia or what is best for the Internet. It's a sensitive issue for them, and they can get very angry as soon as Flash is brought up. Nevertheless, the future of using the Internet should include interactive multimedia and that means a replacement for the .SWF format for reasons of portability.

What Would It Look Like?

Right away, this file format could just be called .IDF (Interactive Document Format). On any social media website, this universal, multimedia file format would show up as an upload option, positioned next to the video file option (.MP4) or the still image option (.JPG, .PNG, etc.). The file format simply would serve the same range of functionality as Flashs .SWF, and the authoring tools-- regardless of the software vendor-- would all compile towards this file format.   The difference is that this time, many authoring tools of all kinds would serve to produce output for this format, not just a proprietary one from Adobe.  The main problem people had with Flash was that it was private and proprietary. It also required a higher end software license, whereas many authoring tools today are free or have inexpensive options.

With this type of multimedia file, a website user will be able to embed a multimedia program on any website across the world that allows it, not just social media.  Doing this is actually setting use of the Internet right. All kinds of organizations and their websites stand to gain, as these kinds of documents can be transmitted over e-mail, not just the web.  It's quite feasible today, as a case example already existed from Wolfram software company, in its short-lived and niche .CDF (computable document format).

Self-Contained Is What Matters for The File Format

What is important is establishing the characteristics of a complete, packaged multimedia file that has no external dependencies (no extra pieces in a directory that sit outside of the single document). As mentioned, a PDF is what people send to each other because everything is packaged and there is an assurance it will work every time. It can be that way for executable interactive media.

Flash's file format, .SWF, provided a major convenience, that it could be easily embedded into a web page just like a .JPG image or .MP4 movie file without much effort and it was easy to upload and move around. If anything interactive is to be uploaded today, it has to be set up or approved of by the owner of the website.

The reality is that there are different types of software developers and they are not all of the same background. Those who influenced the course of the web brought with them a controversial set of objectives, to embolden JavaScript and CSS-- both of which were late add-ons to the web browser and have many downsides.

After Flash was removed from web browsers, visitors of websites suddenly without a way to upload simple programs into posts.

Social Media Will Be More Inviting

When interactive documents return to the web, the state of social media will improve. It will be more inviting to Internet users who are uninterested in making personal, political commentary. As stated, all kinds of interactivity provided by Flash in the past will be available once again. Along the way, this future file type would allow uploading video games to social media posts. But the primary purpose would be to expand the range of social media (and the web) beyond consumption of short video clips, text, and photos.

With a new file format that replaces .SWF, website users will be able to download small programs from the websites, like the soundboard.  They will even be able to edit them if the author permits it-- if this file format is designed accordingly.

Hard drive space is much larger today and processors are much faster. That's why for many tasks, an app is an outdated concept compared to a cross-platform document executable. Although it could embody a full range of functionality contained in typical app, the interactive program would exist as a document, containing all needed files that make it run.  Its goal would be portability-- not being an app first. Earlier attempts at this include the Java applet.

The portability of .SWF was somewhat incidental, a byproduct of how Flash was set up, whereas it was deliberate with .PDF (which stands for Portable Document Format).  Portability of interactivity is an essential need for the globally-networked personal computer to be made coherent.

The Creative Coding Community Is Prevented From Attaching Small Programs to Posts

On Twitter, there are communities of multimedia programmers who showcase their live, digital art pieces. What they make often reminds a person of screensavers from older computers. This is called creative coding, and it is associated with specific programming frameworks (such as Processing.org or P5JS). But, because there is no technical means to upload the interactive programs to a website, these programmers are capturing videos of them and posting the clips on social media. When Adobe Flash was widely installed in the web browser, the programmers didnt have this problem.  They could embed their interactive work directly into a post if they wanted, in the form of .SWF.  It shows that the web has gone backwards in this respect.

Today, web browsers are very capable of executing complex programs in real time, much more than the time period when .SWF was in widespread use.   But by promoting JavaScript (.JS) file fragments instead of a .SWF replacement, the web stood still as social media expanded in popularity and became a main part of Internet usage.  Just a small portion of the computer's capabilities were incorporated into social media: video, text, and still images. So, the main issue is that there is a specific file format missing.

Normally, website visitors would be able to use a mouse and keyboard to interact with the creative coding work like the one below, but this isnt possible because social websites cannot accept uploads of small multimedia programs like they did when Adobe Flash was widely available.  It's really just a low standard that was accepted over time, but the result has been a major deficiency in the functionality of websites and the web browsers.  In the early days of the web, there were other technologies playing the same role as Flash (such as Java applets) but they were less favored beginning in the 2000s. For one, Java does not facilitate production of interactive multimedia. Java applets were actually more like small computer programs. Professional multimedia was made with Flash because Flash tools provided an integrated animation timeline for timing the interactivity. Nothing in Java or the web browser provides this for a website developer.

PROGRAM: https://twitter.com/KomaTebe/status/1636106517437984772

Everything that Flash did is technically available in the web browser, but its organization is not adequate, which is why everything is the way it is.  Supposedly moving everything from Flash to the web browser made it more open, but what happened instead is people relied on commercial authoring tools. What this shows is that there has to be more than just the technical capability; people have to be able to make use of it for real within an integrated setup. Web developers too often believe they have all the tools they need when, from an app programmer's perspective they are content to work with a scattered set of technologies.

Reasons The Uploaded File Has to Be Self-Contained Like Flash (.SWF)

In a self-contained form, an interactive program will be able to be e-mailed to groups and individuals just like a .PDF or an image document, which is something that would be powerful today. Security concerns are limited as long as the e-mailed document is understood not to be given file system access, etc.

When computer programs are uploadable to a website like Twitter or Facebook easily, just like they once were, this means that a cottage industry will emerge and provide these programs to the public.  Novices taking up programming for the first time can post their early computer programs to their Twitter accounts or some other social website but only if the file format they use has been standardized everywhere. 

Social media can offer more than one-way consumption of passive entertainment to the website visitor who only has the option to make a text comment in response to a video or photo. The computer is an interesting device-- or it used to be regarded this way-- not because it allows a giant chat room like Twitter, but because it provides interactivity that people cannot get from other machines, such as clicking on things.

Regarding WebAssembly

WebAssembly is often promoted as a solution to the problem mentioned. But it is not a consolidated, interactive file format and its objective is very generic and non-specific, just to act as a target medium for traditional desktop or mobile apps, to make them run in a web browser.  A certain specificity is lacking in it for what is needed here, which is more along the lines of the HyperCard file format for the original Macintosh and its descendants, Macromedia Flash, SuperCard, etc.  The earlier term "applet" is more helpful. When there is no specific plan, usually things don't work out well and WebAssembly has for years failed to gain traction because it doesn't have an overarching objective or try to provide any product.

What people actually need is a way to take their small to medium sized programs and games and compile them towards a portable format. It has to be consumer friendly, like HyperCard. Compared to that, WebAssembly is just a technical standard for executing code in a web browser. A large part of the success of the first Macintosh was HyperCard. Power users were able to make HyperCard products without learning professional programming, which is much more involved.

Here the purpose is not to execute all low-level computer code that would be executed on a desktop or mobile machine but rather to provide a set of standards for the needs of interactive media, for self-contained packages for distribution and uploading.  A consumer-oriented file format, like Adobe Flash (.SWF) or HyperCard for the original Macintosh, allows many types of interactive programs, even many utility programs, but it is not a completely raw and generic target like WebAssembly.

Often, web developers have wanted to tie future interactive formats to the web browser itself, like WebAssembly.  History has shown, however, that successful file types do not rely on the web browser to be edited or viewed, whether it is .PDF, .DOCX, .JPG, .XLSX or .MP4.  They would have it so that if you wanted to open that document you would have to open a web browser.

But frequently, the wishes of web standards advocates conflict with what people do in the real world. People use spreadsheets, usually in .CSV or .XLSX, but still the web browsers don't natively read these, which is why many file formats fit awkwardly into usage of the web.

In the future, when there is an interactive file format, third parties need to be able to make their own authoring and viewing software that does not require embedding a web browser inside it. The web browsers are too large now. Relying on the web browser for rendering a file format is highly questionable, as there are only a few web engines in actual use and they are now very large in file size and code base.

If as a workaround WebAssembly is the designated vehicle for this interactive file format just to get it off the ground, that is acceptable for a short period of time. This is the most likely short-term outcome.

Interactive Media Authoring Tools

Surpassing the number in previous decades by many times, today there are dozens of free and professional tools for making interactive experiences, from the high end (Unreal Engine and Unity) to the low end and completely free. However, the majority are skewed towards making video games, which is a different direction from interactive media (such as the titles found on the CD-ROMs of the 1990s).   

What the public needs is a file format that is conducive to serving interactive media because video games are not appealing to everyone. There is a lot of overlap between the two uses of computers, but in the past there were interactive human anatomy CD-ROMs.

These recent tools like Unreal Engine and Unity are often referred to as game engines, and they do not incorporate many of the software conventions specific to interactive multimedia.   Video games are typically for entertainment whereas there is much more range to multimedia that includes research.

In any case, when there is a common file format for packaged interactive media, providing all of the same capabilities as .SWF, all game engines and multimedia authoring tools can export to this format. It should not be the case that Adobe or any other company owns this entire category. Multitudes of programs, can export to .PDF. Therefore, the same should occur for interactive multimedia: without any restrictions, multitudes of programs should be able to export to a future .IDF (Interactive Document Format).

item.title: Grids: A Future Tool for Rapid Software Development
item.dc:creator: dfork_staff
item.content:encoded:
Conceptually-speaking, a large number of software development situations involve grids or transformations of grids.  In video games, this is very apparent:

Tic-Tac-Toe

Chess 

Checkers

Sudoku

Solitaire

Crossword puzzles

Tetris

Breakout (Arkanoid)

Wordle

Bingo

Mahjong

Snake (1976's Blockade)

However, when it comes to computer programming, a software development system that provides an interactive grid that could make all of these games-- by way of modifying and customizing a grid from its initial generic state-- is not yet available for app development.

Existing programming systems for video game development focus entirely on practical methods, to achieve specific outcomes. Any grid-related convenience exists for a narrow set of purposes. A tile system, for example, is used for establishing the graphical world map of a 2D video game, and it doesn't intend to address overall dynamic of the game. It isn't the same as what is being discussed here, which is a deeply versatile grid component that anticipates a broad range of interactive scenarios.

Since the grid we are talking about would not be limited to just a few, predefined aspects of making a game or an app, the grid component itself would have to be built out thoroughly as a complete software development system. It have to assemble a dozen or more generic categories of grid-based programming outcomes, classified under broad conceptual headings, so that anything can be constructed that involves a grid. The categories and accessory components for this grid can't be very specific in terms of what they make, but they allow a pyramid type of process for building the software, in which each programmer ends at a final configuration (a pyramid) of his own, but everyone starts by using the same base. There is no process like this present in software development today, notably.

The goal is to provide something that is used frequently by programmers. In software, anything that interacts with a grid, a transformation of a grid, sits on top of one, or just needs one for layout purposes could make use of this system. Put succinctly, it could produce any of the games in the list above by letting the programmer start out from the initial primitive state that the grid exists in. The modifying components would be comprehensible enough that any of the games would not take too long.

Such a system wouldn't be limited to production of video games. A deeply-programmed interactive grid system, one that is cumulatively modified by the programmer to achieve outcomes, could make:

spreadsheet tables

calendars

static tables of data

a presentation of gallery thumbnails

forms with text fields

As long as the grid can be configured in terms of a clipping component and scrolling, many controls in use today, like spreadsheet tables, can be made by starting with a base grid. It would be the grid item or cell that is extensively programmed (just like the grid itself) to match the behaviors of grid cells in the project, such as a spreadsheet.

Though less obvious at first, there are many more controls that can be discussed in terms of a conceptual grids, it's just that the development system's grid would have to be customized by the programmer in that direction.

a drum sequencer

a timeline editor for video or audio editing

a custom animation curve editor placed on a timeline

The only difference is that a timeline editor involves clipping the horizontal and vertical contents and only loading items when they are needed for display. Both of those conventions can be represented diagrammatically. It is still a grid that has been modified in the end.

Occasionally in software there is an onscreen keyboard. A keyboard is basically a grid with various transformations applied to its rows and cells, starting with the offsetting of the rows. Thus, an onscreen keyboard could also be made out of an interactive grid system that acknowledges these operations, to offset and extend. It would be configured in terms of its offset rows and the modification of key widths for the various side keys, like SHIFT. Each onscreen keyboard key would exist first as a class of button, a specific kind of grid-item. All of this could be represented in a GUI builder, without a line of code. This is the kind of system that could cover many cases that could be easily generalized under various headings. Presets could be provided to the programmer (such as a grid of buttons) to make many outcomes (an onscreen keyboard) quickly.

The goal is not to make programs without code per se. The goal is to make software development more inclined towards being conceptual diagrammatic in those instances when it ought to be or can be. In that list of video games, so many carry the same underlying interactive and graphical characteristics (e.g. sudoku, crossword puzzles) that diagrammatic generalizations are certainly possible for software. The grid is a place to start, with other places to follow.

The Buildup Of Software Instead of Line-By-Line Definitions

The outcome arrives cumulatively, which is why the example of making a pyramid from its base is given. The existence of this type of grid suggests that the software development tool will allow the grid to be built up and modified in multiples steps, as opposed to how everything in code is made today. For the most part, code is defined in practical terms once, tweaked or corrected, and then executed.

By contrast, the goal here is to use an interactive grid as a primitive starting point for software development, setting the stage for the programmer to take it in various conceptual directions according to the specifications of the project. The sequence of steps followed is superior because there is an actual process put in place for any outcome.

As an example, let's say that there is a video game and the foundational grid is going to be used for rectangles that are going to be knocked out. But in one of the stages, the corners of this grid have no cells in them, because that is the layout of the stage. The resulting is appearance is like a diamond of grid cells.

The programming process would be different from regular code and start from the basic stage of a grid:

  1. Define the row count and column count as well as spacing between the cells.
  2. Add a subtractor component that removes certain cells, so that the corner cells are removed from the final product.
  3. Add a grid-item component to the grid that assigns certain interactive grid items (that were set up and customized for this game in advance) to all of the remaining cells.
  4. Edit those interactive grid items manually inside the GUI editor so that they have different colors, contain certain items, or behave differently according to their property configurations.

The grid software development system has to be very deeply programmed, able to accommodate a wide range of scenarios, but it can do this by way of providing components, such as the subtractor component. It's easy to see that process counts here, unlike typical programming: all grids have row counts and column counts, so this would usually be defined first by a programmer.

The associated components, like the grid items that define grid cell behavior or the subtractor component, have to be able to make almost anything a grid is for. A term would be Immensely Versatile Generic Programmatic Component.

Programmers would be able to leverage this immensely versatile, generic grid component and modify it extensively to suit their specific needs. When we say it would have to be deeply programmed, to be able to accommodate the many directions a grid can go in software, this would take place by listing all of the different uses of grid already in existence then setting up all kinds of components (e.g. the subtractor component). There are patterns to how people use grids and thus there are general categories of components that can be made for this system. A tab control could be constructed with this because, in essence, a tab control uses a viewport area as a swappable slot. So, the grid component for the rectangle would be swappable-slot. If there are eight cells acting as swappable-slots in a 4x4 grid, clicking on a button might load 16 separate pieces of content in this grid. All that it would take is defining a 4x4 grid in terms of dimensions and then assigning the swappable-slot component to the entire list of grid cells (which would be accessible as a property of the grid).

In another example, using this interactive grid toolset, one could construct a game like Tetris within a matter of minutes, as the concept of an interactive grid would be combined with how it interacts with individual grid items (the tetromino pieces). It would be that the programmer defines what the pieces do (rotate 90 degrees, move left and right by 1 square unit) relative to the grid. This would not be placed in code in the typical way, but would involve building up the grid system with relationship objects that connect items (tetrominoes) to the grid.

In the case that code editors and IDE's provided programmers with a concept-based grid system that allows them to start from an archetypal interactive grid concept, this would offer immense versatility for rapid software development, allowing all sorts of projects to move nimbly across different forms and behaviors. It would be easy to move from programming chess to programming checkers, whereas currently that is not how code frameworks work.

Never before have software engineers leveraged the flexibility and adaptability of configurable grids as a fundamental building block, speaking in terms of code. By utilizing such an interactive grid system as a central framework of a video game, programmers will be able to develop a wide range of games and applications quickly.

Accessory Components for The Grid

To make the functionality of the interactive grid possible, a collection of accessory components will be provided. These components would modify the grid's form, such as offsetting rows, and determine the content of each cell, which could include clickable buttons or other interactive elements. Grid squares could serve as platforms for games like chess, checkers, and crosswords, allowing for the placement of multiple items within a single cell.

By starting with a conceptual foundation rather than a strictly practical one, software development becomes more flexible and efficient. The same interactive grid toolset that enables game development can also be utilized to construct other applications, such as an alarm clock with flipping cards or a train station timetable. The possibilities are virtually endless, as each grid can be modified and customized to suit the desired outcome.

For modified grids, the toolset includes functions and descriptors to subtract individual cells, portions of rows, squares, and more, allowing for non-rectangular grid shapes. Additionally, the ability to offset rows provides further flexibility in grid design and presentation.

The immense versatility of the interactive grid system opens up new avenues for software development scenarios beyond gaming. Calendars and toolbars, for instance, can be built on the foundation of a grid, providing a structured and interactive interface. Other applications such as spreadsheets, data tables, timeline editors, touchscreen phone home screens (app launchers), image thumbnails, vector fields, and math matrix controls can also benefit from the grid-based approach.

By embracing grids as a starting point for software development, programmers can tap into their conceptual potential and rapidly create a wide range of applications. The interactive grid system offers flexibility, adaptability, and efficiency, enabling developers to explore various conceptual outcomes easily.
